MAURER--Phoebe. The RiverSpring Health and Hebrew Home at Riverdale families mourn the passing of Phoebe Maurer, a passionate and talented artist and author, who was deeply devoted to her husband Herb of 70 years, and her children, Ira, Gale and Jeffrey, the Chairman of the Board of Trustees of the Hebrew Home at Riverdale. Phoebe's spirit, pride and wit will live on in the hearts of all who knew her. We extend our deepest condolences to the entire Maurer and Finger families. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Daniel Reingold President and CEO RiverSpring Health 1/3

SOKOLIN--Bill. The Management, Brokers and Staff of Fox Residential Group mourn the passing of Bill Sokolin, husband of our beloved colleague, Gloria Sokolin. No one who knew Bill will ever forget his magnetic personality, his expertise in fine wine, and the fun he was to be around. We will all miss Bill terribly. Barbara Fox, President 1/3

EMDEN--Howard. June 12, 1939 - April 25, 2015, of Scottsdale, Arizona died, surrounded by family, at the home of his daughter Allison who lovingly cared for her father throughout his long illness. Endearing, smart, funny and sensitive, our big brother Howard will always be our champion. As an astute financial advisor, he spent most of his career with Cowen & Co., ending with Morgan Stanley. When our Dad passed away, Howard assumed the role of family advisor, helping his three brothers navigate their way to manhood (Jeffrey deceased 2008). Howard and his beloved wife Lois (deceased 2007) were believers in philanthropy, taking greatest pride in their support of the Tucson Hospital Cancer Center. For those left behind, Allison and his son Sloane, his grandchildren, son and daughter-in-law, brothers, sisters-in-law, nieces and nephews, Howard's legacy will remain strong as he touched us all. Bobby and Margie and Jimmy and Barbara 1/3

SHUTE--Elizabeth Duff (Betty) Shute, of Sleepy Hollow, NY, and Chebeague Island, ME, on April 23, 2015, at the age of 99. She is survived by daughters Gail S. Williams and Jane S. Scifres; 5 grandchildren and 8 great grandchildren. She was predeceased by her husband John V. Shute and her daughter Elizabeth L. S. Roby. A celebration of her life will be held on May 17, 2015 at 3:30 P.M. at Kendal on Hudson, Sleepy Hollow, New York. The family requests donations in her memory and that of her daughter Elizabeth L. Roby to the Juvenile Diabetes Research Fund, jdrf.org
MARTINO--Cynthia R. of NYC. Beloved wife of Alfred and sister of Elissa SegalMeadow. For information, Eden Memorial Chapels (201) 947-3336. 1/3

JACOBY--John S.,66, died peacefully at home on April 8. Former general manager of Newark Airport, he retired in 2011 to become South Africa Country Director for the Peace Corps. Surviving are his wife of 42 years, Carolyn (nee Shaw) and daughters Maggie and Sara, son-in-law Seth, and grandson Benjamin. A memorial service will be held on May 2 at 11:30 at Rubin Museum of Art in NYC. 1/3

MILLER--Harvey R. It is with great sadness that we announce the passing of Harvey Miller after a courageous battle with ALS. He was 82 years old. Mr. Miller was born in 1933. He earned his Bachelor of Arts degree at Brooklyn College in 1954 and graduated from Columbia Law School in 1959. He joined Weil, Gotshal & Manges LLP in 1969 as the Firm's 14th partner and was an integral member of the Firm for the majority of his long and distinguished career. From September 2002 to March 2007, he was a Managing Director and Vice Chairman of the independent investment bank Greenhill & Co. Mr. Miller created Weil's bankruptcy practice and, in so doing, elevated the practice of bankruptcy law to the large law firm environment as a profitable and mainstream practice group of most major U.S. law firms. Throughout his career, he played a key role in the most significant, notable and complex bankruptcies and restructurings in history, including Lehman Brothers, General Motors, American Airlines, R.H. Macy, Texaco, WorldCom and Enron. He also played a key role in managing Weil. Mr. Miller, along with three other partners, managed the Firm up until it elected its first Executive Partner in 1989, and his leadership and vision significantly impacted Weil's evolution from a small, two-office law firm to one of the world's major full-service firms. Described by colleagues as a gifted teacher as well as practitioner, Mr. Miller spent significant time teaching at a number of institutions, including Columbia University Law School, Yale Law School and New York University School of Law. He trained and mentored a number of future leaders of the restructuring bar, and championed young talent. He was the consummate practitioner, colleague and friend to so many. Mr. Miller was a member of the National Bankruptcy Conference, a fellow of the American College of Bankruptcy, a fellow of the American Bar Foundation, and a Trustee of the Committee on Economic Development. Mr. Miller loved the opera, and he was a long-time Advisory Director for The Metropolitan Opera. Mr. Miller's vast contributions to the law and the community will live on through the many people he impacted throughout his life and career. He will be missed greatly by his many colleagues and friends at Weil and beyond. Mr. Miller was a beloved and devoted husband. He is survived by his wife, Ruth. In honor of Mr. Miller, Weil has established the Harvey R. Miller Lecture Series at Columbia Law School. To make a gift, please make your check payable to Columbia Law School and indicate The Harvey R. Miller Lecture Series Fund. Send to the attention of David Strumeyer, Executive Director for Weil, Gotshal & Manges LLP, 767 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10153. 1/3

MAURER--Phoebe. Beloved wife of Herbert; devoted mother of Jeffrey, Gale and Ira; adored mother-in-law of Wendy, Edward and Audrey; cherished grandmother of Craig and Shari, Brooke and Gordon, Joshua and Nicole, Arin and Ena, Lauren and Carly; survived by great-grandchildren Ayden, Sofia, Harry, Caroline, Noah, Isaac, Chloe and Landan; loved by sister Maxine, nieces Mina and Sandy and nephew David. Married Herbert on June 11, 1944. Deeply in love with Herbert from the day they met and throughout their 70 year marriage. Raised their family based upon a foundation of love. Admired, respected and loved by all who knew her throughout her life. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, April 29, 2015 at 12:45pm at The Hebrew Home at Riverdale, 5901 Palisades Ave., Bronx, NY. The family asks that in lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Hebrew Home at Riverdale. 1/3

KALPAKJIAN--Gary, beloved husband, father, grandfather, and great -grandfather, died on April 21st, 2015 in Gulf Stream, Florida. Born in Constanza, Romania in 1927 to loving Armenian parents Mihran and Nevart Kalpakjian, in 1937 he left Europe with his parents and brother Henry to come to America. They settled in Brooklyn, where he met Helen Hartigan, whom he married in 1950. He graduated Brooklyn Technical High School and enlisted in the US Navy at the outbreak of World War II, but after losing his brother in the war he completed his service in Jacksonville, Florida. Gary started his first successful food business selling sandwiches over the fence at JAX naval air station to fellow servicemen. This began a period of great entrepreneurial invention and success. After leaving the Navy, he and Helen started a family and soon settled in Dix Hills, Long Island. There, Gary pioneered a home frozen food delivery service named Thrift-Pak, and over the next 30 years he expanded the business nationwide as Colorado Prime, eventually earning a public listing on the New York Stock Exchange. His foresight in combining convenience and quality with home delivery anticipated many current trends, proving itself far ahead of its time. In addition to being a brilliant and creative businessman, Gary was a warm and charismatic human being with a great sense of humor who loved food, wine, and social gatherings with family and friends. He believed in and lived the American Dream with the love of his life Helen and their three children Lydia, Gary, and Craig. He enjoyed his success in true style, pursuing his passions for art and architecture, including commissioning the great post-modern architect Robert Venturi to build a family home in Glen Cove, New York in 1983. He is survived by his wife Helen Kalpakjian and his three children Lydia Kalpakjian-Cox, Gary Henry Kalpakjian, Craig Mihran Kalpakjian; his three grandchildren Robert Mihran Cox, Lillian Brinton Cox, David Kalpakjian Cox; and great-grandson Ethan Sebastian Cox. Funeral services and entombment were held in Florida. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to Catholic Charities USA www.catholiccharitiesusa.org /Donate. Lorne & Sons Funeral Home, Delray Beach, FL. 1/3

NAPOLEON--Marty. Marty Napoleon, Jazz Pianist, a man who lived a life of true passion has died April 27, 2015 at 93. Benny Goodman, Louis Armstrong, Gene Krupa, Charlie Barnett are just some of the jazz luminaries who Marty played piano with. Born in Brooklyn on June 2, 1921 to Sicilian Immigrants Matteo Napoli and Giovanina (nee Giamporcaro) (A/K/A Marty and Jenny Napoleon). Marty was destined for a life in music. Music constantly filled the Napoleon household. His father Marty played banjo. His mother Jenny played guitar and sang. Older brothers Teddy (piano), Andy (drums), older sister Marge Alleluia and younger sister Jo Shine were vocalists. And his Uncle Phil gained fame as "Phil Napoleon and His Memphis Five". Marty's father and his brother Andy were also artists. Blessed with innate talent and combined with a passionate dedication, Marty began his illustrious career as a teenager, playing with Bob Astor's band. At age 20, he joined Chico Marx and his Orchestra, with lead singer 16 year old Mel Torme. He soon became a favorite of all the top jazz musicians, who wanted the remarkably talented and always jovial Marty to join them...George Auld, Teddy Powell, Joe Venuti, Lee Castle, Charlie Barnett, Benny Goodman, Gene Krupa, Charlie Shavers, Coleman Hawkins, Red Allen and Charlie Ventura. Soon he became part of the legendary "The Big Four" which included Marty, Buddy Rich, Chubby Jackson and Charlie Ventura. He went on to form several groups who gained wide- spread fame...particularly in the early days of the Hamptons. Included in these groups were Ronnie Odrich, Doc Severinson, and Morgana King, among others. Marty also had a two-piano quartet with his brother Teddy on the second piano, in Las Vegas. Marty gained his greatest fame and joined the pantheon of all-time greats playing with Louis Armstrong and His All Stars, replacing Earl Hines in 1952. He toured the world with the All Stars. They were featured on the Dean Martin Show, Johnny Carson, Dick Cavett, Jackie Gleason and Danny Kaye shows. They also did an NBC special with Herb Alpert. He continued playing with "Satchmo" over the years until Louis' final performance at the Waldorf Astoria. Marty's distinctive piano virtuoso can be heard on many of Armstrong's biggest hits, including "Hello Dolly", "Mame", and "It's A Wonderful World". Over the course of his storied career Marty played at the top Jazz venues - Michael's Pub, the Metropole, Basin Street East, and the World Trade Center. He performed at the most prestigious jazz festivals in the world - Newport, Kool, JVG, and San Remo (in Italy). In 1992, Marty did a one-man Concert at Carnegie Hall. 1987 was a particularly good year for Marty. He was selected to play with Lionel Hampton at the historic Frank Sinatra Show at Carnegie Hall and topped that by playing at The White House for President Ronald Reagan. Marty's movie credits include "To Beat The Band", "The Glenn Miller Story", "All That Jazz", "The French Connection", "Raging Bull" and "Tootsie". Marty never lost his passion for music, playing Jazz concerts into his early 90's with his friends Ray Mosca and Ron Odrich. But Marty Napoleon's passion extended way beyond the keys of his piano. Marty was all about family. Marty was married to the love of his life, the late "Bebe" (nee Marie Giordano) Napoleon for 67 years. He was a loving father to Jeanine and her husband Steve Goldman, and to Marty Jr. and his wife Teresa. He adored his grandchildren Cherie Napoleon Goldman, Todd Goldman, Marty Warren Napoleon and Brent Napoleon, and they adored him. (Brent was instrumental in helping his grandfather put together all his biographical notes for a book.) He was also the cherished greatgrandfather of Alexander Napoleon Inoa. The world will miss this amazing talent. His friends and family will miss this amazing man. The family will receive friends Thursday 3-5, 7-9 at McLaughlin Kramer Megiel Funeral Home, 220 Glen St. Glen Cove, NY. Religious Service Friday 12 noon. Interment St. Johns Cemetery, Middle Village, N.Y. 1/3

NASH--Sheldon W.,89, on April 27. Renaissance man, scholar, world traveler and philanthropist. He graduated from City College with a Masters in Economics. During World War II he served in the Navy in the Pacific on the Destroyer escort Chase which was attacked by Japanese kamikaze. He was founder and CEO of Carnation Paper Corp. a private label paper plate manufacturer. He is deeply mourned by his wife Suzanne, sister Gloria Noschkes, children Abby, Jeremy and Carol, stepson Michael Clinger and six step- grandchildren. His first wife Ruth Lopin passed away in a tragic accident at a young age. Funeral services are private. 1/3

KREINDLER--Ellen Cohen. Called by some "The Fabulous Ellen K", she was beautiful, elegant, artistically gifted and very accomplished, but most of all, she had an infinite capacity for love. Her love for her husband Donald, her children Russell Cohen, Carlen Leeser, John Cohen and their spouses, and her eight grandchildren and one great- granddaughter, was so deep and everlasting and was returned in equal measure by all of them. She loved and was loved in turn by many others. She will be sorely missed. Services: Friday, May 1 at 11am at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue and 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to Mt. Sinai Heart. 1/3

PASCOE--Rev. Louis B.,SJ., - on April 27, 2015. Long-time history professor at Fordham University. Survived by his brother, Ronald, of Carbondale, PA. Reposing at the Murray-Weigel Hall Chapel, 515 East Fordham Rd., Bronx, NY, on Thursday, 3-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass at the Fordham University Church, Bronx, NY, Friday, 10:30am. Interment at the Jesuit Cemetery, Wernersville, PA. For information contact Farenga Bros., Inc., Directors (718) 654-0500. 1/3

HENDERSON--Lawrence, 62, on April 25, 2015, of Scotch Plains, NJ. Worked as Labor Arbitrator in New Jersey. Memorial gathering on Friday 4-8 and Saturday 11-1:30 at Memorial Funeral Home in Fanwood, NJ. For complete obituary, visit www.fanwood memorial.com. 1/3

MILLER--Harvey, R. The world has lost an amazing mind and we have all lost a great friend. Harvey has always been a reliable, incredible friend to our family and our organization for many years. We will miss his insight, his sense of humor and his commitment to doing the right thing. Thank you for always being there for us and our family and for being such a great friend. Harris & Nicole Schwartzberg 1/3

ARANOFF--Jonathan, M.D. We record with profound sorrow the death of Jonathan Aranoff, M.D., age 58, on April 27, 2015, after a long illness. Dr. Aranoff was an anesthesiologist in cardiacbypass surgery, at the Manhattan V.A., for over twenty-five years. He is survived by his devoted wife, Susana Krausz Aranoff, his loving sons, Akiva, Ben, and Daniel, his mother Freda Appleman Aranoff, and his sisters, Shera Aranoff Tuchman and Gaya Aranoff Bernstein. He is also mourned by his brothers-inlaw, Lewis Bernstein and Alan Tuchman, his loving nieces and nephews, and his large extended family, all of whom benefited from his brilliant business acumen and guidance, which was always accompanied by unquestionable ethics and a self-deprecating sense of humor. He will be profoundly missed. May his memory be a blessing and may his soul be bound in everlasting life. 1/3

ZORNBERG--Dr. Edward David, a prominent dentist who practiced on Madison Avenue for over four decades, and served as President of the Park East Synagogue Men's Club, and who had retired and moved to Weston, FL in 2012, died Monday at peace in his home at the age of 96. He received his BA and DDS degrees from New York University had practiced dentistry as a Captain in the Army in World War II and later at Manhattan General Hospital. He is survived by his wife of 70 years, Florence, his devoted son Eric and his wife Debra, loving daughter Dr. Gwen Zornberg and her wife the Honorable Deborah A. Batts, and three grandchildren. He was predeceased by his son Ely and a grandson. Services will be held Thursday, April 30, 2015, 11:45am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Interment to follow at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, New York. 1/3

STRICKER--Rochelle 78, died April 27, 2015 at her home after a long illness. Devoted wife of Irwin Jesse, who passed in 2011. Loving mother of Sharon, Janet and Alan. Dear mother-in-law of Andy, Tom and Sara. Cherished grandmother of Ava, Charles, Julia, Madeline, Matthew and Nora. Rochelle was a warm, generous woman who will forever be missed. Funeral Services Wednesday, 10a.m. at "Gutterman's Inc." 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY.

SILMAN--Marcelle S.,died April 27, 2015 at 98. Beloved wife of Harry. Cherished mother and mother-in- law of Lydia and Jack Zakim and Barbara and Jeffrey Silman. Adored grandmother of Jordana and Justin Blitz, Noah Zakim, Kristy and Harry Silman and Jeb Silman. Loving great-grandmother of Julian Blitz. Funeral April 30, 11am, at Schoem's, W150 Rt. 4 East, Paramus, NJ 07652. 1/3

EMDEN--Howard. To our beloved "Uncle Dog". Your funny, witty, quirky sense of humor will forever be missed. We will always cherish the times we spent with you and Aunt Lois in Arizona and New York. Please give her a big kiss from us. With Love always, David, Elissa, Mikey Lauren and Danny 1/3

SOKOLIN--William, 85. We would like to celebrate the life of William Sokolin. He passed peacefully at his home on April 28th surrounded by family. ARANOFF--Jonathan, M.D. We record with profound sorrow the death of Jonathan Aranoff, M.D., age 58, on April 27, 2015, after a long illness. Dr. Aranoff was an anesthesiologist in cardiacbypass surgery, at the Manhattan V.A., for over twenty-five years. He is survived by his devoted wife, Susana Krausz Aranoff, his loving sons, Akiva, Ben, and Daniel, his mother Freda Appleman Aranoff, and his sisters, Shera Aranoff Tuchman and Gaya Aranoff Bernstein. He is also mourned by his brothers-inlaw, Lewis Bernstein and Alan Tuchman, his loving nieces and nephews, and his large extended family, all of whom benefited from his brilliant business acumen and guidance, which was always accompanied by unquestionable ethics and a self-deprecating sense of humor. He will be profoundly missed. May his memory be a blessing and may his soul be bound in everlasting life. 1/3

MAURER-- Phoebe. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Phoebe Maurer, beloved wife of the late Hebert Maurer, who instilled a commitment to the Jewish community and philanthropic giving in her children. Our heartfelt condolences go out to Phoebe's children, Jeffrey (Wendy), Ira (Audrey), and Gale (Edward); her grandchildren; her great-grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3

ZORNBERG--Dr. Edward David. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of our devoted longtime Trustee, Dr. Edward David Zornberg, beloved husband of Sisterhood Honorary President Florence Zornberg, father of Eric, Gwen, and the late Ely, dear grandfather. Our deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Herman Hochberg, President 1/3

PATTERSON--Robert P.,Jr. The board and staff of Prisoners' Legal Services of New York (PLS) are deeply saddened by the death of Bob Patterson. He was a founder of PLS and served as its first board chair, from 1976 until 1988. During his tenure, PLS became a highly credible organization in its representation of NYS prisoners on civil matters. He will be remembered as an inspiring leader and a courageous champion of justice for incarcerated individuals. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. 1/3

ZORNBERG--Dr. Edward David, a prominent dentist who practiced on Madison Avenue for over four decades, and served as President of the Park East Synagogue Men's Club, and who had retired and moved to Weston, FL in 2012, died Monday at peace in his home at the age of 96. He received his BA and DDS degrees from New York University had practiced dentistry as a Captain in the Army in World War II and later at Manhattan General Hospital. He is survived by his wife of 70 years, Florence, his devoted son Eric and his wife Debra, loving daughter Dr. Gwen Zornberg and her wife the Honorable Deborah A. Batts, and three grandchildren. He was predeceased by his son Ely and a grandson. Services will be held Thursday, April 30, 2015, 11:45am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Interment to follow at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, New York. 1/3

KREINDLER--Ellen Cohen. Called by some "The Fabulous Ellen K", she was beautiful, elegant, artistically gifted and very accomplished, but most of all, she had an infinite capacity for love. Her love for her husband Donald, her children Russell Cohen, Carlen Leeser, John Cohen and their spouses, and her eight grandchildren and one great- granddaughter, was so deep and everlasting and was returned in equal measure by all of them. She loved and was loved in turn by many others. She will be sorely missed. Services: Friday, May 1 at 11am at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue and 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to Mt. Sinai Heart. 1/3

SOKOLIN--Bill. The Management, Brokers and Staff of Fox Residential Group mourn the passing of Bill Sokolin, husband of our beloved colleague, Gloria Sokolin. No one who knew Bill will ever forget his magnetic personality, his expertise in fine wine, and the fun he was to be around. We will all miss Bill terribly. Barbara Fox, President 1/3

MILLER--Harvey R. It is with great sadness that we announce the passing of Harvey Miller after a courageous battle with ALS. He was 82 years old. Mr. Miller was born in 1933. He earned his Bachelor of Arts degree at Brooklyn College in 1954 and graduated from Columbia Law School in 1959. He joined Weil, Gotshal & Manges LLP in 1969 as the Firm's 14th partner and was an integral member of the Firm for the majority of his long and distinguished career. From September 2002 to March 2007, he was a Managing Director and Vice Chairman of the independent investment bank Greenhill & Co. Mr. Miller created Weil's bankruptcy practice and, in so doing, elevated the practice of bankruptcy law to the large law firm environment as a profitable and mainstream practice group of most major U.S. law firms. Throughout his career, he played a key role in the most significant, notable and complex bankruptcies and restructurings in history, including Lehman Brothers, General Motors, American Airlines, R.H. Macy, Texaco, WorldCom and Enron. He also played a key role in managing Weil. Mr. Miller, along with three other partners, managed the Firm up until it elected its first Executive Partner in 1989, and his leadership and vision significantly impacted Weil's evolution from a small, two-office law firm to one of the world's major full-service firms. Described by colleagues as a gifted teacher as well as practitioner, Mr. Miller spent significant time teaching at a number of institutions, including Columbia University Law School, Yale Law School and New York University School of Law. He trained and mentored a number of future leaders of the restructuring bar, and championed young talent. He was the consummate practitioner, colleague and friend to so many. Mr. Miller was a member of the National Bankruptcy Conference, a fellow of the American College of Bankruptcy, a fellow of the American Bar Foundation, and a Trustee of the Committee on Economic Development. Mr. Miller loved the opera, and he was a long-time Advisory Director for The Metropolitan Opera. Mr. Miller's vast contributions to the law and the community will live on through the many people he impacted throughout his life and career. He will be missed greatly by his many colleagues and friends at Weil and beyond. Mr. Miller was a beloved and devoted husband. He is survived by his wife, Ruth. In honor of Mr. Miller, Weil has established the Harvey R. Miller Lecture Series at Columbia Law School. To make a gift, please make your check payable to Columbia Law School and indicate The Harvey R. Miller Lecture Series Fund. Send to the attention of David Strumeyer, Executive Director for Weil, Gotshal & Manges LLP, 767 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10153. 1/3

SHORT--Muriel McKay. The Board and staff of Public Art Fund note with deep sadness the death of Muriel McKay Short, mother of Charles Short, the organization's tireless Board Treasurer, dedicated leader, and dear friend. We send our sympathy and deepest condolences to Chuck, John, and their family. Jill Kraus, Chair; Susan K. Freedman, President; Nicholas Baume, Director 1/3

SUAREZ--Susana, (nee Fonolleda Aspert in Mollet Del Valles, Spain), died on April 25, 2015. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Francisco Suarez, mother of Therese, Susan, and George; grandmother of Cristina. Visitation at Frank E Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., Thursday, April 30, 4pm-8pm. Memorial service, Friday, May 1 at 11am Holy Trinity Church, 209 West 82nd Street. Her charm, humor and spirit will be greatly missed. 1/3

STONE--Jacqueline Goddet, daughter of Jacques and Adele Goddet, wife to Louis Stone of New York, mother to Oliver Stone, and three grandchildren, Sean, Michael, and Tara, passed quietly in her sleep of heart failure at her home in Indian Wells, CA on Tuesday, April 28. She was 93 years old. Born in Paris on August 16, 1921, she immigrated to the US in 1946. A woman of great heart who loved and was loved by a multitude of friends, she wished to be cremated at Forest Lawn in Cathedral City, CA. Remembrances, letters, photographs, condolences can be sent to her son, Oliver at 12233 W. Olympic Blvd. Suite 322, Los Angeles, CA, oliverstone.forjps1@ gmail.com, or in France to her nephew Jean-Pierre Goddet at jpgoddet@aol.com. 1/3

MILLER-- Harvey. Kirkland & Ellis mourns the passing of Harvey Miller. Harvey was a visionary in the world of corporate restructuring, helping to shape the future of countless companies. His dedication to his profession and the many charitable causes he supported inspired all of us. Harvey will be missed dearly, yet his impact on the restructuring world will continue for generations. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Ruth, and wish her comfort during this difficult time. 1/3

ROBBINS--Jean, 89, nee Cohen, of Fort Lee, N.J. passed away on April 29. Jean was born in Newark, NJ, a proud graduate of Weequahic High School. She resided in Teaneck for forty-five years with the love of her life, the late Jack Robbins, one of the original owners of J & J Pharmacy. They were married fifty-three years. She is survived by her son Marc, his wife Renee, daughter Susan and her husband David Barish. She was grandmother to Jason, Joshua and his wife Pam, Amy and her husband Matt Kelly, great-grandmother to Jack and Sarah, sister to Leonard Cohen and the late Ruth Barron. Jean was an avid reader, loved to travel, was passionate about politics and classic movies. Jean and Jack loved to celebrate holidays in their home with their many friends and family. For many years, she was a volunteer for ORT and Meals on Wheels. Please make donations in memory of Jean to those organizations or charity of your choice. Please visit www.GuttermanMusicant Wien.com. Service Friday 11:30am at Gutterman and Musicant Hackensack, NJ. 1/3

CRONKITE--Peter Reilly Rush. 22, died Sunday, April 26, 2015 in Waterville, ME. He took his own life. Peter was to have graduated from Colby College, as a Classics major, in May. Peter was graduated from St. Bernard's School in Manhattan and Horace Mann School in the Bronx. Peter was Sports Editor of the Colby Echo and co-captain of the Colby rugby team. His life on teams in school and area hockey leagues as a goalie was a great happiness in his life. As a Classics major he spent one summer course studying in Greece and another on an ancheological dig in Ostia, Italy. He was slated to receive the Foster Prize for excellence in his major. Last summer he worked for his beloved Mets team at Citi Field. He also worked during the 2012 Olympics for Sports Illustrated. Peter enjoyed tutoring at the Colby Writing Center for the past two years and coached youth hockey. Peter, an avid film enthusiast, was the voice of Dennis the Menace for an animated movie when he was nine years old. He will be missed by his many Martha's Vineyard friends. Peter is survived by his parents, Deborah Rush and Chip Cronkite, and his brother Walter Cronkite lV. The funeral service will be held Saturday, May 2, 11am, at The Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, please donate to the Colby College Men's Rugby Team. 1/3

SHEPARD--Thomas R.,Jr. May 1, 2015--Thomas Rockwell Shepard, Jr., former publisher of Look magazine; legendary advertising sales executive, World War II veteran; and author of four books, the last of which he published at age 95, died April 29 of pneumonia at Sarasota Memorial Hospital. He was 96 years old. At a career crossroads after almost five years of U.S. Navy service in the Western Pacific theatre, Mr. Shepard considered both Harvard Business School and Look magazine's training program. Mike Cowles, the founder and publisher of Look, convinced him that he would get a better business education by joining Look. Assigned first to the magazine's Cleveland office, Mr. Shepard launched a 26-year career that included stops in Boston and Los Angeles before he landed in New York in 1949. He rose from salesman to advertising sales manager to director of advertising before being named Look's publisher in 1965. In the mid-1960's, Look, which showcased photographs in its feature pages, passed its rival Life in circulation, reaching 8.5 million. However, television's inroads into the advertising sales that were Look's principal source of revenue prompted a financial crisis at the magazine. Look ceased publishing in 1971. Life folded a few months later, ending the era of the mass market photography feature magazine. When Look shut its doors, Mr. Shepard made sure everyone on his sales team had new employment, and then joined the Institute of Outdoor Advertising as president, a job he held until 1976. During that time, Outdoor Advertising quadrupled in revenue, and he was elected to the Outdoor Advertising Hall of Fame. Mr. Shepard was born in 1918 at Lying-In Hospital in New York City, the son of Thomas Rockwell Shepard and Marie Maze Dickinson Shepard. He grew up in East Orange, N.J., during the Great Depression and graduated from East Orange High School, where he was president of his senior class. In 1940, he graduated from Amherst College, which he attended on scholarship and where he waited tables for spending money. After graduation, Mr. Shepard, who wanted to get married but knew jobs were scarce, applied for what he believed was the best opportunity for a successful future in business--the very competitive Vick School of Applied Merchandising in New York, an executive marketing training program created by the Vick Chemical Company. He was one of just three graduates in 1941, by then having been a traveling salesman of Vick's Vapo-Rub to smalltown country stores. Recounting the experience in letters to his fiancee, Nancy Kruidenier, he described Texas as being filled with "bogs, bugs, mules, wild dogs, [and] the ever present danger of rattlers and bulls." He married Nancy Kruidenier of Des Moines, Iowa in September of that year. The day after the attack on Pearl Harbor three months later, Mr. Shepard went to New York's Navy headquarters and volunteered to serve. Based on his experience with small boats, he was commissioned as an ensign and eventually assigned to Destroyer Escort 419, the USS Robert F. Keller, as gunnery officer. He was involved in six major campaigns in the western Pacific in 1944 and 1945, including Iwo Jima and Okinawa. He also endured two typhoons at sea, including three grueling days of conning the ship safely through "Halsey's Typhoon," which sank three U.S. destroyers. At the end of his service, he was the Keller's executive officer and held the rank of lieutenant commander. Following his career in advertising and publishing, Mr. Shepard spent the next three decades of his life traveling the world extensively with his beloved wife, Nancy. He remained deeply involved with Amherst College and his Amherst classmates throughout his life, raising funds for the college in every capacity. In 1990, he received Amherst's Medal For Eminent Service. He was president of the Class of 1940 for the past 20 years, frequently encouraging--or admonishing--his classmates to "stay vertical." He enjoyed writing: his final book of four, Making the Sale: The Art of Salesmanship, was published last year. Mr. Shepard was passionate about national politics and international news his entire life and prided himself on his tenacity to stay informed. Rare was the day that he didn't devour The New York Times, listen to broadcast news, and become engaged in serious conversation with friends and family about national and international issues. In the early 1990's, Mr. Shepard chaired George H.W. Bush's presidential campaign in Connecticut. A staunch, lifelong devotion to the Republican Party ended a decade later when Mr. Shepard began to prefer more moderate Democratic candidates. A longtime resident of Greenwich, Conn., Mr. Shepard was deeply involved in the community, holding multiple civic leadership positions. He was a member of the Round Hill and Belle Haven Clubs. He also had a home in Sarasota, where he was a member of the Bird Key Yacht Club. Mr. Shepard is survived by his wife, Nancy; three daughters, Sue Shepard Jaques of Lambertville, NJ, and her husband Pete Jaques, Molly Dickinson Shepard of Philadelphia and her husband Peter Dean, and Amy Shepard Knight of Chevy Chase, Md., and her husband Edward Knight; a son, Thomas R. (Rocky) Shepard III of Rye, NY and his wife Peggy O'Neal Shepard; nine grandchildren and twelve great grandchildren. Funeral services will be private. 1/3

MILLER--Harvey R. It is with great sadness that we announce the passing of Harvey Miller after a courageous battle with ALS. He was 82 years old. Mr. Miller was born in 1933. He earned his Bachelor of Arts degree at Brooklyn College in 1954 and graduated from Columbia Law School in 1959. He joined Weil, Gotshal & Manges LLP in 1969 as the Firm's 14th partner and was an integral member of the Firm for the majority of his long and distinguished career. From September 2002 to March 2007, he was a Managing Director and Vice Chairman of the independent investment bank Greenhill & Co. Mr. Miller created Weil's bankruptcy practice and, in so doing, elevated the practice of bankruptcy law to the large law firm environment as a profitable and mainstream practice group of most major U.S. law firms. Throughout his career, he played a key role in the most significant, notable and complex bankruptcies and restructurings in history, including Lehman Brothers, General Motors, American Airlines, R.H. Macy, Texaco, WorldCom and Enron. He also played a key role in managing Weil. Mr. Miller, along with three other partners, managed the Firm up until it elected its first Executive Partner in 1989, and his leadership and vision significantly impacted Weil's evolution from a small, two-office law firm to one of the world's major full-service firms. Described by colleagues as a gifted teacher as well as practitioner, Mr. Miller spent significant time teaching at a number of institutions, including Columbia University Law School, Yale Law School and New York University School of Law. He trained and mentored a number of future leaders of the restructuring bar, and championed young talent. He was the consummate practitioner, colleague and friend to so many. Mr. Miller was a member of the National Bankruptcy Conference, a fellow of the American College of Bankruptcy, a fellow of the American Bar Foundation, and a Trustee of the Committee on Economic Development. Mr. Miller loved the opera, and he was a long-time Advisory Director for The Metropolitan Opera. Mr. Miller's vast contributions to the law and the community will live on through the many people he impacted throughout his life and career. He will be missed greatly by his many colleagues and friends at Weil and beyond. Mr. Miller was a beloved and devoted husband. He is survived by his wife, Ruth. In honor of Mr. Miller, Weil has established the Harvey R. Miller Lecture Series at Columbia Law School. To make a gift, please make your check payable to Columbia Law School and indicate The Harvey R. Miller Lecture Series Fund. Send to the attention of David Strumeyer, Executive Director for Weil, Gotshal & Manges LLP, 767 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10153. 1/3

Friedman--Jacklyn, 89, died peacefully at her home in Hewlett Harbor on April 29. Devoted wife of the late Jack Friedman, she will be greatly missed by her children David, Dianne, and Steven, her son-in-law Michael, her daughter-in-law Rebecca, and 11 grand and great-grandchildren. Her love of beauty and extraordinary talent showed in everything she did, especially through her painting, printmaking, sculpture, and gardening. A memorial service will be held at Gutterman's in Rockville Centre on Thursday, May 7 at 5:30pm.

GOLDSTEIN--Patricia. Emigrant Bank, New York Private Bank & Trust, and the Milstein family mourn the loss of our dear friend and colleague, Patricia Goldstein, Vice Chairman and Head of Commercial Real Estate for Emigrant Bank, who passed away on April 29th. She was an iconic, larger than life leader in banking and real estate in New York City and the nation, a true force of nature, a pioneer in her field for women, and a mentor to many. She was passionate about the industry, serving her clients, and negotiating deals. Pat loved what she did, day-in and day-out, and excelled in her field. Pat joined the Milstein family businesses 15 years ago on the real estate investment side. In 2004, Pat assumed the roles of Chief Credit Officer and Head of Commercial Real Estate at the Bank. Before joining us, Pat had a long, diverse career in banking and real estate, including with Citicorp, M.J. Raynes and Olympia & York. Pat was critically injured in an accident on April 24th and passed away surrounded by family. She was a loving and devoted wife, mother, grandmother and friend. Pat leaves behind her husband, Howard Epstein; daughter Alicia Goldstein and spouse, James Prusky; son Jeffrey Goldstein and spouse Samantha Greenes; grandchildren Jack Prusky and Jetson Goldstein; and many friends and colleagues. She was my partner and my friend. Rest in peace, dear Pat, and sincerest condolences to your family. Howard P. Milstein, Chairman; Emigrant Bank & Milstein Properties 1/3

BERNSTEIN--Julius "Julie", longtime resident of Malverne, NY passed away at age 94, on May 1, 2015. Loving husband, father, grandfather, brother, and uncle. A gentleman and a gentle man, he will be dearly missed by all who loved him. Services at Gutterman's Funeral Home, Rockville Centre.

MILLER--Harvey R. It is with great sadness that we announce the passing of Harvey Miller after a courageous battle with ALS. He was 82 years old. Mr. Miller was born in 1933. He earned his Bachelor of Arts degree at Brooklyn College in 1954 and graduated from Columbia Law School in 1959. He joined Weil, Gotshal & Manges LLP in 1969 as the Firm's 14th partner and was an integral member of the Firm for the majority of his long and distinguished career. From September 2002 to March 2007, he was a Managing Director and Vice Chairman of the independent investment bank Greenhill & Co. Mr. Miller created Weil's bankruptcy practice and, in so doing, elevated the practice of bankruptcy law to the large law firm environment as a profitable and mainstream practice group of most major U.S. law firms. Throughout his career, he played a key role in the most significant, notable and complex bankruptcies and restructurings in history, including Lehman Brothers, General Motors, American Airlines, R.H. Macy, Texaco, WorldCom and Enron. He also played a key role in managing Weil. Mr. Miller, along with three other partners, managed the Firm up until it elected its first Executive Partner in 1989, and his leadership and vision significantly impacted Weil's evolution from a small, two-office law firm to one of the world's major full-service firms. Described by colleagues as a gifted teacher as well as practitioner, Mr. Miller spent significant time teaching at a number of institutions, including Columbia University Law School, Yale Law School and New York University School of Law. He trained and mentored a number of future leaders of the restructuring bar, and championed young talent. He was the consummate practitioner, colleague and friend to so many. Mr. Miller was a member of the National Bankruptcy Conference, a fellow of the American College of Bankruptcy, a fellow of the American Bar Foundation, and a Trustee of the Committee on Economic Development. Mr. Miller loved the opera, and he was a long-time Advisory Director for The Metropolitan Opera. Mr. Miller's vast contributions to the law and the community will live on through the many people he impacted throughout his life and career. He will be missed greatly by his many colleagues and friends at Weil and beyond. Mr. Miller was a beloved and devoted husband. He is survived by his wife, Ruth. In honor of Mr. Miller, Weil has established the Harvey R. Miller Lecture Series at Columbia Law School. To make a gift, please make your check payable to Columbia Law School and indicate The Harvey R. Miller Lecture Series Fund. Send to the attention of David Strumeyer, Executive Director for Weil, Gotshal & Manges LLP, 767 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10153. 1/3
APPEL--Alfred, Jr. May 2, 2009. In loving memory. The Family 1/3

MILLER-- Harvey. Kirkland & Ellis mourns the passing of Harvey Miller. Harvey was a visionary in the world of corporate restructuring, helping to shape the future of countless companies. His dedication to his profession and the many charitable causes he supported inspired all of us. Harvey will be missed dearly, yet his impact on the restructuring world will continue for generations. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Ruth, and wish her comfort during this difficult time. 1/3

STONE--Nancy Klee, of White Plains, New York and Dunewood, Fire Island, died much too soon at age 79. Her grieving family and friends comforted her in her last days at home while she was in the care of the Hospice of Westchester and the Montefiore Medical Center. She leaves, Robert, her loving husband of 35 years; her children, Peter Kempner and his wife, Betsy of Stamford, CT; James Kempner and his fiancee, Sara Bassett of Westport, CT; and Carrie Getz and her husband, Matthew of New Canaan, CT; her sister Mary Ellen Klee of Pacific Palisades, CA; her grandchildren Robert, Douglas, Ellen, and Julia Kempner, and Brian and Daniel Getz, and a stepdaughter, Lesley Stone. Nancy was born in NYC, daughter of Rhonie Berlinger and David Klee. After graduating from Nightingale Bamford and Smith College, Nancy devoted much of her life to volunteer work at White Plains Hospital, United Hospital, Blythedale Children's Hospital and the Institutional Review Board for Research of the New York Medical College. In her work with Hospice of Westchester, Nancy and her dog, Mickey formed a therapy team for visiting the sick and infirmed. Nancy founded and operated Family Friends which provided free housing for families of hospital patients in this region. She had a lifetime love of music and opera. Some of her other interests were painting, bridge, travel and computers, for which she had a rare talent. She had many friends, some going back to her days at Camp Accomac. There will be a celebration of her life to be held on Monday, May 11, 2015 at Community Unitarian Church, 468 Rosedale Ave, White Plains, NY 10605. Her family will be receiving visitors from 3pm-8pm on May 3rd and 4th at 1 Littlejohn Place, White Plains, NY 10605 and from 5-9pm on May 5th and 6th at 60 Ridge Road Drive, Stamford, CT. Contributions in her memory can be made to the charity of your choice. 1/3

Her beauty and humor will be greatly missed by her family and all who knew her. 1/3

NEWTON--The Reverend, Willoughby, resident of New York City, died on April 18, 2015 at the age of ninety. Father Newton was the son of Frederick Griffith and Kathleen Sutherland Taylor Newton and was born on April 8, 1925 in Orange, Virginia. Before finishing high school he enlisted in the Army Air Corps and served for three years, being discharged on his 21st birthday. He graduated in three years from the University of Virginia where he was inducted into Phi Beta Kappa. He was awarded the Alfred I. DuPont Fellowship to attend Christ's College, Cambridge University from which he received a B.A. and a M.A. In 1951 he began teaching at Kent School, Kent, Connecticut. He was made deacon in the Episcopal Church in 1955 and was ordained priest in 1956. He served briefly as rector of St. Andrew's Church, Marble Dale, Connecticut, and in 1960 he returned to Kent to become the first chaplain of Kent School (Girls.) In 1963 he helped in the refounding of Wykeham Rise School in Washington, Connecticut, and in 1964 the school reopened with Father Newton as headmaster. In 1976 he moved to New York City and in 1977 he was appointed Director of Institutional Development at WNET/Channel Thirteen. In 1987 he became Vice President of General Theological Seminary, retiring in 1990. In 1981 he was awarded an honorary Doctor of Divinity degree by St. Paul's College in Lawrenceville, Virginia. Over the years Father Newton served on the boards of various ecclesiastical, educational and civic organizations. Father Newton is survived by his dear friend, Shastri Kedarnauth, eight nieces and nephews, their children and grandchildren, and worked very hard at being the favorite uncle. He is also survived by many friends, for whose friendship he was always grateful, and of which he was properly proud. His funeral service will be held on May 23rd at his final resting place, Yeocomico Church, Cople Parish-1233 Old Yeocomico Road, Kinsale, VA 22488. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made either to the Frederick and Kathleen Newton Family Fund of Cople Parish, P.O. Box 110, Hague, Virginia 22469 or to the Chelsea Square Conservancy, General Theological Seminary, 175 Ninth Avenue, New York 10011 to support the Willoughby Newton Fragrance Garden. 1/3

JONES--Robert K.,MD, PhD, 1924-2015, died April 26. Neurosurgeon and neurologist (Philadelphia, London, Montreal, Maine, Boston). WW II naval officer and POW survivor. BOYD--James W.,79, of Orleans, MA, passed away peacefully on February 4, 2015 in Port Orange, FL. Jim was born on May 8, 1935 in West Orange, NJ and was a graduate of The Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, Class of 1957. He was a Vice President at Morgan Guarantee Trust Co. for 22 years, and married Catherine H. Gallagher in 1998. Upon retirement they moved to Orleans, MA where they lived for 17 years. They spent their winters in Vero Beach and most recently Ponce Inlet, FL. Jim was an avid golfer and enjoyed the piano and entertaining his family and friends with an endless repertoire of Broadway show tunes. Jim's true dedication was to his family. He was the beloved husband of Catherine H. Gallagher Boyd, of Milton, NY, and the devoted father to Lisa Boyd Linton, James W. Boyd, Jr. and Alexander L. Boyd as well as the cherished grandfather of Chip Linton, Reese Linton, Sarah Boyd, Ellis Boyd, Alexandra Linton, Christopher Boyd and Graydon Boyd. He also leaves behind his loving step children Cathy Gallagher, Joy Gallagher, John Gallagher, and Tom Gallagher as well as four step grandchildren, Danielle, Julieann, Ryan and Jake. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, May 16, at 2pm at The Church of the Holy Spirit, 204 Monument Rd, Orleans, MA. FARVER--Jane. The ISCP board, staff and residents mourn the sudden passing of our fellow board member Jane Farver. MILLER--Harvey R. It is with great sadness that we announce the passing of Harvey Miller after a courageous battle with ALS. He was 82 years old. Mr. Miller was born in 1933. He earned his Bachelor of Arts degree at Brooklyn College in 1954 and graduated from Columbia Law School in 1959. He joined Weil, Gotshal & Manges LLP in 1969 as the Firm's 14th partner and was an integral member of the Firm for the majority of his long and distinguished career. From September 2002 to March 2007, he was a Managing Director and Vice Chairman of the independent investment bank Greenhill & Co. Mr. Miller created Weil's bankruptcy practice and, in so doing, elevated the practice of bankruptcy law to the large law firm environment as a profitable and mainstream practice group of most major U.S. law firms. Throughout his career, he played a key role in the most significant, notable and complex bankruptcies and restructurings in history, including Lehman Brothers, General Motors, American Airlines, R.H. Macy, Texaco, WorldCom and Enron. He also played a key role in managing Weil. Mr. Miller, along with three other partners, managed the Firm up until it elected its first Executive Partner in 1989, and his leadership and vision significantly impacted Weil's evolution from a small, two-office law firm to one of the world's major full-service firms. Described by colleagues as a gifted teacher as well as practitioner, Mr. Miller spent significant time teaching at a number of institutions, including Columbia University Law School, Yale Law School and New York University School of Law. He trained and mentored a number of future leaders of the restructuring bar, and championed young talent. He was the consummate practitioner, colleague and friend to so many. Mr. Miller was a member of the National Bankruptcy Conference, a fellow of the American College of Bankruptcy, a fellow of the American Bar Foundation, and a Trustee of the Committee on Economic Development. Mr. Miller loved the opera, and he was a long-time Advisory Director for The Metropolitan Opera. Mr. Miller's vast contributions to the law and the community will live on through the many people he impacted throughout his life and career. He will be missed greatly by his many colleagues and friends at Weil and beyond. Mr. Miller was a beloved and devoted husband. He is survived by his wife, Ruth. In honor of Mr. Miller, Weil has established the Harvey R. Miller Lecture Series at Columbia Law School. To make a gift, please make your check payable to Columbia Law School and indicate The Harvey R. Miller Lecture Series Fund. Send to the attention of David Strumeyer, Executive Director for Weil, Gotshal & Manges LLP, 767 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10153. 1/3
LINDHDavid E.P. Holland Lodge #

STONE--Nancy Klee, of White Plains, New York and Dunewood, Fire Island, died much too soon at age 79. Her grieving family and friends comforted her in her last days at home while she was in the care of the Hospice of Westchester and the Montefiore Medical Center. She leaves, Robert, her loving husband of 35 years; her children, Peter Kempner and his wife, Betsy of Stamford, CT; James Kempner and his fiancee, Sara Bassett of Westport, CT; and Carrie Getz and her husband, Matthew of New Canaan, CT; her sister Mary Ellen Klee of Pacific Palisades, CA; her grandchildren Robert, Douglas, Ellen, and Julia Kempner, and Brian and Daniel Getz, and a stepdaughter, Lesley Stone. Nancy was born in NYC, daughter of Rhonie Berlinger and David Klee. After graduating from Nightingale Bamford and Smith College, Nancy devoted much of her life to volunteer work at White Plains Hospital, United Hospital, Blythedale Children's Hospital and the Institutional Review Board for Research of the New York Medical College. In her work with Hospice of Westchester, Nancy and her dog, Mickey formed a therapy team for visiting the sick and infirmed. Nancy founded and operated Family Friends which provided free housing for families of hospital patients in this region. She had a lifetime love of music and opera. Some of her other interests were painting, bridge, travel and computers, for which she had a rare talent. She had many friends, some going back to her days at Camp Accomac. There will be a celebration of her life to be held on Monday, May 11, 2015 at Community Unitarian Church, 468 Rosedale Ave, White Plains, NY 10605. Her family will be receiving visitors from 3pm-8pm on May 3rd and 4th at 1 Littlejohn Place, White Plains, NY 10605 and from 5-9pm on May 5th and 6th at 60 Ridge Road Drive, Stamford, CT. Contributions in her memory can be made to the charity of your choice. 1/3

GAMBLE--Frederica Vanderbilt (Webb), 101, died peacefully at her home in Westwood, MA on April 16th after a period of declining health. She is survived by her daughter, Frederica Gaynor Gamble, as well as nieces, nephews, cousins and friends, for whom she was an elegant and iconic presence. Born in Manhasset, NY, Freddy's family tree included Cornelius Vanderbilt, Webb generals from the Revolutionary and Civil Wars and her maternal grandfather, William Gaynor, who served as mayor of New York City. She projected this patrician heritage, leavened by humility and a keen sense of humor. After a marriage of 40 years her beloved husband David died too young, but well into her 80's she traveled the globe to explore and enjoy the wonders of the natural world. Hail and farewell. Contributions in Freddy's memory may be made to Shelburne Farms, 1611 Harbor Rd., Shelburne, VT 05482. 1/3

VICUNA--Cecilia Alexandra Capitola Fulton, 23, passed away on April 27, 2015 from injuries sustained during a tragic accident in San Francisco, CA. Cecilia Alexandra was born February 16, 1992, in Santa Monica, CA and grew up in New York City where she attended school at Lycee Francais de New York. She was a top student, president of her class and fluent in French, Spanish, and English. She also attended school at Leysin American School in Leysin, Switzerland. She earned a Associates Degree in Homeland Security and was taking a year off and planning to intern at Buzzell Law Group, PC in San Francisco, CA this summer. She was an athlete and loved the outdoors. She excelled in snowboarding, loved to hike, and rafted internationally on the Futaleufu River in Chile. She was an environmentalist and interned with Robert Kennedy Jr. at Pace University in their Environmental Studies Program and as a volunteer for the Waterkeeper Alliance. She is survived by her mother, Victoria Linda Fulton Vicuna; her grandmother Cecilia Vicuna Elguin her grandfather and step-grandmother, Edward and Norma Fulton; her uncle Frank Copsidas, her aunt Jennifer and uncle Paul Granstrom; her uncle Edward Fulton Jr., and three cousins. She is survived in Santiago, Chile by numerous relatives from the Vicuna family. She is also survived by her boyfriend Jason Bernick. She was preceded in death by her father Don Simpson. Services will be held at 3pm, Thursday, May 14th, 2015 at St. Joseph's Church of Yorkville, 404 E. 87th St., New York, NY, 10128. In lieu of flowers, individuals may make a donation in the memory of Cecilia Alexandra to the ASPCA at ASPCA.org by clicking donate and have the e-cards sent to: mapucheyusa@gmail.com 1/3

LINDH--David, E.P. We're deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend and colleague David. DAVID--Clive. An internationally renowned party architect passed away February 19th, 2015 in La Jolla, CA after a long and valiant struggle with ALS. He was born, June 6, 1934, in Manchester, England, and attended Berkhampstead School and The Royal College of Art in London. After immigrating to the United States in 1957, his love for this country never waned. Clive maintained residences in New York, Los Angeles and La Jolla. The preeminent party architect created galas for the rich and famous, including President John F. Kennedy's Birthday Party where Marilyn Monroe sang "Happy Birthday Mr. President," also for Queen Elizabeth ll, Prime Minister Golda Meir, John and Patricia Kluge, and Barbara Walters along with many others. Among his splendorous affairs was the Un Ballo en Maschera in Venice. His tributes included The Twenty-Fifth Anniversary Salute to Israel in Jerusalem and The Los Angeles Bicentennial Tribute to Men and Women of Achievement. There were legendary weekend celebrations in Virginia and at La Costa, CA, as well as extravaganzas in New York, Los Angeles, London and many other locations around the globe. His major events and parties scanned a period of time between 1962-1999. Clive also shared his knowledge and remarkable experiences during his 16 year national lecture circuit, "Party Planning par Excellence." He was the recipient of many awards, including Freedom Foundation Award, Valley Forge, Pennsylvania, City of Hope Award, Philadelphia, 1962, The Mayor's Medal for Voluntary Service, Los Angeles, 1972, Shalom Award, The State of Israel, 1974, Honorary Citizen of Columbus, Ohio, 1978. He was listed in Who's Who in America and Who's Who in the World. He was pre-deceased by his mother, Claire, and his step-father Willem Kattenburg who resided in Lausanne, Switzerland and his father Marcus Wiener of Manchester. He is survived by his cousins, Fay Hassid and Shirley Kingsley and their sons Jed Hassid and Jermey Kingsley residents of the Manchester area. His funeral and interment was March 10th in Lausanne, Switzerland. The memorial service was held at Beth Israel Synagogue in San Diego on April 21. He will be missed by his many friends. Clive's words of farewell were always "God Bless." 1/3

KIRKPATRICK--Anise. Anise Wallace Kirkpatrick, 62, died after a long struggle with cancer on Sunday, April 19, 2015, at her home in San Francisco. Born on January 17, 1953 in Atlanta, Georgia, she graduated from the University of Georgia. During the 1970's and 80's Anise was a financial journalist in New York, a senior writer for Institutional Investor magazine, freelance reporter for The New York Times Business section (where she described how portfolio insurance led to the 1987 stock market crash), and reporter for the American Banker newspaper and Pensions and Investments magazine. In 1991 she moved to San Francisco and in 1995 received an M.A. in Library Science from San Jose State University. Anise was an early adopter of the Internet and used it innovatively in a successful financial research company she founded in 1995 and directed until 2012. In 1995 she married David Kirkpatrick. The couple lived in London before resettling in San Francisco in 1997. They traveled extensively in Europe and the United States, often hiking or skiing. Insatiably curious, Anise was an avid reader, a lover of nature, art, and gardening, and a fan of the San Francisco Giants. She was treasured for her generosity, warmth, wisdom, playful sense of humor, and enthusiastic spirit. She is survived by her husband, David, and niece, Emily Ferguson. Memorial donations may be made in her name to the Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation or Friends of the Urban Forest. 1/3

WRIGHT--Daniel R. After a full life, Dan Wright died April 27, 2015, at 88. He leaves his beloved partner Anne Impellizzeri, his children Kathryn, Mark, Sarah and Liz, and four grandchildren. A graduate of Haverford, he served in the U.S. Navy in the eastern Pacific in World War II. Starting as a reporter at The Wall Street Journal, at IBM he became director of public affairs and served as liaison to the Kennedys in Washington, and director of communications for the "War on Poverty". Later, as a consultant, clients ranged from the Electronic Industries Association of Japan to the City of Indianapolis. In Cold Spring, NY since 2000, he has fought to prepare the Port of New York for giant container ships and to gain popular appreciation for the decisive role of the Hudson River in the American Revolution. Service Sunday, May 10, 4pm, at The Chapel Restoration, Cold Spring. 1/3

GOLDSMITH--Dolores. May 2, 2009. I Am Not There. Do not stand at my grave and weep, I am not there I do not sleep, I am a thousand winds that blow, I am the diamond glints on snow, I am the sunlight on ripened grain, I am the gentle autumn's rain, When you awaken in the morning's hush, I am the swift uplifting rush of quiet birds in circled flight, I am the soft stars that shine at night, Do not stand at my grave and cry, I am not there, I did not die. 1/3

SCHNEIDER--Rita. Died peacefully at home surrounded by loved ones on April 28, at age 93. Rita and her sister, Claire (who resides in Red Bank, NJ) were raised by their mother in the Bronx, Manhattan and then Brooklyn after their father died when Rita was age 8. After graduating from Hunter High School and City College, Rita began a 25-year career as an accountant working in a male-dominated field. She and her husband Edward, "the love of her life," were married in 1946. Together they raised their daughters Debra (Shelkowitz) and Diane (Landau) until Eddie's death in 1985. Rita and Eddie were active participants in city politics, the New York City labor movement, ORT and Union Temple of Brooklyn and the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue. They travelled extensively around the world for both business and pleasure. In 1963 Rita was appointed to serve as the first Chairperson of the Local School Board for District #

GOLDSTEIN--Patricia. Emigrant Bank, New York Private Bank & Trust, and the Milstein family mourn the loss of our dear friend and colleague, Patricia Goldstein, Vice Chairman and Head of Commercial Real Estate for Emigrant Bank, who passed away on April 29th. She was an iconic, larger than life leader in banking and real estate in New York City and the nation, a true force of nature, a pioneer in her field for women, and a mentor to many. She was passionate about the industry, serving her clients, and negotiating deals. Pat loved what she did, day-in and day-out, and excelled in her field. Pat joined the Milstein family businesses 15 years ago on the real estate investment side. In 2004, Pat assumed the roles of Chief Credit Officer and Head of Commercial Real Estate at the Bank. Before joining us, Pat had a long, diverse career in banking and real estate, including with Citicorp, M.J. Raynes and Olympia & York. Pat was critically injured in an accident on April 24th and passed away surrounded by family. She was a loving and devoted wife, mother, grandmother and friend. Pat leaves behind her husband, Howard Epstein; daughter Alicia Goldstein and spouse, James Prusky; son Jeffrey Goldstein and spouse Samantha Greenes; grandchildren Jack Prusky and Jetson Goldstein; and many friends and colleagues. She was my partner and my friend. Rest in peace, dear Pat, and sincerest condolences to your family. Howard P. Milstein, Chairman; Emigrant Bank & Milstein Properties 1/3

SOKOLIN--William. New York Fine Wine Legend Passes Away, 85. We would like to celebrate the life of William Sokolin, leading New York City wine merchant, who passed away peacefully in his home on Tuesday, April 28th, 2015, surrounded by family. Loving husband to Gloria Sokolin, father to Deanne and David Sokolin, father-in-law to Glenn Goldstein and devoted grandfather to Jeremy and Lilly Goldstein. As a young man, Bill attended Horace Mann in Riverdale and Tufts University where he excelled in sports. He said that a big moment in his life happened when he signed with Branch Rickey of the Brooklyn Dodgers and saw images of Hank Greenberg dancing around him. As a patriot, Bill left the Dodgers for the US Army during the Korean War. When he returned from serving his country, he went directly into the family's liquor business, which his father opened on Madison Avenue in 1934, immediately after Prohibition ended. Bill discovered his passion for wine long before it had been mainstreamed in America, and he innovatively changed the focus of the store from liquor to wine by 1959. A pioneering force in the fine and rare wine business, Bill was considered one of the leading experts on the subject of wine and wine investing. He was a published author of "Liquid Assets" and "The Complete Wine Investor" and essentially invented the concept of fine wine investment in the Bordeaux market in the mid-1960s. Bill was known not only for his vast wine knowledge, but also for his charm, leaving customers with wonderful and memorable shopping experiences. Bill was once famously quoted as saying: "What is the definition of a good wine? It should start and end with a smile." Bill was a true original as anyone who knew him can attest to. He will be greatly missed, but the memories with him leave us smiling.

STAUTBERG--Aubrey Theodore, "Ted," Jr.,68, died on Wednesday, April 29th, 2015 from throat and mouth cancer. Ted was born in Houston on July 24th, 1946 to Mr. Aubrey Stautberg and Mrs. Thelma McAlister Stautberg. He graduated from St. John's School, and from both the University of Texas, and the University of Texas Law School in Austin. After working as an Attorney at the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington DC, Ted was a Vice President of Butcher and Singer, Inc. in Philadelphia, where he was responsible for many of the oil and gas activities of the firm. Ted moved to New York as the Founder, President, and a Director of Triumph Resources Corporation and the Chairman of Triumph Securities Corporation. He also served as a Director of several companies. He enjoyed spending time in Newport and Palm Beach, and in his clubs. Ted is survived by his wife, Susan Schiffer Stautberg, and their son Edward Berwind Stautberg and his wife Alison Devenny Stautberg, and his sister Ann Stautberg Tolbert and her husband Frank X Tolbert, II. Ted's sense of humor, kindness, stubbornness and legendary style, made him such a uniquely fun man. He will be greatly missed. There will be a small, private family "Celebration of Life" in May in New York and a memorial service in Houston later. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation in Ted's name to Community Foundation for Palm Beach and Martin Counties, 700 South Dixie Highway, Suite 200, West Palm Beach, FL 33401, Phone: (561)659-6800, or the St. John's School, 2401 Claremont Ln, Houston, TX 77019, Phone: (713)850-0222. 1/3

GRAND--Ruth. Ruth Young Grand, 94, of Topsham, ME, died peacefully of natural causes on January 28, 2015. She was born on November 11, 1920; the daughter of the late William Henry Young and Ruth Agnes Gervais in New York City. She was raised by her grandmother, Minnie Knowlton Young. Ruth graduated from the Tuxedo Park School and Miss Hewitt's Classes in 1938. She married the late Gordon Grand Jr. on February 27, 1943 at The Church of the Incarnation in New York City. They lived in Millbrook, NY, Washington, DC, Greenwich, CT, New York City and Fishers Island, NY. A classically trained pianist, at age 15 Ruth was awarded the youth medal by Lily Pons for her accomplishments in the New York Philharmonic Symphony Concert Program, under the direction of Ernest Shelling. She went on to teach piano to such notables as Peter Duchin of the Peter Duchin Orchestra. In the 1960s and early 1970s, she served as the summer organist for the St. John's Episcopal Church in Fishers Island, NY. An avid horticulturist, she volunteered at the New York Botanical Garden, the New Canaan, CT Nature Center and the Wild Garden in Acadia National Park, ME, where she supervised the summer intern program. Ruth is survived by her children: Gordon Grand, III, of North Salem, NY; Lorna Grand Stengel of Brunswick, ME; Diana Grand Masters of South Hadley, MA; and Timothy Weatherford Grand of Coconut Grove, FL. She is predeceased by her bother, Henry Knowlton Young, and her oldest daughter, Minette Dill Grand Krech. She is also survived by ten grandchildren: Kerry Krech Morrison, Teal Krech Paynter, Angela Grand Cavallo, Harry Spencer Grand, Jake Weatherford Grand, Brooke Stengel Murdock, William Pepper Stengel II, Diana Stengel Lyman, Henry-Gordon Masters and Timothy James Masters; as well as 16 great-grandchildren: Hannah Seabright Morrison, Eloise Shepard Morrison, and Maisie Dill Morrison; Clara Dill Paynter and Lillian Gooch Paynter; Grace Emma Murdock and Abigail Ruth Murdock; Charles Grand, George William Stengel and Thomas Sloan Stengel; Grey William Lyman; Samuel Gordon Cavallo and Ellie Grace Cavallo; Lillian Pond Grand, Winthrop Fowler Grand and Beatrice Olive Grand. A service will be held on August 8th at St. John's Church on Fishers Island, NY. Donations in her memory can be made to the Fishers Island Conservancy, P.O Box 553, Fishers Island, NY 06390 or at www. fishersislandconservancy.org 1/3
