McGINLEY--Gerald Hayes, long time businessman and star University of Pennsylvania football player, Gerald Hayes McGinley, died on February 23 at his home in Hobe Sound, Florida. The cause was organ failure and cancer. McGinley's investment career spanned more than 45 years. He began work at W.R. Grace & Co. as an Assistant to the President, and later worked at Crown Cork & Seal Co. Gerry went on to dedicate three decades of service to Kidder, Peabody. And later, finish his investment career as a Senior Vice President at UBS at the age of 80. McGinley earned his Bachelor of Science in Economics from the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania, in 1952. Hailed by the legendary Penn Football Coach, George Munger, as "the greatest linebacker in the country," Gerry won the prestigious class of 1915 Award for the ideal Penn athlete and earned All-American honors in his senior season. McGinley was active in many educational and community organizations. He served as Treasurer for the Malta Human Services Foundation and as a Trustee for both the New Community Foundation and Camp Tecumseh in Center Harbor, New Hampshire. Additionally, McGinley was on the council for the Pennsylvania Society and was a life member of the Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick. He was also a past member of the Millburn Board of Education and a former trustee of the Avon Old Farms School. At his alma mater, he served on the President's Council and the "Quakers" Athletic Board of Advisors. Gerry also served on the President's Council at the College of the Holy Cross. Always supportive of outstanding scholar-athletes, Gerry established the Edward F. McGinley, Jr. Scholarship Fund (at Penn), in memory of his father, an All-American tackle at University of Pennsylvania, immortalized in the College Football Hall of Fame. After finishing his tour in the Army, McGinley came home and married Patricia O'Neill in 1957. Pat was the love of Gerry's life and the two would stay married for 58 years. McGinley is survived by wife, Patricia and five loving children: Pam, John, Helen, Gerry and Mark, as well as 12 grandchildren and both of his brothers, Edward and Rick. 1/3

EDELSTEIN--Murray, passed away on May 2, 2015 at age 95. He was a loving husband, son, father, grandfather and great grandfather. Dr. Edelstein lived a full and fruitful life that was filled with personal achievement, professional success, a zest for life, a love of baseball, and the love and admiration of his family and friends. He was a proud WWII Veteran who served in the European campaign, including the Battle of the Bulge, and received a Bronze Star. His chosen profession was Podiatry where, over many years, he built a thriving practice in Brooklyn, New York. He became a leader in Podiatry practice and education where he held numerous local, state and national positions. In 1973, he became President of the New York College of Podiatric Medicine where he revitalized the College during his six year tenure. Later, he returned to private practice in West Palm Beach, Florida until his retirement. Murray was married for 61 years to his beloved wife, Vicky, and was the proud father of his three sons Lee, Mitchell, and Russell, his daughters-in-law Heather, Janet, and Natalie, his grandchildren Seth and Lauren, their spouses Jessica and Brian, and his great grandchildren Hayley, Stella, and Davis. Always a gentleman, we will miss the stories he loved to tell and the unconditional love he showered upon us. To make a long story short, he was a fabulous guy! 1/3

EMDEN--Howard. June 12, 1939 - April 25, 2015, of Scottsdale, Arizona died, surrounded by family, at the home of his daughter Allison who lovingly cared for her father throughout his long illness. Endearing, smart, funny and sensitive, our big brother Howard will always be our champion. As an astute financial advisor, he spent most of his career with Cowen & Co., ending with Morgan Stanley. When our Dad passed away, Howard assumed the role of family advisor, helping his three brothers navigate their way to manhood (Jeffrey deceased 2008). Howard and his beloved wife Lois (deceased 2007) were believers in philanthropy, taking greatest pride in their support of the Tucson Hospital Cancer Center. For those left behind, Allison and his son Sloane, his grandchildren, son and daughter-in-law, brothers, sisters-in-law, nieces and nephews, Howard's legacy will remain strong as he touched us all. Bobby and Margie and Jimmy and Barbara 1/3

STONE--Nancy Klee. The Violates mourn our beloved Nancy, our intrepid traveling companion on land and sea and our fantastic Fire Island hostess. We cherish the wonderful memories of our time together. 1/3

KING--Ben E. We mourn the loss of our client and friend. An iconic entertainer, a devoted family man and a fine gentleman. Our sincerest condolences to his wife, Betty, and their family. Randy Irwin Peter Lane, Esq. 1/3

MARDER--JoAn Teetor. May 11, 1928 - April 26, 2015. JoAn Teetor Marder, beloved wife, mother and grandmother, of Tucson, Arizona, passed away Sunday evening, April 26, after a battle with cancer. She was 86 years old. JoAn was born in Indianapolis to Macy Orville Teetor and Lucille Alcus Teetor on May 11, 1928, and grew up in Newcastle, Indiana. She attended boarding school at Kingswood School Cranbrook in Bloomfield Hills, Michigan, graduating in 1946. She went on to major in music at Sweetbriar College in Virginia, and she spent her junior abroad in Paris, studying at the Sorbonne. After graduating from Sweet Briar in 1950, she moved to New York and attended The Katherine Gibbs School. She lived at the Barbizon Hotel for Women, and she worked for Time Inc. in New York for several years, moving to Scarsdale, New York, in 1959, where she raised two children, Emily Saxe Nydam and Raymond Daniel Saxe III, with her first husband, R. Daniel Saxe, Jr. She taught piano and was active in local civic affairs for many years, contributing her time and energy to many charitable organizations, including chairing the annual fundraising ball for the White Plains Hospital Women's Auxiliary. In 1985 (after her first marriage ended in divorce), she married Steven S. Marder, and in 1990 they moved to Tucson, Arizona, where they have been members of the Tucson Country Club. In Tucson, JoAn was a longtime member of the Tucson Patio Garden Club, and she found a new passion for playing tennis. One of her proudest moments was when her Tucson Country Club tennis team went to the Southwestern Sectional Finals. She is survived by her husband Steven S. Marder of Tucson, her daughter, Emily Saxe Nydam of Boston, and her five beloved grandchildren: Amanda, Abigail and Rachel Saxe, and John and James Nydam. There will be a private memorial service at the Teetor Family Mausoleum in Hagerstown, Indiana. JoAn touched so many lives, and she brought joy to everyone who knew her. "She was a wonderful, lovely, gracious lady," said one friend upon hearing the news of her passing. "She will be missed." 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Lillian, passed away at the age of 93 on April 25, 2015. She lived in Nyack, NY. She was a great writer and was loved by family and friends. She was fun to be with. There will be a service in celebration of her life at the main sanctuary of the Riverdale Temple, 4545 Independence Avenue, in the Bronx on Saturday, May 9th at 12:30pm. Please contribute to the Alzhemier's Association in memory of her life. 1/3

SCHOONMAKER--Samuel V. III, 79. Accomplished matrimonial lawyer and tennis player, Sam will be remembered for his humor, generosity and warmth. Graduate of Lawrenceville, Yale and Yale Law School. Managing partner of Cummings & Lockwood and founder of Schoonmaker & George in Connecticut. Beloved husband of Carolyn (nee Peters). Loving father of Sam and Eric. Memorial services at Noroton Presbyterian Church, Darien, CT, May 19. 1/3

MILLER--Harvey, R. The world has lost an amazing mind and we have all lost a great friend. Harvey has always been a reliable, incredible friend to our family and our organization for many years. We will miss his insight, his sense of humor and his commitment to doing the right thing. Thank you for always being there for us and our family and for being such a great friend. Harris & Nicole Schwartzberg 1/3

RICE--Catherine R.,(Dailey), passed away on April 22, 2015 at her home in Bradenton, FL with her family at her bedside. Survived by daughter, Therese Marie and sons Cameron and Kenneth and grandsons Thomas and Kevin. Catherine was born in Airdrie, Scotland and emigrated from England to Montana with her husband, Thomas Rice, M.D. (predeceased) and children in 1965. Memorial Mass will be held Monday, May 4, 10:45am at Our Lady of The Blessed Sacrament Church in Bayside, Queens. Donations can be made in her memory to the National Women's History Museum. www.NWHM.org 703-461-1920. 1/3

MILLER-- Harvey. Kirkland & Ellis mourns the passing of Harvey Miller. Harvey was a visionary in the world of corporate restructuring, helping to shape the future of countless companies. His dedication to his profession and the many charitable causes he supported inspired all of us. Harvey will be missed dearly, yet his impact on the restructuring world will continue for generations. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Ruth, and wish her comfort during this difficult time. 1/3

YARON--Jacob Cantor-Rabbi, 82 years old passed away on April 29, 2015. Loving husband of Elizabeth. Caring father of Benjamin Alexander, Joseph David and Shamir Yaron. Devoted brother of the late Abraham. Graveside services were held at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. Donations in his memory may be made to The Long Island Alzheimer's Foundation, Port Washington, NY, or, St. Francis Hospital, Flower Hill, NY, or, The Community Synagogue of Sands Point, NY. 1/3

ROBERTS--Earl. May 1, 1920 - May 10, 2014 Loving husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather, friend, golfer, news/ sports junkie, Big Band aficionado and crime novel savant who loved to laugh. Happy Birthday, Earl Dear. 1/3

TSIEN--Patricia Koo, passed away on April 25, 2015, at the age of 97, in Montgomery Village, Maryland. She was born on October 17, 1917, in Washington DC, daughter of May Tang Koo and V.K. Wellington Koo, the prominent Chinese diplomat. After receiving the B.Sc. degree in physics at London University, she joined the United Nations in 1947. She devoted herself to the work of decolonization, and was a senior official in the Department for Political Affairs, Trusteeship and Decolonization. Mrs. Tsien was the founding president of the Ad Hoc Group on Equal Rights for Women in the U. N. Secretariat. After retirement in 1979, she was a long time member of the Association of Former International Civil Servants, serving as its president for three years. She was regarded by her colleagues as a model international civil servant. Her husband, Kiachi Tsien, and her son, Michael Tsien, predeceased her. She is survived by her step-mother, Juliana Young Koo; her daughter, Ying-Ying T. Yuan; her grandchildren, Nicole Yuan and Christopher Tsien; and two great-grandchildren. A celebration of her life will be held at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York City on May 9, 2015, at 10am. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Kiachi and Patricia Koo Tsien Fund, Columbia University Libraries, c/o Matthew Hampel, 507 Butler Library, 535 West 114th Street, New York, NY 10027. 1/3

GOTTSEGEN--Gloria Behar, Ph.D. Professor Emerita, Lehman College (CUNY) passed away peacefully in Boca Raton, FL on April 21 at the age of 84. Born in New York City to Marco and Flora Behar, Gloria is survived by her loving partner of 12 years, Barnett Singer (daughters, Alexa, Laura and Mindy), her adoring children Abby (Len) and Paul (Jane), grandchildren Margot and Andrew Haas, William and Holly Gottsegen, and nephew Brett Behar (Teri). She is also survived by her loving brother, Maury Behar, with whom she shared a special bond. A Memorial service will be held at a future date (to be announced). In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Special Olympics. 1/3

HANSLER--Dr. George E. Passed away April 26, 2015 in St. Paul, MN at the age 93. Preceded in death by his parents, Rev. George and Dorothy Hansler and his partner of 65 years, Gregory Martinez. Survived by sister, Elsie Trapp of St. Paul, MN; brother, Dr. Richard (Wanda) Hansler of Cleveland, OH; nieces and nephews. Funeral Service 2:30pm Tuesday, May 5th (visitation Tuesday 1:30-2:30pm) at Como Park Lutheran Church, Hoyt and Sheldon Aves., St. Paul. Interment will be at a later date at Centro Espanol Memorial Park Cemetery Tampa, FL. George lived most of his adult life in the Chelsea area of New York City, taught music and conducted various acclaimed musical groups for more than 40 years at New Jersey City University, Jersey City, NJ. Memorials preferred to the George Hansler Music Scholarship Fund at New Jersey City University or donor's choice. 1/3

RUBINGER--Robert, on April 20, 2015 at Amsterdam House. Husband of Nancy Brilliant, father of the late Susan and David (Hedy Silver), grandfather of Jill, Scott, Adam and Eric. Memorial service Monday, May 25, 10am, Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. 1/3

SCHIFF--Edward. July 18, 1946-February 14, 2015 of Livingston, NJ. Actor, producer, director, writer, teacher and friend. Ed spent a lifetime pursuing a craft he loved and was loved by the many people whose lives he touched. Survived by his longtime partner, Stephanie Gerstein, sister Ellen Prisco and her husband Tony, sister Gail Shepherd, niece Rory McCormick and nephew Arthur Fisher. A memorial celebration will be held on Monday, May 11 at 5:30pm at The Actor's Temple, 339 West 47th Street, New York, NY. Contributions in Ed's memory may be made to The Actor's Fund, 729 Seventh Avenue, New York, NY 10019. 1/3

LINDH--David Edward Post, Died peacefully on April 24th, 2015 at Sycamore Creek Ranch, Whitesboro, Texas. He was born in New York on July 30th, 1932 to Alice Lee B. Lindh and Fritz P. Lindh. He attended The Buckley School and St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Yale University in 1954. He was Master of Holland Lodge and President of the ASPCA and a life member of the The Union Club. He was active in National Horse Show serving as Treasurer and President. He was President of The Huguenot Society, a member of The St. Nicholas Society, The Society of Colonial Wars, The New England Society, The New York Genealogical & Biographical Society and The New York Historical Society. In Newport, he was a Trustee of The Preservation Society and helped revive the Coaching Club of America. He is survived by his wife, Lynda, his two children, Beverly and Kenneth, four grandchildren, and his brother Henry. 1/3

KOUSI--John D.,long time resident of New York City died on April 4 in Malibu, CA. from complications of quadriplegia. John was born in Bay Shore long Island on January 21, 1934. He graduated from Yale University and New York University Law school and began his career practicing corporate law at Lovejoy Wasson Lundrgren and Ashton in New York City. He served as President of Fairfield International, a ship- owning firm, for 14 years. In 1987 he was one of the founding shareholders of Eastwind Maritime, an international shipping firm that came to own and operate dry bulk carriers, refrigerated ships, oil tankers, and container- ships. Following his retirement he remained involved for the rest of his life with private investments in international shipping. He will be so missed by his wife Elizabeth Easter Kousi, his wife of 50 years and their daughters, Christina Kousi Dobbs of London, England and Katherine Kousi of Malibu, CA. and his six grandsons - Conway Dobbs, Sinclair Dobbs, Ossian Dobbs, Aidan Flanigan, Truman Flanigan and Fergus Flanigan. 1/3

RUBIN--LeRoy, died May 2, 2015 at home in Manhattan of natural causes. He was 90 years old. Born in Bronx, NY on November 13, 1924, LeRoy was the son of Aaron and Dorothy Rubin and brother to Justine Auerbach, who predeceased him. He was married for 63 years to Barbara Eydenberg Rubin who survives him. They have three children-Jim Rubin (Faye Weitzman), Jane Hoffman (Coley) and Patty Sacks (Douglas), 11 grandchildren (Alexis (Evan), Zac, Josh, Danny, Sophie, Hillary, Tim, Chris, Olivia, Elizabeth and Haley), one great-grandchild (Myles), one nephew and three nieces. Lee was the founder and owner of LeeBar Management Company. Leebar owns and manages a variety of residential, commercial, and industrial properties both in and around New York and in other parts of the country. Lee converted numerous prewar apartment buildings on the upper westside into cooperatives, and loved to tell stories of his great bargaining accomplishments with the tenants groups in these buildings. Lee loved the business and remained until his death a very savvy bargain seeker and indefatigable deal hunter. He was an active board member of the Paul Taylor Dance Company and the President's Council at Weill Cornell Hospital. Lee was a long standing member and director of the Lotos Club. A hearty club participant, he served on the finance and arts committee. He was often found at state dinners, reading plays, and engaging with great interest in history book groups. Lee was known for a quick wit and irreverent sense of humor that often entertained and sometimes offended. He was an elegant man, a dapper dresser and loved conversation. Leroy graduated from Dewitt Clinton High School and the University of Pennsylvania. His college years were interrupted by his service in the US Army as a member of the 103rd Infantry Division in World War II. After basic training he was deployed to France but was soon captured by the Germans. He spent months in a POW camp in the Czech Republic. His wartime experiences - which influenced much of his adult life - were documented both by the Shoah foundation and the book, No Hero, No Coward, by George Davis. Above all, Lee cherished time with family, his adored wife, and their active life in the community of Stamford, Connecticut where he sat on school and museum boards. His quiet time was spent in the out of doors, on the ski slopes of Vermont, Colorado and Europe, fox hunting and horseback riding in Upper Westchester and with a great book. Lee remained to the end a patriarch and embracer of family time. He was an impulsive and persistent telephoner of his three children, their spouses and the 11 grandchildren. Lee, Dad, Grandpa, Great-gramps, Uncle Lee will be sorely missed but will live on in the family members he touched and deeply influenced. Rest well, Le Roi- our king! Our hearts are broken. The family will receive guests Monday and Tuesday from 4-8pm at 35 Sutton Place #

GAMBLE--Frederica Vanderbilt (Webb), 101, died peacefully at her home in Westwood, MA on April 16th after a period of declining health. She is survived by her daughter, Frederica Gaynor Gamble, as well as nieces, nephews, cousins and friends, for whom she was an elegant and iconic presence. Born in Manhasset, NY, Freddy's family tree included Cornelius Vanderbilt, Webb generals from the Revolutionary and Civil Wars and her maternal grandfather, William Gaynor, who served as mayor of New York City. She projected this patrician heritage, leavened by humility and a keen sense of humor. After a marriage of 40 years her beloved husband David died too young, but well into her 80's she traveled the globe to explore and enjoy the wonders of the natural world. Hail and farewell. Contributions in Freddy's memory may be made to Shelburne Farms, 1611 Harbor Rd., Shelburne, VT 05482. 1/3

FRANKLIN--Frederic. June 13,1914 - May 4,2013 My Dearest Freddie, I love and miss you so. Bill Dear Friends, Please celebrate Freddie's legacy with a gift to his scholarship fund to support a dancer at American Ballet Theatre's JKO School, 890 Broadway, NY, NY 10003.

BERG--Laurence G. September 2, 1929 - May 1, 2015. Loved and loved by his wife Sally, his children Mary and Peter, his son-in-law Larry, his grandchildren Alexandra, Joshua, Emmett, and his many friends. Semper Fi. 1/3
STAUTBERG--Aubrey. I will miss you Ted, a warm and courageous friend and a gentleman to the core. You were admired by everyone you knew and for good reason. Most Sincerely, Joel I. Berson 1/3

BENTON--Charles. We mourn the passing of Charles William Benton, 1931-2015, our beloved family friend for more than 50 years - humanistic businessman, family man, tireless public servant, pioneer in educational films and philanthropist. We will greatly miss "Uncle Charles" and send our sympathies to his loving family, devoted wife of 62 years Marjorie, daughter Adrianne and son Craig and the Benton and Furniss family. In lieu of flowers, the family encourages gifts to honor Charles' lifelong passion, the Benton Foundation, and its efforts to ensure that media and telecommunications serve the public interest and enhance democracy. Benton Foundation, 1560 Sherman Ave, Suite 440, Evanston, IL 60201. Much Love, Richard, Renee and John Edelman and Family 1/3

BENNET--Silvia Strong, of Marblehead, MA, formerly of New York City, on 1 May 2015 in 104th year of her age. Widow of John Reinhart Bennet, mother of Helena Prentice Bennet and David LaTourette Bennet, mother-in-law of Marcia Merker Bennet, grandmother of John Merker Bennet. Services at Old North Church, Marblehead, MA at the convenience of the family. 1/3

GOLDSTEIN--Patricia. The Broido family deeply mourns the untimely passing of Patricia Goldstein, friend and colleague for thirty-eight years, and extends our heartfelt sympathy to Howard, Alicia, Jeffrey, Jim, Samantha, Jack and Jetson. Michael and Jane Broido 1/3

SHEFRIN--David. Passed away peacefully at his home in Scottsdale, AZ on Tuesday April 28. He is survived by his two sons Andrew (Mary Lou) and Gregory (Nancy), his loving partner Doris Perlmutter and her family, sister Diane Harris and five grandchildren. David was a successful business owner, entrepreneur and supporter of the state of Israel.

EDELSTEIN--Murray, passed away on May 2, 2015 at age 95. He was a loving husband, son, father, grandfather and great grandfather. Dr. Edelstein lived a full and fruitful life that was filled with personal achievement, professional success, a zest for life, a love of baseball, and the love and admiration of his family and friends. He was a proud WWII Veteran who served in the European campaign, including the Battle of the Bulge, and received a Bronze Star. His chosen profession was Podiatry where, over many years, he built a thriving practice in Brooklyn, New York. He became a leader in Podiatry practice and education where he held numerous local, state and national positions. In 1973, he became President of the New York College of Podiatric Medicine where he revitalized the College during his six year tenure. Later, he returned to private practice in West Palm Beach, Florida until his retirement. Murray was married for 61 years to his beloved wife, Vicky, and was the proud father of his three sons Lee, Mitchell, and Russell, his daughters-in-law Heather, Janet, and Natalie, his grandchildren Seth and Lauren, their spouses Jessica and Brian, and his great grandchildren Hayley, Stella, and Davis. Always a gentleman, we will miss the stories he loved to tell and the unconditional love he showered upon us. To make a long story short, he was a fabulous guy! 1/3

GOLDSTEIN--Patricia. Emigrant Bank, New York Private Bank & Trust, and the Milstein family mourn the loss of our dear friend and colleague, Patricia Goldstein, Vice Chairman and Head of Commercial Real Estate for Emigrant Bank, who passed away on April 29th. She was an iconic, larger than life leader in banking and real estate in New York City and the nation, a true force of nature, a pioneer in her field for women, and a mentor to many. She was passionate about the industry, serving her clients, and negotiating deals. Pat loved what she did, day-in and day-out, and excelled in her field. Pat joined the Milstein family businesses 15 years ago on the real estate investment side. In 2004, Pat assumed the roles of Chief Credit Officer and Head of Commercial Real Estate at the Bank. Before joining us, Pat had a long, diverse career in banking and real estate, including with Citicorp, M.J. Raynes and Olympia & York. Pat was critically injured in an accident on April 24th and passed away surrounded by family. She was a loving and devoted wife, mother, grandmother and friend. Pat leaves behind her husband, Howard Epstein; daughter Alicia Goldstein and spouse, James Prusky; son Jeffrey Goldstein and spouse Samantha Greenes; grandchildren Jack Prusky and Jetson Goldstein; and many friends and colleagues. She was my partner and my friend. Rest in peace, dear Pat, and sincerest condolences to your family. Howard P. Milstein, Chairman; Emigrant Bank & Milstein Properties 1/3

GANNON--Mary Katharine, (nee Talley), died on May 3, age 82. Devoted nurse, mother, sister and aunt. United States Air Force Veteran and friend to many. "Buttons" was the mother of Jeffrey T. Gannon, sister of Patricia Connors, Alfred J. Talley and the late John J. Talley. Funeral Mass - May 7, 1pm at Our Lady of Peace, 237 E. 62nd Street, New York, NY. 1/3

GAMBLE--Frederica Vanderbilt (Webb), 101, died peacefully at her home in Westwood, MA on April 16th after a period of declining health. She is survived by her daughter, Frederica Gaynor Gamble, as well as nieces, nephews, cousins and friends, for whom she was an elegant and iconic presence. Born in Manhasset, NY, Freddy's family tree included Cornelius Vanderbilt, Webb generals from the Revolutionary and Civil Wars and her maternal grandfather, William Gaynor, who served as mayor of New York City. She projected this patrician heritage, leavened by humility and a keen sense of humor. After a marriage of 40 years her beloved husband David died too young, but well into her 80's she traveled the globe to explore and enjoy the wonders of the natural world. Hail and farewell. Contributions in Freddy's memory may be made to Shelburne Farms, 1611 Harbor Rd., Shelburne, VT 05482. 1/3

SCHNEIDER--Rita. The Mount Sinai Auxiliary Board mourns the passing of our greatly esteemed member, Rita Schneider. Her generosity and commitment to our Board will be greatly missed. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family and friends. Jennifer Price, President The Mount Sinai Auxiliary Board 1/3

GOLDSTEIN--Sol. The Board of Directors of Rebuilding Together, Long Island mourn the loss of our colleague and friend, the founder and President of our organization. For twenty three years, his dedication and inspirational leadership have enabled Rebuilding Together to better the lives of thousands of Long Island families. 1/3

POLLACK--Allen, died in New York City at 77. Beloved son, brother, uncle and friend, He will be missed for his insight and knowledge. Allen taught Russian history at Columbia University and was a leading Zionist activist for many years. In his college days he was the North American Chairman of the Habonim Youth Movement and in 1967 he helped found American Professors for Peace in the Middle East. 1/3
HOROWITZ--JR. In loving memory of Saul Horowitz, Jr. on his 90th birthday, May 5, 1925. Duty, Honor, Country. 1/3

RUBIN--LeRoy. Our special friend and dinner companion. We will miss his smile, sense of humor and thoughtful opinions. To his beloved wife Barbara, his adored children and grandchildren, our love and sympathy. Deedy and David 1/3

IRWIN--Frances. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Frances Irwin, a Holocaust survivor and longtime friend of UJA-Federation. We extend our deepest condolences to Frances's son, Martin; her grandchildren; her great- grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3

ARGERAKIS--George Peter, DDS, MSD of Fort Lee, NJ passed away in New York on May 2nd, 2015. Born in Sparta, Greece and raised in Washington DC, George is survived by his wife Joanna, sons Peter (Nathalie) and Nicholas (Joy), and grandsons George Peter and George Nicholas. George graduated from Georgetown Dental School (DDS) and NYU College of Dentistry (MSD), was a former attending at Memorial Sloan Kettering, Clinical Professor of Prosthodontics at NYU, and had his private dental practice in Manhattan, NY. George was also an Archon of the Ecumenical Patriarchate.

RUBIN--LeRoy. LeRoy Rubin, died May 2, 2015 at home in Manhattan of natural causes. He was 90 years old. Born in Bronx, NY on November 13, 1924, LeRoy was the son of Aaron and Dorothy Rubin and brother to Justine Auerbach, who predeceased him. He was married for 63 years to Barbara Eydenberg Rubin who survives him. They have three children-Jim Rubin (Faye Weitzman), Jane Hoffman (Coley) and Patty Sacks (Douglas), 11 grandchildren (Alexis (Evan), Zac, Josh, Danny, Sophie, Hillary, Tim, Chris, Olivia, Elizabeth and Haley), one great-grandchild (Myles), one nephew and three nieces. Lee was the founder and owner of LeeBar Management Company. Leebar owns and manages a variety of residential, commercial, and industrial properties both in and around New York and in other parts of the country. Lee converted numerous prewar apartment buildings on the upper westside into cooperatives, and loved to tell stories of his great bargaining accomplishments with the tenants groups in these buildings. Lee loved the business and remained until his death a very savvy bargain seeker and indefatigable deal hunter. He was an active board member of the Paul Taylor Dance Company and the President's Council at Weill Cornell Hospital. Lee was a long standing member and director of the Lotos Club. A hearty club participant, he served on the finance and arts committee. He was often found at state dinners, reading plays, and engaging with great interest in history book groups. Lee was known for a quick wit and irreverent sense of humor that often entertained and sometimes offended. He was an elegant man, a dapper dresser and loved conversation. Leroy graduated from Dewitt Clinton High School and the University of Pennsylvania. His college years were interrupted by his service in the US Army as a member of the 103rd Infantry Division in World War II. After basic training he was deployed to France but was soon captured by the Germans. He spent months in a POW camp in the Czech Republic. His wartime experiences - which influenced much of his adult life - were documented both by the Shoah foundation and the book, No Hero, No Coward, by George Davis. Above all, Lee cherished time with family, his adored wife, and their active life in the community of Stamford, Connecticut where he sat on school and museum boards. His quiet time was spent in the out of doors, on the ski slopes of Vermont, Colorado and Europe, fox hunting and horseback riding in Upper Westchester and with a great book. Lee remained to the end a patriarch and embracer of family time. He was an impulsive and persistent telephoner of his three children, their spouses and the 11 grandchildren. Lee, Dad, Grandpa, Great-gramps, Uncle Lee will be sorely missed but will live on in the family members he touched and deeply influenced. Rest well, Le Roi- our king! Our hearts are broken. The family will receive guests Monday and Tuesday from 4-8pm at 35 Sutton Place #

STAMPA--Priscilla, theater professional and activist, died on April 26, 2015. She was a founding member, Managing Director, actor and costumer for New York theater group Heat & Light Co., Inc. and originated roles in many of Tony Kushner's plays. She performed at the Repertory Theatre of St. Louis, Williamstown Theater Festival and numerous New York theaters. She was Costume Designer for Bent Spoons in Toronto and Resident Costume Designer at Staples High School in Westport, CT with Marjorie Watt. See full obit at legacy.com 1/3

RUBIN--LeRoy. Paul Taylor, his dancers, the administration and the trustees of the Paul Taylor Dance Foundation mourn the passing of LeRoy Rubin. Lee, a valued Board member for more than two decades, was a generous champion of Paul Taylor's work and most recently was instrumental in the Lotos Club's honoring of the Dancemaker. We will greatly miss Lee's charm, dashing style, uncommon sense, and sense of humor. Our thoughts are with his beloved family. 1/3

DAVID--Julianne, passed away on May 3 at the age of 63. Beloved wife of the late Rafael David. Loving mother of Liron (Talia), Shachar and Tal. Beloved sister and sister in law of George and Illana Lloyd. Adoring grandmother of Jack and Sam. Cherished aunt and great aunt of Daniella and Aaron Werman, Sarah and Reuben Lloyd, Elazar Lloyd, Saraemma and R.J. 1/3
RUBIN--LeRoy. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and longtime friend, LeRoy Rubin, and send condolences to his family. 1/3

NELDBERG--Robert Dane, 26, passed away on Friday, May 1, 2015. He was born on June 14, 1988. He is survived by loving parents, Lynn and Harvey Ravner and Todd Neldberg, along with many devoted family members. Calling hours will be held between 4:00-8:00pm, on Tuesday, May 5, 2015 at the Frank E. Campbell Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue. 1/3

GILLESPIE--Mary Eliza ("Woozy") Brown, 1921-2015, passed away peacefully at Hospice in Branford, CT, on May 3, 2015, in the presence of her loving children and grandchildren. Born and raised in Pittsburgh, PA, as part of the extended Brown- Howe clan, she spent years during the Depression in Woodland, NY, the Botchford family homestead that remained her favorite family gathering place and trout- fishing haunt. She graduated from Chatham Hall School and was a member of the class of 1942 at Vassar College, leaving in 1941 to marry Gardner Fordyce ("Spider") Gillespie, Jr., as war loomed. She raised her family in Rye, NY, and became an accomplished artist, painting landscapes and children's portraits and continuing her work until her final weeks. She was an active member of the Silvermine Artists Guild and later served on the Killingworth, CT, Wetlands Commission. For the last 15 years, and continuing after the death of her beloved Spider, she lived in Chester, CT. She is survived by her four children (Susan Howe Gillespie, Gardner Fordyce Gillespie, III (and his wife Stevie), Nancy Clift Gillespie de la Selle (and her husband Sebastien) and Douglas Brown Gillespie (and his wife Ellie), nine grandchildren (Jennifer Kapczynski, Nathaniel Gillespie, Amy Kapczynski, Clara Gillespie Ferraro, Elise de la Selle Jones, Evan Gillespie, Violette de la Selle, Jamie Gillespie and Augusta Gillespie), and 10 great grandchildren. The family is planning a memorial celebration of Woozy's life this summer in Woodland. To sign the online guestbook please visit HawleyLincolnMemorial. com. 1/3
ARON--Paul Henry, 72, of Scotch Plains, NJ, computer architect for Citibank, born June 10, 1942, died May 4, 2015. 1/3

MOLLOY--Patrick John died Saturday, May 2, 2015 after a long illness. He is survived by his wife, Maureen, his nephew Naveen Molloy and his nieces Katki Molloy Windsor, Hannah and Hayley Cloke. Patrick was born on December 16, 1941 at Mission Dolores, San Francisco, grew up in southern California and attended Mater Dei High School in Santa Ana. He graduated from University of California at Davis, and University of Chicago. He taught sociology at Queens College, and Montclair State College, New Jersey. He became a financial analyst at Axa Equitable Life Insurance Company in New York and held this position until his retirement in 2007. His passion for books and learning led him to become a volunteer research associate at the Morgan Library and Museum. He contributed historical research and background readings for their exhibitions. His interest in architecture gave him the opportunity to give tours of St. Patrick's Cathedral, New York. The funeral mass is Wednesday, May 6 at Church of the Epiphany, 375 2nd Ave. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the NYU Langone Clinical Cancer Center, 160 E.34th St., New York, NY 10016. 1/3

O'NEILL--Sara Lyons. It is with great sadness that we announce the death of Sara L. O'Neill, 77 years old, on April 28, 2015. She was the daughter of the late Jeremiah P. Lyons and late Isabel Delehanty Lyons. A lifelong resident of Manhattan and Spring Lake, NJ, she graduated from Hunter College Elementary School, Friends Seminary, and Mount Holyoke College, Class of 1959. The beloved wife of Paul J. O'Neill, Jr., to whom she was married for 54 years, she was the mother of Christopher, Bradley, and Hilary, and the grandmother of Brendan, Meghan, Katharine and Emily. During her career, she served as the Director of Finance and Business Operations for several New York area independent schools, including Woodmere Academy, The Hewitt School, and Packer Collegiate Institute. A woman of intelligence, grace and great integrity, she will be dearly missed by all who knew her. Visitation on Saturday, May 9 from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue and 81st Street and Funeral Mass on Monday, May 11 at 10am at St. Jean Baptiste Church, Lexington Avenue and 76th Street, New York City. 1/3

Services today 12 noon at "Gutterman's", 8000 Jericho Tpk., Woodbury, NY. Interment to follow at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. 1/3

BROADDUS--Gloria Moncur, 89, of Irvington, VA died on May 4, 2015. Funeral services will be held at 11am, Thursday, May 7, 2015 at Grace Episcopal Church, Kilmarnock, VA. Interment will follow the service at the Historic Christ Church Burying Ground, Irvington, VA. 1/3

RUBIN--LeRoy. Paul Taylor, his dancers, the administration and the trustees of the Paul Taylor Dance Foundation mourn the passing of LeRoy Rubin. Lee, a valued Board member for more than two decades, was a generous champion of Paul Taylor's work and most recently was instrumental in the Lotos Club's honoring of the Dancemaker. We will greatly miss Lee's charm, dashing style, uncommon sense, and sense of humor. Our thoughts are with his beloved family. 1/3

McGINLEY--Gerald Hayes, a retired senior vice president at UBS, died February 23, 2015, at his home in Hobe Sound, FL. He was 85 years old. McGinley was married for 58 years to the love of his life, Mary Patricia O'Neill of Merion, PA. McGinley's investment career spanned more than 45 years. He began his work at W.R. Grace & Co. as an assistant to the president, and later worked at Crown Cork & Seal Co. He went on to dedicate 35 years of service to Kidder, Peabody & Co. He finished his career at UBS at the age of 80. McGinley was born in Westfield, NJ on October 14, 1929. He graduated in 1948 from Westfield High School, where he was captain of the football and swim teams, and he received his Bachelor of Science in Economics from the University of Pennsylvania (Wharton School) in 1952. While at Penn, McGinley won the prestigious Class of 1915 Award for the ideal Penn athlete and earned All-American honors his senior year. He was drafted by the Philadelphia Eagles in 1952, but instead chose to serve his country during the Korean War, rising to the rank of First Lieutenant in the United States Army. Throughout his adult life, McGinley maintained a commitment to numerous civic, charitable and educational causes. He was a Knight of Malta, overseeing its New Jersey chapter for many years. He served as a trustee of Avon Old Farms School, The New Community Foundation and Camp Tecumseh, and on the Millburn, NJ Board of Education. Additionally, McGinley was on the council for the Pennsylvania Society and was a life member of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick. At Penn, his alma mater, he served on the President's Council and the Athletic Board of Advisors. He also served on the President's Council at the College of the Holy Cross. McGinley is survived by his beloved wife Pat and five children: Pam McGinley Quackenbush (Scott), John C. McGinley (Nichole), Helen E. McGinley, Gerald O. McGinley (Debbie), Mark H. McGinley (Shelley), as well as 12 grandchildren. Also, by his brothers Edward and Richard. A Memorial mass will be celebrated at Saint Rose of Lima in Short Hills, NJ on May 8, 2015 at 11:00am. 1/3
GIBSON--Margie Nehls. Mother of Jacqueline Gazella (Joseph). Grandmother of Mary Christine Giosia (Gabe). Details and guest book at www.andrettfuneral home.com 1/3

GARTEN--Col. Melvin (Ret.), died May 2, 2015, at his home in Lake Oswego, Oregon, at age 93. He was born May 20, 1921 in New York City. After graduating from City College he volunteered as a paratrooper in World War II, launching what would be an illustrious 30-year military career. At the time of his 1968 retirement from the U.S. Army, he was among the most decorated combat veterans of his time, with honors from heroic actions and serious wounds in three wars: WWII, Korea and Vietnam. He was awarded the Distinguished Service Cross, three Silver Stars, four Bronze Stars, five Purple Hearts, the Legion of Merit, two Joint Commendation Medals and two Air Medals. His 70-year marriage to Ruth Engelman, of the Bronx, began before he departed for battle in the Philippines. There he took part in the audacious airborne raid of Los Banos in 1945, rescuing more than 2,000 U.S. and Allied civilians from a Japanese prison camp. Col. Garten's feats of bravery in the Korean War garnered recommendations for the Congressional Medal of Honor. He was gravely wounded in Vietnam, but even after losing a leg he requested and received assignment as post commander at Fort Bragg. Having earned a master's degree in International Relations from George Washington University, he became a professor of history and political science at the University of Tampa in 1970. He and Ruth, who died in 2013, moved to Oregon in 2001 to be near their grandchildren. He is survived by sons Allan (Pam) of Portland, OR, and Jeffrey (Ina) of East Hampton, NY; sister Shirley Maslow of New York City; two granddaughters and two great-granddaughters, all of Portland, OR. Funeral will be Friday, May 8, in Portland. Interment, with full military honors, will be at Arlington National Cemetery. 1/3

He is survived by his wife Loretta, their children Jeffrey and Paula, son-in-law Ira and his grandchildren Allison, Jack, Samantha, and Lindsay. The funeral will be at 10:00am on May 7th at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY. Contributions may be made to The Meeting House, 133 East 58th St., Suite 704, New York, NY 10022. 1/3

GILROY--Tom. It is with great sadness that Hughes Hubbard & Reed LLP notes the passing of retired partner Tom Gilroy on Saturday, May 2 at the age of 88. Tom was born in San Francisco on January 31, 1927 and served in the U.S. Navy as a seaman, first class from 1945 to 1946. He received his undergraduate degree from Princeton University in 1949 and his law degree from Columbia University in 1952. Tom, a highly regarded securities lawyer, spent his entire legal career at Hughes Hubbard and served as chair of the Corporate Department and Opinion Committee. He wrote and lectured widely on securities law issues and trained generations of Hughes Hubbard corporate lawyers during his nearly 50 years with the firm. Besides his preeminence as an attorney, he was known and will be remembered for his kindness and his devotion to the firm and his colleagues. 1/3

ROYCE--Kermit, passed away on May 2. Beloved husband of Billie, devoted father of Nancy, Andrew and Douglas and in laws Kenneth, Loli and Florence. Loving grandfather of Jason, Derek, Sydney and Emma. Funeral Service will be Thursday, May 7 at 12:00pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Mt. Vernon, NY. Interment at Mt. Judah Cemetery in Ridgewood, NY. 1/3

COHN--Maurice J. The staff and trustees of the North Shore-LIJ Health System mourn the loss of Life Trustee Maurice J. (Sonny) Cohn, a long-time benefactor of North Shore-LIJ and North Shore University Hospital (NSUH). Sonny and his wife Marilyn were committed to ensuring that the best emergency care was available to the community. Thanks to their generosity, the Marilyn and Maurice Cohn Trauma Center at NSUH provides the highest level of quality care to patients. Sonny's friendship, philanthropic support and dedication to the health system helped North Shore-LIJ become a regional and national leader in healthcare. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Marilyn, daughters Karen Cohn and Marcia Cohn, brother Milton (Bud), grandchildren Sarah, Hannah, and Aaron Rosenbaum, and the rest of the family. The funeral will be at 1pm on Thursday, May 7, 2015, at Riverside Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Shiva will be observed at the Cohn's home, 54 Elderfields Road, Manhasset, NY, on Friday, May 8, from 1-6pm and Sunday, May 10, from 1-6pm. Mark L. Claster, Chairman, Board of Trustees, North Shore-LIJ Health System Michael J. Dowling, President and CEO, North Shore-LIJ Health System 1/3

IRWIN--Frances. The Board of Trustees, professional staff and students of Tanger Hillel at Brooklyn College note with sadness the passing of Frances Irwin. A cherished friend and supporter, she survived hell at Auschwitz and came to America to make a new life. She had an impact on us all, through good deeds, charity and her dedication to warn of the dangers of intolerance. A little woman, she left a big legacy, her memory will endure. We extend condolences to her adored son, Martin; her grandson and the entire family. We love her and will miss her. 1/3

KOLMAR--Klaus W.,of Sea Cliff, NY on May 4, 2015. A long-time concert and theatrical agent. HALL--Alan. Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center mourns with great sorrow the untimely death of our esteemed colleague Alan Hall, Chair of the Sloan Kettering Institute's Cell Biology Program. A brilliant and gifted scientist, Dr. Hall joined MSK in 2004 to lead that program. During an extraordinary career, he made fundamental contributions to our understanding of how the cellular cytoskeleton is organized and regulated. His work has important implications for how tumor cells become metastatic and spread. He received several prestigious international awards including the Novartis Medal and the Gairdner International Award, and was a Fellow of the Royal Society. But it was in his daily life at MSK that Dr. Hall shined the brightest. He was a devoted teacher and mentor, a generous and good-humored colleague, and a remarkable human being. He will be deeply missed, but his scientific contributions, the work of the cadre of young scientists he trained, and his friendship to all will remain an enduring legacy. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Eileen, his children, and his entire family. Craig B. Thompson, MD President and CEO Joan Massague, PhD Director, Sloan Kettering Institute 1/3

COHN--Maurice J. The Atlantic Golf Club mourns the loss of fellow member, Maurice J. "Sonny" Cohn. STAMLER--David M. We mourn the passing of David Stamler, who died peacefully at his home in Stamford, CT, on Monday, May 4, 2015. He was a loving father and grandfather, and will be deeply missed. He is survived by his wife Loretta, their children Jeffrey and Paula, son-in-law Ira and his grandchildren Allison, Jack, Samantha, and Lindsay. The funeral will be at 10:00am on May 7th at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY. Contributions may be made to The Meeting House, 133 East 58th St., Suite 704, New York, NY 10022. 1/3

Des ROCHES--John (age 40). Award winning film maker, producer, photographer, family man died on April 18th, after a short battle with Metastatic Colon Cancer. Mr Des Roches leaves behind his three young children, Ezra (4) Kefirah (6) Anais (8), and a host of family and friends who remained unfalteringly by his side until the end. Memorial service will be held at 1:00pm on Saturday May 9th at The Bell House 149 7th St, Brooklyn, NY 11215. Donations can be made at Youcaring.com by searching "John DesRoches". 1/3
BLACK--Frederick Michael "RICKEY" June 27, 1951 - May 7, 2013 Missing the light and love of our lives. Remembering him today and everyday. 1/3

LESLIE--F. Andrew. The Board of Directors and Staff of Dramatists Play Service mourn the passing of its past President F. Andrew Leslie in Edgartown, MA on April 29, 2015. Mr. Leslie led the Play Service for almost 30 years, until his retirement in 1990. He was a playwright as well; his adaptations of classic works of literature continue to be produced. We salute his contribution to the American theatre and value his leadership at DPS. Peter Hagan, President 1

COHN--Maurice J. of Manhasset, NY. March 28, 1931- May 4, 2015, beloved husband of Marilyn, father of Marcia and Karen, brother of Jeanette and Milton, grandfather of Sarah, Hannah, and Aaron, devoted friend to many, a man with an enormous heart and love for life, and happiest when surrounded by family, friends and Lola. 1/3

NICHOLSON--Lewis Edward, Ph. D.,93, of South Bend, IN and the University of Notre Dame died Tuesday, April 28th. He was a well-known professor of medieval and Anglo-Saxon studies at the University. 1/3

O'NEILL--Sara Lyons. It is with great sadness that we announce the death of Sara L. O'Neill, 77 years old, on April 28, 2015. She was the daughter of the late Jeremiah P. Lyons and late Isabel Delehanty Lyons. A lifelong resident of Manhattan and Spring Lake, NJ, she graduated from Hunter College Elementary School, Friends Seminary, and Mount Holyoke College, Class of 1959. The beloved wife of Paul J. O'Neill, Jr., to whom she was married for 54 years, she was the mother of Christopher, Bradley, and Hilary, and the grandmother of Brendan, Meghan, Katharine and Emily. During her career, she served as the Director of Finance and Business Operations for several New York area independent schools, including Woodmere Academy, The Hewitt School, and Packer Collegiate Institute. A woman of intelligence, grace and great integrity, she will be dearly missed by all who knew her. Visitation on Saturday, May 9 from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue and 81st Street and Funeral Mass on Monday, May 11 at 10am at St. Jean Baptiste Church, Lexington Avenue and 76th Street, New York City. 1/3

WINTER--Marvin S. We remember you each day with love. Your Family 1/3

SCHWARZ--Harry. The Principal and Staff of Steven E. Bachmann & Co CPAs have lost a dear friend and valued long time client. EDELSON--Jane Levin. On Tuesday, May 5, 2015, Jane Levin Edelson, watercolorist, art historian, editor, jewelry maker, dance notator, crossword expert, pianist, and master of language and listening, died peacefully at home, surrounded by her devoted husband of 62 years, Gilbert, and her three loving daughters, Martha, Paula, and Daisy. She lived 84 joyous years, and as we mourn her death, we just as ardently celebrate her life. 1/3
BIER--Bernard H, Esq. You are the sun on my face and the wind at my back. Loved forever, Your Family 1/3

HALL--Alan. We mourn the passing of our esteemed Chairman of Cell Biology, a brilliant scientist whose kindness and intellect was admired and respected by all. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. The Cell Biology Program Faculty, Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center 1/3

DUNHAM--Edward Wood (Jack). Wiggin and Dana LLP mourns the passing of Jack Dunham, former Chair of its Executive Committee, at the age of 61. Mr. Dunham was a nationally recognized trial lawyer for over thirty years. He served as Chair of the American Bar Association Forum on Franchising from 2007 to 2009, and he was a Fellow of the American College of Trial Lawyers. Before joining Wiggin and Dana in 1979, Mr. Dunham was a law clerk to the Honorable Robert A. Ainsworth, Jr., of the U.S. Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit. He was a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Trinity College and received his J.D. from the NYU School of Law. We extend our deepest sympathies to Betsey, Nick, Hayden, John and Eliza. 1/3

EDELSON--Jane Levin. The members of the Art Dealers Association of America mourn the passing of Jane L. Edelson, wife of Gilbert S. Edelson, former Vice President and Counsel Emeritus of the ADAA. Our sympathy and condolences go out to her husband and three daughters, Martha, Polly and Daisy. The family will be receiving at a time and place to be announced. Dorsey Waxter, President Linda Blumberg, Executive Director 1/3

GILROY--Tom. It is with great sadness that Hughes Hubbard & Reed LLP notes the passing of retired partner Tom Gilroy on Saturday, May 2 at the age of 88. Tom was born in San Francisco on January 31, 1927 and served in the U.S. Navy as a seaman, first class from 1945 to 1946. He received his undergraduate degree from Princeton University in 1949 and his law degree from Columbia University in 1952. Tom, a highly regarded securities lawyer, spent his entire legal career at Hughes Hubbard and served as chair of the Corporate Department and Opinion Committee. He wrote and lectured widely on securities law issues and trained generations of Hughes Hubbard corporate lawyers during his nearly 50 years with the firm. Besides his preeminence as an attorney, he was known and will be remembered for his kindness and his devotion to the firm and his colleagues. 1/3

FINN--Philip Pearce Jr.,resident of New York, NY from 1968-1999, passed away peacefully in the comfort of his home on May 4, 2015 in Aiken, SC. View the full obituary at www.georgefuneral homes.com. 1/3

He is remembered as a beloved father to Bruce and Cheryl, Alicia and Ira, Madelyn and Rick, and Eve and Greg. Devoted grandfather to Nicole, Alex, Liz, Rebecca, Sam, Marissa, Jennifer, Jake and Emily and great-grandfather to Charlie and Parker. Forever in our hearts. 1/3

DUNHAM--Edward Wood (Jack). Wiggin and Dana LLP mourns the passing of Jack Dunham, former Chair of its Executive Committee, at the age of 61. Mr. Dunham was a nationally recognized trial lawyer for over thirty years. He served as Chair of the American Bar Association Forum on Franchising from 2007 to 2009, and he was a Fellow of the American College of Trial Lawyers. Before joining Wiggin and Dana in 1979, Mr. Dunham was a law clerk to the Honorable Robert A. Ainsworth, Jr., of the U.S. Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit. He was a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Trinity College and received his J.D. from the NYU School of Law. We extend our deepest sympathies to Betsey, Nick, Hayden, John and Eliza. 1/3

SAMITT--Mark D.,52, beloved family man, devoted friend and successful business professional, of Woodcliff Lake, NJ, died on May 6, 2015 after a long and valiant fight with cancer. Mark graduated from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, and received his MBA from Harvard Business School. He served as a management consultant with Deloitte & Touche, Chief Operating Officer of North American and Global Supply Chain at Movado Group, and then as COO and president of Steuben Glass. He then created his own consulting firm, RD Management Group. Mark inspired and supported others through his determination, thoughtfulness and generosity of spirit. In the midst of his battle with melanoma, Mark created "Mark the SPOT!," a partnership with the Melanoma Research Foundation aimed at creating awareness among the hair stylist community about spotting unusual moles or lesions during the routine styling process. Mark is survived by his loving wife Gayle, daughters Rachel and Danielle, parents Bruce and Florence Samitt, brother Craig Samitt (Steven Hart), sister Alison Samitt (Anthony Calcagni), in-laws Robert and Barbara Allen, and many loving family members and friends. For those wishing to honor Mark, the family suggests donations be made to the Melanoma Research Foundation at www. melanoma.org/ MarktheSPOT 1/3

FROST--Louis. The attorneys and staff of Davidson, Dawson and Clark mourn the passing of their respected, admired and beloved leader, Louis B. Frost, on May 6, 2015. Those he left behind at the firm are saddened by his untimely death but grateful to be the beneficiaries of Lou's stewardship of the firm's fabric and practice for so many years. We extend our deepest condolences to Anne, Val, Jen, Dave and the rest of his family. 1/3

FROST--Louis Bentley, Managing Partner of Davidson, Dawson & Clark, former Mayor of Pelham Manor and former President of the Pelham Country Club, died on Wednesday in New York City. He was 74 years old. Beloved husband of Anne DuVal Frost, father of Louis DuVal Frost, Jennifer Frost Garrow and David Bentley Frost, and grandfather of William, Charlotte, Anna, Connor and Patrick. Louis excelled professionally, but always put his family and friends first. He touched everyone he met with his warm smile and his love of life. Visitation 3-5pm and 7-9pm Monday and Tuesday, May 11 and 12 at Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Ave., Pelham, NY. Funeral 10:30 am Wednesday, May 13 at Huguenot Memorial Church, 901 Pelhamdale Ave. Pelham Manor, NY. 1/3

FROST--Louis. The attorneys and staff of Davidson, Dawson and Clark mourn the passing of their respected, admired and beloved leader, Louis B. Frost, on May 6, 2015. Since joining the firm in 1966, Lou brought zeal and joy to advising and advocating for his clients and to leading the firm to a preeminent position in the trusts and estates legal community. Those he left behind at the firm are saddened by his untimely death but grateful to be the beneficiaries of Lou's stewardship of the firm's fabric and practice for so many years. We extend our deepest condolences to Anne, Val, Jen, Dave and the rest of his family. 1/3

YOUNG--Alexander K. 86, passed away peacefully on May 6, 2015, in New Paltz, NY. Previously Faculty Associate on Modern Japan at Columbia University, he was Professor of International Relations at SUNY New Paltz. He authored several books and articles regarding trade relations between the US., Japan and Taiwan and received a medal of honor from the Government of Japan for his work on trade relations. In 1982, his book, "The Sogo Shosha: Japan's Multinational Trading Companies" was a catalyst in federal legislation, "The U.S. Export Trading Companies Act of 1982", signed into law by President Ronald Reagan. In addition to being a Strategic & International Studies Fellow at the Taiwan Research Institute, he was consulted upon and appointed National Policy Advisor to then President Lee of Taiwan and co-chaired with former U.S. Congressman Benjamin Gilman, a conference on "U.S. Asian Policy in the Second Bush Administration" in New York in 2005. In addition to his wife, Setsuko, he is survived by daughter, Sophia, two sons, Alexander T. and Eric, and two grandsons, Patrick and Eric. Funeral services will be held Sunday, May 10, 2015 at 2:30pm at Trinity Covenant Church, 343 East Cedar Street, Livingston, NJ 07039. Services are under the direction of Copeland Funeral Home, Inc., 162 South Putt Corners Road, New Paltz, NY 12561. Condolences may be made to the family at: www.copelandfhnp.com 1/3

McINTOSH--Michael. The Board and Staff of NRDC mourn the loss of our treasured friend and founding trustee, Michael McIntosh. Michael was instrumental in building NRDC and its mission. His fighting spirit embodied the heart and soul of the institution. He was a champion of justice, a protector of people, and a defender of our last great landscapes, including his cherished Alaskan wilderness. We will forever remain honored to be a part of his remarkable legacy. Our deepest sympathies go out to his beloved wife Winsome, his sons and grandchildren and everyone who had the privilege to call him a friend. Daniel R. Tishman, Chairman, Rhea Suh, President, John H. Adams, Founding Director, Frances Beinecke, former President 1/3

MORSE--Shirley, 86, of New York NY, passed away peacefully on May 5, 2015 after a brave struggle with cancer. Loving mother of Clifford Morse (Karen) and Lisa Morse (Ric Roy), grandmother and great-grandmother. Former President of the National Council of Jewish Women, Forest Hills Section for many years, she was devoted to her family and was the consummate New Yorker. She loved new adventures and traveled the world. An eternal optimist, her motto was "think sunny thoughts." We will miss her. 1/3
COLBIN--Annemarie passed away in Denver surrounded by family. Memorial at SVA Theatre, 333 W 23rd, on May 25 at 4pm. With love, her daughters, Shana and Kaila

HIRSH--Richard Lawrence. July 25, 1941--April 24, 2015. Richard Lawrence Hirsh passed away on April 24, 2015 at age 73. His two grandchildren, Callie and Lyla Hirsh, will fondly remember him as the crazy grandfather who would always visit with weird presents when returning from China, where he lived for most of their lives. He will be deeply missed by his wife, Wan Qing, his son, daughter and daughter-in-law, Denton, Julia and Kristi Hirsh, as well as his brother, Gerry Hirsh. He will be remembered as someone who marched to the beat of his own drum right until his very last day. To write a condolence for the family please visit www.mckenziefuneral services.com 1/3

SENATOR--Miriam Brickman, 81, died April 30 just after midnight alongside her husband Ronald, in a house fire. Born in Gt. Barrington, MA, raised in Albany, NY, graduate of Queens College and Juilliard. She was a brilliant, worldwide concert pianist who loved people, poetry, languages, and performing everywhere from concert halls to prisons. Her vibrant soul and festive music gatherings will be sorely missed. Miriam is survived by brother, Arthur (Carol) of Raleigh, NC, nieces and nephews. 1/3

SENATOR--Ronald, 89, died April 29 just before midnight alongside his wife, Miriam, in a house fire. Born in London, England, he was an eminent and prolific composer, publisher, educator, and author. Graduate of Oxford and University of London, and was Professor of Composition at the Guildhall School of Music. His operas, musicals, and chamber works were performed worldwide. His oratorio Holocaust Requiem, also known as Kaddish for Terezin, commemorates first wife Dita Branicky, an Auschwitz survivor, and the children of Terezin concentration camp. Ronald is survived by nieces and nephews. 1/3

GERTLER--Menard M.,physician, researcher, and professor of cardiology died on 6 May 2015 at the age of 95 years old. He was two weeks and one day short of his 96th birthday. Dr. Gertler had a distinguished career in medicine that spanned seven decades and which put him at the forefront of medical discovery and education. While a student at the Faculty of Medicine at McGill University in the 1940s, Menard Gertler worked with two legendary doctors, Wilder Penfield and Francis McNaughton, with whom he assisted in the construction of a plastic model of the human brain. During a second period of study at McGill, Dr. Gertler joined pioneering surgeon, Arthur Vineberg, to develop a major technique of heart surgery that is still used today. In the 1950s, Dr. Gertler worked with Paul Dudley White at Harvard and Massachusetts General Hospital, a collaboration which resulted in the publication of the monograph, Coronary Heart Disease in Young Adults: A Multi-Disciplinary Study, which was cited in the early 2000's by the New England Journal of Medicine as one of the landmark publications in the field of cardiology of the past fifty years. Inspired by the work of Nobel-Prize winning biochemist Severo Ochoa also during the 1950s, Dr. Gertler went on to do his own research on congestive heart failure which led to the introduction of the drug Inocor as a treatment. Dr. Gertler and Dr. White collaborated on yet another book on cardiology which was followed by Gertler's book entitled You Can Predict Your Heart Attack and Prevent It, published by Random House in 1961. While Dr. White wrote the forward, Dr. Gertler credited his wife, Anna Paull Gertler, for translating the entire manuscript from medical into lay terms for the general public. In addition, Dr. Gertler wrote articles in many medical publications and lectured in more than fifteen countries. Considered one of the giants in his field, he has taught medicine at McGill, Harvard, NYU, Columbia and Cornell Universities. When Dr. Gertler retired from Weill Cornell, the college bestowed on him the title of Professor Emeritus. Born in Saskatoon, Saskatchuwan, the oldest of five children, he finished his undergraduate work at the University of Saskatchuwan before entering McGill Medical School. He met his wife, Anna Paull Gertler, in Montreal while acting as the resident doctor in an ambulance. When his future mother-in-law fell in the snowy streets of Montreal and broke her leg, he met his wife. Together they had three children during a marriage that lasted for sixty-five years until his wife's death in 2009. Dr. Gertler is survived by his daughter, Barbara Victor, her husband, Edward Lebar, and a son, Jonathan Paull Gertler. Another daughter, Stephanie Gertler Schiffer died in 2015. Also surviving are seven grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren. A memorial will be held at Weill Cornell Medical College toward the end of May followed by a reception at the Griffiths Faculty Club. Information about the Memorial will be announced by e-mail throughout the Medical College and through his daughter, Barbara Victor. Instead of flowers, donations in memory of Dr. Menard Gertler may be designated to Weill Cornell College for the Hajjar Laboratory, %Weill Cornell Medical College, Office of External Affairs, 1300 York Avenue, Box 314, New York, New York 10065. 1/3
DUFFY--Francis X.,Jr., Buzz, 65, passed May 1, 2015 at his beloved home in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan.
BLACK--Frederick Michael "RICKEY" June 27, 1951 - May 7, 2013 Missing the light and love of our lives. Remembering him today and everyday. 1/3

MARCUS--Aaron Jacob. A loving husband and father, an impassioned scientific mind and mentor, Dr. Aaron J. Marcus died peacefully in his sleep on May 6. He spent his entire professional career pursuing the secrets of blood. This was a long pursuit, which began with the publication of his first paper in 1958 and was still going on just a few weeks ago. Despite his pure passion for science, he was no less enamored of the opera, Thomas Mann, fountain pens, fine leather shoes, audio equipment, photography, the Beatles, chocolate, and the Chrysler Building. There was always an omnivorous, endearingly daffy curiosity in play, and an eagerness to share his enthusiasms. He was born in Brooklyn in 1925 and educated at the University of Virginia and New York Medical College. He spent more than fifty years at the Veterans Administration Harbor Healthcare System, dedicating himself to experimentation in a narrow, instrument-crammed lab. One colleague called the place "his secret garden of science"--and the harvest went on for decades, abetted by a productive association with Weill Cornell Medical College, where he was a Professor of Medicine. He was the kindest, funniest, and quirkiest of human beings, and will be missed forever by those who loved him. He is survived by his wife, Deana; his sister, Evelyn; his children, Lisa, James, and Douglas, and their spouses, Lee and Nina; his grandchildren, Nathaniel, Chiara, Shanti, Jamila, and Ishai; and the very wide circle of people whose lives he touched.

FROST--Louis Bentley, Managing Partner of Davidson, Dawson & Clark, former Mayor of Pelham Manor and former President of the Pelham Country Club, died on Wednesday in New York City. He was 74 years old. Beloved husband of Anne DuVal Frost, father of Louis DuVal Frost, Jennifer Frost Garrow and David Bentley Frost, and grandfather of William, Charlotte, Anna, Connor and Patrick. Louis excelled professionally, but always put his family and friends first. He touched everyone he met with his warm smile and his love of life. Visitation 3-5pm and 7-9pm Monday and Tuesday, May 11 and 12 at Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Ave., Pelham, NY. Funeral 10:30 am Wednesday, May 13 at Huguenot Memorial Church, 901 Pelhamdale Ave. Pelham Manor, NY. 1/3

WEG--John G.,M.D. (Jack) died May 3, 2015, surrounded by his wife of 60 years, Mary Loretta Flynn, his six daughters, their spouses, his 12 grandchildren and his brother. He was Chief of Pulmonary and Critical Care Medicine at the University of Michigan. Among his many accomplishments, he was President of the American College of Chest Physicians and received its Master Fellow Award. He lives on in our hearts. 1/3

KOUSI--John D.,long time resident of New York City died on April 4 in Malibu, CA. from complications of quadriplegia. John was born in Bay Shore long Island on January 21, 1934. He graduated from Yale University and New York University Law school and began his career practicing corporate law at Lovejoy Wasson Lundrgren and Ashton in New York City. He served as President of Fairfield International, a ship- owning firm, for 14 years. In 1987 he was one of the founding shareholders of Eastwind Maritime, an international shipping firm that came to own and operate dry bulk carriers, refrigerated ships, oil tankers, and container- ships. Following his retirement he remained involved for the rest of his life with private investments in international shipping. He will be so missed by his wife Elizabeth Easter Kousi, his wife of 50 years and their daughters, Christina Kousi Dobbs of London, England and Katherine Kousi of Malibu, CA. and his six grandsons - Conway Dobbs, Sinclair Dobbs, Ossian Dobbs, Aidan Flanigan, Truman Flanigan and Fergus Flanigan. 1/3

LERNER--Norman, of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Great Neck, NY, died on May 3, 2015. A most generous spirited man. He was a gentleman of the old school and "his like shall not pass this way again". Respected by all who knew him personally and in business, he was a student of history and a mentor to many. He leaves his loving and dearly loved wife Inez (nee Yondorf). He was a caring, devoted, and generous father to Holly (and the late Hans- Geert), Bambi (Michael) and John (Amy). He was proud of his grandchildren Benjamin, Garrett, Reid, Rachael, and Billy. He will be missed by many, most of all his grieving family. Contributions in his name my be sent to Boca Raton Regional Hospital or Hospice By The Sea in Boca Raton. 1/3

BRECKON--Claire Ann May, Teacher and the wife of Foreign Service Officer M. Lyall Breckon, died on December 7, 2014, at home in Maryland at the age of 77. A native of Alameda, CA, Claire attended Seattle University and earned her BA in education from Lewis and Clark University. She and Lyall married in 1961. Claire joined Lyall in representing America on diplomatic posts to Saigon, Bangkok, Madras, Kuala Lumpur, Vienna, and Geneva. A teacher and principal, who loved her vocation so much she would say, "I can't believe they pay me," Claire taught at the American School Saigon, and Maryland and Virginia public schools. In Thailand, she was a private tutor to Princess Ubolratana, where she successfully prepared her for study at MIT. After leaving Foreign Service life, Claire volunteered in the Office of the First Lady for Hillary Clinton and continued her service when Mrs. Clinton held her Senate seat. Claire had a contagious enthusiasm for learning from all of the cultures and people she encountered. Her adventures included Malaysian jungle hikes and strolls in the Vienna Woods, and stormy boat rides in the Indian Ocean and the North Sea. Local food markets and textile shops were equally thrilling and rewarding. In India, she studied with Krishnamacharya, the authoritative yoga instructor; she practiced and taught yoga throughout her life. Claire was an accomplished pianist who greatly enjoyed music, art and fashion. She loved reading and she was a published children's author. Claire's most cherished moments were with her husband, children, grandchildren, and her extended family and friends. Claire's natural curiosity led her to take sincere and consistent interest in the lives of those around her. Her boundless love, grace, optimism, and generosity brought light and inspiration to the lives of those fortunate enough to meet her. Donations may be sent to So Others Might Eat and Caring for Cambodia.

SCHMAIS--Claire, on May 7, 2015. Beloved wife of the late Aaron, devoted mother of Beth, Michael, and Libby. Dance therapy pioneer, beloved teacher and mentor. Services Monday 11:15am at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. 1/3

FROST--Louis. The attorneys and staff of Davidson, Dawson and Clark mourn the passing of their respected, admired and beloved leader, Louis B. Frost, on May 6, 2015. Those he left behind at the firm are saddened by his untimely death but grateful to be the beneficiaries of Lou's stewardship of the firm's fabric and practice for so many years. We extend our deepest condolences to Anne, Val, Jen, Dave and the rest of his family. 1/3

MORSE--Shirley, 86, of New York NY, passed away peacefully on May 5, 2015 after a brave struggle with cancer. Loving mother of Clifford Morse (Karen) and Lisa Morse (Ric Roy), grandmother and great-grandmother. Former President of the National Council of Jewish Women, Forest Hills Section for many years, she was devoted to her family and was the consummate New Yorker. She loved new adventures and traveled the world. An eternal optimist, her motto was "think sunny thoughts." We will miss her. 1/3

SACHS--Rose. Businesswoman, style ma- ven, mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, widow, friend and long-time resident of Palm Beach and New York City--died on April 28, 2015, at the age of 103. Over all the years of her life, she kept her eyes on the future. When she died, her calendar was full of upcoming dates she'd made with friends. In recent years, a fashion photographer discovered Rose walking down Madison Ave. He called her "the best dressed 99 year old on the Upper East Side." Rose leaves her son, Ira, eight grandchildren, and six great-grandchildren. The family asks that anyone wishing to honor Rose make a donation to the Rose Sachs Memorial Fund, Kravis Center for the Performing Arts, 701 Okeechobee Blvd., West Palm Beach, FL 33401. The fund will provide underserved and needy audiences access to Kravis Center programs. 1/3

BERMAN--Lynda, passed away May 7, 2015, from Pulmonary Fibrosis. She was wife to Barry, mother to Matthew and David, grandmother to Andrew. She came to New York from London to open, as lead stylist, Vidal Sassoon's first United States salon and resided in Great Neck for 43 years. She owned both Four Seasons Gifts and the Culinary Connection. Funeral will be held Monday, May 11, 9:30am, at Riverside Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York. 1/3

SILVERMAN--Ruth, noted photographer, curator, and author, died at home in Berkeley, California, on April 10 at age 78. Though her lifetime accomplishments are innumerable, she is best remembered for her groundbreaking work at the International Center of Photography in New York in the 1970s and 80s where she curated more than 100 exhibitions, as well as for her award winning book "The Dog Observed" among many others, and as a fine art dealer in San Francisco where she introduced many important Asian photographers to American audiences. A lifelong friend to dogs, she spent her final months producing a photo-based auction of museum quality work to benefit the San Francisco SPCA and the Humane Society of the U.S. Ruth had an abundance of wit, charm, warmth and a deep intelligence which drew friends from all walks of life. She is an irreplaceable treasure. Friends are invited to gather for a memorial on August 30 in California. Donations can be made to the San Francisco SPCA. 1/3

AGRISS--Irene, 83, of Livingston New Jersey, died, Friday, May 8, 2015. Ms. Agriss was born August 1, 1931, in Orange, NJ, to Mary and Michael Corvino. She was one of three children. Irene was a be-loved mother and grandmother. She is survived by her daughter, Marcy, her son-in-law Michael and her grandson, Andrew. Her son Howard, daughter-in-law Anna and grandson Jesse. She is also survived by her brother Tom (Sonny) Corvino and his wife Ellen. Irene was a law librarian from 1985 to 2008, for the law firm, Brach Eicler, in Roseland, NJ. Prior to that, she was a quality controller for New York Bakeries in Cleveland Ohio. She was preceded in death by her husband Alvin, her mother, Mary, her father Michael, and her brother Horace. Funeral services will be held, Monday, May 11, 2015 at 11:00am at the: Bernheim-Aptner-Kreitzman Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, New Jersey. 1/3

COHEN--Arlana. It is with great sadness that Cowan, Liebowitz & Latman P.C., its attorneys and staff, mourn the untimely death of our esteemed colleague, partner and friend, Arlana S. Cohen on May 7th at the age of 57. Arlana was a skillful and uncompromising advocate for her clients in complex intellectual property matters. Arlana was highly regarded as an expert in trademark and trademark counterfeiting law and had been named many times as a leading attorney in the field by such publications as the New York Super Lawyers in Intellectual Property Law, the WTR 1000 World Leading Trademark Professionals and the Legal 500. Arlana's practice focused on all aspects of domestic and international trademark law including branding, product development, licensing, anti-counterfeiting and litigation in courts throughout the United States. Arlana received her undergraduate degree cum laude from the State University of New York at Buffalo in 1978 and her law degree from the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law in 1981. Besides her preeminence as an attorney, Arlana will be remembered for her devotion to the firm and her colleagues. We will miss her very much. Arlana was a long-time resident of Pelham Manor, New York and is survived by her daughter Natali Wind. Our thoughts are with Natali and her family and friends. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel at 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue on Monday, May 11th, at 10am. In lieu of flowers, please make a gift to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Att: Carol Blumenfeld, 633 Third Ave., New York, NY 10017. 1/3

She is missed. 1/3

McINTOSH--Michael. The Board and Staff of NRDC mourn the loss of our treasured friend and founding trustee, Michael McIntosh. Michael was instrumental in building NRDC and its mission. MYARA--Daniele. Aged 75, died in Manhattan on January 27, 2015. The beloved husband of Kay Lee Shadley, Esquire for over 23 years, he was a talented writer, photographer, painter, and author of "Casablanca Without Bogart" - an autobiographical novel. Born in Casablanca, Daniele lived in Paris, France; Spain; and Israel; ultimately settling in Manhattan in 1980. He spoke five languages, in addition to a strong proficiency in Latin. Daniele was a powerful intellect; a worldly, renaissance person, full of "joie de vivre" with an unforgettable smile and sense of humor. His friends remember him as strong, optimistic, charismatic, thoroughly charming and handsome. Daniele was intensely creative and had a love for art, music, reading, film, fashion, food, wine, and orchids. His career in fashion spanned from Malaga to Manhattan. His passion for animals was unparalleled, as was his kindness and tenderness. Above all, his love and devotion to his father, Juda Myara, was extraordinary. Daniele is survived by his adoring wife Kay Shadley and dear cousin, Bruce Elbilia. Daniele's life will be celebrated in a memorial service on May 16, 2015 at The Grolier Club. In Daniele's memory, a donation to the America-Israel Cultural Foundation to support young Israeli artists would be appreciated. www.aicf.org/donate. 1/3
