LUCAS--Dr. Gerald Morton, Victory Day 1945 was a meaningful day for Dr. Gerald Morton Lucas, 90 (April 9,1925 - May 8, 2015) both then and now. Back then, French nurses kissed him as a War Hero for which he obtained a Purple Heart. This year, it was the day he passed, surrounded by his kids and grandkids, and accompanied by a photo of Marie. Son of Rose and Sam, he lived with and loved Marie Heaney for over 54 years. His kids Leslie, Wendy and Tyler survive him. Dr. Lucas was educated at the Townsend Harris High School. He graduated at age 15, spent two years at City College and volunteered to serve in the Army. Gerry studied Physics and Philosophy, receiving a PhD from Columbia University. He went on to Post Graduate study at NYU's Clinical Psychology program, where he met Marie. They married in 1959. He embarked on his true passion as a clinical psychoanalyst and practiced until he was 88. Gerald is credited with developing "Psycho--Karate" to help patients defend against verbal bullies. He founded the Institute for Modern Psychoanalysis. He credited all of his successes in life to his wife, his biggest and best supporter. 1/3

McCARREN--J. Reilly. The Directors and employees of the Arkansas & Missouri Railroad mourn the loss of their distinguished Chairman, Chief Executive Officer, close colleague and friend, J. Reilly McCarren. Reilly passed away April 26 at the age of 58. He was an accomplished railroader and dedicated leader who spent his entire professional career in our industry. A graduate of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology with a Bachelor of Science degree and a Master of Science degree in civil engineering, Reilly began his railroad career with Conrail in 1978. He advanced to President of the Gateway Western Railway, and later President and CEO of Wisconsin Central Ltd.'s North American operations. In 2002, he acquired the majority interest in the A&M and its affiliated company, Allied Enterprises, Inc. He worked tirelessly over the last 13 years to bring these companies to the first rank of the regional railroad industry. These accomplishments have been recognized through a series of national awards. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Caren, their children, Christopher and Kathleen, Reilly's mother, Judith, and his brothers, Gerard and Mark. We have lost an esteemed colleague who always demonstrated deep love for our industry and our company, with its commitment to Northwest Arkansas. 1

LEWIS--Margaret (M.E.H. Lewis), award-winning playwright and author, died on March 21 in Bradenton, Florida. She was 50. Lewis produced plays in Chicago and in the national theater scene. Her first staged play, Charms for Protection, won the Julie Harris Award, the first of numerous honors Lewis would receive in her career. Since then, Lewis created more than a dozen works that garnered critical acclaim and earned her grants from the Illinois Arts Council, residencies at the Ragdale Foundation, and a Tremain Grant. Her first production in Chicago, Stage Left's production of Burying the Bones, was nominated for three Joseph Jefferson awards, including Best New Work. Burying the Bones is perhaps Lewis's best-known work. It has been staged across the country, most recently finishing successful and sold-out runs in both Buffalo and Detroit. Lewis's work addressed issues of social justice and reflected on the ways the past haunts and informs the present. Burying the Bones deals with the ramifications of apartheid and a woman's personal journey to find her presumed-dead husband. 2010's Here Where It's Safe tells the story of an Indian woman carrying a child for a barren American couple. Fellow Travelers, which won the Jeff Award for Best New Work in 2006, centers around the friendship between two young artists in 1930s Berlin. In each of these works, Lewis humanized events that were distant from her own life and helped localize global and historic struggles. Lewis's work was seen at theaters in New York, Los Angeles, Melbourne, Detroit, Milwaukee, and Stockholm, but her heart and soul were given to the Chicago theater community. In addition to writing, Lewis devoted her life to education. She taught young playwrights in schools across Chicago, working most recently with Chicago Dramatists. She also believed passionately in helping out others in the theater world and was a member of both the Dramatists Guild and the Women's Theatre Alliance. Her final script, 180 Degree Rule, co-authored with Barbara Lhota, will be produced in Chicago by Babes with Blades in the spring of 2016. Lewis was preceded in death by her mother, Rosemarie Lewis, and her brother, Tom Lewis. She is survived by her father, John Lewis, her nephew, Marcus Lewis, her niece, Jaina Shaw, and dozens of beloved and close friends throughout the world. An open house memorial service will be held for her on Sunday, May 17 from 6:30pm-10:00pm at the Chicago Dramatists located at 1105 W. Chicago Avenue, Chicago, Illinois 60642 (also visit their website at www.chicago dramatists.org) The family requested donations be made in Lewis's name to Doctors Without Borders, Heifer International, or the M.E.H. Lewis Memorial Fund in lieu of flowers. The M.E.H. Lewis Memorial Fund will award monetary grants to living playwrights seeking financial assistance. Executors of the Memorial Fund will select playwrights who embody the integrity, truth and compassion of the fund's namesake, M.E.H. Lewis. Donations to the memorial fund should be payable to Chicago Dramatists-- please mark in the memo line: M.E.H. Lewis Memorial Fund and sent in care of Chicago Dramatists- 1105 W. Chicago Avenue, Chicago, Illinois 60642. 1/3

WHITNEY--C. Searle. Born November 14,1944 - died March 27, 2015 to parents Cornelius V. Whitney and Eleanor Searle Whitney McCollum. Searle grew up in his tender years in Old Westbury, New York. His most joyous times were the years in the different seasons in the Adirondacks. It brought him, at an early age in touch with nature. It became a part of him for his 70 years of life. He gave back this Joy. He graduated from Choate, Yale PhD and then to Harvard where He was chosen to work on a unique program, which was quite a secret in Computer Psychology. We, today are exposed to that unusual work in a current film "The Immitation Game". Leaving Harvard, changed the course of his life. He went West landing in Berkeley, California with the Adirondack soil still alive in him and under his thumb nails, he began to create beautiful untraditional gardens. Another passion was music. Chopin in the early years. He married Sarah Cross in the late 80's and had a son Harry C. Whitney. The marriage was short lived, but Searle passed both his passion for music and the great outdoors to Harry. Searle Whitney was an economist, psychologist and a philanthropist. He was very concerned about the effects of a growing human population on our communities and the environment. In 2006 he started the Institute for the Population Studies to raise awareness for population growth. According to Searle and what became the organization's mission statement "We can help solve all this by increasing access to low cost contraception, supporting women's rights, and increasing environmental awareness. With these tools, people everywhere can determine the best population size for their family, their region and the world." Searle fought a long two years battle of Hodgkins Lymphoma. In his ending, at Home with Hospice Care he had his old time music partner, Laura Lind who was also his significant other. His beloved son, Harry C. Whitney was by his side. There was a celebration of Searle Whitney, an extraordinary man, at All Saints Episcopal Church on Saturday, May 9, 2015. in Berkeley. His wonderful True Blue friends were all there to celebrate him and their music. 1

BARKIN--Leonard, M.D. Leonard Barkin, M.D.,a psychiatrist and psychoanalyst in New York City, died peacefully at home on May 9, 2015, a week before his 85th birthday. Len is survived by his spouse, Jacqueline Dryfoos; his son, Edward Barkin of New York, NY; his brother, Alan Barkin of Menlo Park, CA; his stepchildren, Carolyn Greenspon of Newton, MA and Michael Greenspon of New York, NY, and their spouses, Rick Gershberg, and Jennifer Gundlach, respectively, as well as four grandchildren. He was predeceased by his first wife, Anya Wajnberg Barkin. Len grew up in the Bronx and went to Bronx Science High School. He went to New York University for college and then onto SUNY Downstate College of Medicine, graduating in 1955. He was a psychiatrist in the Air Force, stationed outside of Tokyo, Japan. He then returned to New York and finished his training at Albert Einstein Medical Center in the Bronx. His psychoanalytic training was at SUNY Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn. At the time of his death, Len was practicing psychiatry in New York City, was a clinical professor at New York University and a Training Analyst at the Institute for Psychoanalytic Education. Psychoanalyst, teacher, supervisor, reader and author, Len had a mind that never stopped exploring. One of his most rewarding experiences was creating an interdisciplinary seminar with the English department at NYU. He was an avid reader of The New York Times, a devotee of sports radio, loved the theatre, opera, classical music, art, travel and his country pool. His presence in all our lives will be sorely missed. Donations in his name can be made to the New York Botanical Gardens where he played as a child and continued to enjoy as an adult. 1/3

RICE--Julius, M.D. The Zucker Hillside Hospital, its staff, former trainees and patients mourn the passing of Julius Rice, M.D. He was an exceptional clinician, teacher, role model and colleague. He touched the lives of countless patients and hundreds of trainees during the 32 years that he spent in a leadership position at our institution. He was always poised, gracious, wise and generative, no matter how difficult the circumstances. His smile was infectious and his warmth palpable. Julius Rice graduated from The University of the Witwatersrand in South Africa in 1948 and was in general practice for a number of years before he emigrated to the United States in 1963. He completed a residency in psychiatry at Pilgrim State Psychiatric Hospital in 1965 and joined the staff at Hillside shortly thereafter, where he remained for over three decades. He is the author of a book "Ups and Downs". Valerie Rice, his wife for 67 years passed in 2013. He is survived by his daughters Beverley Rice (and her husband Lawrence Davis) and Leonie Rubin (and her husband Lorry Rubin), three grandchildren (Marcie Rubin, Craig Rubin, and Lindsay Rubin), and three great- grandchildren (Brett, Miles, and Sybil Schaffner). He will be sorely missed. 1/3

GRAND--Timothy. Timothy Weatherford Grand, (known as T.) of Miami, Florida passed away suddenly in Titusville, Florida on May 4, 2015. He was born in New York City on December 3, 1960, the son of the late Gordon Grand Jr. and Ruth Young Grand. T. grew up in Greenwich, Connecticut and Fishers Island, New York. He attended Greenwich Country Day School. He then went on to St. Paul's School in Concord, NH graduating in 1979 and to Yale where he received his B.A. degree in 1985. T. had an extraordinary creative writing gift and imagination, which led to a career in communications. He spent many years as a talented senior copywriter at some of the most successful advertising agencies in New York and Miami. These included: NW Ayer (New York, NY), AC&R Advertising (New York, NY), and Crispin Porter & Bogusky (Miami, FL). He then combined his communication skills with his love for the outdoors by first becoming Communications Director for Trout Unlimited (Arlington, Virginia) followed by a position as Florida Communications Director for the National Audubon Society (Miami, Florida). T. was always happiest when he was on the water or in the woods fishing or bird watching with his close friends and his dogs. He held a Commercial Captain's license which spoke to his skills in all shapes and sizes of boats. He excelled as a salt and fresh water fisherman and few people were more knowledgeable about birds in their varied habitats than T. It was a rare treat to be with him fishing off the Race at Fishers Island on a summer evening as he pointed out the bird and sea life activity around him. Most of all, T. loved his family and friends. He is survived by his siblings: Gordon Grand III of North Salem, NY, Lorna Grand Stengel of Brunswick, Maine, and Diana Grand Masters of South Hadley MA. His oldest sister, Minette Dill Grand Krech predeceases him. He is also survived by 10 nephews and nieces and their 16 children. He will be sorely missed by all. memorial service with a reception afterward is planned for 11am on Wednesday, May 20, 2015 at Gordon and Cecily Grand's residence, 424 Hawley Road, North Salem NY. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Fishers Island Conservancy, P.O. Box 553, Fishers Island, NY 06390 1/3

GRAHAM--Amy. We mourn the loss of Amy Graham and extend our heartfelt condolences to her family. With love to our second mother, a wonderful person who left us far too soon, Alex L., Brian K., Danny G., Eric G., Eric W., Jesse E., Matt S., and Rory G. 1/3

KANE--Daniel Abraham, Chairman of Bayonne Medical Center and Carepoint Health, passed away on May 8th after a nearly three year battle with ALS. Born and raised in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn, NY, he received masters degree from the Columbia University Graduate School of Public Health followed by his PhD from the University of Pittsburgh. He served his community for over 50 years working as an administrator and CEO at various hospitals around the country. He took special interest in revitalizing hospitals on the edge of bankruptcy, keeping them running for the communities they served. Over the course of his career, he had been an active philanthropist and the recipient of several awards for his actions. Mr. Kane is survived by his sons, Joshua Alexander Kane and Seth Andrew Kane; a daughter-in-law, Erin Ashley Kane; his former wife, June Kozak-Kane; his brother, Robert Kane; his caregiver, Daniel Acquah, and nieces and nephews. Donations can be made in Mr. Kane's honor to the ALS Association. Funeral service 1pm Monday at Temple Beth El 221 Schraalenburgh Road, Closter, NJ. 1/3
MAHONEY--Irene, O.S.U.,an Ursuline Sister, died on May 9, 2015. She was 94. For the complete obituary and for visiting hours, please visit: www.lloydmaxcy.com 1/3

ZELMAN--Stanley R.,died on May 9th surrounded by his family after celebrating his 89th birthday. A devoted husband of 64 years to Lyla, a loving father to Elyn and Barry Rosenthal and Phillip and Lucy Zelman, playful grandfather and awesome "GG." Brother to Selma Back. Stanley brought joy to so many as a master kibbutzer, lover of the beach and avid traveler. Funeral services Monday, 12 noon at Gutterman's, 175 N. Long Beach Rd. Rockville Center. 1/3

WEG--John G.,M.D. (Jack) died May 3, 2015, surrounded by his wife of 60 years, Mary Loretta Flynn, his six daughters, their spouses, his 12 grandchildren and his brother. He was Chief of Pulmonary and Critical Care Medicine at the University of Michigan. Among his many accomplishments, he was President of the American College of Chest Physicians and received its Master Fellow Award. He lives on in our hearts. 1/3

BOWIE--Marilyn Miller, aged 89, died Friday at her daughter's home. She led a wonderful life: happily married to Ted Bowie for nearly 40 years, Executive Director of Planned Parenthood in Bloomington, IN, and VP for Affiliate Development and Education at Planned Parenthood Federation of America, curious and intrepid traveler, and fiercely competitive tennis player. Survivors include her daughters Alexandra Bowie and Jocelyn Bowie, sons-in-law Daniel Richman and David Semmel, grandchildren Nick, Eli, and Cassidy Molin, and Matthew and Rebecca Richman. She adored her brothers Leonard Miller and Bob Miller and their wives, her nieces and nephews, and their children and grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to a charity of your choice. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

CAPRONI--John Daniel. We mourn the passing of John Caproni, 94 years old, on May 7, 2015. An accomplished architect with an amazing and profound love of life. John was a graduate of The Yale School of Architecture, a Fulbright scholar and a veteran of WWII. John was married to his wife Sonja for 45 years. He is also survived by his two sons, Marc and Christopher and their respective wives Paulette and Robin; four grandchildren, Lauren, Stephen, Connor and Austenne; four great-grand-children, Tristan, Lillian, Charlotte and Ryan. Also surviving John is his elder brother Leo Jr. and his sister-in-law Joanna. The family further extends their heartfelt thanks to John's loving and dedicated caregivers Sali Kone, Duane Evans and Acharo Smith. A memorial service will be held Monday, May 18 at 5pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the Central Park Conservancy, 14 E. 60th St, New York, NY, 10022. 1/3

FEINER--Ronald E. BAM's executives, Board of Trustees, and staff mourn the loss of Ronald E. Feiner, beloved friend. Ron's passionate support of BAM was beyond measure. He will live on in our hearts. 1/3

LEVINE--Ethel "Bunny" nee Hatala, age 69 died peacefully at home surrounded by her family on May 8th. She is survived by her husband of 47 years, Paul, and sons Alec and Mark and her daughter-in-law, Heather. Also by her grandchildren, Jackson, David, Hannah, Max, and Olivia - her greatest loves. Also survived by her older siblings, Vincent, Eileen (Lou), and Princess. Bunny will be remembered for her unconditional love, vitality, selflessness, devotion, beauty, honesty, dignity, resolve, and courage. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, May 12th at 11:45am at Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Ave and 76 St. Family will receive visitors two hours prior to the service at the chapel. 1/3

ELKMAN--Steven Munro passed away Friday, May 8, 2015, following a courageous battle against pancreatic cancer. He was surrounded by family at his home in Ridgefield, Connecticut. He was born on October 1, 1946 to Phyllis (Peale) and Sidney Elkman of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Mr. Elkman graduated from Graham-Eckes School in Palm Beach, Florida in 1964. He then attended Cornell University, where he was a member of Theta Delta Chi, and Columbia University. Mr. Elkman was a Managing Director at Deutsche Bank in New York City, following decades on Wall Street at the firms Clark, Dodge & Co, Kidder Peabody & Co, Alex. Brown & Sons and Bankers Trust. A devoted animal lover, Mr. Elkman was Chairman Emeritus of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (ASPCA). He also served as a director of several companies and non-profit organizations. Steven spent his time in Ridgefield, Connecticut, and New York City where he was a member of The River Club, and Newport, Rhode Island where he was a member of Spouting Rock Beach Assoc iation. He was a passionate collector of antique automobiles, tinkering and restoring vehicles in his garages. Steven was a historical non-fiction enthusiast; he also enjoyed travel, tennis and trap shooting. Steven cultivated friends of all ages throughout his life and as a natural raconteur with generous and precise humor, he will be greatly missed. He is survived by wife, Linda (Dawson), and their two children, Allison and Bradley, brother, William Elkman of Manhattan Beach, California and aunt, Renee Brown of New York City. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation in Steven Elkman's name to Abramson Cancer Center of the University of Pennsylvania or the ASPCA. A memorial service and celebration of life are being planned.

LEVINE--Ethel. The board and staff of the Jewish Board of Family & Children's Services mourn the passing of Ethel Levine, wife of our former CEO Paul. Ethel lit up every room she entered with her charm and presence and will be dearly missed by all of us. 1/3

BAUMEISTER--Matthew C. 4/5/86 - 5/11/05 Our Precious Matthew, For ten years our hearts have ached with sadness. For ten years our tears have continued to flow. What it means to have lost you no one will ever know. For ten years we have loved you and kept you in our thoughts but missing you is a heartache that never goes away. Loving you forever, missing you always, Mom, Dad & Jared 1/3

KIRBY--James Lewis Jr.,died peacefully on Thursday, May 7, 2015 at his James River farmland estate of Claremont Manor in Surry County, Virginia, after an exceptionally fruitful life flavored by a scholarly passion for history, heraldry, and genealogy. To that end, he was a diligent member of more than 30 organizations devoted to those subjects. He was an ardent preservationist and saved from development his ancestral property of Football Quarter Creek in Poquoson, Virginia. He also was the author, contributor, or publisher of numerous books on his family and Claremont Manor. He was born on July 13th, 1923 in Portsmouth, Virginia, the son of James Lewis Kirby and Dorette Wigg Kirby, both of whom were from Norfolk, Virginia; his father was an officer of the Seaboard Railway Company. As a boy he attended private and public schools in Norfolk before graduating from Episcopal High School in Alexandria, Virginia in 1941. He interrupted his studies at Princeton by entering active service in the Army as an enlisted man in 1943. After specialized training he eventually became a member of Cannon Company, 345th Infantry Regiment, 87th Infantry Division. He sailed with his regiment for Scotland on the unescorted Queen Mary in October, 1944. His unit fought in campaigns in Northern France, Ardennes, Rhineland, and Central Europe. The 87th was attached to General Patton's 3rd Army during the Battle of the Bulge. According to his bronze star citation, his service as a motor messenger required him to drive through areas subjected to artillery and small arms fire. He and two other soldiers in a jeep were among the first to enter Orhdruf concentration camp, part of the Buchenwald complex. After World War II he was discharged as a tech sergeant and returned to Princeton, graduating in 1948. While at Princeton he was on both the Honor and Undergraduate Councils, Manager of the Varsity Golf Team, Chairman of the Freshman Committee of Orange Key, a member of Ivy Club, and president of his class. He worked for many years in New York City as an officer or director in several insurance brokerage and investment businesses: Lukens, Savage and Washburn; Alexander and Alexander; Investors Diversified Services; and Corroon and Black. He served in the Army National Guard of New York State (1945-1954), and then the Organized Federal Reserves, before resigning as a 1st lieutenant in 1955. He was a member of the Church Club, the Knickerbocker Club, and the University Club. He was on the board of East Side House Settlement, a non-profit serving children and families in the Mott Haven section of the Bronx. On May 29, 1954 he married Ann Sutherland Kirby. They lived in Morristown, New Jersey before moving to Virginia when he became president of the Guilford Company and Guilford Foundation in Richmond. While in New Jersey he was active in The Harding Township, Green Village Bridle Path Association. His wife died on July 3, 1996. His survivors include: his son Wade Kirby of Morristown, New Jersey, wife Linda, and their sons Croft, Taylor, and Reade; his daughter Annette Kirby of Warm Springs, Virginia; and his son Roger Kirby of Richmond, Virginia, wife Louise, and their daughter Laura and son James. An Episcopal funeral service at Claremont Manor's chapel will be private. In lieu of flowers the family wishes that any memorial contributions be sent to: The Order of St. John, 1850 M Street NW #

ELKMAN--Steven Munro passed away Friday, May 8, 2015, following a courageous battle against pancreatic cancer. He was surrounded by family at his home in Ridgefield, Connecticut. He was born on October 1, 1946 to Phyllis (Peale) and Sidney Elkman of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Mr. Elkman graduated from Graham-Eckes School in Palm Beach, Florida in 1964. He then attended Cornell University, where he was a member of Theta Delta Chi, and Columbia University. Mr. Elkman was a Managing Director at Deutsche Bank in New York City, following decades on Wall Street at the firms Clark, Dodge & Co, Kidder Peabody & Co, Alex. Brown & Sons and Bankers Trust. A devoted animal lover, Mr. Elkman was Chairman Emeritus of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (ASPCA). He also served as a director of several companies and non-profit organizations. Steven spent his time in Ridgefield, Connecticut, and New York City where he was a member of The River Club, and Newport, Rhode Island where he was a member of Spouting Rock Beach Assoc iation. He was a passionate collector of antique automobiles, tinkering and restoring vehicles in his garages. Steven was a historical non-fiction enthusiast; he also enjoyed travel, tennis and trap shooting. Steven cultivated friends of all ages throughout his life and as a natural raconteur with generous and precise humor, he will be greatly missed. He is survived by wife, Linda (Dawson), and their two children, Allison and Bradley, brother, William Elkman of Manhattan Beach, California and aunt, Renee Brown of New York City. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation in Steven Elkman's name to Abramson Cancer Center of the University of Pennsylvania or the ASPCA. A memorial service and celebration of life are being planned.

Board of Directors, The Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theatre 1/3

EISERT--Dr. Jack, born August 15, 1931; died peacefully on May 11, 2015. Retired dermatologist and Clinical Professor of Dermatology at Columbia Medical School. He will be deeply missed by his wife Barbara; sons Richard and Douglas; daughters-in law Sarah Jaffe and Ning Lu and grandchildren Alex and Nat Eisert. He touched the lives of so many. BARKIN--Leonard, M.D. Leonard Barkin, M.D.,a psychiatrist and psychoanalyst in New York City, died peacefully at home on May 9, 2015, a week before his 85th birthday. Len is survived by his spouse, Jacqueline Dryfoos; his son, Edward Barkin of New York, NY; his brother, Alan Barkin of Menlo Park, CA; his stepchildren, Carolyn Greenspon of Newton, MA and Michael Greenspon of New York, NY, and their spouses, Rick Gershberg, and Jennifer Gundlach, respectively, as well as four grandchildren. He was predeceased by his first wife, Anya Wajnberg Barkin. Len grew up in the Bronx and went to Bronx Science High School. He went to New York University for college and then onto SUNY Downstate College of Medicine, graduating in 1955. He was a psychiatrist in the Air Force, stationed outside of Tokyo, Japan. He then returned to New York and finished his training at Albert Einstein Medical Center in the Bronx. His psychoanalytic training was at SUNY Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn. At the time of his death, Len was practicing psychiatry in New York City, was a clinical professor at New York University and a Training Analyst at the Institute for Psychoanalytic Education. Psychoanalyst, teacher, supervisor, reader and author, Len had a mind that never stopped exploring. One of his most rewarding experiences was creating an interdisciplinary seminar with the English department at NYU. He was an avid reader of The New York Times, a devotee of sports radio, loved the theatre, opera, classical music, art, travel and his country pool. His presence in all our lives will be sorely missed. Donations in his name can be made to the New York Botanical Gardens where he played as a child and continued to enjoy as an adult. 1/3

FEINER--Ronald. "Ron" Edward, 72, of New York City, passed away Sunday, May 10, 2015. Born in Brooklyn, son of the late Helen and Sol Feiner. Survived by his devoted partner Karen Brooks Hopkins, loving children Daniel (Meredith) and Anna, grandsons Chase and Dylan, brother Joel (Gail), stepson Matt (Annie) and their three daughters. Practiced entertainment law for over 40 years, representing clients in theatre, television, film, music, and not-for-profit. Served on Boards of BAM and St. Ann's Warehouse. Caring, beautiful spirit, great sense of humor. Gifted artist, doting grandfather. Treasured time in Montauk. A magical heart. In lieu of flowers, family suggests contributions to Brooklyn Academy of Music and Mount Sinai Medical Center. Services today, 10am, "The Riverside" W. 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. 1/3

HAUSER--Herbert David. Born September 14, 1927. BA and MBA from NYU. Credit Analyst and Vice President at CIT. Longtime resident of Yorktown Heights, NY and West Yarmouth, MA. Quick wit and lively storyteller. Lover of nature and the arts. Generous philanthropist. Beloved husband of Doris (nee Socher) for 64 years. Loving father, brother, grandfather, and great-grandfather. (DOROTUSA.org). 1/3

LOCKWOOD--Donald. Donald A. Lockwood, of Delray Beach, FL, died May 10 at the age of 88. He received his B.A. in Mathematics from Columbia College and a Master's degree in Statistics from Columbia University. He was a consulting actuary and president of Pension Planning Co. in New York. He was predeceased in 2002 by his beautiful wife Joan whom he adored and was the love of his life. A Silver Life Master and avid bridge player for over 75 years, Don is survived by his children Steven and Wanda Lockwood and Lisa and John Winston, and grandchildren Rachel (Sean), Tracy, Scott and Robbie. Services will be held Wednesday, May 13 at 10am at Temple Sholom at 300 E. Putnam Ave. in Greenwich, CT. 1/3

ALEXANDER--Robert Charles, 72, died quietly at home after a short bout with pancreatic cancer. He is survived by his devoted wife of 45 years, Margo, two loving sons, Nichol and James, their wives, Sarah and Gabriela and two beloved grandchildren, Madeline and Charles. Bob was born July 7, 1942, in Norman, Oklahoma to Paul and Ruth Alexander and is survived by his brother John (and family) of Austin, Texas and his sister, Margaret Ann (and family) of Newton Upper Falls, Massachusetts. He leaves behind nieces, nephews, and other young friends and relatives who always found Bob to be interested in them, their projects and dreams. Bob graduated in Electrical Engineering from Cornell University in 1965, served in Guatmala with the Peace Corps and graduated from Harvard Business School with the highest honors. Possessing an excellent memory he was as likely to quote Shakespeare as Bob Dylan. An energetic, stubbornly dedicated worker, Bob pursued key businesses in the ever- changing media and entertainment industries. He co-founded Streetwise Records, a pioneer in the rap world that has subsequently become a cult label. His latest project IndiePix, is an independent film distributor focused on inspiring audiences and talented, passionate film makers. Bob is remembered by friends and family as a kind, curious and friendly man, with a broad smile and an optimistic outlook. He brought us endless fascinating conversations on endless topics, lots of laughter and great love. Our family is grateful to our loving circle of friends who have supported us through this painful ten weeks. The funeral is scheduled for Thursday, May 14 at 4pm at The Church of Heavenly Rest, 2 East 90th Street with a reception to follow. All are welcome to attend and celebrate Bob's life. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to The New York Stem Cell Foundation. 1/3

MARCUS--Janet Kahn, age 80, passed away Wednesday May 6, 2015 after an extended illness. Janet is a former resident of Newburyport, Massachusetts, where she lived with her husband, Edward Barz, until his death in 2012, as well as New York City, New York. Janet was born in Brooklyn, New York on January 22, 1935 to Edith and Sidney Kahn. Over the course of her life, her accomplishments were great and her contributions were significant. She attended Woodmere High School and from there went on to graduate from Cornell University with honors in 1955. In 1956 she earned a teaching degree from Harvard University, Phi Kappa Phi. Following a notable career in publishing in New York City, she changed course and became a high school teacher, sharing with others her incredible quest for knowledge, which would remain with her throughout her 80 years. In 1965 she married David Marcus and moved to White Plains, New York, where their son, Adam, was born. Despite the challenges of being a new mother, Janet managed to complete a law degree at Hofstra University with honors in 1977 and pass the New York State Bar that same year. She worked as a public defender in the Bronx until her retirement in 1999. She truly helped change the course of many people's lives and was a crusader of justice and equality. Throughout her years, Janet took advantage of life to the fullest. She was enthusiastically involved in numerous community organizations, charities and hobbies. Her friends were many. She loved tennis, gardening, travel, the arts, and, above all else, learning. She had an unsurpassed capacity and thirst for knowledge; and, until this past year, served as a docent at the Peabody Essex Museum in Salem, Massachusetts. She is survived by her son, Adam D. Marcus, daughter in-law Carrie Marcus and her grandchildren, Sidney and Rose Marcus. She was a fiercely devoted mother, mother-in-law, grandmother and friend. She passed peacefully, in the presence of her loved ones. Funeral Services will be held at the Twomey-LeBlanc and Conte Funeral Home 193 High Street Newburyport, MA 01950 on Friday May 8, 2015 at 2:30pm. There were will be a private memorial service in Manhattan on Wednesday, May 13th at 12pm. Please contact Adam at amarcust07@gmail.com for further details. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Planned Parenthood or The Peabody Essex Museum. 1/3

NAMMACK--William J. Passed away peacefully on May 11, 2015. Beloved husband of Carol. Loving father of Caitlin Nammack Weissman, and the late Peter Nammack. Devoted and loving grandfather of Hillary, Christopher, and Sarah Nammack, and Avery and Margaret Weissman. Bill was a graduate of the Peddie School and Princeton University. He was an Officer with the Navy on the Battleship U.SS. Wisconsin during World War II. A Specialist on the New York Stock Exchange as a Partner of Sprague & Nammack, and later a Partner of Murphy, Marseilles, Smith & Nammack. He was a Governor of the New York Stock Exchange and a Member of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Dominic RC Chapel, 96 Anstice St., Oyster Bay, NY on Tuesday May 18, 2015 at 10:30am. Interment Locust Valley Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory to the Salvation Army, 992 Prospect Ave., P.O. Box 974, Westbury NY 11590 or www.salvationarmyusa. org would be appreciated. For further information www.oysterbayfuneral home.com 1/3

LINDENBAUM--Belda. It is with a heavy heart that we say farewell to our beloved sister-in-law. Our only consolation is that she lived a wonderful life filled with love, laughter, leadership and family. We will miss her dearly. Heartfelt condolences to Marcel, Nathan, Matthew, Bennet, Vicky, Abigail, spouses and grandchildren. Jean and Armand Lindenbaum and Family 1/3

ALEXANDER--Robert. The staff and associates of Indiepix deeply mourn the death of their visionary founder Bob Alexander. His integrity, imagination and optimism will continue to inspire and enlighten us all. Barnet L. Liberman, Chairman 1/3

BARKIN--Leonard. The Board and staff of The New York Botanical Garden (NYBG) are deeply saddened by the death of Leonard Barkin, M.D., husband of Jacqueline Dryfoos, a member of the Board of Managers of the Botanical Garden, and son-in-law of Marian Heiskell, also a Garden Board member. Leonard enjoyed traveling abroad with the NYBG Board, most recently to Cuba; his keen intellect and interest in the world made him an excellent companion. He will be fondly remembered as a good friend of the Garden. We send our warmest condolences to Jacqueline and her family. Maureen K. Chilton, Chairman Gregory Long, President 1/3

STRAUS--Lewis B.,81, died in Manhattan on May 10, 2015. Husband of Elly Weiss, father to Paul and Alex from a previous marriage, brother to Donald (Selma), uncle to six nieces, nephews and their 11 children. A pioneering advocate for ending hunger in America. Mentor and friend to all who worked with and for him on the local, state, and federal level. His passion for a just society was equaled by his love of jazz. Once a student of Nabokov and always a fan of the Yankees, he could do a wicked impression of Fred Astaire. A memorial service will be held in the fall. 1/3

BARKIN--Leonard, M.D. The Faculty of the Institute for Psychoanalytic Education (IPE) and the Board and Members of the Psychoanalytic Association of New York (PANY) are deeply saddened by the death of our colleague and friend, a devoted teacher and talented psychoanalyst. 1/3

ELKMAN--Steven Munro passed away Friday, May 8, 2015, following a courageous battle against pancreatic cancer. He was surrounded by family at his home in Ridgefield, Connecticut. He was born on October 1, 1946 to Phyllis (Peale) and Sidney Elkman of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Mr. Elkman graduated from Graham-Eckes School in Palm Beach, Florida in 1964. He then attended Cornell University, where he was a member of Theta Delta Chi, and Columbia University. Mr. Elkman was a Managing Director at Deutsche Bank in New York City, following decades on Wall Street at the firms Clark, Dodge & Co, Kidder Peabody & Co, Alex. Brown & Sons and Bankers Trust. A devoted animal lover, Mr. Elkman was Chairman Emeritus of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (ASPCA). He also served as a director of several companies and non-profit organizations. Steven spent his time in Ridgefield, Connecticut, and New York City where he was a member of The River Club, and Newport, Rhode Island where he was a member of Spouting Rock Beach Assoc iation. He was a passionate collector of antique automobiles, tinkering and restoring vehicles in his garages. Steven was a historical non-fiction enthusiast; he also enjoyed travel, tennis and trap shooting. Steven cultivated friends of all ages throughout his life and as a natural raconteur with generous and precise humor, he will be greatly missed. He is survived by wife, Linda (Dawson), and their two children, Allison and Bradley, brother, William Elkman of Manhattan Beach, California and aunt, Renee Brown of New York City. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation in Steven Elkman's name to Abramson Cancer Center of the University of Pennsylvania or the ASPCA. A memorial service and celebration of life are being planned.

FEINER--Ronald. William A. Perlmuth, Chairman Joan Finkelstein, Executive Director Jody Arnhold and Etta Brandman, Trustees 1/3

ALEXANDER--Robert Charles, 72, died quietly at home after a short bout with pancreatic cancer. He is survived by his devoted wife of 45 years, Margo, two loving sons, Nichol and James, their wives, Sarah and Gabriela and two beloved grandchildren, Madeline and Charles. Bob was born July 7, 1942, in Norman, Oklahoma to Paul and Ruth Alexander and is survived by his brother John (and family) of Austin, Texas and his sister, Margaret Ann (and family) of Newton Upper Falls, Massachusetts. He leaves behind nieces, nephews, and other young friends and relatives who always found Bob to be interested in them, their projects and dreams. Bob graduated in Electrical Engineering from Cornell University in 1965, served in Guatmala with the Peace Corps and graduated from Harvard Business School with the highest honors. Possessing an excellent memory he was as likely to quote Shakespeare as Bob Dylan. An energetic, stubbornly dedicated worker, Bob pursued key businesses in the ever- changing media and entertainment industries. He co-founded Streetwise Records, a pioneer in the rap world that has subsequently become a cult label. His latest project IndiePix, is an independent film distributor focused on inspiring audiences and talented, passionate film makers. Bob is remembered by friends and family as a kind, curious and friendly man, with a broad smile and an optimistic outlook. He brought us endless fascinating conversations on endless topics, lots of laughter and great love. Our family is grateful to our loving circle of friends who have supported us through this painful ten weeks. The funeral is scheduled for Thursday, May 14 at 4pm at The Church of Heavenly Rest, 2 East 90th Street with a reception to follow. All are welcome to attend and celebrate Bob's life. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to The New York Stem Cell Foundation. 1/3

SCHAEFER--Marilyn L.,Professor Emerita in the Department of Art & Advertising Design of the New York City Technical College, CUNY, died on May 8 in New York City. She was born in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, and worked for many years as both a teacher and an artist in New York, having previously received a Master's degree from the University of Chicago; a Master of Fine Arts degree from Cranbrook Academy of Art in Bloomfield Hills, Michigan; and a Master's degree from St. John's College in Santa Fe, New Mexico. She is survived by her sister, Suzan, of New York City; two brothers, Carol, of Davenport, Iowa, and Jack of Barrington, Illinois; and a sister- in-law, Carolyn, of Barrington; as well as by numerous nieces, nephews, great- nieces, and great-nephews. Her family extends its gratitude to her many devoted friends. Donations in her memory may be made to UNICEF, the Humane Society, or to St. Johns College, Santa Fe, New Mexico. 1/3

LINDENBAUM--Belda Kaufman. SAR Academy/ SAR High School mourn with deep sadness the passing of Belda Lindenbaum. Belda leaves a legacy of leadership and commitment to Israel and to generations of Jewish women worldwide. We extend our condolences to SAR parents, Nathan (Shari) Lindenbaum, an SAR Trustee and Victoria (Ben) Feder and the entire family. Jack C. Bendheim, President Ludwig Bravmann, Chairman 1/3

ALEXANDER--Robert. The New York Stem Cell Foundation deeply mourns the loss of our dear friend Robert Alexander, beloved husband of our cherished board member and steadfast supporter, Margo Alexander. We rejoice in having known Bob, whose exuberant spirit enriched us all, and we send our deepest sympathies to Margo, James, Gabriela, Nichol, Sarah, Madeline and Charles. Roy Geronemus, Chairman of the Board, Susan L. Solomon, CEO, and the entire NYSCF family 1/3

FEINER--Ron. The Board of Trustees and staff of The Joyce Theater Foundation mourn the passing of Ron Feiner and extend condolences to his family, to Karen Brooks Hopkins, and to the Brooklyn Academy of Music for their loss. BURG--Stanley. Adored by Ellen, his bride of 53 years, and by Fran and Mel, his daughter and son-in-law. He was Stan the Man, August 11, 1936 - May 11, 2015.

O'BEIRNE--William H.,90, of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn and Garden City, NY on May 7, 2015. Beloved brother of Florence Beach and the late Peter, Veronica Moriarty and Thomas. Adored uncle and great uncle "Willy" to many nieces and nephews. Visitation Thursday from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, 1201 Franklin Avenue, Garden City, NY. GRANGER--Helen, known to most as MariElena Granger, passed away on the 23rd of April surrounded by loved ones in her home. A celebration of her life will be held noon May 13th at Judson Memorial Church, 55 Washington Square South. In memoriam donations can be made to Give a Jumpstart, 414 Redwood Ave., Corte Madera, CA 94925 (www.giveajumpstart. org). Wife of the late playwright Percy Granger, she will be remembered for her joie de vivre, impeccable floral skills, excellent mothering, and charitable works in Zambia. She is survived by her sons Andrew and James, and her granddaughter Reece. 1/3

ROOS--William Joseph, of Honesdale, PA. Died May 9 at age 94. Retired President of Katz Bros. Department Store. Husband of 64 years of Paula Sparrow Roos. Father of Liza, Sigmund and Joel. Memorial Services Friday at 2 at Congregation Beth Israel, Honesdale.

BARKIN--Leonard, M.D. Leonard Barkin, M.D.,a psychiatrist and psychoanalyst in New York City, died peacefully at home on May 9, 2015, a week before his 85th birthday. Len is survived by his spouse, Jacqueline Dryfoos; his son, Edward Barkin of New York, NY; his brother, Alan Barkin of Menlo Park, CA; his stepchildren, Carolyn Greenspon of Newton, MA and Michael Greenspon of New York, NY, and their spouses, Rick Gershberg, and Jennifer Gundlach, respectively, as well as four grandchildren. He was predeceased by his first wife, Anya Wajnberg Barkin. Len grew up in the Bronx and went to Bronx Science High School. He went to New York University for college and then onto SUNY Downstate College of Medicine, graduating in 1955. He was a psychiatrist in the Air Force, stationed outside of Tokyo, Japan. He then returned to New York and finished his training at Albert Einstein Medical Center in the Bronx. His psychoanalytic training was at SUNY Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn. At the time of his death, Len was practicing psychiatry in New York City, was a clinical professor at New York University and a Training Analyst at the Institute for Psychoanalytic Education. Psychoanalyst, teacher, supervisor, reader and author, Len had a mind that never stopped exploring. One of his most rewarding experiences was creating an interdisciplinary seminar with the English department at NYU. He was an avid reader of The New York Times, a devotee of sports radio, loved the theatre, opera, classical music, art, travel and his country pool. His presence in all our lives will be sorely missed. Donations in his name can be made to the New York Botanical Gardens where he played as a child and continued to enjoy as an adult. 1/3
DEITCHMAN--Bruce M.D. Our hero's long battle with illness is over. Dad, we love you and miss you. Love, Nick and Sophia 1/3

DEITCHMAN--Bruce M.D.,on May 10, 2015, survived by his wife Lorraine Matovina, his children Nicholas and Sophia Campbell-Seremetis, a niece Heather and nephew Jamie, and many wonderful friends, colleagues, patients and family and cousins, both blood related and intentionally chosen. DEITCHMAN--Bruce M.D. The physicians and staff of Madison dermatology with profound grief mourn the untimely passing of our esteemed colleague. He also played a prominent national role representing the specialty of dermatology in policy negotiations before Medicare. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Lorraine and family. He will be greatly missed. 1/3

KELLER--Samuel B.,CPA, age 95, formerly of Atlantic Beach, NY, died peacefully on May 9. Beloved husband of Eleanor Keller (deceased). Loving father of Ellen (Mark) Abramson and Susan (Joel) Schlossberg. Devoted grandfather of four; great-grandfather of five. Founding partner of Keller & Steinmuller in 1951. Joined WeiserMazars in 1998. Services on Thursday, May 14, 11:30am, Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, Hewlett, Long Island, NY. 1/3

HUNT--John F. The lawyers and staff of Cravath, Swaine & Moore LLP mourn the passing of their partner, colleague and friend, John F. Hunt. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife and family. Mr. Hunt joined Cravath in 1953 and left later that year for military service. He returned to Cravath in 1955, became a partner in 1963 and retired in 1995. Mr. Hunt's practice focused primarily on project finance, with a special emphasis on natural resources, utilities and infrastructure. Mr. Hunt was a member of the New York City Bar Association, where he was on the Committee on Administrative Law, the American Bar Association, the International Bar Association and the New York State Bar Association. He was also involved with the American Judicial Society and the International and Corporation Law Center. Mr. Hunt was born in Newark, New Jersey. He received an A.B. summa cum laude from Seton Hall College in 1950, where he was a Departmental Medalist, and an LL.B. from Columbia Law School in 1953, where he was a Harlan Fiske Stone Scholar, a James Kent Scholar, an Articles Editor of the Law Review and a recipient of the Beck Real Property Prize and the Schwartz Administrative Law Prize. Mr. Hunt was a beloved and devoted husband and father. He is survived by his wife Miriam and two children, Mary and John. 1/3

BERMAN--Doris Boris, 63, passed away on Mother's Day, May 10, 2015. Born in Innsbruck, Austria, she grew up in Salzburg and achieved recognition as a recording artist under the name Isabell Domin. To pursue a career as a multi-media artist she moved to the United States. She was equally at home in San Francisco, New York, Berlin and Paris. Her vitality and creativity touched many lives. She is survived by her children, Aniko and Max, her former husband, Russell, and her brother, Peter Quehenberger. Her family and many friends around the world will miss her dearly and will continue to hold her vibrant memory in their hearts. In lieu of flowers, please donate to Free Arts NYC. Private memorial celebration for her friends and family, Sunday, May 17, 1:30pm. More information at http://ourmemory of.com/dorisborisberman/ 1/3
TAYLOR--Barbara R.,Ed.D., died peacefully May 10, in Hanover, NH. An educator and world traveler, she is missed by her sons Peter, Robert, and Josh, daughter Jennifer, and their families. 1/3

EVANS--James H. NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital mourns the loss of James H. Evans, a visionary leader and dear friend to our institution. Elected a Governor of the Society of the New York Hospital in 1971, a Life Governor in 1990 and a Life Trustee of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital in 1998, Mr. Evans' generosity and insight greatly contributed to many Hospital achievements over the past five decades. He served on numerous committees and was the first President of the New York Hospital - Cornell Medical Center Advisory Board, where he worked to ensure that our patients always received the best possible care. A visionary philanthropist, he devoted his time and energy to charitable enterprises and educational institutions across the country. We will dearly miss his courteous and gracious spirit, and offer our deepest sympathies to his family and loved ones. Frank A. Bennack, Jr., Chairman of the Board Steven J. Corwin, MD, Chief Executive Officer Herbert Pardes, MD, Executive Vice Chair NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital 1/3

STRAUS--Lewis B.,81, died in Manhattan on May 10, 2015. Husband of Elly Weiss, father to Paul and Alex from a previous marriage, brother to Donald (Selma), uncle to six nieces, nephews and their 11 children. A pioneering advocate for ending hunger in America. Mentor and friend to all who worked with and for him on the local, state, and federal level. His passion for a just society was equaled by his love of jazz. Once a student of Nabokov and always a fan of the Yankees, he could do a wicked impression of Fred Astaire. A memorial service will be held in the fall. 1/3

HUNT--John Francis, 86, of Upper Montclair, NJ, and New York City, passed away on May 11, 2015. Mr. Hunt was raised in the Vailsburg section of Newark, NJ, where he was born. He received an A.B. summa cum laude from Seton Hall College in 1950 and an L.L.B. from Columbia Law School in 1953, where he was a Harlan Fiske Stone Scholar, a James Kent Scholar, Articles Editor of the Law Review, and recipient of the Beck Real Property and Schwartz Administrative Law Prizes. Mr. Hunt joined the law firm of Cravath, Swaine, and Moore in Manhattan in 1953 and returned to work there for the remainder of his career after serving in the US Army from 1953-1955. He became a partner at Cravath in 1963 and retired in 1995. Mr. Hunt's legal practice focused on project finance, with an emphasis on natural resource extraction, utilities, and infrastructure. He also represented IBM in anti-trust negotiations in the 1970s and 1980s. Mr. Hunt's other clients included Columbia Gas System, Kuhn & Loeb, First Boston, MetLife, Equitable Life, Moore-McCormack, Oglebay Norton, and Pickands Mather. He also represented members of the theology faculty of the Catholic University of America in free speech proceedings within the University and in a related civil suit. He was a benefactor of Columbia Law School and the Center For Catholic Studies at Seton Hall University, a member of the Board of Trustees of Seton Hall Preparatory School, and a faithful parishioner of St. Cassian R.C. Church in Upper Montclair. Mr. Hunt's survivors include: his beloved wife, Miriam (nee Kelly); his devoted children, Mary E. Hunt of Upper Montclair and Prof. John F. Hunt III and his wife Anne B. Metcalf of New York City; three grandsons, John F. Hunt IV, Henry S. Hunt, and Andrew K. Hunt; his younger brother, Leonard Hunt of Hackettstown, NJ; and his older sister, Regina Nugent of Aberdeen, NJ. He was predeceased by his younger brothers Robert Hunt and Frank Hunt. Funeral services will be held on Saturday 9:45am from the Bizub-Quinlan Funeral Home, 1313 Van Houten Avenue, Clifton and 10:30 am at St. Cassian R.C. Church, 187 Bellevue Avenue, Upper Montclair. Entombment to follow at Immaculate Conception Cemetery, 712 Grove Street in Upper Montclair. Visiting hours will be held on Friday from 2-4 and 7-9 pm. A memorial service will also be held on Thursday, May 21, at 10am at St. Jean Baptiste RC Church, 184 East 76th Street in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, please consider a memorial contribution to the Center for Catholic Studies at Seton Hall University, 400 South Orange Avenue, South Orange, NJ 07079 or to the scholarship fund at Seton Hall Preparatory School c/o Monsignor Michael Kelly, 120 Northfield Avenue, West Orange, NJ, 07052. Please visit www.bizub.com for driving directions and online condolences. 1/3

NAMMACK--William J. Passed away peacefully on May 11, 2015. Beloved husband of Carol. Loving father of Caitlin Nammack Weissman, and the late Peter Nammack. Devoted and loving grandfather of Hillary, Christopher, and Sarah Nammack, and Avery and Margaret Weissman. Bill was a graduate of the Peddie School and Princeton University. He was an Officer with the Navy on the Battleship U.SS. Wisconsin during World War II. A Specialist on the New York Stock Exchange as a Partner of Sprague & Nammack, and later a Partner of Murphy, Marseilles, Smith & Nammack. He was a Governor of the New York Stock Exchange and a Member of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Dominic RC Chapel, 96 Anstice St., Oyster Bay, NY on Tuesday May 19, 2015 at 10:30am. Interment Locust Valley Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory to the Salvation Army, 992 Prospect Ave., P.O. Box 974, Westbury NY 11590 or www.salvationarmyusa. org would be appreciated. For further information www.oysterbayfuneral home.com 1/3

The beautiful qualities of her life shall endure forever in the hearts of those who loved and cherished her. She will be missed. 1/3

ALEXANDER--Bob. Pam, Peter, Jonathan and David Flaherty mourn the passing of their dear friend, Bob Alexander, husband of Margo, father of Nichol (Sarah) and James (Gabriela). You have enriched our lives for nearly 50 years. We love you and will miss you. 1/3

HESS--Frances Aaron, of New York City, originally from Pittsburgh, PA. Fran died on May 12 at 82 years of age, surrounded by loved ones, following a battle with cancer. She was predeceased by her beloved husband, Robert L. Hess. Fran had a passionate commitment to her family. She is mourned by her devoted children and children-in-law, Carl, Carol, Laura, Jonathan, Beth, Roger, and Casey, and by her treasured grandchildren: Alexandra, Robert, and Peter Hess; Rachel and Daniel Wachman; Rebecca, Lily, and Amelia Posner-Hess; and Tyler, Adam, and Sophia Hess. Fran is survived by her sister Maxine Rosston, her brother Marcus Aaron II, her sister and brother-in-law Elinor and James Langer, her sister-in-law Judith Hess Cochin, and many devoted nieces and nephews. Fran's life was shaped by a drive to give back to the community. The Jewish community was one of her great loves, and she served for many years on the Board of Governors of Hebrew Union College and as an officer of the American Jewish Committee. After her husband's death, Temple Emanu-El became a second home to her. Deeply committed to higher education, she was a trustee and valued volunteer of her beloved alma mater, Vassar College. Always on the go and full of energy, she cherished her time hiking in the Canadian Rockies with family and friends. She will be sorely missed. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to the Frances Aaron Hess Fund at Vassar College (24 Raymond Avenue, Poughkeepsie, NY 12604- 0725) or the Women's Auxiliary at Temple Emanu- El (1 E. 65th St, New York, NY 10065). Private funeral services will be held on May 14 in Pittsburgh, with a memorial service in New York City to be scheduled for a later date. 1/3

ALLISTER--Barbara. Never forgotten, living in our hearts always. The Allister, Kennedy, and Bloom Families 1/3

MYARA--Daniele. Aged 75, died in Manhattan on January 27, 2015. The beloved husband of Kay Lee Shadley, Esquire for over 23 years, he was a talented writer, photographer, painter, and author of "Casablanca Without Bogart" - an autobiographical novel. Born in Casablanca, Daniele lived in Paris, France; Spain; and Israel; ultimately settling in Manhattan in 1980. He spoke five languages, in addition to a strong proficiency in Latin. Daniele was a powerful intellect; a worldly, renaissance person, full of "joie de vivre" with an unforgettable smile and sense of humor. His friends remember him as strong, optimistic, charismatic, thoroughly charming and handsome. Daniele was intensely creative and had a love for art, music, reading, film, fashion, food, wine, and orchids. His career in fashion spanned from Malaga to Manhattan. His passion for animals was unparalleled, as was his kindness and tenderness. Above all, his love and devotion to his father, Juda Myara, was extraordinary. Daniele is survived by his adoring wife Kay Shadley and dear cousin, Bruce Elbilia. Daniele's life will be celebrated in a memorial service on May 16, 2015 at The Grolier Club. In Daniele's memory, a donation to the America-Israel Cultural Foundation to support young Israeli artists would be appreciated. www.aicf.org/donate. 1/3

HESS--Frances Aaron. The Women's Auxiliary of Congregation Emanu-El mourns the passing of our esteemed past and honorary president, Fran Hess. Beloved board member, her energy and commitment served as a role-model; her memory will be a blessing to all who knew and loved her. 1/3
ROTTER--Saul D.,renowned cardiologist in West Palm Beach, FL, died quietly on May 12 at age 103. He will be sadly missed by his family Stephen, Zoe, Janet and Patricia and David Barabas. 1/3

FREDERICKS--Tina S.,died peacefully at her home in East Hampton, NY on Monday, May 11, 2015. Born in Berlin in 1922, Tina left Germany with her family in 1933. She graduated from New Rochelle High School and attended Bennington College. She was a Mademoiselle Magazine guest editor in the summer of 1941 and mentored by Alexander Liberman, went on to become the art director of Glamor Magazine and later The Ladies Home Journal. She gave Andy Warhol his first published job - a drawing of shoes. In 1963 she moved to East Hampton to her summer house and somewhat randomly began the career in real estate for which she is best known. At Tina Fredericks Realty she rented, sold, designed or built hundreds of houses in the Hampton's. Responsible for some of the areas first seven and eight digit transactions, Tina had an encyclopedic knowledge of the areas housing stock and land. Twice divorced, she is survived by her daughters Devon Fredericks (Eli Zabar) and Stacey Fredericks (Jonathan Cohen) and four grandchildren. In ninety three enormously diverse years she never lost her creativity or her talent for reinvention. Zen in her world view, original in every way, she was a gifted, hardworking, fiercely independent woman who leaves all who loved her a legacy of resilience and self determination, good taste and great style. A private memorial service is planned for this summer. 1/3

RADUTZKY--Milton (Pete), died peacefully in his 93rd year on May 12, 2015. Milton Radutzky is survived by his devoted wife of 66 years, Marian, two loving and grateful sons, Michael and Richard, their wives, Kathryn and Leslye, and six grandchildren, Danielle, Sam, Kelly, Ben, Jack, and Sophie. Milton was born in Brooklyn, NY to Rae and Nathan Radutzky, who founded the Joyva Corporation, a confectioner on the Lower East Side, in 1906. A World War II Army-Air Force Veteran, Milton was stationed in Manila, The Philippines. In 1948, Milton joined his three brothers, Alex, Harry, and Max in the family business. The candy factory, his family, and golf were his passions, and he continued to manage the business with son Richard and great-nephew Sandy, until late last year. The funeral is scheduled for 11am Thursday, May 14, 2015 at Temple Beth Sholom, 401 Roslyn Road, Roslyn Heights, NY. 1/3

VANDERBILT-- Albert Rudkin "Peter, died May 11, Saunderstown, RI. He was born in 1924 in New York City, to Joseph Belcher and Adrienne Rudkin Vanderbilt. He attended the Buckley and Millbrook Schools and the Stevens Institute of Technology. He married Elizabeth Street of Port Washington, NY in 1950, after starting work as an engineer for McCord Corporation in Detroit, MI. He retired as President of the McCord Winn Division of Textron Corporation in Winchester, MA. He is survived by his wife of 64 years, seven children and four grandchildren. Relatives and friends are invited to attend a Mass of Christian Burial in St. Veronica Chapel, Narragansett, RI on Friday, May 15th at 10am. Burial will take place at a later date. Visiting hours are respectfully omitted. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation in his memory. Visit www.Nardolillo.com for online condolences. 1/3

KLEIN--Don, of New Milford, CT, on May 11, 2015, after a long illness. Don was a loving and devoted husband of Michaela, father of Jennifer Schwartz and Stephanie Di Christina, and grandfather to Graham, Eliza, Aaron and Lucy. He was a true renaissance man - an accomplished advertising executive, writer, car enthusiast and collector, global traveler and connoisseur; a dear friend to many. Don was a graduate of Dartmouth College and received his MBA from Columbia University. He loved advertising and creative and rose to SVP, Creative Director at Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising during the '70s, working on some of the country's most iconic brands. He was President and Creative Director of his own agency, McNamara, Clap and Klein, in the '80's and '90's. Upon retirement, Don wrote commentary and blogs for some of the country's leading automotive publishers and raced and enjoyed the action at Lime Rock Park. Donations may be made to St. Jude Children's Hospital. If love were enough, he would still be here with us. Rest in peace, dear Don. 1/3

HESS--Frances A. The HUC-JIR family mourns with profound sorrow the death of Frances A. Hess, a member of the College-Community for nearly four decades. Originally, a member of the Cincinnati and New York Boards of Overseers, Fran became a Governor In 1996. She had the historic distinction of being a third generation member of the Board - her grandfather, her father and she. Frannie served on the Academic and Faculty Affairs, Executive and Institutional Advancement Committees, as well as Chair of the Student Welfare Committee. She supported the College-Institute with devotion and she was loyal to the Reform Movement in its entirety. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her beloved children and grandchildren. May the family find comfort together with all those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Aaron Panken, President, HUC-JIR Andrew Berger, Chairman of the Board 1/3
The Lightning are one stage away from the Stanley Cup finals for the first time since 2011, when they lost to the Boston Bruins in seven games.
Warren went seven strong innings for the Yankees, who may soon have a surplus of starting pitchers.

South Korea’s spy agency said Gen. Hyon Yong-chol was executed by an antiaircraft gun while hundreds of fellow generals and senior party officials watched, but analysts questioned the authenticity of the report.
Chris Christie said the U.S. system of worldwide corporate taxation was like North Korea’s. South Korea is a more apt comparison.

LENGYEL--Livia Louisa Delej, passed away on April 24, 2015 at the age of 100. Hungarian by birth, she was raised in Berlin and sailed for the United States in 1937. She was dedicated to her son Peter Lengyel, her three grandchildren and her seven great grandchildren, who were all equally devoted to her. Her husband, writer and professor Emil Lengyel, died in 1985. Livia spent her career in advertising, followed by many years as a proud volunteer at the New York City Ballet and Channel 13. She delighted in all that New York had to offer, the joy of reading and the pleasure of a sunny day. 1/3

GRIFFITH--Dr. Derrick. The friends and colleagues of Derrick Griffith in the Office of the Senior University Dean for Academic Affairs at The City University of New York are devastated by the news of his death in the AMTRAK train derailment. We had the privilege of working with Derrick from 2003 to 2010. He is justifiably best known for his work in founding and inspiring CUNY Prep, a program that enabled thousands of out-of-school youth to earn high school equivalency diplomas and enter college during his tenure as principal. But, from the day he began, his intellectual and practical influence was evident in our work far beyond CUNY Prep's walls. For example, in 2008 Derrick was a key member of the University Committee charged with planning the Guttman Community College. His approach to work with young people was unique. It often appeared that he knew what they were thinking before they knew it themselves. When he spoke to them, they listened; when he challenged them, they responded; and, perhaps most important, when he believed in them, they came to believe in themselves. His ability to communicate and connect with young people who had far too often been told they would never be successful encouraged all of us to think deeply about our own work with youth. He had much the same effect on his colleagues as he had with students--we listened, we responded and we believed. He was a willing and provocative advice- giver. His convictions were deeply held and he seldom hesitated to speak his mind. His death has deprived the people of the city of the brilliance, the passion and the talent of an outstanding educator and one of its finest residents. We will miss him. Our thoughts are with his mother, Carlea Griffith, and son, Darryus Griffith, as they confront their loss. John Mogulescu, Senior University Dean for Academic Affairs and Dean of the School of Professional Studies, CUNY 1/3
SEIDEMAN--Abby Rachel. Nov. 18, 1974 - May 15, 2012. In loving memory. Mom, Dad and Wendy 1/3

GRIFFITH--Derrick. The Graduate Center, CUNY, deeply mourns the loss of Derrick Griffith, a 2015 graduate of the Ph.D. Program in Urban Education. An exceptional teacher and scholar, Derrick inspired students, colleagues and friends alike through his commitment to others. We send heartfelt condolences to his family. Chase F. Robinson, President, The Graduate Center 1/3
