GRIFFITH--Dr. Derrick. The CUNY Prep community is heartbroken over the tragic death of our Founding Principal and Director, Dr. Derrick Griffith--who transformed the educational landscape for out-of-school youth in New York City. Dr. Griffith was instrumental in developing CUNY Prep in the Bronx, an alternative pathway from the High School Equivalency Exam to and through college. Dr. Griffith was a true visionary and extraordinary educator, whose compassion and intelligence were paralleled only by his gigantic sense of humor and love for his students, colleagues and friends. His untimely death leaves a gaping hole in the world of education and in our hearts, but his legacy lives on in the school he founded and the countless lives he touched. "Bless your heart" Griff. Our deepest sympathies to his son Darryus Griffith and his mother Carlea Griffith. Principal Jenny Ristenbatt 1/3
DUDGEON--Martina Hoff. 5/15/2013 Time only enhances our admiration for your spirit, friendship and love of life. Joan and Marty Deutsch 1/3

FREDERICKS--Tina S.,died peacefully at her home in East Hampton, NY on Monday, May 11, 2015. Born in Berlin in 1922, Tina left Germany with her family in 1933. She graduated from New Rochelle High School and attended Bennington College. She was a Mademoiselle Magazine guest editor in the summer of 1941 and mentored by Alexander Liberman, went on to become the art director of Glamor Magazine and later The Ladies Home Journal. She gave Andy Warhol his first published job - a drawing of shoes. In 1963 she moved to East Hampton to her summer house and somewhat randomly began the career in real estate for which she is best known. At Tina Fredericks Realty she rented, sold, designed or built hundreds of houses in the Hampton's. Responsible for some of the areas first seven and eight digit transactions, Tina had an encyclopedic knowledge of the areas housing stock and land. Twice divorced, she is survived by her daughters Devon Fredericks (Eli Zabar) and Stacey Fredericks (Jonathan Cohen) and four grandchildren. In ninety three enormously diverse years she never lost her creativity or her talent for reinvention. Zen in her world view, original in every way, she was a gifted, hardworking, fiercely independent woman who leaves all who loved her a legacy of resilience and self determination, good taste and great style. A private memorial service is planned for this summer. 1/3

FEINER--Ronald E. The Board of Directors and Staff of St. Ann's Warehouse are deeply saddened by the passing of our fellow Board Member, mentor, and dear friend, Ron Feiner. For over 15 years, Ron was our lawyer, advisor, and number one consensus builder. He helped guide the organization through exciting and challenging times with his kindness, wisdom, and a good-hearted laugh. We send our deepest sympathies to Karen Brooks Hopkins, the love of his life; his children Daniel and Anna; his family and friends. We miss you, Ron. 1/3

LANDES--Nehama, passed away after a brief illness. She is survived by her sister, Dr. Ruth Arnon and two daughters Diana Landes and Susan Cohen and three granddaughters Lindsey, Alexa and Jamie. Nehama Landes was the devoted wife of the late Leo Landes. She was a wonderful mother, grandmother and a gifted pianist. She was very kind and was special to all who knew her. Funeral will be held Friday, May 15 at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 175 North Long Beach Road in Rockville Centre, NY at 1pm. 1/3

WEGIER--Hedy. The Board and staff of The Leir Charitable Foundations are saddened by the death, at age 111 1/2, of Hedy Wegier, the beloved sister of Henry J. Leir. She and her husband Maurice came to America from Germany in 1940, and together they were successful in business, friendships and family. She was highly intelligent, charming and dynamic throughout her long life. We offer our condolences to her daughter, Marcelle and to her grandchildren and great- grandchildren. The Leir Charitable Foundations 1/3

GAY--Peter. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague. He was a foremost intellectual historian of his generation, his interests spanning the history of psychoanalysis, art, and philosophy. 1/3

POLLARA--Bernard, MD, PHD, died peacefully in his sleep after succumbing to bladder cancer on May 10, 2015 at his home in Tampa, FL with his devoted wife, Jeannette, and youngest daughter, Julia (who he delivered at birth) at his side. He was 87. Bernard Pollara was born on July 28, 1927 in Chicago, IL to Sicilian immigrants Giuseppe and Dominica Pollara. He served as a Hospital Corpman in the United States Navy from 1945 to 1946. Under the G.I. Bill, he earned a BS in Chemistry from Northwestern University (1951) and an MS in Chemistry from the University of Illinois (1954). He went on to receive an MD (1960) and a PhD in Biochemistry (1963) from the University of Minnesota, where he did his Pediatric Residency and Immunology Fellowship. In 1969, he moved with his family to Albany, NY to head up the New York State Health Department's Kidney Disease Institute while also teaching pediatrics at Albany Medical College. In 1979, he became Chairman of the Department of Pediatrics at Albany Med, where he remained until 1994. He moved to Tampa, FL to become the John E. and Aliese Price Professor of General Pediatrics and Adolescent Medicine at the University of South Florida (USF) College of Medicine where he served as Division Chief, Medical Director, and Interim Chair, retiring reluctantly in 2010 when his health began to fail. Dr. Pollara had extensive expertise in immunology, having trained with the world-renowned Dr. Robert A. Good at the University of Minnesota. He led USF Pediatrics' clinical research initiatives and headed dozens of studies related to the safety and efficacy of childhood vaccines. Dr. Pollara was very dedicated to the training of medical students and residents and to faculty development, and was awarded federal grants that supported his initiatives in these areas. Among his many distinctions, he was awarded the Academic Laureate while at Albany Medical College. This year, USF honored Dr. Pollara with the establishment of the annual Bernard Pollara Resident Lectureship. He founded the Children's Hospital at Albany Medical Center and was dedicated to the care of children, particularly those in underserved communities. As an officer in the US Public Health Service Reserve, he worked as a visiting physician for the Navajo Indian Health Service in New Mexico and Arizona, the Migrant Farm Workers Clinic in Washington State, and the Black Feet Community Hospital in Montana. In 1992/1993, he spent a sabbatical in Bethel, Alaska as a staff pediatrician at the Yukon-Kuskokwim Regional Health Corporation venturing out into remote areas to attend to the first nation peoples, many of whom had never seen a doctor of western medicine. He was a gourmet chef who loved traveling the world, fly-fishing, betting on football games, and eating pie. He loved spending time with his family and was thrilled to see his grandchildren thrive. He will be dearly missed. Dr. Pollara is survived by his wife Jeannette Fleischer, his five children and six grandchildren: Dominique (Kurt Rosen), Sacramento, CA; Lia Friel (Jack) daughters Shelby and Christina, Weston, MA; Gina son Bernard, NYC; Julia Riggin (Ray) son Rayce, Wheatridge, CO; and Joseph (Gwen) son Luca, daughter Maya; as well as his sister Anna Schmidt, Chicago, IL; and his first wife, Joanne Pollara, Albany, NY. A funeral mass will be held on Saturday, May 16, 2015 at 11am at Christ the King Church (821 S. Dale Mabry Highway, Tampa, Florida). He will be interred at the Calvary Catholic Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Bernard Pollara, M.D, PhD Resident Lectureship at University of South Florida Department of Pediatrics. Visit the guestbook at BlountCurryMacDill.com Blount & Curry MacDill 813-876-2421 1/3

LINDENBAUM--Belda Kaufman. The Yeshiva University family grieves the passing of Belda Kaufman Lindenbaum, a widely admired Jewish communal leader who served as a devoted worker on behalf of the YU Museum, and on behalf of numerous educational institutions, and as a champion of women's Jewish education. She and her beloved husband, Marcel Lindenbaum '53YC, are long- time supporters of Yeshiva University. Heartfelt condolences are extended to Marcel and their children: Nathan (and Shari) Lindenbaum, Bennett (and Rebecca) Lindenbaum, Matthew (and Ray) Lindenbaum, Victoria (and Ben) Feder, Abigail (and Shai) Tambor and their grandchildren. May they and the entire Lindenbaum, Kaufman, Ghity and Max Stern, z"l, families be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm President Emeritus 1/3

GRIFFITH--Dr. Derrick. The City University of New York deeply mourns the tragic death of Dr. Derrick Griffith, Dean of Student Affairs and Enrollment Management of Medgar Evers College, a beloved member of our community who died in the Amtrak derailment that took place earlier this week. Dr. Griffith was well-known throughout the CUNY system, the City of New York and beyond for his exemplary leadership in education, including his outstanding service as the Founding Principal of the CUNY Preparatory Transitional High School. He served in a number of senior administrative capacities at Medgar Evers College in both the academic and student services offices, and he recently completed his doctoral studies at The CUNY Graduate Center. Dr. Griffith was also known by many through the high esteem expressed about his work and character by his many admiring colleagues. They were inspired by his profound dedication to the education of underrepresented youth in economically disadvantaged communities. Most recently, he accepted membership in a University working group focusing on men of color and enhanced educational success strategies. We extend our deepest sympathies and condolences to his family. Dr. Griffith will be sorely missed by all who benefited from his life's work on behalf of the education of the people, all the people. Benno Schmidt, Chairperson, Philip Alfonso Berry, Vice Chairperson, Board Of Trustees; James B. Milliken, Chancellor 1/3

RADUTZKY--Milton (Pete), died peacefully in his 93rd year on May 12, 2015. Milton Radutzky is survived by his devoted wife of 66 years, Marian, two loving and grateful sons, Michael and Richard, their wives, Kathryn and Leslye, and six grandchildren, Danielle, Sam, Kelly, Ben, Jack, and Sophie. Milton was born in Brooklyn, NY to Rae and Nathan Radutzky, who founded the Joyva Corporation, a confectioner on the Lower East Side, in 1906. A World War II Army-Air Force Veteran, Milton was stationed in Manila, The Philippines. In 1948, Milton joined his three brothers, Alex, Harry, and Max in the family business. The candy factory, his family, and golf were his passions, and he continued to manage the business with son Richard and great-nephew Sandy, until late last year. The funeral is scheduled for 11am Thursday, May 14, 2015 at Temple Beth Sholom, 401 Roslyn Road, Roslyn Heights, NY. 1/3

HESS--Frances A. AJC mourns the passing of a devoted leader and beloved colleague. We are so fortunate that, for 65 years, Fran was part of the AJC family, including many national and regional governance roles. She inspired us with her profound commitment to strengthening the Jewish future, building intergroup understanding, and defending democratic values. We are deeply grateful for Fran's friendship and partnership, and send our heartfelt condolences to her family. Stanley M. Bergman, AJC President David Harris, AJC Executive Director 1/3
ZUCKER ALTSCHUL--Lena. Happy 100th Birthday Dawda Lena. Loved and Remembered Forever and a Day. Cynthia 1/3

EVANS--James. James Hurlburt Evans of East Hampton and New York City, passed away peacefully at home on May 11, 2015. He was born in Lansing, Michigan on June 26, 1920 to parents Mary Hurlburt Evans and James Lafayette Evans. He graduated from Centre College and The University of Chicago Law School. Mr. Evans was predeceased by his beloved wife, Mary Johnston Evans, his son, Eric Evans, grandson, Douglas Madsen, former wife, LoRaine Bertram Evans, and sisters, Blanche Goetzman and Kathryn Evans. Mr. Evans, is survived by his loving daughters, Carol Evans Jepperson (Tom) and Joan Evans Madsen (Richard), step-children, Marcy Head Benson (Bruce), Paul Johnston Head (Jean), and Eric Talbott Head (Shelley Magness), four grandchildren and six great- grandchildren. He leaves behind his dedicated assistant, Kathleen Noonan Roskell, who served at his side for nearly 50 years. James Evans' illustrious career culminated in his retirement as Chairman of the Board of Union Pacific Corporation in 1985. He began his association with Union Pacific in 1965 when he became a member of the Board of Directors of Union Pacific Railroad Company. Upon the formation of Union Pacific Corporation in 1969, Mr. Evans joined its management as President and a Director. He served as President of Union Pacific Corporation from 1969 until 1977, at which time he became Chairman and Chief Executive Officer. Mr. Evans came to Union Pacific from The Seamen's Bank for Savings where he had served as President and then Chairman and President. Prior to joining The Seamen's Bank, he was Financial Vice-President and Director of Dun & Bradstreet, Inc., following the merger with Reuben H. Donnelley Corporation at which he had served first as Secretary- Treasurer and General Counsel and then was elected as a Vice President. His first position following his service as a Navy Lieutenant in World War II was with Harris Trust & Savings Bank in Chicago as an attorney and loan officer. James Evans was a former Director of American Telephone and Telegraph Company, The Anaconda Company, Bristol-Myers Company, Citicorp/Citibank, Dun & Bradstreet, Inc., General Motors Corporation and Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. He was a former Co- Chairman of The Business Roundtable and a former Member of The Business Council. Mr. Evans was a Life Trustee of the Central Park Conservancy (former Chairman). He also served on the governing boards of New York-Presbyterian Hospital, The University of Chicago, Centre College (former Chairman of the Board), and The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts (former Co-Chairman). He served as a member of the Board of Governors of the American National Red Cross (former National Fund Chairman) and the President's Committee on Environmental Quality. He was a Trustee of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund and the founding Chairman and Life Trustee of the National Recreation and Park Association. Mr. Evans was a member of the Racquet & Tennis Club and Knickerbocker Club, both of New York City; the Maidstone Club of East Hampton, New York; Alfalfa Club and the Metropolitan Club of Washington, D.C. Jim Evans was a brilliant, cultured, charismatic man with a charming personality and generous spirit. He will be sorely missed by his family, friends and those who had the privilege to work with or for him. Memorial service will be held at 2:00pm, Wednesday, May 20 at The Brick Presbyterian Church, 91st St. and Park Ave., NYC. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Central Park Conservancy, 14 E. 60th St., NY, NY 10022. 1/3
PFAHL--Charles Alton. MAY 15, 1946 - OCT 4, 2013 FOREVER LOVING YOU. SHARON

RADUTZKY--Milton. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Milton Radutzky, who leaves behind a loving family that carries on a tradition of exceptional Jewish philanthropy. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Milton's wife, Marian; his children, Michael (Kathryn) and Richard (Leslye); his grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3

HARRIS-HILLIARD--Audrey Peck, 87, died in New York City Monday after complications from cardiac surgery. She is survived by her son Dean Harris and daughter Alison Harris, their spouses Marcia and Wes, three grandchildren Zach, Anna and Drew, her sister Margot Serden and stepsons Brooks, David and Bill Hillard. Her two husbands Roy Harris and Merle Hilliard predeceased her. Audrey was born in Manhattan on November 18 to Florence and Harry Peck. She was educated at Fieldston, St. Lawrence University (BA), Yeshiva University (MSW) and Columbia Teachers College (Ed.D). For most of her professional career she taught Gerontology at a number of universities including UCLA Medical School, Florida State and Yeshiva. Audrey was an original organizer of the National Hospice Foundation and for her work received a Presidential Points of Light Award at The White House. She will be remembered for her devotion to family and friends, her sharp mind, passion for education, literature and the arts as well as her zest for life. Audrey was a friend and inspiration to all that knew her. Our family is grateful for the outpouring of love and support. Funeral arrangements are private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the National Hospice Foundation in her name. 1/3

Radutzky--Milton. Brookdale Hospital Medical Center mourns the passing of its former Board Member, Milton Radutzky. Mr. Radutzky's contributions to Brookdale's well-being will always be appreciated and we extend our deepest condolences to the family. Mark E. Toney, President & CEO

ROSENBLOOM--Irving Richard, "Dick" passed away Wednesday, May 13 following a courageous battle with pancreatic cancer. He leaves his wife Bernis; with whom he shared many happy years and who had given him such loving care. He is also survived by his daughter Amy, son David, grandchildren Alison, Michael and Dylan, sister Erna and brothers Arthur, Gerry and Dan. Dick was born in New York on June 28, 1925 to Sol Rosenbloom and Frieda Vogel. He spent spent most of his early years in Belle Harbor, Long Island and in 1939 moved with the family to Richmond, VA where he graduated from John Marshall High School. With the War on, and having barely attained the age of 18, he enrolled in the United States Army Air Corp's Air Cadet program from which he was commissioned a Second Lieutenant and assigned to duty on a B29 Superfortress bomber. After the War, Dick joined and served for many years with the family's Richmond based wholesale apparel business. After retiring in Florida, he decided to return to work establishing Richard Rosenbloom Associates providing merchandising and marketing services to a wide array of independent retailers which he successfully headed until the past year. Dick was extremely close and loyal to all his family. Strikingly handsome, unusually charming and energetic his warm presence was highly valued. Most importantly, he was receptive to the comments and thoughts of his many friends and sincerely hopeful for their well being. He will be sorely missed. Services at 12 Noon, Monday, May 18 at Quattlebaum Funeral Home, 5411 Okeechobee Boulevard, West Palm Beach, FL 33417. Shiva from 4pm, Tuesday, May 19 only at Amy's home. Telephone 212-674-5990. 1

CHARLOP--Helen, 99 years young, of Fort Lee, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Seymour, devoted mother of Linda Charlop and Steven Charlop, dear sister of Roz Robinson, loving grandmother of Rebecca, Samantha, Olivia and Lindsay. Service 11:30am, Sunday at Gutterman and Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ. 1/3

BERMAN--Doris Boris, 63, passed away on Mother's Day, May 10, 2015. Born in Innsbruck, Austria, she grew up in Salzburg and achieved recognition as a recording artist under the name Isabell Domin. To pursue a career as a multi-media artist she moved to the United States. She was equally at home in San Francisco, New York, Berlin and Paris. Her vitality and creativity touched many lives. She is survived by her children, Aniko and Max, her former husband, Russell, and her brother, Peter Quehenberger. Her family and many friends around the world will miss her dearly and will continue to hold her vibrant memory in their hearts. In lieu of flowers, please donate to Free Arts NYC. Private memorial celebration for her friends and family, Sunday, May 17, 1:30pm. 1/3

EVANS--James. James Hurlburt Evans of East Hampton and New York City, passed away peacefully at home on May 11, 2015. He was born in Lansing, Michigan on June 26, 1920 to parents Mary Hurlburt Evans and James Lafayette Evans. He graduated from Centre College and The University of Chicago Law School. Mr. Evans was predeceased by his beloved wife, Mary Johnston Evans, his son, Eric Evans, grandson, Douglas Madsen, former wife, LoRaine Bertram Evans, and sisters, Blanche Goetzman and Kathryn Evans. Mr. Evans, is survived by his loving daughters, Carol Evans Jepperson (Tom) and Joan Evans Madsen (Richard), step-children, Marcy Head Benson (Bruce), Paul Johnston Head (Jean), and Eric Talbott Head (Shelley Magness), four grandchildren and six great- grandchildren. He leaves behind his dedicated assistant, Kathleen Noonan Roskell, who served at his side for nearly 50 years. James Evans' illustrious career culminated in his retirement as Chairman of the Board of Union Pacific Corporation in 1985. He began his association with Union Pacific in 1965 when he became a member of the Board of Directors of Union Pacific Railroad Company. Upon the formation of Union Pacific Corporation in 1969, Mr. Evans joined its management as President and a Director. He served as President of Union Pacific Corporation from 1969 until 1977, at which time he became Chairman and Chief Executive Officer. Mr. Evans came to Union Pacific from The Seamen's Bank for Savings where he had served as President and then Chairman and President. Prior to joining The Seamen's Bank, he was Financial Vice-President and Director of Dun & Bradstreet, Inc., following the merger with Reuben H. Donnelley Corporation at which he had served first as Secretary- Treasurer and General Counsel and then was elected as a Vice President. His first position following his service as a Navy Lieutenant in World War II was with Harris Trust & Savings Bank in Chicago as an attorney and loan officer. James Evans was a former Director of American Telephone and Telegraph Company, The Anaconda Company, Bristol-Myers Company, Citicorp/Citibank, Dun & Bradstreet, Inc., General Motors Corporation and Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. He was a former Co- Chairman of The Business Roundtable and a former Member of The Business Council. Mr. Evans was a Life Trustee of the Central Park Conservancy (former Chairman). He also served on the governing boards of New York-Presbyterian Hospital, The University of Chicago, Centre College (former Chairman of the Board), and The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts (former Co-Chairman). He served as a member of the Board of Governors of the American National Red Cross (former National Fund Chairman) and the President's Committee on Environmental Quality. He was a Trustee of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund and the founding Chairman and Life Trustee of the National Recreation and Park Association. Mr. Evans was a member of the Racquet & Tennis Club and Knickerbocker Club, both of New York City; the Maidstone Club of East Hampton, New York; Alfalfa Club and the Metropolitan Club of Washington, D.C. Jim Evans was a brilliant, cultured, charismatic man with a charming personality and generous spirit. He will be sorely missed by his family, friends and those who had the privilege to work with or for him. Memorial service will be held at 2:00pm, Wednesday, May 20 at The Brick Presbyterian Church, 91st St. and Park Ave., NYC. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Central Park Conservancy, 14 E. 60th St., NY, NY 10022. 1/3

SPIZZIRRI--Richard D. The Juilliard School mourns the passing of Richard D. Spizzirri, a trustee of Juilliard from 1967 to 2001 and trustee emeritus. His wise counsel and good spirit were important attributes during his time on the Juilliard Board. He will be greatly missed by all. Bruce Kovner, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, President 1/3

FREDERICKS--Tina S.,died peacefully at her home in East Hampton, NY on Monday, May 11, 2015. Born in Berlin in 1922, Tina left Germany with her family in 1933. She graduated from New Rochelle High School and attended Bennington College. She was a Mademoiselle Magazine guest editor in the summer of 1941 and mentored by Alexander Liberman, went on to become the art director of Glamor Magazine and later The Ladies Home Journal. She gave Andy Warhol his first published job - a drawing of shoes. In 1963 she moved to East Hampton to her summer house and somewhat randomly began the career in real estate for which she is best known. At Tina Fredericks Realty she rented, sold, designed or built hundreds of houses in the Hampton's. Responsible for some of the areas first seven and eight digit transactions, Tina had an encyclopedic knowledge of the areas housing stock and land. Twice divorced, she is survived by her daughters Devon Fredericks (Eli Zabar) and Stacey Fredericks (Jonathan Cohen) and four grandchildren. In ninety three enormously diverse years she never lost her creativity or her talent for reinvention. Zen in her world view, original in every way, she was a gifted, hardworking, fiercely independent woman who leaves all who loved her a legacy of resilience and self determination, good taste and great style. A private memorial service is planned for this summer. 1/3

ROSENBLOOM--Richard. Farewell Dear Dick. Words can not express how much Danny and I will miss you. You were his hero from childhood and also became mine upon my wonderful fortune to become part of the Rosenbloom family. You were so handsome and charming, a true gentleman and possessed that rare quality of being able to impart your warmth and caring to so many; including this Italian girl -- Arrivederci. I hold your hand and smile. I do not cry. Arrivederci. Giovanna 1

SPIZZIRRI--Richard. Davis Polk & Wardwell mourns the loss of our friend and former partner Richard Spizzirri. Dick joined Davis Polk in 1958, became a partner in 1967 and retired in 1994. He specialized in corporate finance, venture capital and R&D partnerships. After his retirement, he served on the boards of numerous organizations including the Juilliard School and the Whitney Museum of Art. 1/3

WEGIER--Hedy. The Board and staff of The Leir Charitable Foundations are saddened by the death, at age 111 1/2, of Hedy Wegier, the beloved sister of Henry J. Leir. She and her husband Maurice came to America from Germany in 1940, and together they were successful in business, friendships and family. She was highly intelligent, charming and dynamic throughout her long life. We offer our condolences to her daughter, Marcelle and to her grandchildren and great- grandchildren. The Leir Charitable Foundations 1/3

HESS--Frances Aaron. Brooklyn College mourns the passing of Frances Aaron Hess, a member of the board of trustees for the Brooklyn College Foundation since 1992, who served in the place of her late husband, Robert L. Hess, President of Brooklyn College (1979-1992). A proud Vassar graduate, she was made an honorary Brooklyn College alumna by her husband; she also served as Honorary President of the Faculty Circle and as a member of the board of the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts. After her husband's death, she instituted The Robert L. Hess Scholar-in-Residence Program, and worked closely with the Ethyle R. Wolfe Institute for the Humanities to bring academic luminaries to campus for extended visits. A vivacious presence at alumni and Brooklyn College Foundation events, she left her most notable legacy by donating The Hess Collection on Ethiopia and the Horn of Africa and the Robert L. Hess Collection on the Continent of Africa to the Brooklyn College library. Thanks to her generous gift and continuing support, Brooklyn College attracts scholars from around the world who use this unique resource. Fran is remembered with fondness and gratitude by her fellow trustees and the entire Brooklyn College community. 1/3

THOMAS--David Gilbert, Researcher, Scientist, Executive, Volunteer, Loving Father, Litchfield. Research scientist and Executive Director at Bell Laboratories for 38 years, died on Saturday, May 9 at the Charlotte Hungerford Hospital in Torrington, Ct. He was 86 years old. Mr. Thomas was born on August 4, 1928 in London, England, and was the son of Alan Thomas and Elsa (Auger) Thomas. He married in 1957 and was the beloved husband of June M. Thomas. His United States citizenship was granted in 1960. The educational years of his youth were spent at Harrow School, in England, and at The Putney School in Vermont. He received his BA, MA and PhD in Chemistry from Oxford University where he finished his educational studies in 1952. Afterwards, he worked as a researcher for the Royal Military College in Kingston, Canada. While at a musical concert in New Jersey, Mr. Thomas met a scientist who told him about a place called "Bell Laboratories." He was intrigued and began working there in 1954. Once employed, his scientific mind flourished, and for the next 38 years he worked to create technological advancements that have affected our telecommunication abilities to this day. The first research he did at Bell Labs led him to the solid- state chemistry of semiconducting materials. Later, he directed his research toward the optical properties of semiconductors, including their luminescence. After becoming Head of the Semiconductor Electronics Research Department in 1962, Mr. Thomas conducted studies leading to the development of gallium phosphide light-emitting diodes, which were used extensively as indicator lights of maintenance equipment, control panels, and some new multiline telephones and business telephone consoles. A practical application at the time was the "Princess" phone which lit up with a green glow when lifted from its handset. In 1969, Mr. Thomas moved from research into development and became the Executive Director of the Electronic Devices, Process and Materials Division responsible for the development of electronic devices, including their materials and fabrication. During this same year, he was a co- recipient, along with John Hopfield, of the Oliver E. Buckley Solid State Physics Prize of the American Physical Society for his theoretical and experimental work related to the interaction of light and solids. Mr. Thomas was also the holder of seven patents, one of which was awarded to him and his colleague Willard S. Boyle. This patent helped lead to the development of the semiconductor injection laser, which is found in many electronic appliances. In 1976, Mr. Thomas became Executive Director of Bell Laboratories' Transmission Systems Division. His chief activity here was to oversee the development and design of a variety of transmission systems, and to assist in their introduction into manufacture. These systems included digital fiber optic systems for terrestrial use, and also submarine fiber optic systems for transoceanic use. The 1988 submarine fiber optic system that Mr. Thomas worked on was designed to increase phone transmissions from the United States, England and France to 40,000 simultaneous phone calls. One of the challenges that arose were sharks who, sensing the magnetic field created by the cable's high voltage, bit them. Thicker cable were subsequently designed to help with this problem. Mr. Thomas continued to work at Bell Laboratories until 1992. He and June then moved to Dallas, Texas where he briefly worked for a small electronics company and, in 1994, he began his retirement. Not one prone to idleness, he embraced the computer age with zeal by building his own and by using his skills to help organizations computerize their data records. These organizations included the Dallas District Attorney's office Division of Family Violence and, after moving to Litchfield, Ct., in 2002, the Town of Litchfield's Assessor's Office, the Litchfield Historical Society, the Greenwood Counseling Center, the Warner Theater, and the Susan B. Anthony Project. He also made annual treks to Avon, Ct. where he would help people to file their tax returns. Mr. Thomas was an avid reader and could be politically vocal about supporting liberal policies. He very much enjoyed the beauty and solitude of the nearby White Memorial Woods. Mr. Thomas was predeceased by his loving wife, June, in January of this year. He is survived by his beloved children Virginia S. Thomas of New York, New York and Victoria C. Thomas of New Canaan, Ct., as well as, granddaughters Eliza K. Lupone and Madeline J. Lupone. His brother, Gerry Thomas, resides in London, England. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to Charlotte Hungerford Hospital in memory of David G. Thomas, c/o Development Office, 540 Litchfield St., Torrington, Ct. 06790. Kindly visit www.rowefuneralhome.net to send the family an online condolence. 1/3

FORELLI--Matthew. We mourn the loss of Matthew Forelli in the early hours on May 9. Matt succumbed to a series of physical problems that had plagued him for nearly four years. Matt and his wife Martha were residents of Westport, CT and wintered at his beloved Ocean Reef Club in Key Largo, FL. No one who knew Matt will ever forget him. He was a complicated and unique man, who approached everything he did with limitless energy and enthusiasm. He was a truly loveable curmudgeon. In 1960, after graduating from St. Lawrence University, Matt married his first wife Sharon Briggs, fathered two sons Briggs and Peter, moved to Connecticut and joined his father's company Precision Gear Inc.; then located in Corona, Queens. PGI is now a seventy six year old aerospace manufacturing company that makes parts for both the commercial and defense aerospace markets. Matt was a sportsman. He loved both freshwater and saltwater fishing, hunting waterfowl on the Long Island Sound and upland birds in New Brunswick, camping by a stream, car racing and playing golf with friends and family. For many summers Matt spent July and much of August fly fishing in Montana, Idaho and Wyoming. With his friend Bob D'Ambruoso he co-owned "Headwaters Angling," a fly fishing and guide shop in Ennis, MT. Another Forelli entrepreneurial venture was a popular steakhouse/bar in Darien, CT called "Lock Stock & Barrel." Of all Matthew's good qualities, and he had many, the most important was his unquestioned generosity. Matt supported innumerable charities. To name just a few: Bonefish & Tarpon Trust, AmeriCares, Brigham & Women's Hospital, Kids in Crisis, the Ocean Reef Foundation, and his alma mater St. Lawrence University; where there is a Forelli Family Scholarship. Matt's generosity also extended to his friends. He had a host of them and he was always there for them. Whatever they needed - money, advice, a place to stay, a shoulder to cry on. In addition to his wife Martha, Matt is survived by his sister Margaret Urciuoli; brother Billy; son Briggs and wife Jennifer, their children Matthew and Meg; son Peter and wife Michaela, their boys Briggs, Beau and Brodie; his former wife Sharon; Martha's two daughters Brook Lewis and Diana Cuyler and her four grandchildren Hannah, Harper, Lily and Elias. 1/3

SPIZZIRRI--Richard D.,of Aspen, Colorado and East Hampton, NY died peacefully with his children at his bedside from complications of multiple myeloma on May 12, 2015 He was 82. Richard, the son of Anthony and Marie Spizzirri was born and raised in Oak Park, Illinois with his sister, the late Theresa Provenzano. After graduating from Oak Park River Forest High School, he graduated Magna Cum Laude from Brown University in 1955 and Cum Laude from Harvard Law School in 1958. Richard joined the international law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell headquartered in New York City where he practiced for 35 years before retiring as a senior partner in 1994. He was legal advisor to many leading investment banks and venture capital firms. As well as giving advice on a wide range of corporate legal matters, he specialized in corporate finance and structured and pioneered the use of research and development limited partnerships as a means of raising project-based capital for emerging biotechnology companies in the 1980's, including Amgen and Genentech. The use of these structures was critical to funding the clinical development of many of today's most important drugs, including Amgen's Neupogen, and Johnson and Johnson's ReoPro. Richard served on the boards of a number of technology and biotechnology companies and was an active investor in many entrepreneurial ventures. He was a patron of the arts and was a member of the board of trustees of the Julliard School of Music from 1967 through 2001. He had passions for art, gardening, classic films, music and was a long time member of the Metropolitan Opera Club. He was an enthusiastic sportsman, particularly as a hiker and skier in the mountains surrounding his Colorado home, and was an avid tennis player. In 1957 he married Lucy Irvine Forkner and settled in Greenwich CT in 1961. Together they had four children, Abigail (Kamen), Hillary (McAtee), Peter and Andy. Richard and Lucy were divorced in 1971. In addition to his children, Richard is survived by his wife Holly Leuders and his stepchildren, Margo, Jaime and Venetia Young, and his grandchildren, Alexander and Elizabeth Kamen, Haley, Jackson and Melody McAtee, Eliot, Nicholas and Alexandra Spizzirri and Lucas Spizzirri. A private memorial will be planned. Donations may be made to The Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation. 1/3

She is survived by her four children, Michael Mandell (Louise), Frederic Mandell (Rosny), Lenore Monsour (James), and Charla Barnathan (Michael), 11 grandchildren and six great grandchildren. She loved keeping up with current events and politics and was technologically savvy into her 90s, driving herself to weekly computer classes. Of all the things Della loved, she loved her family the most. She has been our constant beloved mother, grandmother, friend and confidant. She will be deeply and eternally missed. 1/3

ROSENBLOOM--Irving Richard, "Dick" passed away Wednesday, May 13 following a courageous battle with pancreatic cancer. He leaves his wife Bernis; with whom he shared many happy years and who had given him such loving care. Dick was born in New York on June 28, 1925 to Sol Rosenbloom and Frieda Vogel. He spent spent most of his early years in Belle Harbor, Long Island and in 1939 moved with the family to Richmond, VA where he graduated from John Marshall High School. With the War on, and having barely attained the age of 18, he enrolled in the United States Army Air Corp's Air Cadet program from which he was commissioned a Second Lieutenant and assigned to duty on a B29 Superfortress bomber. After the War, Dick joined and served for many years with the family's Richmond based wholesale apparel business. After retiring in Florida, he decided to return to work establishing Richard Rosenbloom Associates providing merchandising and marketing services to a wide array of independent retailers which he successfully headed until the past year. Dick was extremely close and loyal to all his family. Strikingly handsome, unusually charming and energetic his warm presence was highly valued. Most importantly, he was receptive to the comments and thoughts of his many friends and sincerely hopeful for their well being. He will be sorely missed. d'AYMERY--Gilles. Gilles d'Aymery, 64, died peacefully on May 9 at his home in San Francisco after a lengthy illness. Aymery was born in France and educated at the Universities of Economics & Law of Toulouse and Paris, and at the Institut d'Etudes Politiques de Paris. He began his career in the international oil and gas industry, moved to the U.S. in 1982 where he eventually became a computer consultant to small businesses, and in 1996 he changed course to pursue his true passion: writing, launching the Web magazine Swans Commentary, where he was publisher, co- editor, essayist, and political commentator. Aymery was a long-time advocate of policies that promote cooperation, equal allocation and sharing of created wealth entailing redistribution of revenues, collective decision-making on the control of resources, and underconsumptionism to mitigate growing human-made ecological mayhem. As a contrarian by nature and a secular humanist by affinity, he was never a member of or affiliated with a political party, and never embraced any ideological chapel. His socioeconomic stance landed him in the socialist libertarian corner, and he was profoundly antiwar. His work included endless correspondence with the political and literary hodgepodge, assiduous reading, and researching that resulted in over 400 essays and articles that can be read at http://www.swans.com/library/archives.html. Swans condemned the commercialization of the Web and refused advertising, instead relying on the contribution of readers to support publishing costs. Aymery is survived by his wife, Jan Baughman, their beloved pets, and her family; mother Anne and brothers Patrick and Marc-Antoine of France and their families; and numerous friends, writers, and readers who will miss his brilliant mind, irreverent humor, revealing insights, sharp analysis, and willingness to challenge conventional wisdom, while promoting poetry, music, arts, and culture. Private remembrances will be held in the U.S. and France. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution to the American Civil Liberties Union. 1/3

EVANS--James. James Hurlburt Evans of East Hampton and New York City, passed away peacefully at home on May 11, 2015. He was born in Lansing, Michigan on June 26, 1920 to parents Mary Hurlburt Evans and James Lafayette Evans. He graduated from Centre College and The University of Chicago Law School. Mr. Evans was predeceased by his beloved wife, Mary Johnston Evans, his son, Eric Evans, grandson, Douglas Madsen, former wife, LoRaine Bertram Evans, and sisters, Blanche Goetzman and Kathryn Evans. Mr. Evans, is survived by his loving daughters, Carol Evans Jepperson (Tom) and Joan Evans Madsen (Richard), step-children, Marcy Head Benson (Bruce), Paul Johnston Head (Jean), and Eric Talbott Head (Shelley Magness), four grandchildren and six great- grandchildren. He leaves behind his dedicated assistant, Kathleen Noonan Roskell, who served at his side for nearly 50 years. James Evans' illustrious career culminated in his retirement as Chairman of the Board of Union Pacific Corporation in 1985. He began his association with Union Pacific in 1965 when he became a member of the Board of Directors of Union Pacific Railroad Company. Upon the formation of Union Pacific Corporation in 1969, Mr. Evans joined its management as President and a Director. He served as President of Union Pacific Corporation from 1969 until 1977, at which time he became Chairman and Chief Executive Officer. Mr. Evans came to Union Pacific from The Seamen's Bank for Savings where he had served as President and then Chairman and President. Prior to joining The Seamen's Bank, he was Financial Vice-President and Director of Dun & Bradstreet, Inc., following the merger with Reuben H. Donnelley Corporation at which he had served first as Secretary- Treasurer and General Counsel and then was elected as a Vice President. His first position following his service as a Navy Lieutenant in World War II was with Harris Trust & Savings Bank in Chicago as an attorney and loan officer. James Evans was a former Director of American Telephone and Telegraph Company, The Anaconda Company, Bristol-Myers Company, Citicorp/Citibank, Dun & Bradstreet, Inc., General Motors Corporation and Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. He was a former Co- Chairman of The Business Roundtable and a former Member of The Business Council. Mr. Evans was a Life Trustee of the Central Park Conservancy (former Chairman). He also served on the governing boards of New York-Presbyterian Hospital, The University of Chicago, Centre College (former Chairman of the Board), and The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts (former Co-Chairman). He served as a member of the Board of Governors of the American National Red Cross (former National Fund Chairman) and the President's Committee on Environmental Quality. He was a Trustee of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund and the founding Chairman and Life Trustee of the National Recreation and Park Association. Mr. Evans was a member of the Racquet & Tennis Club and Knickerbocker Club, both of New York City; the Maidstone Club of East Hampton, New York; Alfalfa Club and the Metropolitan Club of Washington, D.C. Jim Evans was a brilliant, cultured, charismatic man with a charming personality and generous spirit. He will be sorely missed by his family, friends and those who had the privilege to work with or for him. Memorial service will be held at 2:00pm, Wednesday, May 20 at The Brick Presbyterian Church, 91st St. and Park Ave., NYC. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Central Park Conservancy, 14 E. 60th St., NY, NY 10022. 1/3

HERRON--Douglas M.,died Thursday, May 7 at age 72. He is survived by his wife Anita Herron, daughter Natasha Chriss, son-in-law Neil Chriss, grandchildren Abby, Noah and Sophia, mother-in-law Lucille Rhodes, sister-in-law Michelle Rhodes and nephew Kazio Sosnowski. Doug was a deeply thoughtful, caring man, a lover of language and literature, a serious and avid bridge player. He was a kind, sensitive person whose wisdom and counsel was often sought out. After an earlier career teaching Russian literature at Reed College, he worked at the Robert Louis Stevenson School in New York City for several decades in various administrative roles, including comptroller, acting head and CFO. Doug was a devoted and loving husband, a wonderful father and grandfather. His unexpected death leaves his family, co-workers and his many friends bereft. Donations in Doug's honor can be sent to the Robert Louis Stevenson School, 24 West 74th St, NY NY10023. 1/3

FISCHER--Dorothee, German galerist, passed away on May 9, 2015, at age 78. In 1967, she and her husband Konrad Fischer established "Ausstellungen bei Konrad Fischer," one of the most influential galleries for Minimal and Conceptual Art, Land Art and Arte Povera in Europe. After Konrad's death in 1996, Dorothee successfully took the helm of the Konrad Fischer Galerie and elaborated the existing program by gradually including younger artists. In 2007 she opened a second space, Konrad Fischer Galerie Berlin. A substantial part of the private collection and the archives of Dorothee and Konrad Fischer was donated by Dorothee and her children to the Dusseldorf-based Kunstsammlung Nordrhein-Westfalen in 2013. Parallel to the donation, the museum acquired an additional group of works from the collection. Dorothee Fischer is survived by her son Kasper, her daughter Berta and four grandchildren. The Konrad Fischer Galerie in Dusseldorf and Berlin will continue under the supervision of Berta Fischer. 1/3

LARSEN--Leslie H.,Jr., aged 77, passed away on May 13th after a short illness. Loving husband of the late Carol Larsen, father of Kari Larsen Pedone and adoring grandfather of Maddie and Ellie. Son of the late Leslie H. and Florence Baldwin Larsen of Brooklyn, NY. Graduate of Poly Prep in Brooklyn, NY '55 and Dartmouth College, Hanover, NH, Class of '59. Les served as Lieutenant Junior Grade in the US Navy aboard the U.S.S. Charles S. Sperry from 1959 to 1961. He worked for David Rockefeller as an advisor to his personal real estate investments and later as the Vice President of Rockefeller Center Development Corporation totaling 16 years with the Rockefeller interests. He continued on to have a successful career in commercial real estate at Cadillac Fairview and Landauer Associates. Les had many things that were dear to him - among them; the New York and then San Francisco Giants, the Montreal Canadians, Poly Prep and Dartmouth College. The family will receive guests at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY on May 20th from 5:00-8:00pm. Religious services will be held at the Shelter Island Presbyterian Church on Friday, May 22 at 12:00. Interment to follow in the Emily French Memorial Cemetery on Shelter Island, NY. Donations in his memory may be made to the Dartmouth College Fund, Hanover, NH. 1/3

SINANOGLU--Oktay (1935-2015), a distinguished, internationally renowned Professor Emeritus of Chemistry and Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry at Yale University, died on Sunday, April 19, 2015 at age 80. He was the youngest appointed full-time professor of the 20th century, as well as the third youngest full professor in Yale's 300- plus year history. Known also as the "Turkish Einstein", Sinanoglu's greatest scientific contributions were a theory of the electronic structure of molecules, known as the Many Electron Theory of Atoms and Molecules; Solvophobic Theory; Network Theory; Microthermodynamics; and Valency Interaction Formula Theory. Methods to address this 'election correlation' problem are still being developed today. In 1995 he was nominated for the Nobel Prize in Chemistry. Sinanoglu was born in Bari, Italy, on February 25, 1935 to Nuzhet Hasim and Ruveyde Karacabey Sinanoglu. His father was an official in the Turkish consulate there, and a writer. His mother was a journalist. The family returned to Turkey in July 1938. Sinanoglu came to the United States in 1953 to study at the University of California- Berkeley, graduating with a B.S. with highest honors in 1956. The following year (1957) he completed an M.S. degree at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he was awarded the Sloan Research Fellowship. He completed a Ph.D. in physical chemistry at the University of California-Berkeley, in 1959. Sinanoglu joined the Yale faculty in 1960, and was appointed Professor of Chemistry in 1963. Sinanoglu is survived by his wife, Dilek Sinanoglu and their twins. He is also survived by his first wife, Paula Armbruster of New Haven, CT, their children, son, Karacabey Levni Sinanoglu, of New Haven, CT; daughter, Elif Sinanoglu Armbruster of Arlington, Massachusetts; son, Murat Alexander Armbruster of Oakland, California, and three grandchildren. 1/3

TAYLOR--Laurance. Born October 14, 1936, Ryde Isle of Wight, England, Laurance died suddenly at home of natural causes. He is survived by a niece, Shirleigh Beeden and his loving wife of forty- four years Patti Cappalli Taylor. Laurance started his career in London at the age of 16, first as an actor, and then as a colorist for Vidal Sassoon. He rose quickly up the ranks at VS and was promoted to Head of Public Relations. In 1965 he opened the first American Salon on Madison Ave. in New York. The company relocated to Los Angeles in 1976 where in short time he was named a Senior VP and Creative Director. With the agency Peter Rogers created the slogan "If You Don't Look Good, We Don't Look Good" along with many other cutting edge product developments, packaging and TV commercials. A Celebration of his life will follow in June. Donations in his name can be made to the Best Friends of Animal Society or Unity of Savannah. Fox & Weeks Funeral Directors, Hodgson Chapel 1/3

MARTIN--Howard Curtiss, 62, died unexpectedly, but peacefully, at the family home in Brooksville, ME on April 30th. Curtiss attended the St. Bernard's, Brooks, and Riverdale Country Schools. He studied economics and history at Tufts University and worked as an economist for the Congressional Research Service of the Library of Congress. He earned his J.D. from the University of Virginia School of Law, where he was a co-founding editor of the Virginia Tax Review. Curtiss practiced tax law in New York with Webster & Sheffield and Paul, Weiss before joining Mobil Corporation in New York and then Fairfax, VA, where his areas of expertise included Federal and international corporate taxation, tax planning, and structuring complex transactions, work he continued in Houston, TX for ExxonMobil after the Mobil merger. Before his recent retirement, Curtiss served as Director, Washington National Tax for KPMG. Curtiss was born in New York to the late Lee G. and Georgina G. Martin. He is survived by his wife Virginia W. Drewry and their daughter Abigail T. M. Martin, both of Alexandria, VA and Brooksville; his sisters Eleanor T. M. Hoagland (Leigh W. Hoagland) and M. Kate Martin (John C. Shimrock) of New York, and Mary Archer Martin of Garrison NY; his nephew and niece Nicholas G. Hoagland and Georgina G. Hoagland of New York; and a host of friends. Please take a moment to write down and share your memories of Curtiss with his family and friends. If you wish, you may also honor his memory by contributing to a project or passion of your choosing; the Blue Hill Public Library, 5 Parker Point Road, Blue Hill ME 04614; or the Island Institute, 386 Main Street, Rockland ME 04841. Services will be held in Maine in August. 1

MATTESON--William Bleecker. 1928-2015. Everything in our father's life was carefully planned: right down to the way he died. We were assembled at West Point Military Academy for our uncle's interment on May 8th, 2015. The weather was beautiful, the church service was profound, and the soldiers were impressive and with their rifles and flag-folding and their gratitude for our uncle's service to our country. It was all very moving and maybe a bit too much for our aging father. He enjoyed a lively dinner with us, then stayed up exchanging animated stories with his sister about their childhood. When he went to bed on Friday, he had a smile on his face. Sadly, he never woke up. William Bleecker Matteson was born in 1928 and grew up in Mount Vernon, NY. He graduated from The Peddie School in 1946 and Yale University in 1950, and married Marilee Brill three months later. It was the beginning of a lifelong love story. He graduated from Harvard Law School as a member of the Harvard Law Review in 1953 and for the next two years, he clerked for The Honorable Augustus N. Hand in the Federal Court of Appeals in the Second Circuit in New York City and Justice Harold H. Burton in the United States Supreme Court. He joined the Debevoise law firm in 1955 and became a partner in 1961. He headed the Paris office of Debevoise from 1973 to 1976. He was presiding partner of the firm from 1988 to 1993. What was so great about Bill? Unlike a lot of powerful business executives today, he knew how to balance his career and his family life. He raised us in New York City so he could eat breakfast and dinner with us and still put in a full day at the office. He didn't want to waste time commuting out to the suburbs like his father did. His friendships were deep and often with other "giants" in the law profession. After our mother was in a devastating car accident in 1968, he promised that if she recovered fully from her countless fractures, they would live life to its fullest. In 1973, we moved to Paris, where we spent three unforgettable years. Bill was one of the leading corporate lawyers of his generation. He handled a lot of high-profile, interesting cases. He used to say that each one felt like a whole new job and he was always excited to tackle it. In 1979, he got a call while we were on vacation: Chrysler was about to go bankrupt, and could he become their lead attorney in the first bailout during the time of the Loan Guarantee Act in 1980. Lee Iacocca was so impressed with Bill's work that he asked him to join the Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island Foundation, a private-sector effort to raise funds for the restoration and preservation of the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island. Bill had three daughters who grew up in the 1970s, and he began to understand the importance of women in the workplace. He was known to mentor young female lawyers at his law firm. One of his mantras was "make your clients your friends and your friends your clients." He was a consummate client developer who worked to understand the people he represented and their businesses. He also lectured at Columbia Law School from 1971 to 1980, except for the years we lived in Paris. He truly believed in the law and we never saw him do anything dishonest, except when he pretended he didn't speak French to get out of a traffic ticket in Paris. Over the years, Bill was active in the International Bar Association and the Bar Association of New York. He served on several boards, including the French-American Foundation, The Hartford Foundation, The Salk Institute, The Board of Foreign Parishes, The Sconset Trust, The New York Institute for Special Education, The Peddie School, Miss Porter's School and Kalamazoo College. A particular interest of his was the U.S. Council for International Business (USCIB), where he served as a Vice Chairman from 1986 to 1999, focusing on key issues of world trade, finance and investments as the U.S. representative on the Business and Industry Advisory Committee to the Organization for Economic Cooperation in Paris (BIAC). We recently received an email from an old friend: "I heard about your Dad, but have no idea what to say. I planned for Bill to live forever." So did we. But in his own special way, his exit was as dignified as his life and career had been. To have spent his last day at his sister's side with the amazingly beautiful backdrop of West Point in spring, it might've just been his plan. Bill Matteson is survived by his wife of almost 65 years: Marilee; his sister: Anne Sisson; his three daughters and their spouses: Lynn Matteson and John Hoops, Sandra and Perry Helm, Holly and Marshall Pagon; and three grandchildren: William Matteson, and Willow and Samuel Pagon. In lieu of flowers: please send donations in his name to the Sconset Trust, PO Box 821, Siasconset, MA 02564 for conservation efforts on Nantucket Island, "his emotional home." A service is planned there later this summer. 1/3

POLSKY--Robert "Bob" Allen, 86, of Zionsville, IN, passed away May 6, 2015. He was born in Boston, MA, the loving son of David and Gertrude (Lowenstein) Polsky. DARWAZAH--Samih, founder and Honorary Life President of Hikma Pharmaceuticals, the FTSE100 multinational pharmaceuticals company, passed away peacefully on Friday 15 May in London at the age of 85. Mr. Darwazah was born in Nablus and educated in Beirut and St. Louis. In addition to founding Hikma, he served as Minister of Energy and Mineral Resources to His Majesty the King of Jordan and was a member of the country's Advisory Economic Council, as well as becoming a senator in Jordan and founding the Jordanian Trade Association. Mr. Darwazah was also an active philanthropist. He is survived by his four children and eleven grandchildren. Condolences can be sent to: condolences@hikma.com. 1/3

FORELLI--Matthew. We mourn the loss of Matthew Forelli in the early hours on May 9. Matt succumbed to a series of physical problems that had plagued him for nearly four years. Matt and his wife Martha were residents of Westport, CT and wintered at his beloved Ocean Reef Club in Key Largo, FL. No one who knew Matt will ever forget him. He was a complicated and unique man, who approached everything he did with limitless energy and enthusiasm. He was a truly loveable curmudgeon. In 1960, after graduating from St. Lawrence University, Matt married his first wife Sharon Briggs, fathered two sons Briggs and Peter, moved to Connecticut and joined his father's company Precision Gear Inc.; then located in Corona, Queens. PGI is now a seventy six year old aerospace manufacturing company that makes parts for both the commercial and defense aerospace markets. Matt was a sportsman. He loved both freshwater and saltwater fishing, hunting waterfowl on the Long Island Sound and upland birds in New Brunswick, camping by a stream, car racing and playing golf with friends and family. For many summers Matt spent July and much of August fly fishing in Montana, Idaho and Wyoming. With his friend Bob D'Ambruoso he co-owned "Headwaters Angling," a fly fishing and guide shop in Ennis, MT. Another Forelli entrepreneurial venture was a popular steakhouse/bar in Darien, CT called "Lock Stock & Barrel." Of all Matthew's good qualities, and he had many, the most important was his unquestioned generosity. Matt supported innumerable charities. To name just a few: Bonefish & Tarpon Trust, AmeriCares, Brigham & Women's Hospital, Kids in Crisis, the Ocean Reef Foundation, and his alma mater St. Lawrence University; where there is a Forelli Family Scholarship. Matt's generosity also extended to his friends. He had a host of them and he was always there for them. Whatever they needed - money, advice, a place to stay, a shoulder to cry on. In addition to his wife Martha, Matt is survived by his sister Margaret Urciuoli; brother Billy; son Briggs and wife Jennifer, their children Matthew and Meg; son Peter and wife Michaela, their boys Briggs, Beau and Brodie; his former wife Sharon; Martha's two daughters Brook Lewis and Diana Cuyler and her four grandchildren Hannah, Harper, Lily and Elias. 1/3

ROWEN--Mary Lee Morey, born in New York City in 1927, died on Friday, May 15, 2015. She is survived by her husband James, sister Grace, children Andy, Robert and Mary and grandchildren James, Nicole, Sam, Ben and Hannah. A graduate of Brearley and Wellesley, a teacher of history and a leader of civic and charitable organizations, she met James at the Lincoln School in 1933. Donations in her remembrance may be sent to The Brearley School. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 81st and Madison, at 3:30pm on Friday, May 22nd. 1/3

HIGGINS--Denise Ellen, of New York, NY and formerly of Muttontown, NY on May 15, 2015 after a long, courageous battle against a debilitating illness. Senior Vice President of Voya Investment Management. Member of JDRF Investment Committee. Beloved daughter of Joan (nee Finn) and the late Edward Robert. Loving sister of Edward (Frances), Geralyn, Kathryn and Joseph (Patricia). Reposing at Beney Funeral Home, 79 Berry Hill Road, Syosset, NY. Visiting Wednesday, 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Thursday 9:45am at St. Edward Confessor RC Church, 205 Jackson Ave., Syosset, NY Interment St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation, 26 Broadway, New York, NY 10004 or www.JDRF.org are appreciated. 1/3

HAYES--Michael A.,Jr., 80, trial lawyer, passed away at his home in Connecticut on May 17, 2015. Beloved husband to Sheila Hagan Hayes and doting father of three daughters, Michael was born in the Bronx on June 14, 1934, to Michael Sr. and Mary (Ross) Hayes. His distinguished courtroom career spanned more than 40 years as partner at Wilson and Bave, then McCabe & Mack. He was past president of the NYC chapter of ABOTA. He earned his bachelor's degree from Fordham University and law degree from Fordham Law School. He served in the US Air Force, rising to Captain and achieving the triple rating of pilot, navigator and bombardier. He will be remembered for his incredible wit and endless repertoire of one-liners. He was an award-winning photographer and skillful paddle tennis player. He is survived by his wife Sheila and daughters, Laura Hayes Morgan (Reginald), Allison Hayes Palsho (Chuck), and Susannah Hayes Jones (John); sister, Eileen Quinn (John), and seven grandchildren. Visiting hours: Abriola Parkview Funeral Home, 419 White Plains Road, Trumbull, CT 4 to 8 pm on Wednesday, May 20. Funeral services Thursday, May 21, 10am, St. Francis of Assisi, 35 Norfield Road, Weston, CT. Burial Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. Memorial donations may be made to Trumbull EMS, Trumbull, CT 06611. 1/3

Devoted mother of Harvey (Jill) and Tova Szporn; loving grandmother of Erica, Adam, Rachael and Joshua; great- grandmother of Zachary, Zoe and Hannah. Services will be held at Temple Emanu-El of Closter, 180 Piermont Road, Closter, NJ 07624 on Wednesday, May 20, 2015 at 10am. The period of mourning will be observed at the residence on Wednesday until 9pm, Thursday, 12-9pm and Friday 12-4pm, Minyan Service 7:30pm. Contributions in Yvette's memory may be made to Yvette Tekel Memorial Fund, c/o Haddasah, 40 Wall St., P.O. Box 1100, New York, NY 10268-1100. 1/3

FAVER--Allen. It is with great sadness that we mourn the passing of our retired partner Allen Faver. Our relationship with Allen and his family extends back over 34 years. To those of us who worked with him he was very bright and creative and an asset to our firm. He always took an interest in those around him. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Irene, son Jason, daughter-in-law Erin, and grandchildren Connell and Ryan. The Partners, Staff and his Friends at Janover LLC Certified Public Accountants 1/3

ALBERT--Louise, 87, died peacefully in her sleep on May 15. Loving wife of the late Floyd Albert, she is survived by her children Elizabeth, David, and Alice; her grandchildren Jacob, Zoe and Alexander; her daughter-in-law Muriel, son-in-law Alan and her brother Robert Spitzer. She was an accomplished novelist and teacher, an avid lover of Mozart, but most of all a woman full of kindness and generosity who always overcame adversity with hope and optimism. She loved life to its fullest and will be deeply missed. 1/3
HAMMOND--Patricia Dempsey. Dearest Friend. Because I knew you, I have been changed for good. bh

O'CONNOR--Patrick J.,passed away in the company of his family on Sunday, May 17, 2015 at the age of 83 in Rye, New York. The beloved husband of Dorothea O'Connor for 60 years and the doting father of Maura, Roderick (Lisa) and Kevin O'Connor; Patrick was adored by his grandchildren, Meredith, Caroline, Rory, Henry, and Dominick. He received his MBA from Columbia University and his PMD from Harvard University. He had a highly successful career in banking and finance which allowed him and Dorothea to live their lives to the fullest, especially travel in later years. Donations may be made in his honor to MSKCC c/o Dr. Howard Scher, 353 East 68th Street, New York, NY 10065. 1/3

HOPPENSTEIN--Reuben. Passed away on May 15, 2015 at the age of 81. Beloved husband of Raquel. Loving father of Tivia Hoppenstein Kramer, Ava Hoppenstein Shore and Charles Hoppenstein and his wife Keli, stepfather of Leon and Deborah Taurel, David and Margarita Taurel and the late Reina Taurel and their families. He was an adoring grandfather to his grandchildren who loved and respected him including Alana, Carson, Maya and Ariella. Loving brother of Hilly and Abe and his wife Taubene and their families. He was born in Benoni, South Africa and earned his medical degree from University Witwatersrand, Johannesburg, South Africa in 1957. He came to New York City in 1960 and trained as a neurosurgeon under Dr. Leo Davidoff at Mount Sinai and was then in private practice as a neurosurgeon specializing in spinal issues. He served on the staff of several prominent New York hospitals including the Joint Diseases, Mount Sinai and Beekman-Downtown. He was a brilliant inventor who created the first disposable plastic syringe and held many patents including those for numerous medical instruments, concept vehicles and glasses-free 3D technologies. He was an entrepreneur who produced the musicals "Jacques Brel is Alive and Well and Living in Paris" (Broadway, revival, 1988) and Dori (Off-Broadway, Toronto, 1988). He developed the first mega yacht marina in the Caribbean, Yacht Club Isle de Sol, St. Martin, NA. He was a brilliant, compassionate and innovative physician, a generous man, full of passion, humor and a beloved friend to all. As he said, "Most people dream in black and white but I dream in technicolor." 1/3

ROSENBLOOM--Irving Richard, "Dickie" a wonderful father and grandfather, who was loved dearly by his son David, daughter-in-law Michele and their children Dylan and Paige. You will be missed but never forgotten. We love you. 1/3

IOSEFSOHN--Marcel, of New York City, May 18. Survived by loving wife Theodora (Ticu) and several nieces and nephews. SPIELMAN--Carol. A magnificent woman with great presence, beauty, intelligence. Mother to niece Susan Schwimmer, grandmother to nephew Matthew, stepmother to Anne Dee Goldin. Loved by many. The world is now a dimmer place for those who were surrounded by her glow. 1/3

GRIFFITH--Derrick. Classroom, Inc. greatly mourns the passing of Derrick Griffith, our beloved colleague. Derrick was a passionate educator who greatly helped the at-risk students we serve. We benefitted from his wisdom, dedication, and sense of humor. We extend our deepest sympathy to his son, Darryus, and his family. Lewis Bernard, Chairman Lisa Holton, President 1/3

MONTALBANO--Dominick, 81, retired Civil Engineer with The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for 34 years, passed away on May 16, 2015 in New York City. Loving and cherished father of Perri, Jill, Matthew and Russell, beloved father-in-law of Brian, Steve, Carla and Sarah, dear brother of Carlo and Charles, and adored grandfather of ten. He will be deeply and eternally missed by family and friends. Services Wednesday, May 20th, 12:45pm, at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. 1/3

CALABRETTA--William. William Samuel "Billy" Calabretta, left his earthly body behind on Saturday, May 16, 2015, and entered his eternal home, a place that is peaceful and free from the pain and suffering he endured during the last months of his earthly existence. Billy lived a big life, being born to parents late in life who adored their only son, and older sisters who surrounded him with love. His personality, good looks and intellect carried him far in life. Billy lived life his way, all the time, even in his last years when confronted with trial and tribulation. Billy struck out to make his own life at the tender age of 19, after the death of his father. He made his own way in life, finding a place to live near the ocean that he loved. Billy put himself through school and had a goal for his future; a goal that he fully achieved. Billy built his business empire "brick by brick" and attained all that he desired in life. Billy was a shrewd businessman and built his business on the premise of a strong will and hard work. In the end, his strength and will sustained him when doctors and nurses questioned his ability to maintain life through such a debilitating illness. Billy was a Financial Planning Specialist and Managing Director, Wealth Management of Morgan Stanley Financial Group in Boca Raton, Florida. He has been honored in the financial world many times, most recently in Forbes Magazine maintaining his high business standards, knowledge and expertise even through the worst of times. It was this work that Billy thrived on and he was regarded in high esteem by his clients and colleagues alike for his business expertise both nationally and internationally in the financial world. Billy lived a full and blessed life with his beautiful and loving wife, Jocelyn Canning Calabretta, who cared for him to the very end. Jocelyn's love for her husband was beautiful to behold and a blessing to him during the dark days of his illness. Jocelyn lived true to her vow "in sickness and in health" and cared and nurtured Billy through the worst of times. Billy's family was devoted to him from his first cry to his last breath. Billy was a life force that drew people to him and he enjoyed the friendship of many. Son, brother, husband, nephew, uncle, Godfather, friend? Billy was and will always be surrounded by love. Billy leaves behind to love him and honor his memory, his wife Jocelyn Canning Calabretta, sister and brother-in-law, Deborah and Randy Renner of Delray Beach, Florida, sister and brother-in-law Connie and Kevin Brogan, of St. Simons Island, Georgia, nephews, Jeff Oliverio of Hollywood, Florida and Gabe Oliverio of Delray Beach, Florida, niece and husband, Jessica Windon Callaghan and Nick Callaghan of St. Augustine, Florida, three great nephews, Jackson and Liam Callaghan and Michael Oliverio and many loving cousins in West Virginia, Maryland, Ohio and North Carolina. Italian family ties run true and deep and Billy will always be remembered with love and smiles to all those who knew him and had the exceptional opportunity to be part of his life. Billy was preceded in death by his father, William Samuel Calabretta and his mother, Rose Oliverio Calabretta. Billy loved his mother dearly and cared for her diligently upon the death of his father many years ago. He was the very best son any mother could have wanted. Bill and Rose celebrate with Billy now, their much beloved son, and happiness and joy abounds in heaven. A Memorial Celebration will be held on Thursday, May 21, 2015, at Seagate Beach Club, A1A Delray Beach, from 6:00pm until 9:00pm. Acknowledgements to Billy's life will begin at 7:15. Family requests that memorial contributions be made to Trustbridge Hospice of the Palm Beaches. 1/3
DARVIN--Renee. ...to have, to hold and then to part was the greatest sorrow of my heart. Love always, Jerry 1/3

ROSENBERG--Alan S.,born March 29, 1930, died at his home surrounded by his family on May 15, in Wrightsville Beach, NC. Alan, a native New Yorker and his wife of 51 years, Ilse spent their married life on the Upper West Side of the city they both so dearly loved. Alan was a graduate of Stanford University. He spent what he would describe as the best years of his life in service the United States Navy aboard the aircraft carrier Midway and in London. Alan practiced law for the majority of his career with the firm Proskaur, Rose, Goetz & Medlesohn where he was known to be able to bring litigious parties together in peaceful, mutually beneficial resolution to problems that were thought to be unresolvable. He was famous for his straight moral compass and unyielding integrity. Alan's tremendous singing voice always entertained friends and family. He was active in promoting arts culture in New York City and numerous other charitable activities. He is preceded in death by only two months by his adoring wife of 51 years and survived by two loving sons and devoted daughter-in-law, two grandchildren, Adam and Chelsea who were the loves of his life and his best friend and sister Yvette. Alan will be sorely missed for his ever present sense of humor, his unflappable optimistic outlook on life and his wise counsel. A funeral service for Alan will be held on Tuesday, May 19 at Riverside Memorial Chapel with graveside service to follow. 1/3

DARWAZAH--Samih, founder and Honorary Life President of Hikma Pharmaceuticals, the FTSE100 multinational pharmaceuticals company, passed away peacefully on Friday 15 May in London at the age of 85. Mr. Darwazah was born in Nablus and educated in Beirut and St. Louis. In addition to founding Hikma, he served as Minister of Energy and Mineral Resources to His Majesty the King of Jordan and was a member of the country's Advisory Economic Council, as well as becoming a senator in Jordan and founding the Jordanian Trade Association. Mr. Darwazah was also an active philanthropist. He is survived by his four children and eleven grandchildren. Condolences can be sent to: condolences@hikma.com. 1/3

LAMBORN--Diane Diane "Didi" Douglas Lamborn, died peacefully in her sleep at home in Southampton. She was predeceased by her former husbands Anthony D. Duke and Hunter Goodrich Jr. and a son Barclay R. Duke. She is survived by her husband George D.F. Lamborn, a son Douglas Duke and two granddaughters Delaney Duke and Georginna Duke, a brother Barclay Douglas of Newport and a sister Susan Yawney of Naples, FL. She was the great-great- granddaughter of James Douglas, founder of Douglastown, NY, the great-granddaughter of William Proctor Douglas who brought Polo and the America's Cup to the U.S. Didi loved deeply her two goddaughters, Helen Christian of Virginia and Leslie Zimmerman of North Carolina and a relative she loved like a brother, Columbus O'Donnell, of England. Didi was born on May 30, 1933 in New York City to Barclay Douglas and Jane Elizabeth Foster. She grew up in New York City and surrounding areas thus attending The Chapin School, Miss Hall's School, The Westover School and graduated from Brillantmont, Switzerland. She was a member of the Colony Club (NYC), The Meadow Club, The Southampton Bathing Corporation, The Moorings Yacht and Country Club (Vero Beach). Didi had several business positions in NYC including the Manager of Donald Bruce White Catering, a job she loved most and loved telling wonderful stories of her experiences. She owned shops in Southampton where she lived on and off for over seventy years. She served on the Southampton Village Planning Board. Didi was a skier and an avid tennis and paddle tennis player. Didi was a Bronze Life Master, Director and owned an ACBL sanction. She had many bridge friends in both Southampton and Vero Beach. Didi for eleven years bravely fought a blood disease that eventually developed into Leukemia which was her last battle. No announcement of Didi's life would be complete if it left out her love of dogs. She was the epitome of the saying "Dogs leave paw prints on your heart," and she is now at peace and comfort with them having crossed the Rainbow Bridge in the early hours of the morning of May 6th, 2015. Didi requested that any memorial contributions be directed to ARF, Daniels Hole Road, Wainscott, NY 11975 or any other animal shelter. June 20th there will be a memorial service at 11:30am at Saint Andrew's Dune Church, Southampton. 1/3
