RUDIN--Lili, 1912 - 2015, wife of the late Rabbi Jacob Phillip Rudin, died peacefully at home on May 17th in her 103rd year. Mother of Jeffrey (Donna) and Jeremiah, mother to Stephen (Gail), and the late Priscilla (Rabbi Jack Stern Jr); grandmother to Rachel (David), Daniel, Wyatt, Cain, Rachel, Jonathan (Jamie), David (Nancy), Debora (Stephen), Elsie (Stephen), Kenneth (Nancy), and 14 great-grandchildren. She lived her life to the fullest, and never saw a day as cloudy, finding true love in her marriage to her beloved husband Jacob Phillip Rudin. Funeral services were held on Tuesday, May 19th. Family will be sitting Shiva at the Laikind home in New York, Wednesday 3-5pm and 7-9pm. Contributions may be sent to Temple Beth El, 5 Old Mill Road, Great Neck, NY 11023, in honor of Lili Rudin and Rabbi Jacob Rudin. 1/3

BLITZER--Susan. Susan Blitzer, 67, of Princeton, New Jersey and Portsmouth, Rhode Island passed away on May 11, 2015. She is survived by her loving husband and children, Michael, Marin, and David, and her two wonderful dogs, Higgins and Watson. Susan was originally from Framingham, Massachusetts and began her career in the retail industry. She started working as a salesperson at Jordan Marsh in Boston. After graduating from Russel Sage College in New York, she moved to New Jersey and worked in the old Princeton Bamberger's store. She then traveled the world as a handbag and jewelry buyer for Bamberger's (now known as Macy's). It was at Bamberger's that she met Michael, and they were married in 1978. But most of all, Susan will be remembered for her philanthropic work, as she was well-known for her successful fundraisers. When designing these charity events, she brought great vigor and creativity, and her style and taste made her fundraisers nights to remember. She devoted her energies to two causes in particular. First, she was a passionate believer in private school education and sent both of her children to Princeton Day School. For many years, she chaired the school's auction committee, where her auctions raised hundreds of thousands for the school's teacher development fund. Then, after her children's graduation, she focused on another cause dear to her heart - animal rescue shelters. She served for several years on the board of SAVE Animal Rescue, an animal shelter in Princeton, and helped run their annual gala. Over the years, she and Michael supported a number of causes, particularly SAVE, Boston Preparatory Charter Public School (the school where her son, David, teaches), and the Home for Little Wanderers (the charity her daughter, Marin, has supported for the last 10 years through her fundraising efforts). To her family, she will be remembered as an avid reader and a crossword zealot. She loved flowers, plants, and herbs. She took great pride in her amazing cooking. Her concern for others gave her an incredible determination to do anything possible, whether it was for the charity efforts she supported or the family she loved. This made her, above all else, a compassionate, loyal, and trusted friend. Susan will be remembered by her family in a private family service. In lieu of flowers, her family requests that people honor her memory by supporting the causes she loved most. Donations can be made to any one of the three organizations below in her name - the charities/non- profits that she cared most about. "You were the wind in our sails." - Michael, Marin, and David. SAVE: www.save-animals.org/ h-m- donations.html or The Home for the Little Wanderers: https://secure2convio.net/ hlw/site/Donation2?idb=709687175&df--id=1200& 1200.donation=form1 Contact: Shermika Turner: sturner@thehome.org Boston Preparatory Charter Public School: www.bostonprep.org/donate/ Contact: Anders Peterson: apeterson@bostonprep.org 1/3

SCHULMAN--Stanley R.,died peacefully on May 18, 2015, shortly after his 86th birthday. Born in The Bronx to Samuel and Bertha Schulman he was a proud graduate of Syracuse University's class of 1950 and received his MBA from Columbia University. Upon his graduation he joined the family business of Alixandre Furs, a company founded by his father in 1923. Actively involved in the business until his death he served as President for 65 years. Stanley worked closely with designers Valentino, Oscar de la Renta, Calvin Klein, and Perry Ellis, in creating timeless designs within the fur industry. Longtime supporter of Brookdale University Hospital, Schulman and Schachne Institute, where he served as past Trustee. An avid golfer, he was a proud member of Old Oaks Country Club for over forty years. Stanley was the beloved husband of Barbara (deceased), devoted father to Brett (Jill), Blake (Jocelyn), adoring grandfather to Robert, Sabrina and Sam, dear brother to Edwin (Dana), Jerry (Marlene), Maxine (deceased) and loving companion to Marcie. He will be remembered for his devotion to family and friends as well as his generous spirit. He will be sorely missed by all who were fortunate enough to have known him. Stanley always knew how to put a smile on someone's face. Funeral arrangements will be private. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, New York Chapter, 360 Lexington Avenue, 4th floor, New York, NY 10017. 1/3

MAZER--Dr. William M.,died on May 17, 2015 in Beacon, NY of heart failure six weeks short of his 91st birthday. Born in Newark, NJ in 1924, his parents and grandparents had emigrated from Poland and Galicia. As an Army Second Lieutenant, he served in Europe as a rifle platoon leader during World War II. He graduated from CCNY and earned a doctorate in electrical engineering from Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn. Mazer moved to Washington, DC in 1962, where he held senior research positions with ITT and the Computer Sciences Corporation. He later founded Electrodata, Inc., specializing in analysis of electrical failures and expert witness testimony. Mazer's first wife, Lorraine Oyle Mazer, passed away in 2002. He leaves behind his wife of eight years, Katharine Treat Warner. His five children are Mark, Ellen, David, Daniel "Banjer Dan" and Joshua Mazer. He also leaves six grandchildren, two great-grandchildren, his brother Art Mazer and his sister Leah Sobel. The funeral will be 12:45pm Thursday, May 21 at Cedar Park Cemetery in Paramus, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington DC. 1/3
SCHULMAN--Stanley R. A great friend. We played golf on weekends at Old Oaks for 40 years. His last years were enhanced by his relationship with Marcie. He will not be forgotten. Jack P. Schwebel 1/3

Irving described her as "an ordinary woman who led an extraordinary life." 1/3

SARNOFF--Arthur. Our deepest condolences to Joan and the family. A caring man of courage and conscience. Barbara and Donald Jonas 1/3

KROSNEY--Rita K. (nee Krasne), 87, of Palm Beach, Florida, passed away surrounded by her family. Daughter of the late Mary and Abraham Krasne. Widow of her beloved Bernard J. Krosney. Dear mother of Karen Ann Wagner and J. Wagner. Devoted sister of Belle K. Ribicoff, Charles A. Krasne, and the late Estelle Rubin. Mother-in-law of Jason Faller. Proud grandmother of Avery, Morley, and Ellery Faller. Stepmother to Herbert Krosney, Ellen Shockro, and Connie Norris. Step-grandmother to Ellen, Andrew, David, Christopher, Ananda Joy, Gregory and Jennifer and ten step great grandchildren. She was a graduate of Fieldston School and Sarah Lawrence College. Her first marriage was to Phillip Wagner of Armonk, NY. Her many travels around the globe, her winters in Palm Beach, and summers at Fairview Country Club with close friends were her raisons d'etre. She was a dedicated patron of the arts and a committed supporter of wildlife conservation. Her stylish flare was remarkable. She will be missed by all who knew and loved her. 1/3

WALTERS--Rupert Adrian III. April 28, 1973-May 20, 2010 To Our Beloved ADRIAN. Each day we remember your indomitable SPIRIT, your Generosity and your delightful Wit and Humor. You are Missed and Loved every day and your Passion for Life lives on in all who love you. Forever in our Hearts, Your Loving Family jeanwalters@optonline.net 1/3

STEIN--Frances Sklar, Beloved wife, adored mother and grandmother, hostess extraordinaire, school teacher and successful business owner. Fran died peacefully at home, where with Alvin, her husband of 67 1/2 years. She enjoyed a great life and raised her children Emily, Debbie and Tom. She is also survived by her beloved grandchildren, Olivia and Alex Grubman, and her son-in-law Don. Her great joy was involvement in the community, especially the Port Washington library and schools where she served as president of the PTA. Fran will be remembered as a generous, caring and loving person. Our holiday celebrations will never be the same. She will be missed terribly by her family and friends. Services will be held at Community Synagogue in Port Washington, NY May 22 at 11am, followed by interment at Nassau Knolls Cemetery, Port Washington, New York. 1/3

Apter, President Bryna Sweedler, Secretary 1/3

SCHULMAN--Stanley R. A loving brother to Edwin, Dana, Jerry and Marlene. You will be missed but never forgotten. We love you. 1/3

SARNOFF--Arthur I.,84, died peacefully at home on May 20, surrounded by family. Loving husband of Joan, brother of Paula Oreck, father of Susan (Jonathan Bram) and Elizabeth (Andrew Cohen) and adoring grandfather of Nathan, Lily, Henry, Julia and Jenny. Arthur was a proud 1949 graduate of The Fieldston School, was surely its longest serving trustee, and maintained cherished lifelong friendships with many of his classmates. Both of his daughters and all five grandchildren continued his legacy there. He graduated from Johns Hopkins University in 1953, where he was a long serving trustee and permanent class president. As was his way, he made many wonderful friends at Hopkins, through whom he ultimately met his bride, Joannie Goldberg of Charleston, SC, a Goucher graduate. From 1954-57, he served in the United States Army Security Agency in Tokyo and was awarded the Commendation Ribbon for Meritorious Achievement. Arthur was the president of Bruno Appliance Corporation, a distribution business started by his father, Irving, which was for many years the country's largest distributor of RCA and Whirlpool appliances. Arthur was a trustee of Beth Israel Medical Center and Continuum Health Partners for many decades. Arthur loved tradition and often joked that he was never one for change, choosing to spend 80 of his 84 years in the same Central Park West apartment. He was president of the Kenilworth's co-op board for many years. Throughout his illness, the dinners he shared with a group of special neighbors were true highlights. Arthur was the youngest child in a large extended family and his pride in his uncle General David Sarnoff's accomplishments was well known. He was thrilled to preside over the enormous and wonderful Sarnoff family Thanksgiving at his home in Yorktown Heights for many years. Arthur also truly embraced Joan's colorful southern family and was in turn embraced by the Dumas clan. In 1978 the couple purchased a home on South Carolina's Sullivan's Island and spent happy summers on the beach surrounded by multiple generations. The annual Shabbat dinners they hosted there were loud and delicious and are cherished memories of their loving extended family. Family legend maintains that Arthur was the first season ticket holder at the new Madison Square Garden, cheering the Knicks to their two championships with an enthusiasm he would later bring to his grandchildren's endless parade of sports games, concerts and the Fieldston fashion show. Arthur was kind and generous to so many people who passed through his life, maintaining meaningful relationships with classmates, neighbors, distant cousins, old army buddies and many of his children's friends and classmates. He was truly loved and he will be missed. Services will be held at 10:30am this Friday at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83rd St. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Arthur Sarnoff Alumni Scholarship Fund at Ethical Culture Fieldston School, attn Whitney Pollack wpollack@ecfs.org 212-712-6242. 1/3

STONE--Dr. Philip M.,of Roslyn Heights, NY, died peacefully on May 20th, 2015. He was born in Manhattan on August 23, 1916. He received his Ph.D in psychology from Yeshiva University. He continued his training as a psychoanalyst at the National Psychological Institute for Psychoanalysis under the tutelage of Dr. Theodore Reich. He is survived by his wife of 71 years, Regina, brother Irving, beloved children Elizabeth Stone Matho (Dr. Konrad), Suzanne (Paul Miles), Dr. Leslie Stone Hirsh (Dr. Robert), Dr. Joanne Stone (Dr. George Getrajdman), and precious grandchildren, Dr. Katherine Matho, Dr. Andrea Matho (Jean Delauney), Daniel Matho, Chloe and Sabrina Getrajdman, and Carolyn, Brian, Andrew Hirsh. Dr. Stone was a ceaseless advocate for his patients and continued treating them until two weeks before his death. He will always be remembered for his deep and unbounded love for family, extraordinary compassion and devotion to his patients and friends. Funeral services will be held at the Mount Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, on Friday, May 22, at 12:30pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Anti-Defamation League or the Israel Defense Forces. 1/3

COOPER--Jerome. It is with a heavy heart that we say farewell to our family patriarch at 86 years of age, Jerome Cooper. He has provided for us a heritage filled with love, respect and great honor being a role model to his children Karen, Paul, and Jonathan; their spouses Barry, Barbara, and Karen; eight golden grandchildren, Rachel, Danny and Amy; Brett, Perri and Bradley; Beth and Sam. His wife, Iylene standing firm at his side will always remember his love for Ohio State University and the many friends he always carried within his heart. He loved arguing cases in the courtroom and his presidency at Green Triboro and Jamaica Buses. Protecting his many employees was always a priority. Various ailments eventually led to the loss of playing golf, but he filled his time reading hundreds of historical volumes. We will miss his great sense of humor, his mind that was so on target and of course, his handsome baby blue eyes. He will be laid to rest in the Cooper Family Circle Plot in New Jersey, but he'll never be far from the hundreds who love him. Services Friday at 9:30am at Temple Israel of Lawrence; 140 Central Avenue, Lawrence, NY 11559. 1/3

USKOKOVIC--Milan R.,Ph.D. died on May 11, 2015, five weeks to the day after the death of his beloved wife, Nada, in Towson, Maryland. Born in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, he was a member of the resistance during World War II. After the war, he and Nada met at the Belgrade Polytechnic University where they both studied chemical engineering. They immigrated to the United States after he received a scholarship to Clark University. After receiving his Ph.D. in organic chemistry, they moved to Upper Montclair, New Jersey, where they resided until 2011. Dr. Uskokovic is considered a leading researcher in Vitamin D synthesis. Chemistry was his passion. He often quoted his fellow New Jersey inventor Thomas Edison; "I never did a day's work in my life. It was all fun." He has sixty-six patents to his name, and was inducted into the New Jersey Inventors Hall of Fame in 1994. He was the Director of Natural Products Research at Hoffmann La Roche. Among his accomplishments, he was on the advisory or editorial boards of six professional journals, a member of the American Chemical Society, and the New York Academy of Sciences, and a Regents Professor at the University of California. A laboratory at the Brown University, School of Medicine, Women and Infants Hospital of Rhode Island was dedicated in honor of his research mentorship. He is survived by his daughter, Moira Bogrov, M.D., her husband, Michael Bogrov, M.D., of Baltimore, MD; Lila Vidger, Ph.D., her husband, Donald Vidger, M.D., of Seattle, WA; five grandchildren, Samuel and Caroline Bogrov, and Madeline, Linea, and Graham Vidger; and his sister Vuka Markovic, of Belgrade, Serbia. His son, Charles Uskokovic, died in 2011. 1/3

PEARCE--Eli M.,86, on May 18. A resident of Manhattan and beloved husband of the late Judith Handler Pearce. Son of Samuel Perlmutter and Sarah Reitzen. Brother of Jay Horowitz and the late Marlene Moskowitz. Father of Dr. Debra Pearce McCall (and Scott) and Russell Gane Pearce (and Michele Hirshman). Stepfather of Michael Ruby (and Louisa) and Elizabeth Ruby Lyden (and John). Grandfather of Kyle and Alexander McCall; Seth and Jacob Pearce; Charlotte, Emily and Natalie Ruby; and Karl, Grace and Clara Lyden. Close family friend of Susan Ei. Born in Brooklyn, Eli attended Boys High School, earned a B.S. from Brooklyn College, an M.S. from New York University and a Ph.D. from Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn (now NYU Poly). After working as an industrial chemist at DuPont, J.T. Baker and Allied Chemical, he joined Polytechnic in 1974 as Professor of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering. He later served as Chemistry Department Head, Dean of Arts and Sciences and Director of the Polymer Research Institute. Elected President of the American Chemical Society in 2002, he led efforts to increase the numbers and influence of women and people of color in the field of chemistry, and to revitalize chemistry education. Funeral at Frank E. Campbell (81st and Madison) at 11:30am, Friday, May 22. Interment at Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY, 10532. Memorial gathering on Monday, May 25 from 8:15pm until 10pm and Tuesday May 26 from 2pm to 5pm and 6:30pm to 9:30pm at the home of Russell Pearce. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to the American Chemical Society Scholars Program for college students from underrepresented backgrounds, http://www.acs.org/content/acs/en/about/makedonation /scholarsprogram.html. 1/3

GINIGER--Bernard B. We mourn the passing of Bernard Giniger, age 92, after a long illness. Bernie was born in Mannheim, Germany, before moving to France and then to New York City. He served in the Counterintelligence Corps during WWII, receiving numerous decorations. In civilian life, Bernie worked in an art gallery and then a fine arts publishing house, bringing beauty to people around the world. He was a deeply ethical man, and a gifted storyteller with a twinkle in his eye and a sense of humor that could make you laugh in any of six languages. He is survived by his wife, Jeanne; his sons Michael and Edward, their wives, his four grandchildren, and a world of friends and relatives who will miss his vibrant personality. 1/3

SARNOFF--Arthur. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the death of our long-time, devoted member for over 50 years. We will miss his love of family, friends and congregation. The Sarnoffs are a mutli-generation Rodeph Sholom family. Our deepest condolences to his beloved wife, Joan, their children, Elizabeth and Andrew Cohen and Susan and Jonathan Bram, grandchildren Lily, Julia, Nathan, Henry and Jenny. Robert N. Levine, DD, Senior Rabbi Martin Flumenbaum, President 1/3

PEARCE--Eli M.,86, on May 18. A resident of Manhattan and beloved husband of the late Judith Handler Pearce. Son of Samuel Perlmutter and Sarah Reitzen. Brother of Jay Horowitz and the late Marlene Moskowitz. Father of Dr. Debra Pearce McCall (and Scott) and Russell Gane Pearce (and Michele Hirshman). Stepfather of Michael Ruby (and Louisa) and Elizabeth Ruby Lyden (and John). Grandfather of Kyle and Alexander McCall; Seth and Jacob Pearce; Charlotte, Emily and Natalie Ruby; and Karl, Grace and Clara Lyden. Close family friend of Susan Ei. Born in Brooklyn, Eli attended Boys High School, earned a B.S. from Brooklyn College, an M.S. from New York University and a Ph.D. from Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn (now NYU Poly). After working as an industrial chemist at DuPont, J.T. Baker and Allied Chemical, he joined Polytechnic in 1974 as Professor of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering. He later served as Chemistry Department Head, Dean of Arts and Sciences and Director of the Polymer Research Institute. Elected President of the American Chemical Society in 2002, he led efforts to increase the numbers and influence of women and people of color in the field of chemistry, and to revitalize chemistry education. Funeral at Frank E. Campbell (81st and Madison) at 11:30am, Friday, May 22. Interment at Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY, 10532. Memorial gathering on Monday, May 25 from 8:15pm until 10pm and Tuesday May 26 from 2pm to 5pm and 6:30pm to 9:30pm at the home of Russell Pearce. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to the American Chemical Society Scholars Program for college students from underrepresented backgrounds, http://www.acs.org/content/acs/en/about/makedonation /scholarsprogram.html. 1/3

MILLER--William J.,of Pearl River, NY died on May 20, at 91. His smile, zest for life, and gift of storytelling will be missed. Born in New York City, he graduated from Manhattan College. Served in the Army Air Corps during WWII. Predeceased by his wife, Joan. Survived by his six children, 10 grandchildren, and one great-grandchild. Nearly 70 years ago, he started as a stringer for The New York Times, eventually settling into the sports department, where his passion was track and field, particularly high school. There wasn't a meet that Bill didn't try to get the editor to give him space for these young athletes. His dedication was admired by journalists and kids alike. His media coverage has been recognized in numerous awards and hall of fame inductions. Funeral details at: pearlriverfuneralhome.com 1/3
SARNOFF--Arthur. Dearest friend. Our world will never be the same without you. Pat & Bernie 1/3

SARNOFF--Arthur. The Trustees, Faculty, and Staff of the Mount Sinai Health System mourn the passing of Arthur Sarnoff, beloved husband of Trustee Joan Sarnoff and member of the Board of Overseers. For more than 40 years, Arthur served our hospitals with enthusiasm and distinction, first as Trustee of the former Beth Israel Medical Center, then as Trustee of Continuum Health Partners. Arthur will long be remembered for his vision and commitment, and we extend our deepest condolences to Joan and the entire Sarnoff family. Peter W. May, Chairman of the Boards of Trustees; Steven Hochberg, Senior Vice Chairman of the Boards of Trustees; Kenneth L. Davis, MD, President and CEO; Dennis S. SARNOFF--Arthur. Arthur, you were an honor to the Sarnoff family. Jean & Eddie 1/3

KIRSCH--Richard A. Jr. Richard Alan Kirsch, Jr.,died with the same intensity with which he lived. He did not surrender to the diseases he battled for five years. He died of a brain aneurysm on May 20, 2015 surrounded by his family. Bigger than life fit Rick. His treasured pack of friends tell unbelievable, but true stories. Backcountry skiing, single-track biking, ice climbing, mountaineering: Rick knew what he loved and he did it, even during his illness. Rick adored his wife, Jodie, and his children, Samantha, Sophie and Jackson. His family was the center of his life. Jodie was his favorite companion and constant support, and especially during the difficult last years of his life. He was fiercely proud of his kids' many accomplishments. Rick had a very successful Rockefeller Center practice as a board-certified prosthodontist since 1990. His empathy, uncompromising ethics, quality of treatment and his brutal honesty brought him a steady influx of patients, and imbued his professional relationships with the warmth of personal ones. From Methuen, MA, Rick stayed close to his extended family all his life. He was devoted to his mother, Gloria, and checked in daily with his brother, Rob. He established and maintained deep connections with people. He had numerous life-long friends and formed strong attachments with his professional colleagues and his patients. We all loved him back. He could be opinionated, stubborn and demanding. But he came from his heart, and from his intense commitment to what he believed was right. He engaged all who knew him more fully with life because he engaged so fully with it. Our lives are richer as a result. Services will be held on Saturday, May 23, 2015 at 2 pm at All Saints Episcopal Church, Scarborough Road, Briarcliff Manor. Please make a memorial donation to the Mount Washington Observatory instead of flowers.

ALSON--Elaine Sloane. 91, of Stamford, CT and Singer Island, FL, and long-time resident of Harrison, NY, died Wednesday in Stamford, CT. A homemaker and dedicated volunteer for many charitable organizations including The Lighthouse for the Blind, New York Presbyterian Hospital Westchester Division children's unit, and the Anti- Defamation League of B'nai Brith. She was a national record holding swimmer at the Broadwood Athletic Club in Philadelphia and a captain of the University of Pennsylvania's women's swimming team, as well as a member of the Penn Varsity golf team and president of the Women's Athletic Association. She was a club champion golfer, as well as a world record holding fly fisherman along with her dearly beloved husband of 60 years, Ernest Stanley Alson, who predeceased her in 2005. Cherished by children Andrew and his wife Diane, Marjorie and her husband Wayne Landis, and Lynn and her husband Michael Canning, and by brothers-in-law Lawrence Alson and Morris Feinson. She was beloved by her grandchildren, Jonathan, David, Lindsay and her husband Taylor Hackbarth, Robin, Julie and her husband Ben Porter, Sarah, Michael and his wife Alison and Amie and her fiance Michael Dell, as well as her great-grandchildren Oliver, Miles, and Lilly, and by all who knew her. She was predeceased by her beloved sister Rita "Billie" Sloane Feinson and her beloved sister-in-law Elizabeth "Libby" Alson. Services Friday, May 22, 2015 at 1pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Mount Vernon, NY. Contributions may be made to New York Times 100 Neediest Cases. 1/3
RUSSELL--Maria Muzio. January 29, 1930 -May 22, 2000 She loved and cared about so many. Her memory is still with us. Faulkner "The past is never dead, it's not even past." Love, Muzio Family 1/3

PARTRIDGE--Martha Gail. August 17, 1937 - May 17, 2015 Daughter of James and Virginia Partridge, sister of Jean Partridge MacAllister (deceased). Born in Palmerton, Pennsylvania, Gail lived everywhere from Wilmington, Delaware to New York City to Edgartown, MA to New Canaan, CT and, finally, New Orleans, LA. She attended the University of Delaware and worked as a real estate agent for Brown Harris Stevens in New York before devoting herself to her family. She was a quick-witted puzzle and game lover, an antiques aficionado, a movie buff, and an avid knitter who was the consummate hostess and life of the party. She was elegant and creative, always served the best hors d'oeuvres, delivered the snappiest one-liners and never skipped dessert. She died on May 17th from heart failure surrounded by her loved ones. Gail is survived by her children, Jesse Weisman and Jean Weisman Sharkey, and beloved step- daughter, Katie Weisman Desvallees, her sons-in-law Devin Sharkey and Christian Desvallees, nieces Phoebe and Daisy Vreeland, grand- nieces Caroline, Alexandra and Satya, as well as her four loving grandchildren, William, Lucie, Tucker and Sunny. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to The Children's Hospital of New Orleans (www.chnola.org) or the ASPCA (www.aspca.org) 1/3

STONE--Dr. Philip M.,of Roslyn Heights, NY, died peacefully on May 20th, 2015. He was born in Manhattan on August 23, 1916. He received his Ph.D in psychology from Yeshiva University. He continued his training as a psychoanalyst at the National Psychological Institute for Psychoanalysis under the tutelage of Dr. Theodore Reich. He is survived by his wife of 71 years, Regina, brother Irving, beloved children Elizabeth Stone Matho (Dr. Konrad), Suzanne (Paul Miles), Dr. Leslie Stone Hirsh (Dr. Robert), Dr. Joanne Stone (Dr. George Getrajdman), and precious grandchildren, Dr. Katherine Matho, Dr. Andrea Matho (Jean Delauney), Daniel Matho, Chloe and Sabrina Getrajdman, and Carolyn, Brian, Andrew Hirsh. Dr. Stone was a ceaseless advocate for his patients and continued treating them until two weeks before his death. He will always be remembered for his deep and unbounded love for family, extraordinary compassion and devotion to his patients and friends. Funeral services will be held at the Mount Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, on Friday, May 22, at 12:30pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Anti-Defamation League or the Israel Defense Forces. 1/3

COOPER--Jerome. It is with a heavy heart that we say farewell to our family patriarch at 86 years of age, Jerome Cooper. He has provided for us a heritage filled with love, respect and great honor being a role model to his children Karen, Paul, and Jonathan; their spouses Barry, Barbara, and Karen; eight golden grandchildren, Rachel, Danny and Amy; Brett, Perri and Bradley; Beth and Sam. His wife, Iylene standing firm at his side will always remember his love for Ohio State University and the many friends he always carried within his heart. He loved arguing cases in the courtroom and his presidency at Green Triboro and Jamaica Buses. Protecting his many employees was always a priority. Various ailments eventually led to the loss of playing golf, but he filled his time reading hundreds of historical volumes. We will miss his great sense of humor, his mind that was so on target and of course, his handsome baby blue eyes. He will be laid to rest in the Cooper Family Circle Plot in New Jersey, but he'll never be far from the hundreds who love him. Services Friday at 9:30am at Temple Israel of Lawrence; 140 Central Avenue, Lawrence, NY 11559. 1/3

STEIN--Frances Sklar, Beloved wife, adored mother and grandmother, hostess extraordinaire, school teacher and successful business owner. Fran died peacefully at home, where with Alvin, her husband of 67 1/2 years, she enjoyed a great life and raised her children Emily, Debbie and Tom. She is also survived by her beloved grandchildren, Olivia and Alex Grubman, and her son-in-law Don. ROCKEFELLER-- Margaretta "Happy" Our beloved Mother, Margaretta "Happy" Fitler Rockefeller, peacefully passed away in her sleep on the morning of Tuesday, May 19. Her children and many loved ones gathered around her in loving memory. We are blessed that up until her death, she was happily active and engaged with her family, beloved friends and interests. Throughout her life, our Mother was a constant inspiration and source of profound love and wisdom for her family and friends. Our Mother cared deeply about her family, friends, and the well being of others. During World War II, she served in the American Women's Volunteer Service and also served as a nurse's aide in the Philadelphia Naval Hospital assisting the wounded. She had a keen interest in understanding and spending time with different peoples and cultures. She worked quietly to promote mutual understanding and had an uncanny ability to generate understanding and respect among people of different backgrounds and views. As First Lady of New York and Second Lady of the United States and as a concerned and interested citizen, she visited all parts of the globe. She was appointed to two terms as a public delegate to the United Nations by President George H. W. Bush in 1991 and 1992, serving under US Ambassador Thomas Pickering. After her service, she continued to advance her country's interests there and host important gatherings. She had a deep love of learning and read throughout her life historical novels and history. She was proud of how her heritage and her family had helped America over the years. Her great-great- grandfather, General George Meade, was Commander of the Union Army at the Battle of Gettysburg. She was the great granddaughter of Edwin H. Fitler, former Mayor of Philadelphia. And she was also descended from Jonathan Dickenson, the founder of Princeton University, and Joseph Harrison, who built the railroads in Russia under Tsar Nicholas II. As a breast cancer survivor enduring two mastectomies shortly after her husband Nelson Rockefeller became Vice President of the United States, she played an important role, along with First Lady Betty Ford, in helping people gain a greater awareness of breast cancer and its detection. Her charitable interests included heartfelt support for the Philadelphia Orchestra and its annual visits to China and the orchestra's mission of promoting international understanding. She supported the Franklin D. Roosevelt Four Freedoms Park in New York City, the Central Park Conservancy, the Rockefeller State Park Preserve, and served on the Board of Historic Hudson Valley and as a Trustee of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund. She served as Chairman of the Board of the Saratoga Performing Arts Center (SPAC) from its formation in 1966 until 1973 and was named as Honorary Chairperson for SPAC's 50th Anniversary Celebration in 2016. As a Mother she guided us with her steadfast love and thoughtful insights and understanding of people and the world. She taught us the value and importance of friends and family and country. She shared with us her deep love of nature from which she drew strength and spirituality. She delighted in feeding birds and wildlife near her home. For over thirty five years she was a dedicated swimmer nearly every day. She deeply enjoyed taking long walks with loved ones as often as she could. Mom was a kind and giving woman, who left us with loving memories that will remain forever. Our Mother, above all, was dedicated to her immediate and extended family and to many dear friends. She greatly loved spending time with her children, including Malinda Menotti who passed away in 2005, and fourteen grandchildren. She had a firm belief in the importance of family and the nurturing, support, and perspective it provides. On Tuesday, June 9 there will be a private funeral with family and close friends. In September there will be a Memorial Celebration of her life. We greatly miss her and we will always be guided by her wisdom and love. The Children of Mrs. Nelson A. "Happy" Rockefeller; James B. Murphy, Wendy M. Bickford, Carol M. Lyden, Nelson A. Rockefeller, Jr., Mark F. Rockefeller. 1

SARNOFF--Arthur I.,84, died peacefully at home on May 20, surrounded by family. Loving husband of Joan, brother of Paula Oreck, father of Susan (Jonathan Bram) and Elizabeth (Andrew Cohen) and adoring grandfather of Nathan, Lily, Henry, Julia and Jenny. Arthur was a proud 1949 graduate of The Fieldston School, was surely its longest serving trustee, and maintained cherished lifelong friendships with many of his classmates. Both of his daughters and all five grandchildren continued his legacy there. He graduated from Johns Hopkins University in 1953, where he was a long serving trustee and permanent class president. As was his way, he made many wonderful friends at Hopkins, through whom he ultimately met his bride, Joannie Goldberg of Charleston, SC, a Goucher graduate. From 1954-57, he served in the United States Army Security Agency in Tokyo and was awarded the Commendation Ribbon for Meritorious Achievement. Arthur was the president of Bruno Appliance Corporation, a distribution business started by his father, Irving, which was for many years the country's largest distributor of RCA and Whirlpool appliances. Arthur was a trustee of Beth Israel Medical Center and Continuum Health Partners for many decades. Arthur loved tradition and often joked that he was never one for change, choosing to spend 80 of his 84 years in the same Central Park West apartment. He was president of the Kenilworth's co-op board for many years. Throughout his illness, the dinners he shared with a group of special neighbors were true highlights. Arthur was the youngest child in a large extended family and his pride in his uncle General David Sarnoff's accomplishments was well known. He was thrilled to preside over the enormous and wonderful Sarnoff family Thanksgiving at his home in Yorktown Heights for many years. Arthur also truly embraced Joan's colorful southern family and was in turn embraced by the Dumas clan. In 1978 the couple purchased a home on South Carolina's Sullivan's Island and spent happy summers on the beach surrounded by multiple generations. The annual Shabbat dinners they hosted there were loud and delicious and are cherished memories of their loving extended family. Family legend maintains that Arthur was the first season ticket holder at the new Madison Square Garden, cheering the Knicks to their two championships with an enthusiasm he would later bring to his grandchildren's endless parade of sports games, concerts and the Fieldston fashion show. Arthur was kind and generous to so many people who passed through his life, maintaining meaningful relationships with classmates, neighbors, distant cousins, old army buddies and many of his children's friends and classmates. He was truly loved and he will be missed. Services will be held at 10:30am this Friday at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83rd St. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Arthur Sarnoff Alumni Scholarship Fund at Ethical Culture Fieldston School, attn Whitney Pollack wpollack@ecfs.org 212-712-6242. 1/3
SCHWARTZ--Selma J. Nov. 2, 1912 - May 22, 2013 Two years without you, missing you every day. All our love, Estelle and Alan 1/3

PARTRIDGE--Martha Gail. August 17, 1937 - May 17, 2015 Daughter of James and Virginia Partridge, sister of Jean Partridge MacAllister (deceased). Born in Palmerton, Pennsylvania, Gail lived everywhere from Wilmington, Delaware to New York City to Edgartown, MA to New Canaan, CT and, finally, New Orleans, LA. She attended the University of Delaware and worked as a real estate agent for Brown Harris Stevens in New York before devoting herself to her family. She was a quick-witted puzzle and game lover, an antiques aficionado, a movie buff, and an avid knitter who was the consummate hostess and life of the party. She was elegant and creative, always served the best hors d'oeuvres, delivered the snappiest one-liners and never skipped dessert. She died on May 17th from heart failure surrounded by her loved ones. Gail is survived by her children, Jesse Weisman and Jean Weisman Sharkey, and beloved step- daughter, Katie Weisman Desvallees, her sons-in-law Devin Sharkey and Christian Desvallees, nieces Phoebe and Daisy Vreeland, grand- nieces Caroline, Alexandra and Satya, as well as her four loving grandchildren, William, Lucie, Tucker and Sunny. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to The Children's Hospital of New Orleans (www.chnola.org) or the ASPCA (www.aspca.org) 1/3
STORCH--George. Always in our hearts and thoughts. We miss you very much. 1/3
CHAIFETZ--Charlotte. Although 30 years have passed, the memory of your love and devotion are forever with us. Rest in peace. Barry & Maureen 1/3

KIRSCH--Richard A. Jr. Richard Alan Kirsch, Jr.,died with the same intensity with which he lived. He did not surrender to the diseases he battled for five years. He died of a brain aneurysm on May 20, 2015 surrounded by his family. Bigger than life fit Rick. His treasured pack of friends tell unbelievable, but true stories. Backcountry skiing, single-track biking, ice climbing, mountaineering: Rick knew what he loved and he did it, even during his illness. Rick adored his wife, Jodie, and his children, Samantha, Sophie and Jackson. His family was the center of his life. Jodie was his favorite companion and constant support, and especially during the difficult last years of his life. He was fiercely proud of his kids' many accomplishments. Rick had a very successful Rockefeller Center practice as a board-certified prosthodontist since 1990. His empathy, uncompromising ethics, quality of treatment and his brutal honesty brought him a steady influx of patients, and imbued his professional relationships with the warmth of personal ones. From Methuen, MA, Rick stayed close to his extended family all his life. He was devoted to his mother, Gloria, and checked in daily with his brother, Rob. He established and maintained deep connections with people. He had numerous life-long friends and formed strong attachments with his professional colleagues and his patients. We all loved him back. He could be opinionated, stubborn and demanding. But he came from his heart, and from his intense commitment to what he believed was right. He engaged all who knew him more fully with life because he engaged so fully with it. Our lives are richer as a result. Services will be held on Saturday, May 23, 2015 at 2 pm at All Saints Episcopal Church, Scarborough Road, Briarcliff Manor. Please make a memorial donation to the Mount Washington Observatory instead of flowers.

STORCH--George D. Dec 26, 1921-May 23, 2012 Survivor of the Holocaust. Decorated and twice wounded Lieutenant, 1st Polish Army under Marshal Konstantin Rokossovsky during World War II. In our thoughts and hearts every day for the past 3 years. Your guidance, humor and love is missed by your adoring family. Oliver Storch & Family 1/3

His knowledge, charm and wit will be much missed both within our firm and in the wider New York art community. We extend our deepest sympathy to his entire family. Marc Porter, Chairman Stephen Lash, Chairman Emeritus John Hays, Deputy Chairman 1/3

AVERY--Lawrence. Beth El Synagogue Center of New Rochelle mourns the passing of our esteemed Cantor Emeritus, Lawrence Avery, who served our community for over six decades. His beautiful voice and warm presence touched generations of our Synagogue family. Heartfelt condolences to his children, grandchildren and thousands of students. Melvin N. Sirner, Rabbi, Samuel E. Berger, President 1/3

MEYLER--Joan. Beloved daughter, wife, mother, and grandmother Joan Bernadette Meyler of Brooklyn, NY, died on May 19, in California, at the age of 71 from complications of acute leukemia. Her generosity, love of learning, and concern for social justice shone through her life. After receiving a BA from Marymount Manhattan College, she served in VISTA and worked for the New York City Department of Housing and Urban Development, where she met her husband. After they married, she pursued a JD at St. John's University, then became an Associate at Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison before deciding to stay at home to raise her daughter. She later completed a PhD in English at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York and taught courses on legal writing and related subjects for fifteen years at John Jay College of Criminal Justice, in the process aiding many students who wished to enter legal careers. Joan was also active in founding Cooperators United for Mitchell-Lama and was a tireless advocate for affordable housing in New York City. After her retirement in 2013, she poured her energies into reading stories and creating art projects for her adored granddaughters. In addition to her husband, John Meyler, and daughter, Bernadette Meyler, she leaves behind her mother, Helen Fischer, her brother, Walter Healy, her son-in-law, Matt Smith, and her granddaughters, Calliope and Minerva Smith. A memorial service will be held in Brooklyn at a later date. In lieu of flowers, please contribute in her memory to the Friends of the Palo Alto Library.

GOODFRIEND--Claire Vivian Baum, July 12, 1918 - May 20, 2015. She was the second of eight children born to Sarah and Isador Baum. Her smile and laugh will be remembered and missed by all who knew and loved her. She is survived by her siblings Seymour, (Elisa), Dolly (Bert), Robert (Marion) and Phyllis, loving children Miriam and Marvin, grandchildren Daniel and Rachel (Max), and great- grandchildren Zeke, Lauren, Kate and Sabrina. The family will receive guests at 499 North Broadway, White Plains, NY on Saturday, May 23, 7-9pm; Sunday, May 24, 2-5pm and 7-9pm and Monday, May 25, 2-5pm. 1/3

KRIEGSMAN--Seymour "Sy", passed away peacefully at home on May 21, 2015 at age 85. He is survived by his devoted wife of 61 years Doris, son Ira and daughter-in-law Laurie, daughter Wendy and son-in law Neal, grandchildren Carly, Ross, Sam, and Hannah, and sister Barbara. He was predeceased by his brother Jack. He was a graduate of Brooklyn Tech and City College, a CPA, a lifelong New York Giants fan, and a Sunday crossword puzzle whiz who bravely served his country in Korea. Sy was a kind and gentle boy from Brooklyn who adored his children and grandchildren. Though he was a man of few words, he could tell a joke like nobody else. "That's a nice dress. Maybe it will come back into style." Papa you will be greatly missed.

ROCKEFELLER-- Margaretta "Happy" Our beloved Mother, Margaretta "Happy" Fitler Rockefeller, peacefully passed away in her sleep on the morning of Tuesday, May 19. Her children and many loved ones gathered around her in loving memory. We are blessed that up until her death, she was happily active and engaged with her family, beloved friends and interests. Throughout her life, our Mother was a constant inspiration and source of profound love and wisdom for her family and friends. Our Mother cared deeply about her family, friends, and the well being of others. During World War II, she served in the American Women's Volunteer Service and also served as a nurse's aide in the Philadelphia Naval Hospital assisting the wounded. She had a keen interest in understanding and spending time with different peoples and cultures. She worked quietly to promote mutual understanding and had an uncanny ability to generate understanding and respect among people of different backgrounds and views. As First Lady of New York and Second Lady of the United States and as a concerned and interested citizen, she visited all parts of the globe. She was appointed to two terms as a public delegate to the United Nations by President George H. W. Bush in 1991 and 1992, serving under US Ambassador Thomas Pickering. After her service, she continued to advance her country's interests there and host important gatherings. She had a deep love of learning and read throughout her life historical novels and history. She was proud of how her heritage and her family had helped America over the years. Her great-great- grandfather, General George Meade, was Commander of the Union Army at the Battle of Gettysburg. She was the great granddaughter of Edwin H. Fitler, former Mayor of Philadelphia. And she was also descended from Jonathan Dickenson, the founder of Princeton University, and Joseph Harrison, who built the railroads in Russia under Tsar Nicholas II. As a breast cancer survivor enduring two mastectomies shortly after her husband Nelson Rockefeller became Vice President of the United States, she played an important role, along with First Lady Betty Ford, in helping people gain a greater awareness of breast cancer and its detection. Her charitable interests included heartfelt support for the Philadelphia Orchestra and its annual visits to China and the orchestra's mission of promoting international understanding. She supported the Franklin D. Roosevelt Four Freedoms Park in New York City, the Central Park Conservancy, the Rockefeller State Park Preserve, and served on the Board of Historic Hudson Valley and as a Trustee of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund. She served as Chairman of the Board of the Saratoga Performing Arts Center (SPAC) from its formation in 1966 until 1973 and was named as Honorary Chairperson for SPAC's 50th Anniversary Celebration in 2016. As a Mother she guided us with her steadfast love and thoughtful insights and understanding of people and the world. She taught us the value and importance of friends and family and country. She shared with us her deep love of nature from which she drew strength and spirituality. She delighted in feeding birds and wildlife near her home. For over thirty five years she was a dedicated swimmer nearly every day. She deeply enjoyed taking long walks with loved ones as often as she could. Mom was a kind and giving woman, who left us with loving memories that will remain forever. Our Mother, above all, was dedicated to her immediate and extended family and to many dear friends. She greatly loved spending time with her children, including Malinda Menotti who passed away in 2005, and fourteen grandchildren. She had a firm belief in the importance of family and the nurturing, support, and perspective it provides. On Tuesday, June 9 there will be a private funeral with family and close friends. In September there will be a Memorial Celebration of her life. We greatly miss her and we will always be guided by her wisdom and love. The Children of Mrs. Nelson A. "Happy" Rockefeller; James B. Murphy, Wendy M. Bickford, Carol M. Lyden, Nelson A. Rockefeller, Jr., Mark F. Rockefeller. 1

JACKREL--Rebecca Robin 43, passed away on Sunday, May 3rd two years after being diagnosed with incurable cancer. After a long winding path - starting with a Masters in music education in New York, to working at a solder manufacturing company in Texas, to providing Quality Assurance at a software company in Silicon Valley, to practicing as a Veterinary Technician at pet hospitals in San Francisco - Rebecca finally found her passion as a wildlife photographer. In the short time she had to practice her art, Rebecca journeyed to all seven continents. With her focus on conservation, she highlighted the dangers of the Pacific Garbage Patch to her beloved albatross, the great toll climate change has inflicted on polar bears, the horrible boat wounds suffered by manatees and more. She also captured the beauty of the natural world, from penguins warming their eggs in Antarctica, to a humpback whale relaxing with her calf in the Dominican Republic, to a polar bear swimming through a glowing twilight near the North Pole. Her crowning achievement was the Ethiopian Wolf Project, a program she created to raise awareness for the critically endangered Ethiopian Wolf. In 2011, after spending five weeks in the highlands of Ethiopia accompanied by fellow wildlife photographer Will Burrard- Lucas, Rebecca produced "The Ethiopian Wolf: Hope at the Edge of Extinction", the definitive book on this unique creature and its struggle for survival. Rebecca's work can be seen at her website: http://www. rebeccajackrel.com/, or through her stock agencies: Alamy, Getty, AGE Fotostock, Danita Delimont and PhotoShelter. More of her work, insights into her process and her chronicle of living with cancer can be found at her blog: http://rebecca jackrel.blogspot.com/. Rebecca's photographs will be featured in the upcoming book "When Mountain Lions are Neighbors: Wildlife in Today's California", by Beth Pratt-Bergstrom, to be published in early 2016 by Heyday Books. Rebecca's art, her dedication to conservation, and the grace and strength with which she faced her final years are an inspiration to us all. Please make any contributions in Rebecca's name to: The Wildlife Conservation Network, Defenders of Wildlife, Forests Forever. 1/3

CULLMAN--Nan Ogburn. Nan Cullman, singer and explorer, died following a stroke on Monday, May 18, at her home in Pittsboro, North Carolina. She was 85. Born in Smithfield, North Carolina in 1929, Nan began a singing career at the age of 15 when she won a scholarship in a statewide competition to attend the Julliard School in New York. She also studied at Columbia University and the University of Heidelberg in Germany. She performed throughout her life with regional opera companies and choral societies. Her favorite role was Fiordiligi from Mozart's Cosi fan tutte that she performed for the Westchester Opera Company. In 1951, she married Hugh Cullman, son of Broadway 'angel' and Port Authority Chairman, Howard S. Cullman, and made her home in Westchester County, New York for the next 40 years. She was active with civic organizations, serving on the board of Youth Consultation Service of New York, the vestry of Christ's Church, Rye and as a volunteer working in the recovery room at United Hospital in Port Chester, New York. She was also a long-term board member of the North Carolina Symphony. In her 40s, Mrs. Cullman took up mountain- eering and other extreme travel pursuits, riding camels with the Tuareg tribe through the Hoggar Mountains of southern Algeria, climbing to the Everest base camps from both the Nepalese and Tibetan sides and obtaining one of the first visas to hike through Bhutan. She almost lost her life on Everest, when she was blinded and at the summit of Mount Kilimanjaro where she was overcome by altitude sickness. According to her daughter, Alexandra Haslingden, "Long before Sheryl Sandberg challenged women to lean in, my mother was jumping in." As recently as 2013, she was hiking in the Dolomites and this year was planning an expedition to the Highlands of Scotland. Mrs. Cullman is survived by her husband Hugh Cullman as well as her three children, Katherine Hedges of London, England, Hugh Cullman Jr. of Rye, New York, and Alexandra Haslingden of Sydney, Australia, and nine grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at St. Paul's Church in Beaufort, NC on Wednesday, May 27 at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the North Carolina Community Foundation. 919-828-4387. nccommunityfoundation.org 1/3

MEYLER--Joan. Beloved daughter, wife, mother, and grandmother Joan Bernadette Meyler of Brooklyn, NY, died on May 19, in California, at the age of 71 from complications of acute leukemia. Her generosity, love of learning, and concern for social justice shone through her life. After receiving a BA from Marymount Manhattan College, she served in VISTA and worked for the New York City Department of Housing and Urban Development, where she met her husband. After they married, she pursued a JD at St. John's University, then became an Associate at Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison before deciding to stay at home to raise her daughter. She later completed a PhD in English at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York and taught courses on legal writing and related subjects for fifteen years at John Jay College of Criminal Justice, in the process aiding many students who wished to enter legal careers. Joan was also active in founding Cooperators United for Mitchell-Lama and was a tireless advocate for affordable housing in New York City. After her retirement in 2013, she poured her energies into reading stories and creating art projects for her adored granddaughters. In addition to her husband, John Meyler, and daughter, Bernadette Meyler, she leaves behind her mother, Helen Fischer, her brother, Walter Healy, her son-in-law, Matt Smith, and her granddaughters, Calliope and Minerva Smith. A memorial service will be held in Brooklyn at a later date. In lieu of flowers, please contribute in her memory to the Friends of the Palo Alto Library.

HANSEN--James Merritt. Born November 29, 1939, James passed away on April 23rd, 2015 in Palm Springs, CA, his winter home. Earlier homes included Los Angeles; Kodiak, AK; Greece; Ashland, OR; Santa Barbara, CA and New York City. Graduated top of his class and a Rhode Scholar, University of California Santa Barbara. He was also an honored U.S. Naval Officer UDT Special Forces and Jag lawyer. James, a Renaissance man, contributed to others in many fields at various times: co-founder of The Tenth Muse - an educational slide and film strip company in California, an Underwater Archeologist in Greece, as well as a prominent dealer of marine-Art, Antiquities and California Impressionists. He owned James M. Hansen Galleries in California and 57th St NYC, and a noted restoration studio of fine antiquities and furniture. Later he became the head curator of the Joan Mitchell Art Foundation in the U.S. and Paris. He owned and operated City Island Sailing School. James is survived by his loving life partner of 30 years, Elen Sevy in NYC, and his two devoted sisters, Linda Brennan and Diane Willauer and their families in Southern California. James will be honored with a Memorial Service and placed to rest at Arlington National Cemetery. 1/3

SARNOFF--Arthur I.,84, died peacefully at home on May 20, surrounded by family. Loving husband of Joan, brother of Paula Oreck, father of Susan (Jonathan Bram) and Elizabeth (Andrew Cohen) and adoring grandfather of Nathan, Lily, Henry, Julia and Jenny. Arthur was a proud 1949 graduate of The Fieldston School, was surely its longest serving trustee, and maintained cherished lifelong friendships with many of his classmates. Both of his daughters and all five grandchildren continued his legacy there. He graduated from Johns Hopkins University in 1953, where he was a long serving trustee and permanent class president. As was his way, he made many wonderful friends at Hopkins, through whom he ultimately met his bride, Joannie Goldberg of Charleston, SC, a Goucher graduate. From 1954-57, he served in the United States Army Security Agency in Tokyo and was awarded the Commendation Ribbon for Meritorious Achievement. Arthur was the president of Bruno Appliance Corporation, a distribution business started by his father, Irving, which was for many years the country's largest distributor of RCA and Whirlpool appliances. Arthur was a trustee of Beth Israel Medical Center and Continuum Health Partners for many decades. Arthur loved tradition and often joked that he was never one for change, choosing to spend 80 of his 84 years in the same Central Park West apartment. He was president of the Kenilworth's co-op board for many years. Throughout his illness, the dinners he shared with a group of special neighbors were true highlights. Arthur was the youngest child in a large extended family and his pride in his uncle General David Sarnoff's accomplishments was well known. He was thrilled to preside over the enormous and wonderful Sarnoff family Thanksgiving at his home in Yorktown Heights for many years. Arthur also truly embraced Joan's colorful southern family and was in turn embraced by the Dumas clan. In 1978 the couple purchased a home on South Carolina's Sullivan's Island and spent happy summers on the beach surrounded by multiple generations. The annual Shabbat dinners they hosted there were loud and delicious and are cherished memories of their loving extended family. Family legend maintains that Arthur was the first season ticket holder at the new Madison Square Garden, cheering the Knicks to their two championships with an enthusiasm he would later bring to his grandchildren's endless parade of sports games, concerts and the Fieldston fashion show. Arthur was kind and generous to so many people who passed through his life, maintaining meaningful relationships with classmates, neighbors, distant cousins, old army buddies and many of his children's friends and classmates. He was truly loved and he will be missed. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Arthur Sarnoff Alumni Scholarship Fund at Ethical Culture Fieldston School, attn Whitney Pollack wpollack@ecfs.org 212-712-6242. 1/3

McCHORD--John Hynes, Jr. died on May 17, 2015. Born in Louisville, KY on May 2, 1932 to John Hynes McChord and Alberta Perkins McChord, he graduated with highest honors from Middlesex School '50 and from Princeton '54 where he was in the Woodrow Wilson School. Drafted from Harvard Law School in 1955, he served in the Army for two years and returned to graduate in 1959. After several years at Carter, Ledyard and Milburn, he was at ITT Corp from 1967 until 1987 where he retired as Assistant General Counsel. He and his wife Ann married in 1964 and lived in New York City and Harlemville, NY. He is survived by his sister Mary M. Doyle of New York City and her children, John K. Doyle Jr and Nancy Doyle, and Ann's sisters, Martha Tarantino of Las Vegas NV and Sarah Lande of Muscatine IA, many nieces and nephews, and his devoted caregiver Brenda Brathwaite. Seasoned travelers for many years, John and Ann enjoyed trips to remote areas, as well as three trips to Europe with his wheelchair. He was a member of Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church where he was an elder, trustee, deacon and treasurer of the church for many years. He was interested in his family's genealogy and stories and was a member of the Society of the Cincinnati. He loved music, the Philharmonic, the Metropolitan and Glimmerglass Operas. The Library of Congress' Service for the Blind and the Physically Handicapped was an important part of his life for 25 years. He was grateful for the fine medical attention he received at the Mount Sinai Hospital, especially the Corinne Goldsmith Dickinson Multiple Sclerosis Center and the Martha Stewart Center for Living. A memorial service is planned for the fall. 1/3

O'TOOLE--Cecelia Ryan, cherished mother of Michele, Sheila and Cecilia and beloved wife of the late Robert G. O'Toole, died peacefully on May 19, 2015, surrounded by her books and her music, holding the hands of her three girls. The Ultimate Teacher, known as Mrs. O, she championed education for all she met, with her motto of "no one can ever take your education away from you." Her passion for learning and reading was insatiable. She earned her MA in 1980 from Manhattanville College some thirty three (32) years after graduating from the College of St. Elizabeth in 1948. Her zest for life and all whom she loved was sustained by her relentless spirit, sheer grit, formidable fortitude and undeniable determination, always with a smile. At the Millennium, her trip to Paris as guests from wonderful friends (JP Azpitarte Family) surpassed her dreams and joy of travel. Her family is eternally grateful to Dr. John Schaefer for his unwavering encouragement, Dr. Jose Meller and Dr. Gerald Sotsky, Dr. David Brillon, her nurses Alberta and Bridget and Thea for their love and commitment, her loyal "friends for life" Polly and Dolores and the late Leon Lobel and Stanley Lobel and Family for their years of special friendship. She will miss all who loved her and leaves all who loved her with her forever smile, sparkling blue eyes, marvelous laugh and directions to keep calm and carry on! We loved you so...'twas heaven here with you...Good night Gracie! 1/3

SCHULMAN--Stanley R.,died peacefully on May 18, 2015, shortly after his 86th birthday. Born in The Bronx to Samuel and Bertha Schulman he was a proud graduate of Syracuse University's class of 1950 and received his MBA from Columbia University. Upon his graduation he joined the family business of Alixandre Furs, a company founded by his father in 1923. Actively involved in the business until his death he served as President for 65 years. Stanley worked closely with designers Valentino, Oscar de la Renta, Calvin Klein, and Perry Ellis, in creating timeless designs within the fur industry. Longtime supporter of Brookdale University Hospital, Schulman and Schachne Institute, where he served as past Trustee. An avid golfer, he was a proud member of Old Oaks Country Club for over forty years. Stanley was the beloved husband of Barbara (deceased), devoted father to Brett (Jill), Blake (Jocelyn), adoring grandfather to Robert, Sabrina and Sam, dear brother to Edwin (Dana), Jerry (Marlene), Maxine (deceased) and loving companion to Marcie. He will be remembered for his devotion to family and friends as well as his generous spirit. He will be sorely missed by all who were fortunate enough to have known him. Stanley always knew how to put a smile on someone's face. Funeral arrangements will be private. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, New York Chapter, 360 Lexington Avenue, 4th floor, New York, NY 10017. 1/3

GINIGER--Bernard B. We mourn the passing of Bernard Giniger, age 92, after a long illness. Bernie was born in Mannheim, Germany, before moving to France and then to New York City. He served in the Counterintelligence Corps during WWII, receiving numerous decorations. In civilian life, Bernie worked in an art gallery and then a fine arts publishing house, bringing beauty to people around the world. He was a deeply ethical man, and a gifted storyteller with a twinkle in his eye and a sense of humor that could make you laugh in any of six languages. He is survived by his wife, Jeanne; his sons Michael and Edward, their wives, his four grandchildren, and a world of friends and relatives who will miss his vibrant personality. 1/3

HOPPENSTEIN--Reuben. Passed away on May 15, 2015 at the age of 81. Beloved husband of Raquel. Loving father of Tivia Hoppenstein Kramer, Ava Hoppenstein Shore and Charles Hoppenstein and his wife Keli, stepfather of Leon and Deborah Taurel, David and Margarita Taurel and the late Reina Taurel and their families. He was an adoring grandfather to his grandchildren who loved and respected him including Alana, Carson, Maya and Ariella. Loving brother of Hilly and Abe and his wife Taubene and their families. He was born in Benoni, South Africa and earned his medical degree from University Witwatersrand, Johannesburg, South Africa in 1957. He came to New York City in 1960 and trained as a neurosurgeon under Dr. Leo Davidoff at Mount Sinai and was then in private practice as a neurosurgeon specializing in spinal issues. He served on the staff of several prominent New York hospitals including the Joint Diseases, Mount Sinai and Beekman-Downtown. He was a brilliant inventor who created the first disposable plastic syringe and held many patents including those for numerous medical instruments, concept vehicles and glasses-free 3D technologies. He was an entrepreneur who produced the musicals "Jacques Brel is Alive and Well and Living in Paris" (Broadway, revival, 1988) and Dori (Off-Broadway, Toronto, 1988). He developed the first mega yacht marina in the Caribbean, Yacht Club Isle de Sol, St. Martin, NA. He was a brilliant, compassionate and innovative physician, a generous man, full of passion, humor and a beloved friend to all. As he said, "Most people dream in black and white but I dream in technicolor." 1/3

FLORMAN--Monte Wolf, 88, died on April 2, 2015 following years of Parkinson's Disease. He was born in New York City to Pearl Wolf and Irving Florman on November 19th, 1926. He attended Columbia Grammar School and New York University, graduating with a degree in engineering at the age of 19. He was hired by Macy's and immediately fired for rejecting shipments of bookcases due to unacceptable quality of construction. He was immediately hired by Consumers Union for precisely that reason! He remained at Consumer's Union for 34 years eventually becoming the Technical Director of the non-profit organization. He testified before the Supreme Court in the Bose Case which was won by CU. He represented Consumer's Union throughout the world at International Consumer's organizations. During his tenure there and in the years following his retirement he wrote numerous books: How to Clean Practically Everything,1001 Helpful Tips, Facts and Hints from Consumer's Reports, Testing Behind the Scenes of Consumer's Union and numerous other publications. Monte was known for his sardonic sense of humor, his devotion to precision of and love of words, language and superb prose. He was able to turn his sharp eye for all grammatical infractions into a position of the true writer. His wisdom and sensitivity during his second wife's end life Alzheimer's Disease impressed and enriched other caregivers for years. Monte was married to Berenice Florman and is the father of David Florman. He is the grandfather of Marc Florman and Amie Florman Davies. He is the great-grandfather of Hazel Florman. Following his divorce from Berenice Florman he married Marjorie Ludmer and was married to her until her death 45 years later. He married Judith Wank-Florman who survives. A celebration of his life will be held on Saturday, May 30th at 3pm at the Rosedale Unitarian Church, 468 Rosedale Avenue, White Plains, NY. The service will be led by his wife, an adjunct Leader of the Ethical Culture Society and Rabbi Frank Tamburello of the Humanistic Jewish movement. Donations may be made to Compassion and Choices, an organization to support, educate and advocate for compassionate end of life care: PO Box 101810, Denver CO 80250 1/3

CESS--Solomon "Soly", Born January 1916, died May 23, 2015. Approaching his 100th year. A true Holocaust survivor, a linguist of over a half dozen languages. His whole family wiped out by the war. Came to America, after the war. Became an importer of optical frames. Remarried, lost a second wife. A red headed member of Park East Synagogue in New York which slowly turned to white. A benefactor to the Synagogue, as well as NYU. Much Love, David Geula and Valerie Rothman Esq. - His guardians 1/3

STONE--Dr. Philip M.,of Roslyn Heights, NY, died peacefully on May 20th, 2015. He was born in Manhattan on August 23, 1916. He received his Ph.D in psychology from Yeshiva University. He continued his training as a psychoanalyst at the National Psychological Institute for Psychoanalysis under the tutelage of Dr. Theodore Reich. He is survived by his wife of 71 years, Regina, brother Irving, beloved children Elizabeth Stone Matho (Dr. Konrad), Suzanne (Paul Miles), Dr. Leslie Stone Hirsh (Dr. Robert), Dr. Joanne Stone (Dr. George Getrajdman), and precious grandchildren, Dr. Katherine Matho, Dr. Andrea Matho (Jean Delauney), Daniel Matho, Chloe and Sabrina Getrajdman, and Carolyn, Brian, Andrew Hirsh. Dr. Stone was a ceaseless advocate for his patients and continued treating them until two weeks before his death. He will always be remembered for his deep and unbounded love for family, extraordinary compassion and devotion to his patients and friends. Funeral services will be held at the Mount Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, on Friday, May 22, at 12:30pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Anti-Defamation League or the Israel Defense Forces. 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Norman passed away on May 9, 2015 three weeks before his 90th birthday. He died of a broken heart after the passing of his beloved wife Zee Friedman just five months ago-a few days past their 69th wedding anniversary. He was the devoted son of the late Sam and Etta Friedman and caring brother, nephew and uncle. He grew up in NYC, attended CUNY and served in the U.S. Air Force during WWII. Norman was a textile engineer, savvy businessman, strong leader and generous boss, having served as President of John Wolf Textiles & Trustee of Cone Mills for decades. Norm had many talents including jokes and storytelling, magic, poker, golf and dancing. Norman was always the best dancer on the dance floor. He and Zee traveled the globe and amassed a fabulous group of friends from all over the world. They loved museums, theater, collecting art, fine dining and wine and spending time with friends at the Mill River Club on Long Island and Gainey Ranch Estates in Scottsdale. There will always be something missing from a meal without Norm ordering "Grey Goose in a wine glass on the rocks with no fruit." Norman was the proud and generous father of Dr. Dana Friedman and Dr. Marc Friedman and daughter-in- law Donna Friedman. He lavished gifts and college educations on all five of his grandchildren, Dr. Brooke Friedman, Jordan Friedman and Samantha, Madeline and Allison Mirzoeff. He regaled them with his magic tricks and silliness and had a short time to share them with his two great grandchildren Caleb and Dalia Ponist. Norm was a "prince of a guy" as friends have said, and he will be deeply missed by his loving family and so many others. Donations for aspiring magicians: Dai Vernon Foundation, Inc., 11333 Moorpark #

SPIELMAN--Carol. A magnificent woman with great presence, beauty, intelligence. Mother to niece Susan Schwimmer, grandmother to nephew Matthew, stepmother to Anne Dee Goldin. Loved by many. The world is now a dimmer place for those who were surrounded by her glow. 1/3
HAMER--William I. (Bill). b. June 27, 1930 d. May 23, 2014. Beloved father, friend, and brother. We love and miss you Dad and in our hearts you will always be.

PARTRIDGE--Martha Gail. August 17, 1937 - May 17, 2015 Daughter of James and Virginia Partridge, sister of Jean Partridge MacAllister (deceased). Born in Palmerton, Pennsylvania, Gail lived everywhere from Wilmington, Delaware to New York City to Edgartown, MA to New Canaan, CT and, finally, New Orleans, LA. She attended the University of Delaware and worked as a real estate agent for Brown Harris Stevens in New York before devoting herself to her family. She was a quick-witted puzzle and game lover, an antiques aficionado, a movie buff, and an avid knitter who was the consummate hostess and life of the party. She was elegant and creative, always served the best hors d'oeuvres, delivered the snappiest one-liners and never skipped dessert. She died on May 17th from heart failure surrounded by her loved ones. Gail is survived by her children, Jesse Weisman and Jean Weisman Sharkey, and beloved step- daughter, Katie Weisman Desvallees, her sons-in-law Devin Sharkey and Christian Desvallees, nieces Phoebe and Daisy Vreeland, grand- nieces Caroline, Alexandra and Satya, as well as her four loving grandchildren, William, Lucie, Tucker and Sunny. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to The Children's Hospital of New Orleans (www.chnola.org) or the ASPCA (www.aspca.org) 1/3

KAYE--Peter B. Dec. 9,1955 -May 25,2014 We cannot believe it has been one year. Our love and memories of you will never diminish nor our tears that would fill an ocean. Mary, Mom, Dad, Jim, Jodi, Matthew and Allison 1/3

MISENHEIMER--Kay Moser. Remembering beloved father on the second anniversary of his passing. Navy Aviator in World War II, dedicated Presbyterian Minister for 45 years, avid sailor, technical wizard and a funny, generous, unforgettable soul. We miss you Dad. Barry K. Misenheimer 1/3

DAVILA--Rene. On May 17, 2015 Dr. Rene Victor Davila died peacefully among family and friends near his home in Miami. Rene was born in Ecuador and grew up in Brooklyn, New York. Rene worked as a respected architect for more than 40 years both in New York and Miami. His accomplishments also included earning his doctorate degree in architecture, numerous gallery showings of his art and photography, and what he would credit as his greatest achievement in life, his daughter and grandchildren, whom he loved tirelessly. Rene is survived in life by his wife, Gaby, his daughter, Tania Zucker, wife of Martin Zucker, and their children, Julianna and Jeremy. Also surviving him are his brothers Byron, Jaime and Oscar Davila, and sisters Elizabeth Davila, Livia Neeves, Nohemy Davila, Esperanza Hemmings and Moraima Campanella. Rene was preceded in death by his parents Maria and Jaime Davila, and brother, Fausto Davila.

SOPHER--Joseph. Congregation Chasam Sopher mourns the loss of our long time benefactor and dear friend Mr. Joseph Sopher. His infectious smile endeared him to all our congregants. The respect and consideration he displayed towards others will remain as a shining example. His spontaneous accompaniment of our cantor this past, which was to be his final, Yom Kippur provided the perfect metaphor for the enhancement he has brought to the lives of our extended Chasam Sopher family. We extend our sincerest condolences to his brother, Hank Sopher, whose dedication to the Synagogue is unmatched. Rabbi Azriel Siff Eugene Weiser, President 1/3

GROSSMAN--Robert, 72, of Hewlett Harbor, NY. Born October 24, 1942, died May 21, 2015. Beloved husband of Rochelle (nee Trager). Proud father of Brooke and Michael Mure. Adored brother of Neal and Mary Grossman, Victor and Pily Trager, and Sharon Trager. A self-made yet selfless man. Robert devoted his life to others, and his love, humor, and spirit will be missed by all. 1/3

LITTMAN--Mary R.,on May 20, 2015. Beloved wife of the late Leon. Loving aunt of John, Timothy and James Ralston. Dear cousin of Barbara Goetz and Mary B. Irving. Mass of Christian Burial, St. John The Evangelist Church, 348 East 55th St., NYC, Tuesday, 10:30am. 1/3

LOUGHRAN--Patrick M.,of New York and Caracas passed away in NYC on May 21, 2015. He is survived by son Frank, daughter-in-law Siobhan, grandchildren Frank Jr., Elizabeth and his brother Thomas. He was formally married to Ann Margaret Hague of Jersey City and New York. Pat was in business in Caracas Venezuela for over 50 years. He is a former member of the Brook, The Links, the Knickerbocker, National GL, Meadow, Blind Brook, Winged Foot, Lyford Cay, White's and Caracas CC.
