ENSIGN--Tod. One year. Not a day goes by. Missing you profoundly, Francine and Rachel 1/3

ROCKEFELLER-- Margaretta "Happy" Our beloved Mother, Margaretta "Happy" Fitler Rockefeller, peacefully passed away in her sleep on the morning of Tuesday, May 19. Her children and many loved ones gathered around her in loving memory. We are blessed that up until her death, she was happily active and engaged with her family, beloved friends and interests. Throughout her life, our Mother was a constant inspiration and source of profound love and wisdom for her family and friends. Our Mother cared deeply about her family, friends, and the well being of others. During World War II, she served in the American Women's Volunteer Service and also served as a nurse's aide in the Philadelphia Naval Hospital assisting the wounded. She had a keen interest in understanding and spending time with different peoples and cultures. She worked quietly to promote mutual understanding and had an uncanny ability to generate understanding and respect among people of different backgrounds and views. As First Lady of New York and Second Lady of the United States and as a concerned and interested citizen, she visited all parts of the globe. She was appointed to two terms as a public delegate to the United Nations by President George H. W. Bush in 1991 and 1992, serving under US Ambassador Thomas Pickering. After her service, she continued to advance her country's interests there and host important gatherings. She had a deep love of learning and read throughout her life historical novels and history. She was proud of how her heritage and her family had helped America over the years. Her great-great- grandfather, General George Meade, was Commander of the Union Army at the Battle of Gettysburg. She was the great granddaughter of Edwin H. Fitler, former Mayor of Philadelphia. And she was also descended from Jonathan Dickenson, the founder of Princeton University, and Joseph Harrison, who built the railroads in Russia under Tsar Nicholas II. As a breast cancer survivor enduring two mastectomies shortly after her husband Nelson Rockefeller became Vice President of the United States, she played an important role, along with First Lady Betty Ford, in helping people gain a greater awareness of breast cancer and its detection. Her charitable interests included heartfelt support for the Philadelphia Orchestra and its annual visits to China and the orchestra's mission of promoting international understanding. She supported the Franklin D. Roosevelt Four Freedoms Park in New York City, the Central Park Conservancy, the Rockefeller State Park Preserve, and served on the Board of Historic Hudson Valley and as a Trustee of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund. She served as Chairman of the Board of the Saratoga Performing Arts Center (SPAC) from its formation in 1966 until 1973 and was named as Honorary Chairperson for SPAC's 50th Anniversary Celebration in 2016. As a Mother she guided us with her steadfast love and thoughtful insights and understanding of people and the world. She taught us the value and importance of friends and family and country. She shared with us her deep love of nature from which she drew strength and spirituality. She delighted in feeding birds and wildlife near her home. For over thirty five years she was a dedicated swimmer nearly every day. She deeply enjoyed taking long walks with loved ones as often as she could. Mom was a kind and giving woman, who left us with loving memories that will remain forever. Our Mother, above all, was dedicated to her immediate and extended family and to many dear friends. She greatly loved spending time with her children, including Malinda Menotti who passed away in 2005, and fourteen grandchildren. She had a firm belief in the importance of family and the nurturing, support, and perspective it provides. On Tuesday, June 9 there will be a private funeral with family and close friends. In September there will be a Memorial Celebration of her life. We greatly miss her and we will always be guided by her wisdom and love. The Children of Mrs. Nelson A. "Happy" Rockefeller; James B. Murphy, Wendy M. Bickford, Carol M. Lyden, Nelson A. Rockefeller, Jr., Mark F. Rockefeller. 1

GIEFFERS-CONHEENY--Fernanda, formerly of New York died November 16, 2014 in Palm Beach, Florida. Interment and Blessing for Fernanda May 28, 2015, 11am at St. Joseph Cemetery, Hackensack, New Jersey. Condolences: Gieffers Family, P.O. Box 151, Palm Beach, Florida 33480. 1/3

TORSON--John. John Archie Torson, private art dealer and resident of New York City for more than 60 years, died Thursday evening, May 14, 2015, from an accident while still in good health, which is what he had always hoped, and not far from the apartment he called home for most of his life. Just short of 90 years of age, John remained active and engaging. He was looking forward with great anticipation to the soon arrival of his family for what he said would be our last get- together. So although his family grieves that he is gone, we take solace that he died while in a happy state and still out and about in the city he so loved. He has been a loyal and contented resident of Manhattan and thought it, indeed, knew it to be the greatest city in the world. John was born in Independence, Wisconsin in 1926. He grew up in this small, rural farming village with his parents and sister. Independence always held a cherished place in his heart, but in his senior year of high school, he was called into the US Navy during war times. After serving until 1947, he then attended the University of Minnesota where he studied art and architecture. Graduating in 1952, he began work in Minneapolis at the Dayton Company. In 1954, he moved to New York City. Once there he was first associated with the Wayah Gallery on 4th Avenue. Encouraged by Mr. Wayah and with the confidence and the initial financial backing of his parents, John ventured out into what would become his profession and went to Europe in 1956 for his first art buying trip. His chosen profession proved ideal for his temperament and critical eye. He never stopped working, loving art, and enjoying people from all over the world who shared his enthusiasm for the arts and the artist behind the creative enterprise. John was a world traveller and always keenly aware of his surroundings and the beauty that a discerning eye could discover. He became schooled in art, music, and architecture without ever losing his love and passion for these artistic forms. He was well known and respected by his peers and clients within the art community. He also supported many fine museums, galleries, and institutions of art and music, especially those in his beloved city, notably The Metropolitan Museum of Art, The Museum of Modern Art, The Morgan Library, The Frick, The Mannes School of Music, and The Julliard School of Music. We know there are many more that should be mentioned. He had friends from all over the world, and all who knew him would agree that our world has lost a very keen eye and provocative mind. John had the unique proclivity of becoming important to the many people whose lives he touched. Primarily because he sought to appreciate each persons's individuality, while at the same time probing to understand, he became significant to each of us. He guarded zealously his own freedom of mind and because of this, chose to remain somewhat anonymous and always independent. He loved children and treasured the pictures made for him by those of a dear friend when he was in the hospital five years ago recovering from a traumatic brain injury. He wanted to be alive in this world only as long as he remained vital. He was never self indulgent, but he certainly enjoyed good food at the places that he frequented. He was a man of routines. And he had many special friends with whom he engaged regularly for meals and events and social occasions. He was friendly, warm, generous, charming, clever, funny, and witty and became special even to strangers, if given a chance to interact. John had to be shared among many people, but he didn't mind. Smile. One friend once said of him, he makes more use of New York City for what it has to offer in the arts than any other person I know. That could also be said of his ability to challenge each of us to see differently and think more deeply. Being a successful art dealer, he also contributed to the financial success of others. But more than anything, he wanted each of us to enter into the visual world he experienced. The art world has lost a great ally, and we have lost a good friend. He will be missed. He is survived by his beloved sister, Patricia (Boyd), and her children whom he adopted as his own -- his nieces, Carol and Cathy, and his nephews, William and Matthew. John opened his home to his extended family and never tired of showing them New York's greatness, as well as its not so easily discovered treasures. We were all blessed to have known him. Family and close friends will gather to celebrate his life in the city he cherished and then return his ashes to Wisconsin to be buried beside his father Archie and his mother Caroline. In lieu of flowers, he can be remembered by a gift in his name to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. 1/3

KAYE--Peter B. Dec. 9,1955 -May 25,2014 We cannot believe it has been one year. Our love and memories of you will never diminish nor our tears that would fill an ocean. Mary, Mom, Dad, Jim, Jodi, Matthew and Allison 1/3

GOTTLIEB--Edythe, We have lost one of the brightest gems in our family crown- she passed away on May 23, at the age of 94. She left this world as she came into it... with extraordinary beauty, grace and dignity. To all who were fortunate to know her, she was her own person - loving, determined, strong, independent, generous, courageous, kind and fiercely loyal. Born to Sarah and Ben, the second of three children, she developed a flair for style, from changing the spelling of her name from "Edith" to "Edythe" at age 7, to becoming a runway model, to bringing new meaning to haute couture and wearing it with style! She was an avid card player and bargain shopper, passionate about theatre, ballet and opera and an enthusiastic world traveler. Always the hostess extraordinaire, she loved entertaining and bringing people together. Her magnetism drew people in and all wanted to be her friend. Friendships were vital to her and friends became members of her family. She was a devoted daughter and granddaughter, an impassioned sibling to her sister, Florence Bauman, and her brother, Morty Grossman, a proud and loving mother and grandmother, and a spirited aunt and cousin. Her femininity and exquisite beauty captivated many men who wanted to marry her, but only three were fortunate enough to call her his wife. Husband of 37 years, Jack Gottlieb remained her greatest love. Celebrating the life of Edythe are daughters Patricia Gardner, Carole Kaplan and Madeline Raffe Robison, stepson Stuart Gottlieb, grandchildren Pamela Goldsmith, Dana George, Stephanie Crispe, Sarah Maisano and Michael Rotolo, great- grandson Raiden Crispe, and numerous nieces, nephews, cousins and friends. Services will be held at "The Riverside" 180 W 76th Street, on Tuesday, May 26, 11:30am. Following the services, all are invited to return to the residence of Pamela Goldsmith through Thursday. 1/3

SARNOFF--Arthur. Our entire family joins in mourning my long-ago high school classmate, my understanding stepbrother, my trusted friend, whose impeccable values were exemplified in every aspect of his life. Karel Fierman Wahrsager Kay Wahrsager Erika Wahrsager Eve Wahrsager Linn 1/3

MEYLER--Joan. Beloved daughter, wife, mother, and grandmother Joan Bernadette Meyler of Brooklyn, NY, died on May 19, in California, at the age of 71 from complications of acute leukemia. Her generosity, love of learning, and concern for social justice shone through her life. After receiving a BA from Marymount Manhattan College, she served in VISTA and worked for the New York City Department of Housing and Urban Development, where she met her husband. After they married, she pursued a JD at St. John's University, then became an Associate at Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison before deciding to stay at home to raise her daughter. She later completed a PhD in English at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York and taught courses on legal writing and related subjects for fifteen years at John Jay College of Criminal Justice, in the process aiding many students who wished to enter legal careers. Joan was also active in founding Cooperators United for Mitchell-Lama and was a tireless advocate for affordable housing in New York City. After her retirement in 2013, she poured her energies into reading stories and creating art projects for her adored granddaughters. In addition to her husband, John Meyler, and daughter, Bernadette Meyler, she leaves behind her mother, Helen Fischer, her brother, Walter Healy, her son-in-law, Matt Smith, and her granddaughters, Calliope and Minerva Smith. A memorial service will be held in Brooklyn at a later date. In lieu of flowers, please contribute in her memory to the Friends of the Palo Alto Library.
GOLD--Sheldon. The memories remain. We love you. Carol and Leonard 1/3

KAYE--Peter B. Dec. 9, 1955 - May 25, 2014. He was my North, my South, my East and West. My working week and my Sunday rest. My noon, my midnight, my talk, my song. I thought love would last forever, I was wrong. Forever in my heart, always in my thoughts. Mary 1/3
RICHARDS--Patricia Farrelly, of Bedminster, NJ on May 18, 2015. For information: www.baileyfuneral.com 1/3

COVELL--C. Jane. November 12, 1934 - May 23, 2015, age 80. Beloved mother, grandmother, sister, friend, died on May 23. She leaves her children, James Gover, Joanne Yoshida, Tzivia Nancy Gover; granddaughters, Miranda Sanders and Yasu Yoshida; brother Robert Covell, sister- in-law Barbara Covell, and her ex-husband Richard Gover and his wife Diane.Donations in Jane's memory can be made The Alzheimer's Association and The Human Rights Campaign. The funeral will take place May 26, 10am, at Star of David Chapels in West Babylon, NY. For info visit jewish-funeral-home.com 1

CESS--Solomon "Soly", Born January 1916, died May 23, 2015. Approaching his 100th year. A true Holocaust survivor, a linguist of over a half dozen languages. His whole family wiped out by the war. Came to America, after the war. Became an importer of optical frames. Remarried, lost a second wife. A red headed member of Park East Synagogue in New York which slowly turned to white. A benefactor to the Synagogue, as well as NYU. Much Love, David Geula and Valerie Rothman Esq. - His guardians 1/3

SCHEER--The Honorable Kenneth, passed away on May 22. He had an illustrious career as an Assistant Attorney General for the State of New York and later served as a Federal Administrative Law Judge. He will be missed by his family and friends. 1/3
COVELL--C. Jane. We will miss her dearly. Barbara and Robert Covell and family 1

MITGANG--Shirley, Esq.,(nee Kravchick), died peacefully at her home in Manhattan on May 22, at age 94. A public service lawyer in New York for more than five decades, she dedicated her career to improving the treatment of children by the justice system. Among her positions in that field, she served as counsel to the Community Service Society in the late 1960s, and as staff counsel from 1971-76 to a number of judicial committees established to modernize the courts by opening them to broader public scrutiny, making proceedings fairer for indigent defendants and children, and developing alternatives to incarceration. During a 12-year tenure as deputy counsel to the New York State Office of Court Administration, she drafted numerous laws and regulations that greatly expanded the rights and protections of children in the family courts. Her pioneering work earned her the New York State Bar Association's Howard A. Levine Award for Excellence in Juvenile Justice and Child Welfare in 1991. She was married for 68 years to the late Herbert Mitgang, prolific author and long-time journalist for The New York Times, who died in 2013. She is survived by a daughter, Laura Mitgang, and son-in-law David Goodman; a son, Lee Mitgang, and daughter-in-law Gina Mitgang; and grandchildren Caroline Mitgang and spouse Wendy Cortese, Celia Mae Goodman and Noah Hart Goodman. Her eldest daughter, Esther Mitgang, died in 2007. 1/3

KRIEGSMAN--Seymour "Sy", passed away peacefully at home on May 21, 2015 at age 85. He is survived by his devoted wife of 61 years Doris, son Ira and daughter-in-law Laurie, daughter Wendy and son-in law Neal, grandchildren Carly, Ross, Sam, and Hannah, and sister Barbara. He was predeceased by his brother Jack. He was a graduate of Brooklyn Tech and City College, a CPA, a lifelong New York Giants fan, and a Sunday crossword puzzle whiz who bravely served his country in Korea. Sy was a kind and gentle boy from Brooklyn who adored his children and grandchildren. Though he was a man of few words, he could tell a joke like nobody else. "That's a nice dress. Maybe it will come back into style." Papa you will be greatly missed.

GROPP--Ann-Maria. After an especially brave battle, Ann-Maria Gropp passed away at home in New York City on Friday, May 22, 2015, surrounded by family. As wife, partner, best and greatest friend for the past 27 years, she is survived by her husband, Gregory Whyte. She is also survived by her brothers Kevin and Stephen Gropp and their families. Ann-Maria had the kindest and gentlest soul. She had an enormous heart and was always concerned about the well-being and happiness of others. She was the best friend anyone could wish for and her trove of life-long friends, all considering her their "BFF", are testament to that. As an educator and Reading Specialist, Ann-Maria dedicated herself professionally to advancing the skills of those left behind in the classroom, and worked tirelessly to help them catch up. Ann-Maria always tread so softly on this earth and asked so little of it. The vacuum she leaves behind is larger than her modesty would have anyone know. Ann-Maria grew up in Ridgewood, NJ, graduated from Syracuse University, and completed her Masters at Teachers College Columbia University. In accordance with Ann-Maria's wishes, the funeral and cremation will be held privately on Monday May 25th, 2015 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in Ann-Maria's memory to The Animal Medical Center, 510 East 62nd Street, NYC 10065 or Channel THIRTEEN PBS, 835 Eighth Avenue, NYC 10019. 1/3
FRIED--Arthur K. Lovingly remembered today and everyday. Goldy and Your Family 1/3

JUSTIN--Howard, 95, passed away peacefully May 20 after a short illness. Devoted husband of 72 years to Esther, and father to Richard. Taught English at Forest Hills High School for 30 years, and continued to teach Bible as literature at United Federation of Teachers in Rego Park past his 92nd birthday. Decorated WWII hero, he survived a plane crash behind enemy lines and was smuggled to safety (see The New York Times, page one, April 17, 1944). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the People's Symphony Concerts: pscny.org/support. 1/3

LEAF--Martin N. A practicing attorney in New York since 1958, Martin N. Leaf died in Manhattan on May 23 after a long illness. In his legal career he created successful joint ventures and business relationships among major companies throughout the world. He managed litigation, handled dispute resolution, conducted complex contract negotiations, and focused on First Amendment and intellectual property rights cases. Leaf obtained his first legal post--a clerkship while still in law school--when the criminal defense lawyer Emile Zola Berman delivered a lecture to 250 law students. When Berman asked if there were any questions, Leaf raised his hand and asked, "Can I have a job in your office?" Berman told him to be at his office the next Monday afternoon--and he got the position. His next clerkship led to a position with Fuchsberg & Fuchsberg, with whom he worked for five years, trying dozens of cases in jury trials. At one point, the young lawyer had earned a record of 20-0. In 1963 Leaf formed the firm of Leaf, Kurzman and Deull together with two other attorneys, Robert G. Kurzman and Ellis M. Deull, and practiced with them for sixteen years, after which he joined the litigation department of Morrison Cohen Singer & Weinstein. Notwithstanding his official retirement in 1990, Leaf continued his relationship with several long-time clients and worked every day since then. In his theatrical practice he represented several entertainment figures, including the actors Raul Julia and Anthony Zerbe, the singer John Denver, and the stage designer Chester Weinberg. Along with his interest in humanitarian projects, he worked with The Hunger Project, an international charity to eliminate hunger across the globe, as a United Nations NGO (non- governmental organization). And he has served as litigation counsel for Landmark, an international development and training company. As counsel for Takachiho Koheki in 1970, he negotiated a ground-breaking joint venture with the computer manufacturer Burroughs Corporation (now Unisys), which became a template for U.S.-Japanese business ventures. Leaf was active in his hometown of Hastings-on-Hudson, New York and served as the Village Attorney for fourteen years through successive political administrations, and also served as Special District Attorney for Westchester County. In 1965, along with his wife, Louise Sarkin Leaf, and five other couples, he co- founded Temple Beth Shalom in Hastings, which now has more than 400 members. While representing Lhamo Dondrub, the 14th Dalai Lama, Leaf got the U.S. State Department to reverse its previous ruling and to issue a visa to let the Dalai Lama come to the United States. He helped the Dalai Lama to add two new chapters to the original plate of his early book, My Land and My People. During the administration of President Jimmy Carter, Leaf served as a "Goodwill Ambassador" to Denmark through the "People to People" program in which U.S. families exchanged visits with their Danish counterparts. Leaf served on the boards of numerous companies, as well as many nonprofit organizations, including the American Arab Council (consisting of retired ambassadors, ministers of state in the Arab world, and other dignitaries); Trail Blazers Camp (camping for inner city children, founded 1887); Windstar (John Denver's nonprofit organization, focused on the environment and sustainability); the Buckminster Fuller Institute, the National Black Theater; Pro Musicis, a 50-year-old organization supporting musical talent in young people and in residents of institutions where great music is not available (such as prisons, mental health facilities, hospitals, and drug rehabilitation centers); and Echo Hills Mental Health Clinic (a facility for Westchester residents). As a delegate for five years to the NGO Branch of the United Nations, he submitted a White Paper on World Hunger. Leaf was born in New York City, February 19, 1932. He graduated from Washington University in St. Louis, and received his law degree from The New York University School of Law. He served with distinction in the U.S. Army, attaining the rank of Second Lieutenant. He was married for almost forty years to Louise Sarkin Leaf, an urban planner in New Rochelle, until her death in 1995. His children are Marc Leaf, an attorney in New York; Jenifer Leaf Jaeger, a physician now working for the NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene; and Cliff Leaf, an author and magazine editor. He loved his grandchildren (in alphabetical order, Connie, Emma, John, Lauren, Rachel, Sam, Sofia, and William) and greatgrandchildren Hadley, Lulu, and Sophie. He was born "with a gift of laughter and a sense that the world was mad," and died surrounded by those he loved and who loved him most, his children, his "everything," Norma Deull, and their extended families. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, May 27, 2015, at 10:00am, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Hunger Project or Citymeals-on-Wheels. 1/3

AUERBACH--Martin Thinking of you today. Always loved and never forgotten. Loving father, grandfather and husband.

GROPP--Ann-Maria. After an especially brave battle, Ann-Maria Gropp passed away at home in New York City on Friday, May 22, 2015, surrounded by family. As wife, partner, best and greatest friend for the past 27 years, she is survived by her husband, Gregory Whyte. She is also survived by her brothers Kevin and Stephen Gropp and their families. Ann-Maria had the kindest and gentlest soul. She had an enormous heart and was always concerned about the well-being and happiness of others. She was the best friend anyone could wish for and her trove of life-long friends, all considering her their "BFF", are testament to that. As an educator and Reading Specialist, Ann-Maria dedicated herself professionally to advancing the skills of those left behind in the classroom, and worked tirelessly to help them catch up. Ann-Maria always tread so softly on this earth and asked so little of it. The vacuum she leaves behind is larger than her modesty would have anyone know. Ann-Maria grew up in Ridgewood, NJ, graduated from Syracuse University, and completed her Masters at Teachers College Columbia University. In accordance with Ann-Maria's wishes, the funeral and cremation will be held privately on Monday May 25th, 2015 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in Ann-Maria's memory to The Animal Medical Center, 510 East 62nd Street, NYC 10065 or Channel THIRTEEN PBS, 835 Eighth Avenue, NYC 10019. 1/3

JARZOMBEK--Henry. January 12, 1925 - May 24, 2015. Mr. Jarzombek was a Holocaust survivor. He had been interred for various durations in Blechhammer, Auschwitz and Buchenwald. He lived in Newport, RI and is survived by his wife, Marianne, his daughter Michelle Drum, his son, Mark, and his brother, Mark Beck.

MEARA--Anne. The board, staff and members of the Alliance of Resident Theatres/New York mourn the loss of our board member, Anne Meara. Our hearts go out to our beloved Jerry, his family and the Stiller and Meara staff. 1/3

GAINES--Betty, passed away on May 23 surrounded by her family. She grew up on Riverside Drive in Manhattan. During World War II, she graduated from NYU while working for the Office of Price Administration. In response to the post war influx of Jewish refugees into the US, she assisted displaced people by helping them integrate into American Society by working for the United Services for New Americans. In 1947, in a Synagogue in Kew Gardens, she married Bernard Gaines who was an aeronautical engineer. Their careers led them to Buffalo, New York, where she graduated with a master's degree in social work from the University of Buffalo. They moved to Long Island where she practiced social work and he played a part in landing Neil Armstrong on the Moon. Betty was a devoted reader of The New York Times and a wonderful cook. She devoted her life to personally assisting discarded people and pets. Her two sons Bill and John, as well as their wives and her three grandchildren survive her. 1/3

LEAF--Martin N. A practicing attorney in New York since 1958, Martin N. Leaf died in Manhattan on May 23 after a long illness. In his legal career he created successful joint ventures and business relationships among major companies throughout the world. He managed litigation, handled dispute resolution, conducted complex contract negotiations, and focused on First Amendment and intellectual property rights cases. Leaf obtained his first legal post--a clerkship while still in law school--when the criminal defense lawyer Emile Zola Berman delivered a lecture to 250 law students. When Berman asked if there were any questions, Leaf raised his hand and asked, "Can I have a job in your office?" Berman told him to be at his office the next Monday afternoon--and he got the position. His next clerkship led to a position with Fuchsberg & Fuchsberg, with whom he worked for five years, trying dozens of cases in jury trials. At one point, the young lawyer had earned a record of 20-0. In 1963 Leaf formed the firm of Leaf, Kurzman and Deull together with two other attorneys, Robert G. Kurzman and Ellis M. Deull, and practiced with them for sixteen years, after which he joined the litigation department of Morrison Cohen Singer & Weinstein. Notwithstanding his official retirement in 1990, Leaf continued his relationship with several long-time clients and worked every day since then. In his theatrical practice he represented several entertainment figures, including the actors Raul Julia and Anthony Zerbe, the singer John Denver, and the stage designer Chester Weinberg. Along with his interest in humanitarian projects, he worked with The Hunger Project, an international charity to eliminate hunger across the globe, as a United Nations NGO (non- governmental organization). And he has served as litigation counsel for Landmark, an international development and training company. As counsel for Takachiho Koheki in 1970, he negotiated a ground-breaking joint venture with the computer manufacturer Burroughs Corporation (now Unisys), which became a template for U.S.-Japanese business ventures. Leaf was active in his hometown of Hastings-on-Hudson, New York and served as the Village Attorney for fourteen years through successive political administrations, and also served as Special District Attorney for Westchester County. In 1965, along with his wife, Louise Sarkin Leaf, and five other couples, he co- founded Temple Beth Shalom in Hastings, which now has more than 400 members. While representing Lhamo Dondrub, the 14th Dalai Lama, Leaf got the U.S. State Department to reverse its previous ruling and to issue a visa to let the Dalai Lama come to the United States. He helped the Dalai Lama to add two new chapters to the original plate of his early book, My Land and My People. During the administration of President Jimmy Carter, Leaf served as a "Goodwill Ambassador" to Denmark through the "People to People" program in which U.S. families exchanged visits with their Danish counterparts. Leaf served on the boards of numerous companies, as well as many nonprofit organizations, including the American Arab Council (consisting of retired ambassadors, ministers of state in the Arab world, and other dignitaries); Trail Blazers Camp (camping for inner city children, founded 1887); Windstar (John Denver's nonprofit organization, focused on the environment and sustainability); the Buckminster Fuller Institute, the National Black Theater; Pro Musicis, a 50-year-old organization supporting musical talent in young people and in residents of institutions where great music is not available (such as prisons, mental health facilities, hospitals, and drug rehabilitation centers); and Echo Hills Mental Health Clinic (a facility for Westchester residents). As a delegate for five years to the NGO Branch of the United Nations, he submitted a White Paper on World Hunger. Leaf was born in New York City, February 19, 1932. He graduated from Washington University in St. Louis, and received his law degree from The New York University School of Law. He served with distinction in the U.S. Army, attaining the rank of First Lieutenant. He was married for almost forty years to Louise Sarkin Leaf, an urban planner in New Rochelle, until her death in 1995. His children are Marc Leaf, an attorney in New York; Jenifer Leaf Jaeger, a physician now working for the NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene; and Cliff Leaf, an author and magazine editor. He loved his grandchildren (in alphabetical order, Connie, Emma, John, Lauren, Rachel, Sam, Sofia, and William) and greatgrandchildren Hadley, Lulu, and Sophie. He was born "with a gift of laughter and a sense that the world was mad," and died surrounded by those he loved and who loved him most, his children, his "everything," Norma Deull, and their extended families. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, May 27, 2015, at 10:00am, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Hunger Project or Citymeals-on-Wheels. 1/3

GIEFFERS-CONHEENY--Fernanda, formerly of New York died November 16, 2014 in Palm Beach, Florida. Interment and Blessing for Fernanda May 28, 2015, 11am at St. Joseph Cemetery, Hackensack, New Jersey. Condolences: Gieffers Family, P.O. Box 151, Palm Beach, Florida 33480. 1/3

HOLUB--Hazel. The partners, attorneys and staff of Golenbock Eiseman Assor Bell & Peskoe LLP acknowledge with great sorrow the passing of Hazel Holub, widow of the late Justin Golenbock and widow of the late Donald Holub, on May 25, 2015. She was the beloved mother of our founding partner, Jeffrey Golenbock. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her three children, Jeffrey, Douglas and Susan, her daughters-in-law, Wendy and Christine, her son-in-law, Marc, her four grandchildren and her two great-grandchildren. She will be profoundly missed by all of them and will be remembered fondly for her love of family and her passion for music and the arts. 1/3

HANSELL--Herbert Joseph, died peacefully at home on May 23, 2015, at age 89. Herb was a consummate lawyer, and began a lifelong association with the firm Jones Day in 1953, in Cleveland, Ohio and in Washington, DC. He chaired the firm's corporate and finance practice, and its international practice. He was instrumental in the creation of the National Railroad Passenger Corporation, which became Amtrak, and served as counsel to its original board of directors from 1970-72. From 1977-79, he served as Legal Adviser in the U.S. State Department, with Secretary of State Cyrus Vance. He was closely involved in the negotiation of the Egypt-Israel Peace Treaty (the Camp David Accords), the Panama Canal Treaties, the Salt II Treaty, and agreements establishing diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China. During 1980, he served as Senior Adviser to the U.S. delegation to the Mid-East Peace Negotiations, with the rank of Ambassador. He had a long-standing interest in economic, political and legal systems in China, and served on the boards of directors of the National Committee on U.S.-China Relations and the America-China Society. Herb was born in Pittsburgh, raised in Salem, Ohio, and lived many years in Cleveland and Washington. He was involved in many organizations concerned with civil and human rights, legal services for the poor, and international diplomacy. He is a graduate of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and Yale Law School. He was married for 58 years to Jeanne Harris Hansell until her death in 2009, and was pre-deceased by his son James in 2013. Herb is survived by his son David and David's partner Robert Cimino, his daughter Linda, his daughter-in-law Andrea, his grandchildren Julie and Adam, his brother Sandy, his companion Adele Silver, and many loving nieces and nephews. He will be dearly missed by his family and many friends and colleagues. A memorial service will be held at 10:30am on Saturday, May 30th at Jones Day, 51 Louisiana Avenue NW, Washington, DC. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to any of the following: (1) the Herbert J. Hansell Scholarship Fund for Public Service at the Salem Community Foundation, www.salemcommunityfoundation.org, (2) the Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights Under Law, www.lawyerscommittee.org, or (3) the Association for Diplomatic Studies and Training, www.adst.org.

HOLUB--Hazel T.,92, of Scarsdale, New York, passed away peacefully at home on May 25, 2015. Born and raised in Atlanta, Georgia, Hazel attended high school in Philadelphia, where she moved specifically to study violin, and graduated from the University of Michigan as an economics major. She continued to play the violin well into her 80's. After her first husband, Justin Golenbock, died in 1984, Hazel later married Dr. Donald Holub. She is survived by her three children, Susan, Jeffrey and Dr. Douglas Golenbock, and their spouses, Marc Weisenfreund, Wendy Golenbock and Christine Larsen, four grandchildren (Scott (and Eileen), Jon, Justin and Sam) and two great-grandchildren (Joey and Ben), and her step- daughters Kathy, Ana and Melissa Holub, and their families. Funeral services will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the "Justin M. Golenbock Memorial Fund at Yale Law School." 1/3

POSNER--Anne, died peacefully on May 20, 2015, at age 106. She was a remarkable woman with an indomitable spirit. Anne and her loving husband Sam founded Eastern Findings Corp. where they worked together for many years. Both were very active in Freemasonry where she served as Matron of the Eastern Star Chapter. Anne is survived by her son, seven grandchildren, and ten great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, Anne requested that trees be planted in her name in Israel through the Jewish National Fund. 1/3

GORDON--Patricia "Patti" Hill, accomplished artist from Red Hook, New York, who exhibited her work widely in the Hudson Valley, died on May 20. She was a loving wife, mother, and grandmother who devoted her life to causes of peace and justice. Memorial plans will be announced shortly. 1/3
ENSIGN--Tod. One year. Not a day goes by. Missing you profoundly, Francine and Rachel 1/3

WILLIAMS--Terrance R.,visionary behind projects that informed the landscape of New York City including the creation of the South Street Seaport, the rezoning of Tribeca, and the Theater District, died of cancer on May 16th in Manhattan. He was 77 years old. Most recently, Williams was a professor at The Catholic University of America School of Architecture and Planning in Washington, D.C. Williams' career spans more than forty years and four continents. In addition to teaching, he served as the Deputy Director of the Mayor's Office of Lower Manhattan Development in New York. He led the 25-person design team for a city within a city, Shahestan Pahlavi in Tehran, Iran and a project for Sanaa University in Yemen for I.M. Pei. Returning to the U.S., he founded The Williams Group in New York City. He was a Fellow of the American Institute of Architects and served as president of the New York Chapter in 1986. Born in Coos Bay, Oregon, in 1938, son of Ephriam Thomas Williams and Margaret Reynolds Williams, Williams received his BArch degree from the University of Oregon and his Master's degree in Architecture from Cornell University. He is survived by his daughter, Margaret Williams. 1/3

HANNOCH--Franklin Francis, Jr. died Sunday, May 24, 2015. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, May 27, at 1pm in the Bernheim-Apter- Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Rd., Livingston. Mr. Hannoch was the beloved husband of Anita (nee Goldman), the devoted father of Nancy Berger and her husband Monte and James Hannoch and his wife Kathleen as well as the adoring grandfather of Carolyn and Andrew Hannoch and Allyson Berger. 1/3

MILLER--Marjorie, passed away peacefully in her home on May 25th at the age of 92. For many years a practicing social worker, Marjorie loved the city and took advantage of its cultural opportunities. She had a passion for reading and for many years ran a vibrant book group. She was a long-time member of Sunningdale Country Club, where she enjoyed golf and tennis and socializing with her many friends. While she loved these activities, the greatest joy in her life always came from her family: daughters Wendy Mnookin and Susan Miller; sons-in-law James Mnookin and Harold Poster; grandchildren Seth (Sara), Abigail (Laura), Jacob (Isabel,) Julia, and step-grandson Jed; and great grandchildren Max, Eliza, and Lucy. Marjorie is predeceased by her husband, Dr. Seymour Miller; her first husband, Dr. Richard Reiss; and her sister, Judith Davis. Funeral services are private. Contributions can be made to Coney Island Prep, a public charter school founded by her grandson Jacob Mnookin, at 501 West Avenue, 3rd Floor, Brooklyn, NY 11224, or Calvary Home Hospice, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, NY 10461. 1/3

GARLAND--Harry, a native Southerner and a longtime resident of the Hotel Ansonia on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, passed away peacefully on May 18 at his retirement home in North Carolina. For nearly 50 years, he was a beloved voice teacher for many Metropolitan Opera artists, pop stars (Bette Midler, Jon Bon Jovi), and performers (F. Murray Abraham, Martin Short). Harry was a seminal force in forming the Ansonia Residents Association in the late '60s and as president, he led the fight to obtain landmark status for the building, preventing its demolition. He is survived by loving family and countless devoted friends. Donations may be made to Lees McRae College/Performing Arts Department, PO Box 128, Banner Elk, NC 28604. 1/3

ROSENBERG--Sheri With great sadness, the Yeshiva University community mourns the loss of our beloved colleague, teacher and friend Sheri Rosenberg, Clinical Professor of Law at the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law. Professor Rosenberg was Director of the Cardozo Law Institute in Holocaust and Human Rights, and Director of the Human Rights and Atrocity Prevention Clinic. A determined advocate and teacher, she inspired students in the use of the law to prevent genocide and mass atrocities. She represented asylum seekers from Haiti and Darfur, and won a landmark case on non-discrimination in the European Court of Human Rights. This spring she was awarded the Spirit of Anne Frank Award, and named a 2015 Peace Ambassador by The Center for Peacebuilding. She is survived by her husband, Gregg Kanter; her three children, Markus, 8, Maurice, 6, and Margaux, 5; her mother, Ann Rosenberg, wife of the late Marcus Rosenberg, and her siblings: Helen Rosenberg (and Shami) Waldman, Steven (and Ruthy) Rosenberg, Lizzy (and Dr. Jules) Greif, and mourned by Randy Pulitzer, husband of the late Margot Rosenberg. She will be deeply missed. May the entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus Matthew Diller, Dean, Cardozo School of Law Melanie Leslie, Dean-elect, Cardozo School of Law 1/3

MILLER--Marjorie, passed away peacefully in her home on May 25th at the age of 92. For many years a practicing social worker, Marjorie loved the city and took advantage of its cultural opportunities. She had a passion for reading and for many years ran a vibrant book group. She was a long-time member of Sunningdale Country Club, where she enjoyed golf and tennis and socializing with her many friends. While she loved these activities, the greatest joy in her life always came from her family: daughters Wendy Mnookin and Susan Miller; sons-in-law James Mnookin and Harold Poster; grandchildren Seth (Sara), Abigail (Laura), Jacob (Isabel,) Julia, and step-grandson Jed; and great grandchildren Max, Eliza, and Lucy. Marjorie is predeceased by her husband, Dr. Seymour Miller; her first husband, Dr. Richard Reiss; and her sister, Judith Davis. Funeral services are private. Contributions can be made to Coney Island Prep, a public charter school founded by her grandson Jacob Mnookin, at 501 West Avenue, 3rd Floor, Brooklyn, NY 11224, or Calvary Home Hospice, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, NY 10461. 1/3

ZIMMER--Donald J.,on May 24, 2015 of Wantagh, NY, at the age of 89. Beloved husband of Laurette. Loving father of Donald, Catherine Z. Collins, (J. Christopher), Anne Bradley (Brush), and Susanne Stone (James). Cherished grandfather of Thomas, Andrew, Rosie, Sarah, Daniel, Michelle, Nicole, Parker, and Christian. Adored brother of Robert (sister-in-law Marge), and the late John (late sister-in-law Patricia), and numerous nieces and nephews. He grew his strength from his faith, family and friends. His faith was unwavering, his love for his wife, children, grandchildren, brothers, sisters-in-law, nieces and nephews was endless, and his bond with his friends was cherished. He was thankful for these gifts and considered his life blessed. Proud WWII US Army Veteran. Graduate of St John's College (1949), St. John's University School of Law (1952), adjunct associate professor at St. John's University. Proud and long serving member of many organizations, as well as NY State Bar Association and Queens County Bar Association committees, including Ethics Committee, Grievance Committee, Executive Committee -- Trusts & Estates Law Section, Judiciary Committee, NY State Bar Association Executive Committee, member of American Bar Association Real Property, Probate & Trust Law Section, Fellow -- American College of Probate Counsel, Queensboro Lung Association, American Lung Association of Queens, Inc. Board, and Delegate to American Lung Association Council. Retired partner of Cahill, Hohl & Zimmer. Avid sailor and Past Commodore and member of South Bay Cruising Club, and past Board member of Unqua Corinthian Yacht Club. Family will receive friends Friday, 2-5 pm and 7-9 pm, at the Charles J. O'Shea Funeral Home: 603 Wantagh Ave. (Exit 28N SS PKWY) Wantagh, NY. Mass of Christian Burial will be held Saturday, 10:30am at St. Frances de Chantal R.C. Interment to follow at St. Charles Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory may be made to St. John's University, Jamaica, NY, or American Lung Association. www.osheafuneral.com 1/3

WOODWARD--John. John Hall Woodward, beloved teacher, noted historian, expert fisherman and devoted father, died May 25 in Kent, CT due to complications from Parkinson's disease. He was 80 and lived in South Kent, CT. Mr. Woodward was born December 5, 1934 in New Haven, CT, the son of Samuel Austin Woodward and Elizabeth Hall Woodward. He graduated from South Kent School in 1953, from Trinity College with a BA degree in History in 1957 and from Boston University with a Master's Degree in History in 1967. Mr. Woodward taught for 34 years at The Hill School, the boarding school in Pottstown, PA, holding positions as History Department Chair, Director of College Advising and Director of Studies. A classroom at The Hill School dedicated in his honor is adorned with a plaque bearing the inscription: A beloved, teacher, mentor, coach and friend, Uncle Woody' inspired generations of young scholars to love history, embrace learning and enjoy life. Mr. Woodward is survived by his wife of 53 years, Diane Whiteley Woodward; a sister, Alice W. Funnell of Orleans, MA; a daughter, Caroline W. Grant of Westborough, MA; a son, Gordon H. Woodward of Bedford Corners, NY; and four grandchildren. Mr. Woodward was predeceased by his son, Henry C. Woodward. The memorial service will be on Saturday, May 30 at 11:00am at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, 1 North Main Street in Kent, CT. The family has requested that, in lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: The John H. Woodward Master Teacher Award, The Hill School, Pottstown, PA 19464.

She was a personal friend and a client for over three decades providing us with 30 plus years of laughter. We grew up with Anne and Jerry making us laugh on the radio and even then you knew their love would last forever. Our sincere condolences to Jerry, Ben and Amy and the entire Stiller family. Sam Greenberger, the partners, staff and all of her devoted fans at Janover LLC Certified Public Accountants 1/3

RUBINSON--Eileen P. PhD.,passed away on May 20th after a year long illness. Daughter of the late Beatrice and Noah Rubinson, Eileen is survived by her brother Elliott, sister-in-law Pamela, and nephew Evan. Eileen was a dedicated psychotherapist who helped many people over her 43 year career at Montefiore. She will be greatly missed by family and friends. 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Lindsay Deak, died suddenly in her sleep at home on May 25, 2015 in Brooklyn, NY at the age of 37. Lindsay is survived by her husband Jason Friedman; her parents Robin Adelman (Barry) and Les Deak (Moshira); her sister Amanda, brother Travis Deak (Lindsay) and nephew Logan; her step-brothers and sisters Todd Adelman (Rebecca) and their daughter Abilene who gave her the nickname of Noodle; Lauren Adelman Perez (Sergio) and nephew Atticus; Adam Namoury (Celia), and Andrew Namoury; her mother-in-law Elaine Friedman and father-in-law Jerry Friedman; her brother- in-law Michael Friedman (Danielle) and their children Adam, Eric and Julie; and by her beloved dog Marvin. Lindsay was Vice President of Talent at Vimeo. She loved her job and her co-workers. More than that, she will be defined by her deep love for her family and friends. She was a loving, generous, witty and beautiful woman who brightened up the lives of all her knew her. Above all came her love for her husband, her family and her dog. She was avid about issues related to domestic violence awareness and cancer and often participated in events to raise money related to these issues. Lindsay was an extraordinary woman who impacted all the lives that she touched. She will be missed by all and will continue to be a large part of her family. A funeral is scheduled for Wednesday May 27, 2015 at 2:00pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St., NY. All are welcome to attend and celebrate Lindsay's all too short life. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Safe Horizon, Donor Services, 2 Lafayette Street, 3rd Floor, NY, NY 10007. 1/3

ZWICKLER--Seymour, of Hollywood, FL. On May 24, 2015 Seymour passed away peacefully at the age of 85. He is survived by his children Caren Levine, Allen Zwickler and Ellen Pikitch. PLATT--Marguerite Beer. February 6, 1937 - May 19, 2015. A 4th generation New Yorker, born to Andrew E. Beer and Marguerite Eilers, she graduated from the Chapin School and Wellesley College where she majored in economics and led the Tupelos singing group. For 13 years as a senior editor, writer and security analyst for Investor's Reader at Merrill Lynch she won interviews with over 1,000 CEOs. An early president of the Financial Women's Association, she redefined the mission and established a much needed network and support system for the professional advancement of women. While she raised her children she taught financial management to women and lobbied for fair tax treatment for working mothers. In 1988 she began her career in real estate, eventually becoming an EVP of Halstead Property LLC, where she worked tirelessly until the end. Her full life included the Blue Hill Troupe, Grosvenor Neighborhood House and the City Gardens Club. She loved golf, gardening, singing, her three golden retrievers and her family and friends. She was a member of the Colony Club, the Quogue Field Club and the Quogue Beach Club. She is survived by her loving husband of 50 years, David N. Platt and her children David S. Platt and Marguerite F. (Daisy) Platt. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, June 4th at 4pm at St. James Church, 865 Madison Avenue. Contributions in her memory may be sent to the City Gardens Club of New York City, 755 Park Ave, NY NY 10021. 1/3

STELTENPOHL--Elizabeth, died on May 22, 2015, in New York City. A native of Cincinnati, Ohio, she has lived in New York since the 1960s. She held bachelor's and master's degrees from the Jesuit University of Detroit and a doctorate from Columbia University. She was a professor of Education at Manhattanville College and at Empire State College of the State University of New York. She took part in the Archdiocesan Education Outreach Program for homeless persons and was a sponsor for the Inner City Scholarship Fund. Betsy is survived by her sister, Jane, and a number of cousins. Memorial donation suggestions: St. Francis Friends of the Poor (website); Habitat for Humanity (habitat.org). Visitation: Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Ave (70th St.), Thursday, May 28, 6- 9pm. Mass of Christian Burial, Church of St. Catherine of Siena, 411 East 68th St., Friday, May 29, 10am. 1/3

CULLMAN--Nan Ogburn. Nan Cullman, singer and explorer, died following a stroke on Monday, May 18, at her home in Pittsboro, North Carolina. She was 85. Born in Smithfield, North Carolina in 1929, Nan began a singing career at the age of 15 when she won a scholarship in a statewide competition to attend the Julliard School in New York. She also studied at Columbia University and the University of Heidelberg in Germany. She performed throughout her life with regional opera companies and choral societies. Her favorite role was Fiordiligi from Mozart's Cosi fan tutte that she performed for the Westchester Opera Company. In 1951, she married Hugh Cullman, son of Broadway 'angel' and Port Authority Chairman, Howard S. Cullman, and made her home in Westchester County, New York for the next 40 years. She was active with civic organizations, serving on the board of Youth Consultation Service of New York, the vestry of Christ's Church, Rye and as a volunteer working in the recovery room at United Hospital in Port Chester, New York. She was also a long-term board member of the North Carolina Symphony. In her 40s, Mrs. Cullman took up mountain- eering and other extreme travel pursuits, riding camels with the Tuareg tribe through the Hoggar Mountains of southern Algeria, climbing to the Everest base camps from both the Nepalese and Tibetan sides and obtaining one of the first visas to hike through Bhutan. She almost lost her life on Everest, when she was blinded and at the summit of Mount Kilimanjaro where she was overcome by altitude sickness. According to her daughter, Alexandra Haslingden, "Long before Sheryl Sandberg challenged women to lean in, my mother was jumping in." As recently as 2013, she was hiking in the Dolomites and this year was planning an expedition to the Highlands of Scotland. Mrs. Cullman is survived by her husband Hugh Cullman as well as her three children, Katherine Hedges of London, England, Hugh Cullman Jr. of Rye, New York, and Alexandra Haslingden of Sydney, Australia, and nine grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at St. Paul's Church in Beaufort, NC on Wednesday, May 27 at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the North Carolina Community Foundation. 919-828-4387. nccommunityfoundation.org 1/3

DORFMAN--Jancy. Friend, Colleague, Mentor, Camp Industry pioneer. We mourn her loss. Bruce and Dan Zenkel 1/3

GILBERT--S. Parker. The Trustees, Fellows, and staff of the Morgan Library & Museum are deeply saddened by the death of S. Parker Gilbert, President Emeritus of the Board of Trustees. He served as President from 1988 to 2011, a period of institutional growth and transformation. Parker's formidable intellect and character were matched and complemented by his profoundly generous spirit. His passion for the Morgan, and the cultural tradition and values it represents, came from the heart. In 2011, Parker received the Morgan Medal, reserved for those few, in each generation, who embody the founders' legacy of philanthropy and leadership. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family and all those who mourn the loss of this great man. Lawrence R. Ricciardi, Pres. Peggy Fogelman, Acting Dir. 1

WEITHORN--Stanley S. 1924 - 2015. Stanley S. Weithorn passed away on Thursday, April 16, 2015 at age 90 at Hospice of the Valley in Scottsdale, Arizona. Born in New York in 1924, he lived a vibrant and productive life. He received his law degree and masters in tax law from New York University. Passionate about social justice, he wrote the seminal multi-volume legal treatise on tax strategies for non-profit organizations, becoming a leader in the field, while representing scores of diverse charitable groups, advising policymakers, and advocating for social reform. His tireless advocacy of liberal causes earned him a spot on Richard Nixon's "Enemies List." He married Corinne Breslow in 1949. Three years after Corinne's 1987 death, he married Muriel ("Mikki") Casper. He is survived by Mikki, his two children, Lois and Michael, his step-son Corey Casper, his grandchildren, Zachary, Cara, Nina, and Delphine, and his brothers, Robert and Howard. Donations in his memory may be made to the American Civil Liberties Union Foundation or Jewish Family and Children's Services of San Francisco. 1/3

MEARA--Anne. The board, staff and playwrights of New Dramatists mourn the passing of Anne Meara. She and Jerry were always there for us in good times and bad, hosting fundraising events and lending their comic gifts to our annual luncheon. Anne was like family, and we want to reach out to her family, Jerry, Ben and Amy, to say how much we loved her and how her spirit lives on in our hearts. 1/3
BROWN-- Lucy. The congregation of Shaaray Tefila records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member. May her memory be for blessing. Rabbi Deborah A. Hirsch Michael Starr, President 1/3

GILBERT--S. Parker, beloved husband to Gail (Auchincloss) for 55 years, died on Wednesday, May 27th, 2015. He was eighty-one years old. Mr. Gilbert was chairman of Morgan Stanley from 1983-90, as well as former president of the Morgan Library and vice president of The Metropolitan Museum of Art. He leaves behind three children, Lynn Tudor, S. Parker Gilbert Jr., and David Gilbert, and eight grandchildren, all of whom will miss him very much. Services are still being arranged. 1

WOODWARD--John. John Hall Woodward, beloved teacher, noted historian, expert fisherman and devoted father, died May 25 in Kent, CT due to complications from Parkinson's disease. He was 80 and lived in South Kent, CT. Mr. Woodward was born December 5, 1934 in New Haven, CT, the son of Samuel Austin Woodward and Elizabeth Hall Woodward. He graduated from South Kent School in 1953, from Trinity College with a BA degree in History in 1957 and from Boston University with a Master's Degree in History in 1967. Mr. Woodward taught for 34 years at The Hill School, the boarding school in Pottstown, PA, holding positions as History Department Chair, Director of College Advising and Director of Studies. A classroom at The Hill School dedicated in his honor is adorned with a plaque bearing the inscription: A beloved, teacher, mentor, coach and friend, Uncle Woody' inspired generations of young scholars to love history, embrace learning and enjoy life. Mr. Woodward is survived by his wife of 53 years, Diane Whiteley Woodward; a sister, Alice W. Funnell of Orleans, MA; a daughter, Caroline W. Grant of Westborough, MA; a son, Gordon H. Woodward of Bedford Corners, NY; and four grandchildren. Mr. Woodward was predeceased by his son, Henry C. Woodward. The memorial service will be on Saturday, May 30 at 11:00am at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, 1 North Main Street in Kent, CT. The family has requested that, in lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: The John H. Woodward Master Teacher Award, The Hill School, Pottstown, PA 19464.

EINEMANN--Julius, passed away at 96 years old. He is survived by his loving wife, Marilyn, of 35 years. Father of Karen King, Candice Werrbach, Ronald Einemann and Robert Einemann, as well the late Glenn Abarno and Francine Einemann. Also survived by many grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Jules was a veteran of the US Army, he was a Sergeant in the 56th Field Artillery Batallion during World War II. Jules received the Silver Star for gallantry in action, the Bronze Star for heroic service, among many other awards. He also was a Captain in the Bethpage Fire Department. He loved serving the community as a fire-fighter and an EMT. He retired from the New York Times, where he was supervisor in the composing room. During his retirement, he enjoyed gardening and traveling the country with his wife, often visiting his military friends. Jules will be interred in our Nation's prestigious Arlington National Cemetery in Virginia with military honors. He was an All-American Hero that loved God, country and family. 1/3

SEXTON--Joan Fleming. Born March 1, 1926; Died May 26, 2015. Mother, mystic, Catholic feminist, poet, witness for peace and advocate for justice. The fifth of six children born to Peter Emmet Fleming and Anna Sullivan. She is survived by her husband of 58 years, Richard; her six children, Molly, Joe, Lucy, Michael, Ann and Kate; and her grandchildren, Ben, Sam, Jane, Lucy, James, Megan, Annabel, Nina, Maisie, Flynn, Rowan, Penelope and Leah. "The beginning of love is to let those we love be perfectly themselves, and not to twist them to fit our own image. Otherwise we love only the reflection of ourselves we find in them." She will be waked Friday, May 29 at the Montauk Club, 25 8th Avenue, Brooklyn. Hours: 3 to 5pm and 6 to 8. The funeral mass will be at 10am Saturday, May 30, at St. Boniface, R.C. Church, 109 Willoughby Street, Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers, poems. 1/3

TALAL--Dr. Norman, an international authority on Sjogren's Syndrome, passed away after a long illness. A founder of Rheumatology and Clinical Immunology in the United States, he contributed to the field internationally by mentoring over 80 medical fellows and scientists from Europe, Asia, and South America. He received the Hench Award from the US Public Health Service and the Middleton Award, the VA's top honor for medical research. Besides many professional accomplishments, he was a brilliant joke teller whose personality was filled with warmth, enthusiasm, elegance, and graciousness. He was an incredible art collector and enjoyed traveling among many other activities. He was a true role model in many different facets of life. He is survived by his wife, Marilynn, their children, Andrew and Melissa, grand-daughter Lilly, and many dear cousins. A memorial, The Norman Talal MD Endowed Fellowship in Rheumatology, has been established: https://makelivesbetter. uthscsa.edu/talal. 1/3

PLATT--Marguerite. Terra Holdings and Halstead Property share with great sorrow the passing of our longtime, devoted agent, Marguerite Platt. An Agent with Halstead for 25 years and based in our Park Avenue office, Marguerite was a consummate professional who specialized in the high-end market throughout Manhattan. Over the course of her lengthy career, she built a widely respected reputation in the community for her strong ethics, sharp negotiation skills and perseverance. Marguerite was honored to be included in the Halstead's Producer's Council and in the last few years, she had worked closely with her son, David. Our deepest condolences to her beloved husband, David, her daughter Daisy, her son, David and her entire family and loved ones. 1/3

LANE-- Joan M. Mutual of America and its Board of Directors, together with its officers and employees, wish to express our deep sense of loss at the passing of our colleague and friend, Joan M. Lane, who served as Senior Field Vice President of the Mutual of America New York Regional Office. Joan Lane joined Mutual of America in 1976 and retired after thirteen years of dedicated service, during which she exemplified the highest standards of excellence, commitment and integrity. Throughout her years with the Company, Joan's pride and belief in the Mission of Mutual of America were evidenced by her outstanding record of sales and service year after year. She freely shared her experience and knowledge, inspiring others to take on greater challenges. Joan Lane was one of a kind. Her life touched many, and her fidelity and concern for those organizations served by Mutual of America will long be remembered. Thomas J. Moran Chairman and CEO John R. Greed President Mutual of America Life Insurance Company 1
TELLER--Seth J. Lovingly remembered, always. 1/3

SELTZER--Adele, 86, passed away unexpectedly on May 27th. Beloved wife of the late Hal Seltzer. Dear sister of Sidney Bender and his wife Marjorie and the late Sheila Henry and her husband Howard. Devoted mother of Amy, Harry, Steven and Sharon. Cherished grandmother of Emily, Jessica, Ellie, Samantha, Jacob and Joshua. She was born in Toronto, Canada on March 19, 1929, but lived most of her life in New York City, spending her summers in Saltaire, Fire Island. She loved all the finer things in life, especially her grandchildren, and lived her life with grace and dignity. Funeral services Friday, 9:30am at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC. 1/3

JACKREL--Rebecca Robin 43, passed away on Sunday, May 3rd two years after being diagnosed with incurable cancer. After a long winding path - starting with a Masters in music education in New York, to working at a solder manufacturing company in Texas, to providing Quality Assurance at a software company in Silicon Valley, to practicing as a Veterinary Technician at pet hospitals in San Francisco - Rebecca finally found her passion as a wildlife photographer. In the short time she had to practice her art, Rebecca journeyed to all seven continents. With her focus on conservation, she highlighted the dangers of the Pacific Garbage Patch to her beloved albatross, the great toll climate change has inflicted on polar bears, the horrible boat wounds suffered by manatees and more. She also captured the beauty of the natural world, from penguins warming their eggs in Antarctica, to a humpback whale relaxing with her calf in the Dominican Republic, to a polar bear swimming through a glowing twilight near the North Pole. Her crowning achievement was the Ethiopian Wolf Project, a program she created to raise awareness for the critically endangered Ethiopian Wolf. In 2011, after spending five weeks in the highlands of Ethiopia accompanied by fellow wildlife photographer Will Burrard- Lucas, Rebecca produced "The Ethiopian Wolf: Hope at the Edge of Extinction", the definitive book on this unique creature and its struggle for survival. Rebecca's work can be seen at her website: http://www. rebeccajackrel.com/, or through her stock agencies: Alamy, Getty, AGE Fotostock, Danita Delimont and PhotoShelter. More of her work, insights into her process and her chronicle of living with cancer can be found at her blog: http://rebecca jackrel.blogspot.com/. Rebecca's photographs will be featured in the upcoming book "When Mountain Lions are Neighbors: Wildlife in Today's California", by Beth Pratt-Bergstrom, to be published in early 2016 by Heyday Books. Rebecca's art, her dedication to conservation, and the grace and strength with which she faced her final years are an inspiration to us all. Please make any contributions in Rebecca's name to: The Wildlife Conservation Network, Defenders of Wildlife, Forests Forever. 1/3
HOCHMAN--Bertha. June 7, 1919 - May 29, 2013 Always in my heart. Loved, missed forever. Your loving daughter, Nettie 1/3

LANE--Joan M. Mutual of America and its Board of Directors, together with its officers and employees, wish to express our deep sense of loss at the passing of our colleague and friend, Joan M. Lane, who served as Senior Field Vice President of the Mutual of America New York Regional Office. Joan Lane joined Mutual of America in 1976 and retired after thirteen years of dedicated service, during which she exemplified the highest standards of excellence, commitment and integrity. Throughout her years with the Company, Joan's pride and belief in the Mission of Mutual of America were evidenced by her outstanding record of sales and service year after year. She freely shared her experience and knowledge, inspiring others to take on greater challenges. Joan Lane was one of a kind. Her life touched many, and her fidelity and concern for those organizations served by Mutual of America will long be remembered. William J. Flynn Chairman Emeritus Thomas J. Moran Chairman and CEO John R. Greed President Mutual of America Life Insurance Company 1/3

FAMULARO--Joseph John, 92, of West Palm Beach, FL passed away Wednesday, May 27 2015 in Danbury Hospital in Connecticut at midnight. Joe was born May 29, 1922 in New York City to Angela Cerabone and Joseph Anthony Famularo. His long-time friend, Bernard H. Kinzer, predeceased him on July 30, 2012. Joe attended NYC public schools, the University of Kentucky (BA), and Columbia University (MA). In 1946, after four years in military service as an Air Force Cadet Trainee during World War II, he spent one year in Geneva, Switzerland at the School for International Studies visiting Italy, England, and France. He worked at The New York Times, eight years at Revlon in NYC, at Columbia Engineering in NYC's corporate offices, and at McGraw-Hill for 25 years, where he was the youngest Vice-President and youngest Senior Vice President appointed at that time. He authored several books on management and, after retirement from the business world, soon became known as a prolific food writer. He published 12 books on food, four of which received James Beard Awards and awards from IACP and IRDA. His writings appeared in The New York Times, the Los Angeles Times, and most magazines and newspapers devoted to food. He was president of the Board of Trustees of Hartley House, a community center on New York's west side for over 25 years, a member of the Perly Fund Foundation for 20 years. Joe lived in NYC, Pawling, NY, and in Key West and West Palm Beach, FL, for the last 30 years. Joe's loves were his family, friends, faith and country. He was known for his wit, loyalty, kindness, humor and charm. Always ready to assist those in need, he quietly gave support to many. He liked people who showed initiative and willingness to assume responsibility. He is survived by his youngest sister, Louise Famularo Imperiale (John) of New Milford, CT, many nieces and nephews, and his "adopted family" Cristopher and Sheila Laus and their daughters Keeshia and Chiara, who cared for Joe with tender loving care for many years. "You have been like a father to me in so many ways. You have taught me to be a man. You have given me support, care and love. You would have been a great father. Thanks for sharing your life with us." Cristopher and family. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 11am on Monday, June 1, 2015 at St. John's Church, Pawling, NY. Joe will be buried in the Old Quaker Hill Cemetery in Pawling. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Hartley House, 413 West 46 Street, NY, NY 10036 or to Historical Society of Quaker Hill and Pawling, 126 East Main Street, Pawling, NY 12564. Services are under the direction of the Horn & Thomes, Inc. Funeral Home, 83 East Main Street, Pawling, NY. For directions or to leave an online condolence, please visit www.hornandthomes funeralhome.com. 1/3

Church, 109 Willoughby Street, Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers, poems. 1/3

GILBERT--S. Parker. The Trustees, Fellows, and staff of the Morgan Library & Museum are deeply saddened by the death of S. Parker Gilbert, President Emeritus of the Board of Trustees. He served as President from 1988 to 2011, a period of institutional growth and transformation. Parker's formidable intellect and character were matched and complemented by his profoundly generous spirit. His passion for the Morgan, and the cultural tradition and values it represents, came from the heart. In 2011, Parker received the Morgan Medal, reserved for those few, in each generation, who embody the founders' legacy of philanthropy and leadership. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family and all those who mourn the loss of this great man. Lawrence R. Ricciardi, Pres. Peggy Fogelman, Acting Dir. 1

JARETZKI--Alfred III, MD. Always 1/3

MUNRO--William Pierce, died quietly on May 26, 2015, in the hospital where he was born on April 17, 1922, near his home in Bronxville, NY. Beloved husband of 62 years to the late Betty Munro, loving father of Constance Munro Kamerman (Jack) and the late Leslie, grandfather to Anne, David, and William and Noelle; uncle to Deb, Bruce, and David; brother-in-law to Marjorie and Gordon. After graduating from Colgate University in 1943 he went on to serve his country in WWII, where he was a veteran of the Normandy Invasion, defense of Europe, and liberation of concentration camps. He was a faithful friend to many who admired his intellect, integrity, humor, loyalty, kindness, and generosity. As an honest, successful, and trusted businessman, he embodied the American work ethic and personified the American dream throughout his years at Sylvania, CBS International, and Sylvan Ginsbury, Ltd. Bill loved his family, his cats, his lifelong friends Bob and Joe, the Yankees and the New York Giants, Glenn Miller, The New York Times crossword, a good tennis game and a fine single malt Scotch. He was proud of his Scottish heritage, his military service, his business career, his home and family, and of having been at Yankee Stadium for Don Larsen's perfect game in the 1956 World Series. He was grateful to Yvonne and Mona for their devoted nursing of both himself and his late wife, Betty, and sad to have been preceded in death by Betty, Leslie, and Gordon. He is mourned by everyone who knew him. Donations to New York- Presbyterian/Lawrence Hospital, 55 Palmer Road, Bronxville NY 10708 www.nyplawrence.org, or the American Heart Association, both of which, together with the excellent Dr. Salvate, helped keep him with us for many years. 1/3

GILBERT--S. Parker, beloved husband to Gail (Auchincloss) for 55 years, died on Wednesday, May 27th, 2015. He was eighty-one years old. Mr. Gilbert was chairman of Morgan Stanley from 1987-94, as well as former president of the Morgan Library and vice president of The Metropolitan Museum of Art. He leaves behind three children, Lynn Tudor, S. Parker Gilbert Jr., and David Gilbert, and eight grandchildren, all of whom will miss him very much. Services to be held at St. James' Church, 71st St and Madison Ave, on Thursday, June 11 at 11am. In lieu of flowers please make donations to the Morgan Library or the Metropolitan Museum of Art. 1

GRIEGO--Tanya. We mourn the passing of Tanya Griego who died at home in Biloxi, MS on April 12, 2015 at 46 years of age. She is survived by her husband Vernon and her father Ron Schlosberg. Tanya served as a captain in the USAF. After completing military service, she worked as a psychotherapist at the Veterans Center in Biloxi, MS. The time devoted to her veterans was her life's passion touching many lives. She was a sensitive, kind and caring person with a life filled with love, laughter and family. 1/3

GILBERT--S. Parker. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn deeply the passing of Parker Gilbert, a devoted leader and friend of the Museum, and one of the most active and influential trustees in its history. He shared his advice and broad expertise over many years as a Trustee (1990-2010), Trustee Emeritus (2010-15), and Vice Chairman of the Board (1999-2010). His involvement also extended to chairing the Met's nominating and investment committees, and serving actively as a member of its executive, compensation, finance, budget, acquisitions, employee benefits, and institutional responsibility committees, as well as the Visiting Committee for the Department of Modern and Contemporary Art. With his wife Gail, he made generous contributions to the Museum, including a landmark gift in 2000 establishing an endowment fund that provides vital support for a range of exhibitions. Parker was a calm, authoritative, and reassuring leader, particularly during times of fiscal strain, and he was always able to look beyond the horizon to define and continue to build a healthier museum. He was a mentor to staff and fellow Trustees, and also contributed generously in the tradition of his family, the Morgans. Always high-minded and determined, while deeply human and philanthropic, he was an extraordinary colleague whom we will miss greatly. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Gail and to the entire family. Daniel Brodsky, Chairman Thomas P. Campbell, Director and CEO Emily K. Rafferty, President Emerita 1

GILBERT--S. Parker. NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital is deeply saddened by the loss of a dear friend and benefactor, S. Parker Gilbert III. A former Chairman of Morgan Stanley Group Inc., Mr. Gilbert was a visionary leader whose generosity has made a tremendous impact on our institution. With his wife Gail, he was an early and dedicated supporter of two signature projects at the Hospital, both bearing the Morgan Stanley name -- the Morgan Stanley Children's Hospital of NewYork-Presbyterianolumbia University Medical Center and the soon-to-be-completed Morgan Stanley Adult Emergency Department at NewYork-Presbyterian/Columbia. His philanthropic efforts have touched the lives of thousands of patients and will continue to serve those in need for many years to come. We offer our most sincere condolences to his wife Gail, their three children Lynn, Parker and David, and all of his family and loved ones. Frank A. Bennack, Jr., Chairman of the Board Steven J. Corwin, MD, CEO Herbert Pardes, MD, Executive Vice Chair NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital 1/3

Also survived by six grandchildren and eight great-grandchil-dren. Services will be private. For obituary, guestbook and donations visit: www.concordfuneral.com 1/3

GILLIGAN--Edward P. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts are deeply saddened by the news of the passing of Edward P. Gilligan, President of the American Express Company. Ed joined our Board in December of 2010 and served Lincoln Center as a member of the Executive Committee, the New Ventures Committee and the Lincoln Center Global Committee. He was a friend and inspiration to all who worked with him. We extend our sympathies to his colleagues at American Express, and to his wife, Lisa, and their children. Katherine Farley, Chair Jed Bernstein, President Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts 1/3

Board of Directors 1
