TAFT--William Halsted, Jr.,of New Vernon, NJ died Thursday, May 14, 2015 after a brave battle with Parkinson's Disease. He was 86. Mr. Taft was a distant cousin of President William Howard Taft. Mr. Taft was born in Montclair, NJ but lived most of his life in Harding Township, NJ where he was a member of the Planning Board for over sixteen years including two years as Chairman, and a member of the Township Committee for twelve years, the last six as Mayor. He was presented the Distinguished Citizen Award by the township in 1989. He was also a former Trustee of The Harding Land Trust and a long time volunteer at The Seeing Eye in Morristown, NJ. After Graduating from The Lawrenceville School In 1948, Mr. Taft attended Rutgers University where he received a Bachelors Degree in Economics. He continued his studies at Northwestern University and New York University Graduate School of business. Mr. Taft entered the U.S. Army and spent 14 months in Korea during the war. For his service in Korea he received The Korean Service Medal with one Bronze Star, The United Nations Korean Service Medal, The National Defense Service Medal and The Army Commendation Medal. After his military service he joined The Prudential Insurance Company in Newark, NJ eventually becoming a Vice President of Investments. Upon leaving Prudential in 1990, Mr. Taft helped organize Asset Corporation of America, Inc., a minority owned pension asset management firm in Alexandria, VA. Mr. Taft was a devoted family man who leaves two sons, William Potter Taft of New Vernon, NJ, Timothy Enger Taft of New York, NY, a sister, Fay Taft Fawcett, her husband Edward plus their two daughters, Ashley Greene and Pamela Hynes and their families. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, June 6th at 11am at The Edith Memorial Chapel, The Lawrenceville School, 2500 Main Street, Lawrenceville, NJ 08648. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name can be made to The Harding Land Trust, P.O. Box 576, New Vernon, NJ 07976. 1/3

STEVENS KRIS--Kathryn Emily. Adored wife, beloved daughter, cherished and trusted friend, Kaly passed away May 24, 2015 in Washington, DC. Born April 23, 1986 in La Jolla, CA, raised in Cardiff-by-the-Sea, CA, Sparta, NJ and Flagstaff, AZ, Kaly graduated cum laude from Georgetown University in 2008 with a major in Russian Language and a minor in Business. Artistic, musical, and athletic, Kaly was a former Sales Manager at Meltwater News in Washington, DC and Dubai, UAE, and an Accounts Manager at Opower, Inc. in Arlington, VA. Wife of Robert Edward Kris of New York, NY, daughter of David and Marian Stevens of Flagstaff, AZ, daughter-in-law of Mark and Mary Ellen Kris and sister-in-law of Mary Kiernan Kris. Her radiant smile and wonderful laugh will be missed by all. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to the Kaly Stevens Kris Sarcoma Research Fund at http://mskcc.convio.net/go to/KalyStevensKris. A service celebrating Kaly's life will be held Saturday June 6th on the campus of Georgetown University. 1/3

CARTER--Elizabeth S.,on Friday, May 29 in Richfield Springs, NY, widow of Peyton F. Carter II, mother of Peyton F. Carter III, sister of Bill Scott, grandmother to three. Memorial service to be held at St. Thomas More at 65 E. 89th St., NYC, June 11, 10:30am. 1/3

GRUNIG--Joseph, of New York City, died on May 2, 2015. Born April 28, 1923, in New Mexico, he grew up in Portales. He was admitted by competitive exam to US Naval Academy during WW II and later received a BA from Harvard College, class of 1948, with studies at the Graduate School of Architecture. His first wife was artist Dorothy Heller. Joe practiced architecture until February, 2015, the last 36 years as a partner in Grunig and Wertz Architects. Early projects include the original Pan Am terminal at JFK Airport while at TAMS E&A and, in his own practice, the first La Mama Experimental Theater Club at 66 E 4th St. He leaves Suzanne Wertz, his wife and architectural partner, nieces, nephews, and a sister-in-law. 1/3

RACHLIN--Edward. Our loss is profound. Dr. Edward Rachlin passed away on May 27. He will remain in memory as a man who exemplified the best a human being could be. Ed entered medical school at seventeen and his passion for working in the field of medicine never ceased, treating patients until the time of his death. An orthopedic Surgeon and Physical Medicine specialist in New York City and Watchung NJ, he was a rarity in the field, always maintaining an holistic perspective. In the last two decades he and his wife Barbara also volunteered their skills in Africa and Asia through Health Volunteers Overseas. A Renaissance man, Ed was an outstanding tennis player, even in his 80's besting opponents half his age. Throughout his life, his clarinet was the vehicle through which he expressed the music in his soul. We were privileged to have known this beautiful man of impeccable integrity, who was humble, kind, compassionate, generous, and wise beyond measure. He is survived by his wife Barbara, his daughters Katherine and Isabel and his son John. He loved unconditionally. Donations can be made to Health Volunteers Overseas https://hvousa.org. 1/3

BURT--Sylvia, peacefully, surrounded by three generations of her loving family, on May 28, 2015. Beloved wife of the late Samuel Dworkis and Paul Burt. Devoted mother of Susan and Michael Nash. Adored grandmother of Ali Nash Lesch and Dani Nash. Cherished sister of Arthur Rosenthal and the late Rose Hibbel. Dear great-grand- mother of Charles, Daniel and Willa. Service Sunday, May 31, 2015, 11:15am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in her memory may be made to ASPCA. 1/3

BOOTH--Stephen A.,passed away peacefully May 27, 2015 at the age of 62 after a long battle with illness. Steve was a veteran technology journalist before the term was invented, well-respected for his fair, objective, and thorough coverage of the consumer electronics industry. While much of his sterling career was spent working for Consumer Electronics Daily, Steve also served as editor-in-chief of Video Review magazine and as a staff editor with Popular Mechanics magazine. Steve's byline also appeared in many other publications, including Rolling Stone and Popular Science. Steve is fondly remembered by his friends and colleagues at CES Publishing where he worked early in his career. Born in Manhattan's Greenwich Village, Steve lived in Dobbs Ferry and Hartsdale, NY in recent decades. Steve's passionate love of baseball was well-known and he served as coach and board member of the Elmsford Little League for 17 years. Steve is a graduate of Cardinal Spellman High School and New York University where he developed a lifelong interest in history. Steve is survived by Jody Booth and their two beloved sons, James and Daniel, his brother Thomas and sister Vicky and her husband Robert Whitaker and their children Robert and Matthew. Visitation Monday 2-5pm and 7-9pm at McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home, 491 Mamaroneck Ave White Plains, NY 10605 where services will take place Tuesday at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers please make donations to either Rosary Hill Home, 600 Linda Ave, Hawthorne, NY 10532 or Phelps Hospice, 701 North Broadway Sleepy Hollow, NY 10591. 1/3

LIBO--William Hershel M.D. January 20, 1928 - May 29, 2015. Dr. Libo of Stamford, CT, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, died peacefully at home. Dr. Libo was born in Norwich, CT, the son of Betty and Louis Libo. He was a proud graduate of the Norwich Free Academy, Tufts University, and Tufts University Medical School. He served in the U.S. Navy from 1953 to 1955 and was the Medical Officer aboard the USS Northampton. He practiced general pediatrics in Brooklyn, NY for over 40 years. Devoted husband of 63 years to his beloved wife, Libby. Loving father of daughter Sheryl (Max) of Playa Del Carmen, Mexico; son David (Miriam) of Los Angeles, CA; and late son Andrew (Jean) of Larchmont, NY. He is also survived by his adoring sister Eunice Greenberg of New London, CT as well as 10 grandchildren, one great-grandson, an aunt, and many cousins, nieces and nephews. 1/3
PINSKER--Jack, great father, husband and friend left us on May 29. He will always be "The Captain" and will live forever in our hearts. 1/3

BROAD--Gerald H. Gerald H. Broad. (1935-2015) of Del Mar, CA passed away after a long battle with heart disease. General Dynamics engineer, artist and beach walker. He will be missed by friends and family. 1/3

GROPP--Ann-Maria. After an especially brave battle, Ann-Maria Gropp passed away at home in New York City on Friday, May 22, 2015, surrounded by family. As wife, partner, best and greatest friend for the past 27 years, she is survived by her husband, Gregory Whyte. She is also survived by her brothers Kevin and Stephen Gropp and their families. Ann-Maria had the kindest and gentlest soul. She had an enormous heart and was always concerned about the well-being and happiness of others. She was the best friend anyone could wish for and her trove of life-long friends, all considering her their "BFF", are testament to that. As an educator and Reading Specialist, Ann-Maria dedicated herself professionally to advancing the skills of those left behind in the classroom, and worked tirelessly to help them catch up. Ann-Maria always tread so softly on this earth and asked so little of it. The vacuum she leaves behind is larger than her modesty would have anyone know. Ann-Maria grew up in Ridgewood, NJ, graduated from Syracuse University, and completed her Masters at Teachers College Columbia University. In accordance with Ann-Maria's wishes, the funeral and cremation will be held privately on Monday May 25th, 2015 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in Ann-Maria's memory to The Animal Medical Center, 510 East 62nd Street, NYC 10065 or Channel THIRTEEN PBS, 835 Eighth Avenue, NYC 10019. 1/3

SHERWIN--Rabbi and Professor Byron L.,Ph.D., age 69, born in New York, NY. Beloved husband of Judith, (nee Schwartz) Sherwin; adoring father of Jason Sherwin; cherished son of Jean and the late Sidney Sherwin; devoted brother of Elliott (Sharon) Sherwin; caring uncle of Beth (Michael) Buls (nee Sherwin), David and Hope Sherwin. Funeral services were held at the Park Avenue Synagogue and officiated by his esteemed student, Rabbi Elliot Cosgrove. Memorial services at Spertus Institute for Jewish Learning and Leadership in Chicago will be announced at a later date. 1/3

ETKES--Asher. Asher Ben-Ami Etkes, died peacefully on May 2, 2015, in New York City, with his wife Charlene by his side. Asher, son of the late Peretz and Yafia (Rothschild) Etkes was born in Haifa, Israel on September 8, 1923. He was schooled at the prestigious Beit Hasefer Hareali in Israel, and at age 15, moved to the United States to further his education. Asher attended the Carnegie Institute of Technology (Carnegie Mellon University) where he studied architecture. Upon the outbreak of World War II, Asher entered the United States Navy. After graduating from Carnegie Institute, he formed his first public relations firm specializing in counseling professionals in the field of architecture. Asher later co-founded the nation's first company offering color negatives for newspaper printing. He was at the forefront of his field in the development of new concepts of play environments for children. He created special playgrounds for able and disabled children who learn through successful movement and games. His most rewarding achievement was the playground at the Frances Blend School For The Visually Handicapped in California. Asher was also one of the first producers of unique modular containment systems for environmental protection with his company, ModuTank. He was a pioneer in many fields in both business and industry during his lifetime. He also had written and lectured on early years' educational development through physical play and on public relations and marketing issues. Asher was a unique man of many talents possessing extraordinary vision. He was most proud of his book entitled Jewish Contributions to the American Way of Life. Asher was well- known for his charming manner and story telling, most often accompanied by his gift for joke telling. Asher was an ardent fan of both the New York Giants and the New York Mets. Whether at Giants Stadium or watching the game with friends, he always had an enthralled audience, as he called many "plays" before they actually happened. Asher was also pre-deceased by his sister Adina Etkes. He is survived by his wife, Charlene Soltz Etkes; his nephew, Dr. Donald Etkes and his niece Jacqueline Soltz. 1/3

FRAUENTHAL--Stephen C. The Helene Fuld College of Nursing Board of Trustees, Faculty, Staff, and Students regret the passing of Stephen C. Frauenthal. Stephen C. Frauenthal, passed away peacefully after a long illness on the morning of Wednesday, May 27, 2015. Known to many as "Steve" or "Frau", he will be remembered for his dedicated service and generous support of Helene Fuld College of Nursing, in Harlem, where he served on the Board of Trustees. We are thankful for his service and longstanding commitment to the College, and extend our heartfelt sympathy to his brother, Dr. James C. Frauenthal. In lieu of flowers, his family has asked that donations be sent to two of the charitable organizations that Steve held close. Contributions may be sent to Helene Fuld College of Nursing, 24 East 120th Street, NY, NY 10035, Attn: Barbara Paxton, Director of Development, or the Chief's Fund, 19 Watchtower Road, Hopkinton, NH 03229, Attn: Ruth B. Needleman, Assistant Treasurer. 1/3

GILLIGAN--Edward P. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts are deeply saddened by the news of the passing of Edward P. Gilligan, President of the American Express Company. Ed joined our Board in December of 2010 and served Lincoln Center as a member of the Executive Committee, the New Ventures Committee and the Lincoln Center Global Committee. He was a friend and inspiration to all who worked with him. We extend our sympathies to his colleagues at American Express, and to his wife, Lisa, and their children. Katherine Farley, Chair Jed Bernstein, President Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts 1/3

FRAUENTHAL--Stephen C.,son of Roslyn L. and Herman C. Frauenthal, died peacefully on May 27, 2015, following a long illness. He taught mathematics for 53 years in the Chappaqua and Hackley Schools. He directed Camp Lincoln in the Adirondacks for many years and was a founding Director of the Chief's Fund. He was a long- term trustee of the Helene Fuld College of Nursing and the Hospital for Joint Diseases. He was an avid outdoorsman, leader and friend to thousands. BODEEN--George Harwood. George Harwood Bodeen, 91, WWII Veteran, and beloved husband of Nancy Bodeen (nee Lindberg) with whom he shared 64 years of marriage, passed away on May 21, 2015. Loving son of the late George Herman Bodeen and the late Alva Bodeen (nee Larson). Dear brother to his late sister, Helen Brockington Richardson (nee Bodeen). He is survived by his wife, Nancy, and his four children; Debbie (Jeff Calhoun), Michael, Julie (Andy Phelps), and Susan; and his eight grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. George was a humble, affable, compassionate, and energetic man who made everyone smile when they saw him. George was a mentor to many and helped guide and foster a sense of confidence in those he helped. PLATT--Marguerite Beer. February 6, 1937 - May 19, 2015. A 4th generation New Yorker, born to Andrew E. Beer and Marguerite Eilers, she graduated from the Chapin School and Wellesley College where she majored in economics and led the Tupelos singing group. For 13 years as a senior editor, writer and security analyst for Investor's Reader at Merrill Lynch she won interviews with over 1,000 CEOs. An early president of the Financial Women's Association, she redefined the mission and established a much needed network and support system for the professional advancement of women. While she raised her children she taught financial management to women and lobbied for fair tax treatment for working mothers. In 1988 she began her career in real estate, eventually becoming an EVP of Halstead Property LLC, where she worked tirelessly until the end. Her full life included the Blue Hill Troupe, Grosvenor Neighborhood House and the City Gardens Club. She loved golf, gardening, singing, her three golden retrievers and her family and friends. She was a member of the Colony Club, the Quogue Field Club and the Quogue Beach Club. She is survived by her loving husband of 50 years, David N. Platt and her children David S. Platt and Marguerite F. (Daisy) Platt. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, June 4th at 4pm at St. James Church, 865 Madison Avenue. Contributions in her memory may be sent to the City Gardens Club of New York City, 755 Park Ave, NY NY 10021. 1/3

TZIMAS--Nicholas. Nicholas Tzimas, 87, died peacefully in his home on May 29, 2015. A brilliant children's orthopaedic surgeon who had patients from all over the world. He was published in Who's Who in America. He was knighted from the Italian government. He was a knight of Saint Andrew in the Greek Orthodox church and a member of the Leadership 100. He graduated from Athens University and came to the United States in 1955 with $125.00 on a boat. He has trained generations of physicians at NYU School of Medicine of where he was a Clinical Professor of Orthopaedic Surgery. He is survived by his daughters Yvonne and Christina Tzimas and his brother Basilli Tzimas in Greece. The wake will be on Monday, June 1, at St. John the Theologian Greek Orthodox church, 353 East Clinton Avenue, Tenafly, New Jersey at 3 to 9 pm. The funeral will be at 11am at St. John the Theologian on Tuesday, June 2nd. 1/3

GROSSMAN--Norman. 1922-2015, distinguished aviation engineer, recognized for his pioneering work in design, production and testing of high performance military air craft, passed away peacefully at his home in Greenwich Village on Friday, May 29th. Dr. Grossman is survived by his wife, Thelma Mudick Grossman and his two nieces, Susan Scribner and Meryl Fiedelman. After a two-year stint in the Merchant Marines during WWII, he began his career at Republic Aviation, which later became Fairchild-Republic, starting as a junior engineer and retiring as its Chairman and CEO. During his tenure, Fairchild was awarded many major military contracts including the A-10 (Warthog), a plane still described as "our most capable close air-support craft". As quick with a smile as he was with the answer to a complex theoretical problem, he was a rare bird in today's world, a gentlemen, a true scholar, one who lived his life with integrity and joy. Norman and Thelma shared a beautiful home on Moriches Bay in Remsenberg, a Bedouin tent in the Sahara Desert, and a hut in the Easter Islands. Services will be held at 9am at the Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St. on Sunday, May 31st. Family and friends will gather at 70 E. 10th St. following the interment after 2pm. In lieu of flowers, please perform one act of random kindness for an elderly person. 1/3

BRODER--Alice, beloved wife, mother and grandmother, she was loved, admired and respected by all who knew her. She lived an exemplary life and had wide- ranging interests. She made important contributions as a non-lawyer to personal injury litigation over the course of 60 years. She was an influential speaker to school children, one of the youngest people to ever enter Hunter College, and a Shakespearean scholar. She embodied everything good in this world, and she believed and taught the principle that the most important thing in life is love. She made the world a better place to live in for all who knew her. 1/3

GALLIN--Henry A.,a highly respected commercial real estate broker in Manhattan, died on May 23, 2015, at the age of 77, after suffering a stroke several months earlier. Gallin was Senior Executive Vice-Presi- dent of the Edward S. Gordon Company, Inc., a predecessor to CBRE. Throughout his 40 year career as a real estate broker, he successfully participated in thousands of lease transactions and directed the marketing campaigns for over 15 million square feet of office properties in prime Midtown area of Manhattan; together with major new office complexes in New York City, he was a developer of resort properties in Colorado and an owner/investor of office buildings. Gallin, with his partner, Craig Tuber, served as consultants to Charles Schwab and Company where they completely reconstructed their real estate holdings. Gallin then gave up his big city life and moved to Crested Butte, Colorado. Along with his skiing and tennis games, he managed to construct and sell, three resort land developments in that area. Mr. Gallin was a natural born leader. He served as Chairman of the Young Men's/Women's Real Estate Association of New York, Chairman of the Brokerage Division of the Real Estate Board of New York, was a recipient of the "Deal of the Year" award presented by the Real Estate Board of New York, Chairman of the Downtown Development Association of Mt. Crested Butte, President of the Center for the Arts in Crested Butte and recipient of NAIOP's national award for the best marketing project. Gallin intensely enjoyed his long, varied real estate career, but his pride and joy was his family. He is survived by his loving wife of twenty years, Judy Norwood Gallin; son, Jonathan and his wife Annie and granddaughter Ruby, and by his daughter Aimee Gallin Lieberman and her husband Aaron and twin grandchildren Milo and Delilah and his beloved brother Sandy Gallin. Memorial service will be held at Sinai Mortuary, in Scottsdale, Arizona on Sunday, May 31 at 2pm in the afternoon. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the www. WoundedWarriorProject.org. 1/3

TEEMAN--Susan, 71, Wall Street Loses an Executive Recruitment Pioneer. Susan was born on August 14, 1943 in Winnetka, Illinois. She graduated from New Trier High School in Winnetka, IL and Skidmore College in Saratoga Springs, NY. In the 1970's Susan came to New York City where she started her life long career as a renowned financial services executive recruiter in the Human Resources department at Lehman Brothers. After several years as the Head of the department, Susan decided to become an entrepreneur and founded her own executive search firm where she recruited and placed Wall Street professionals around the world. Over the years the firm grew to be one of the most prestigious search firms in New York with hundreds of recruiters under the names: Teeman Perley Gilmartin, Teeman Allison Perley, Teeman Kiniry, Teeman Associates and Smythe Teeman. Susan was well respected in the financial community and was recognized for her dedication, kind heart and generosity. She was a pioneer for women in Wall Street and paved the way for women in an industry where they were scarce. Many of the women she trained went on to be top executives at banks and hedge funds, as well as executive recruitment firms of their own. Susan was also a successful fund raiser for the Special Olympics, inspired by her sister Merry. She is predeceased by her parents, and survived by her beloved sister Merry. Friends are welcome to join in celebrating Susan's life at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave., NY, NY 10028. frankecampbell.com on Monday, June 1, 2015 from 2pm-4pm and 7pm-9pm. 1/3

FRAUENTHAL--Stephen C. The Helene Fuld College of Nursing Board of Trustees, Faculty, Staff, and Students regret the passing of Stephen C. Frauenthal. Stephen C. Frauenthal, passed away peacefully after a long illness on the morning of Wednesday, May 27, 2015. Known to many as "Steve" or "Frau", he will be remembered for his dedicated service and generous support of Helene Fuld College of Nursing, in Harlem, where he served on the Board of Trustees. We are thankful for his service and longstanding commitment to the College, and extend our heartfelt sympathy to his brother, Dr. James C. Frauenthal. In lieu of flowers, his family has asked that donations be sent to two of the charitable organizations that Steve held close. Contributions may be sent to Helene Fuld College of Nursing, 24 East 120th Street, NY, NY 10035, Attn: Barbara Paxton, Director of Development, or the Chief's Fund, 19 Watchtower Road, Hopkinton, NH 03229, Attn: Ruth B. Needleman, Assistant Treasurer. 1/3

BERGER--Rita passed away on Saturday, May 30, 2015 at the age of 87. A life-long Brooklynite, she was born November 30, 1927 to Tillie and Sol Brandt. She was pre-deceased by her husband, Harold and brother, Coleman Brandt. She is survived by her sons, Bruce E. Berger, M.D. (fiancee Linda Garrett), Scott A. Berger, M.D. (wife, Deborah), and her daughter, Karen P. Berger (husband, Richard Bruning); her grandchildren Lauren and Evan, Steven, and Amy, Zackary and Alex Bruning; her sister, Lila Kirschner and sister-in-law, Grace Brandt. She earned her Bachelors of Science and Masters Degree in Education from Brooklyn College, and taught in the NYC public school system for 23 years. She lived her life with a quiet dignity and a respect for others. Those who knew her will remember her kindness, compassion and love forever. Services at Parkside Memorial Chapels, 2576 Flatbush Ave, Brooklyn, NY on Monday, June 1 at 12:00 noon. Donations in her honor may be made to the National Council of Jewish Women, Brooklyn Section, 1001 Quentin Road, Brooklyn, NY 11223. 1/3

GILLIGAN--Edward Patrick. On May 29, 2015, beloved husband of Lisa, devoted father of Katie, Meghan, Kevin and Shane. Also survived by his brother Michael. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., on Monday, 2-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral service at All Souls Unitarian Church, 1157 Lexington Ave. on Tuesday 11am. 1/3
EDELSTEIN--Charles. Your sparkle and spirit will be missed at our holiday table. Janet, Liza and Michael, Kim and Craig, Jordan and Cori 1/3

AUERBACH--Robert, died peacefully at home on May 31st at the age of 81 following a long battle with complications from multiple strokes and diabetes. Cherished husband of Joyce, beloved father of Kendra Auerbach Mednick (Josh), dear brother of Larry, and loving brother-in-law of Thomas Kouba (Kiyomi). He was also a kind and caring uncle, cousin and friend. Bob was a self-made man with style and good taste, who always enjoyed a good time. He was charismatic, unforgettable and devoted to family and friends. A philanthropic man, he was involved in multiple charitable organizations, most notably serving as Chairman of the Board of JDRF. His memory is everlasting and he will live in our hearts forever. Funeral services at Riverside Memorial 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Wednesday, June 3rd at 10:00am. 1/3

KAMINSKY--Mintzie (Mildred). May 30, 1918 - May 30, 2015. Wife, Mother, Grandmother, Great-Grandmother. Community Activist, Pioneering Feminist. She spent countless happy hours playing Bach and Beethoven on her piano. Funeral services will be held at 12pm, Monday, June 1 at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. 10024. 1/3

FRAUENTHAL--Stephen C.,son of Roslyn L. and Herman C. Frauenthal, died peacefully on May 27, 2015, following a long illness. He taught mathematics for 53 years in the Chappaqua and Hackley Schools. He directed Camp Lincoln in the Adirondacks for many years and was a founding Director of the Chief's Fund. He was a long- term trustee of the Helene Fuld College of Nursing and the Hospital for Joint Diseases. He was an avid outdoorsman, leader and friend to thousands. He is survived by his brother James C. Frauenthal. A Memorial Service will be held in September. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Helene Fuld College of Nursing in New York City or to the Chief's Fund. 1/3

HUGHES--Thomas James, 29, died on May 28, in New York. Tom attended Hackley School and the Taft School. He graduated from the Canterbury School, in New Milford, Connecticut, and from Northwestern University in Evanston, Illinois, with a bachelor's degree in economics. After college, Thomas worked as an investment banker at Duff & Phelps, UBS, Citibank, and, most recently, Moelis & Co. Thomas was popular and outgoing, and had a great sense of humor. He enjoyed frequent vacations, played golf and squash, and was an expert skier. He lived each day of his short life to its fullest potential. Thomas is survived by his grandmothers, his parents, and his two brothers. A memorial will be held at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club, on June 3. Friends are encouraged to arrive by 8pm. 1/3

CHAIKIN--Stacey (Solomon). Best wife, mother, Nana and friend, died May 29, 2015, peacefully with family at age 65. She fought a valiant two- year battle against glioblastoma. Stacey was a uniquely kind and loving woman, always full of energy and spirit, with perfect priorities. A teacher, lawyer, mediator and children's book author, she will be in our hearts and minds forever. Stacey is survived by her husband of 47 years, Eric, their children, Lee, Wendy and Shana, and the six joys of her life, Grace, Charlie, Cece, Riley, Kitty and Micah; they always loved when Nana came through the door to give hugs, kisses and play; and by her parents, Sylvia and Irwin, her brother Michael (Alice) and sister Penny (Itzhak). Service at Temple Emanu-El, 1 East 65th St., NYC, Monday, June 1, 2015 at 11:00am. Donations in Stacey's memory may be made to MSKCC, Attn. Ms. Glistein, 633 3rd Ave., 28th Flr., NYC, 10017. 1/3
SPITZER--Jeanne. We mourn the passing of our esteemed longtime friend and neighbor, Mrs. Jeanne Spitzer. Our heartfelt condolences go to her family. The Board of Directors 975 Park Avenue Corp. 1/3

SPIEGEL--Miriam "Mickey," passed away on the morning of May 28, 2015. Beloved wife of Irving Spiegel, devoted mother of Renee Citron (Jeffrey), Susan Greenberg (Howard) and Paul Spiegel (Karen), cherished grandmother of Scott, Thomas, Tamara, Laura, Danielle, Adam, Hilary and Matthew. She will be deeply missed. 1/3

SEGGERMAN--Frederick B. Frederick Bonsal Seggerman, 93, of Haddam, CT, husband of Isabelle (Douglas) Seggerman for thirty years, died at home on May 14, 2015. Frederick was a graduate of The Pomfret School and Princeton University. He was a veteran of the United States Army intelligence serving during WWII. Frederick was the founder of Bonsal Seggerman and Company, an international wine importer, and then founded Frederick B. Seggerman Selections, known for fine wine and spirits. Along with his wife, Frederick is survived by five children, Mary Seggerman of Mexico, Tim Seggerman of New York, Leigh Seggerman of California, Julia Sage of California and Eric Seggerman of Connecticut; stepdaughter, Isabelle O'Hara of New York; a sister, Eleanor Campbell of Maine; five grandchildren and one great- grandchild. A memorial service will be held Saturday, June 13th at 2:00pm at First Congregational Church, 905 Saybrook Road, Haddam, CT. If you wish to make a contribution in Frederick's memory, the family requests ASPCA or Our Companions Animal Rescue, Manchester, CT as Frederick truly loved animals. 1/3

AUERBACH--Robert. Bob, you were larger than life. We will miss your vibrant personality and all the fabulous times we shared. You were a fighter until the end, now it is time to rest in peace. You will remain in our hearts forever. Our deepest sympathy to Joyce and Kendra. Love, Leslie and Jim Levy 1/3

RACHLIN--Edward. Our loss is profound. Dr. Edward Rachlin passed away on May 27. He will remain in memory as a man who exemplified the best a human being could be. Ed entered medical school at seventeen and his passion for working in the field of medicine never ceased, treating patients until the time of his death. An orthopedic Surgeon and Physical Medicine specialist in New York City and Watchung NJ, he was a rarity in the field, always maintaining an holistic perspective. In the last two decades he and his wife Barbara also volunteered their skills in Africa and Asia through Health Volunteers Overseas. A Renaissance man, Ed was an outstanding tennis player, even in his 80's besting opponents half his age. Throughout his life, his clarinet was the vehicle through which he expressed the music in his soul. We were privileged to have known this beautiful man of impeccable integrity, who was humble, kind, compassionate, generous, and wise beyond measure. He is survived by his wife Barbara, his daughters Katherine and Isabel and his son John. He loved unconditionally. Donations can be made to Health Volunteers Overseas https://hvousa.org. 1/3
WALLACH--Richard W. Hon. 9/16/27 - 6/1/03 Memories and love today and always. Your, Marli 1/3

He proudly served in the US Army Air Corps during WW II, graduated from NYU, and was successful in many facets of business. He is the beloved husband of Irma (nee Frieder), devoted father of Joseph (wife Cleotilde) and the late Peter Karten, cherished grandfather of Eric, Adam, Steven, Stephanie, Maia Linda, and Carrie Lynne Faith. LIBO--Hersh, M.D. The Medical Staff of Maimonides Medical Center records with sorrow the passing of Dr. Hersh Libo. Dr. Libo was a pediatrician for many years until his retirement 22 years ago. In the 70s, he served as Secretary of the Medical Staff, also being involved with many committees. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Sincere condolences are extended to his entire family. G. Neiderman, M.D., Pres. E. Chapnick, M.D., Pres. Elect H. Adler, M.D., Secy. A. Taub, M.D., Treas. E.Fitzpatrick,M.D.,Past-Pres. 1/3

BRITTIS--Dr. Anthony L.,beloved husband to Marianna (Perry) for over 60 years, and devoted father to his two children, Sarajane Brittis, Ph.D. and Perry Brittis, MD, PhD, died on Friday, May 29, 2015. He was 92 years old. He was double Board-certified in Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation and Neurosurgery. He worked closely with Dr. Howard Rusk, the founder of rehabilitation medicine. Dr. Brittis served in the US Army Medical Corps from 1948-1970, retiring as a full Colonel. During his military tenure he received many medals and commendations for his devoted service and exemplary performance of duty, including the Legion of Merit. In 1971, Dr. Brittis returned to civilian life and practiced neurosurgery in Bronxville, Yonkers, NY and the NY Metropolitan area until his retirement in 2008. He was a man of integrity, deep Christian faith, and strong moral values, which made him a perfect, empathetic healer. He will be most remembered for his gentle, kind, sweet disposition, warm spirit, and the true love he showed to his family and patients. Calling Hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY, between the hours of 2 to 4 and 6 to 9pm, Wednesday. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Thursday, June 4th at 10:45am. 1/3

WHITE--William. William John White, 84, May 27, 2015, died peacefully at NYU Medical Center Thursday morning following an almost decade long battle with renal failure and bone cancer. He was truly a warrior heading through snowstorms and hurricanes to receive dialysis three times a week for four hours a day at 6:00am. A long fought struggle through pain and great suffering is now at end as he is with God in Heaven. Bill was born on August 2, 1930 to Tom and Elizabeth White in Brooklyn, New York. His mother passed away when he was 10 years old and he and his only sibling Tom Jr. found great sanctuary in their summer home at Point Lookout, New York. Tom went off to World War II becoming a key man on General Patton's team at the wars end. He returned home and after years of Bill selling printing presses to industry decided to join forces with his brother. They build some of the greatest, celebrated and indeed simple New York restaurants. Their three star New York Times Giraffe on East 58th Street featured a 20 foot silver giraffe out front and boasted clientele including Aristotle Onassis and John and Yoko Lennon. Their upper East side Beach Cafe on 70th Street and 2nd Avenue which they held for 37 years still continues at 48 years strong with a former manager Dave Goodside. The Point View Inn in in Point Lookout, now the Fisherman's Catch, was a bowling alley when Bill was young. He was a "pinboy" and 50 years later owned the 500 seat seaside lobster joint with other dear family members. He founded the Point Lookout Chamber of Commerce and was a distinguished member of the community there. He was an active member of the Point Lookout Civic Association for over 50 years. He and Patricia are parishioners of Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal R.C. for 65 years. He met his beloved wife Patricia at Ladycliff College in 1955 at a dance near West Point. They later married on May 18, 1957 and remained the loves of each other's lives, best friends and soulmates for 58 years. Two weeks ago this was celebrated at Le Grainne Cafe where he had his favorite french toast. He and Pat travelled the world excited to explore culture and cuisine. He was an avid sailor with his great friend Judge Bill Bennett. People in Paris, Rome, and London would tell him how much they loved the restaurants he, his brother and nephews Tom and Conrad, Nicole and Parker owned. On his 50th wedding anniversary his Holiness Pope Benedict XVII received him at the Vatican blessed them and His Eminence Edmond Cardinal Czoka, The Vatican's number three remarried them at a private Papal chapel under St. Peter's Basilica adjacent to Pope John Paul II tomb. Bill was educated at All Hallows high school by the Irish Christian Brothers who gave him great character. He graduated from Fordham University with a bachelors degree. He and Patricia had one child, Bill. He worked in the family business until 1992 when he became Chief of Staff and right hand to the late Zachary Fisher, the philanthropist who saved the Intrepid Sea Air Space Museum where he remained as its President for almost 20 years raising hundreds of millions for our nation's Veterans. He is now the CEO of Constellations Group in New York City. Bill White was a proud father, loving husband, and an amazing father-in-law to Bill's husband Bryan Eure, a successful commercial insurance broker at Willis. He and Bryan's parents, Joe and Donna Eure and their daughter Adrienne and husband Todd Henningsen were the best of friends. Bill is survived by Patricia, Bill and Bryan and over 80 plus nieces, nephews, cousins, spouses and children thereof. He adored them all. It was his wish to be cremated which occurred on Thursday, May 28th. He's currently on a beautiful beach with his wife and son in St. Barths. Funeral services will be held at Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal Church in Point Lookout, New York on Tuesday, June 9th at 10:00am. The reception at his former restaurant will take place immediately following at 11:30am until 3:30pm. All are welcome and an RSVP for both events to vp@bill-white.net or 212-786-7422 is greatly appreciated for planning purposes. Honorariums in lieu of flowers can be made to the Wounded Warrior Project, his favorite veterans support organization at: woundedwarriorproject.com Thanks to Violeta Prelvukaj, Dylan Sinanaj, Joe Pecoraro, Hava, Edon and Veton Hasangjekaj, Sonia Rivas, Majlinda Prelvukaj, Francine White, Dr. Shike, Dr. Mallioux, Dr. Matallon, Dr. Heffmeister and Dr. Shah. The Garden City DaVita team, North Shore Hospital and NYU Langone Medical Center. 1/3

BERGER--Rita passed away on Saturday, May 30, 2015 at the age of 87. A life-long Brooklynite, she was born November 30, 1927 to Tillie and Sol Brandt. She was pre-deceased by her husband, Harold and brother, Coleman Brandt. She is survived by her sons, Bruce E. Berger, M.D. (fiancee Linda Garrett), Scott A. Berger, M.D. (wife, Deborah), and her daughter, Karen P. Berger (husband, Richard Bruning); her grandchildren Lauren and Evan, Steven, and Amy, Zackary and Alex Bruning; her sister, Lila Kirschner and sister-in-law, Grace Brandt. She earned her Bachelors of Science and Masters Degree in Education from Brooklyn College, and taught in the NYC public school system for 23 years. She lived her life with a quiet dignity and a respect for others. Those who knew her will remember her kindness, compassion and love forever. MURPHY--Peter J. Peter J. Murphy, 76, Entrepreneur and International Businessman. Peter J. Murphy, an international businessman and consummate family man has died. Family members confirmed Murphy died Sunday, May 31, 2015 peacefully in his sleep of natural causes . He was born on February 24, 1939 in the Bronx. Murphy joined Designs for Vision in 1971 after a long career in the medical industry. He was responsible for designing a marketing program and creating an international and national sales force for "Designs." He pioneered the complete visualization solution which utilized magnification and illumination as successful tools for microsurgery. He was the Chief Financial Officer until his retirement in 2014. He is survived by his wife and childhood sweetheart, Maureen T. Murphy (nee O'Sullivan). He was the son of Joseph and Kathryn Murphy (deceased). He is survived by three brothers, Joseph, Frank and Stephen and one sister Mary Goretsky. His sister, Kathryn, predeceased him. In addition to his wife and siblings, he is survived by his children Patti and John Wagner, Jeanne and Bob Washuta, and Maureen and Chris Beil; his grandchildren Peter John (Kate) Wagner, Andrew Wagner, Tim Wagner, Meaghan Wagner, Luke Beil, Matthew Washuta, Ryan Beil, Kevin Beil, Natalie Washuta, Conor Beil, Audrey Washuta and Mackenzie Beil; and two great grandchildren, Jake Wagner and Charlotte Wagner. Visitation Tuesday 2-4pm and 7-9pm at M.A. Connell Funeral Home, 934 New York Ave., Huntington Station. Funeral Mass Wednesday 9:45am at St. Patrick's Church, Huntington. maconnellfuneralhome.com 1/3

PROCTOR--Noble S.,Ph.D., 73, of Branford, CT died on May 28. He was born April 10, 1942 in Derby, CT. He was a professor, wildlife photographer, and author. For over 40 years he led wildlife tours throughout the world, visiting 90 countries. He was among a group of scientists conducting avian field research in the Soviet Union for the U.S. Forest Service and spoke at the United Nations concerning the state of the environment on a world wide scale along with Jane Goodall. Noble worked with Roger Tory Peterson during his revision of the Eastern Field Guide to Birds, and also a founding member of the Roger Tory Peterson Institute for Natural History in Jamestown, NY. He was awarded the Connecticut Ornithological Association Mabel Osgood Wright Award in 2002 and in 2013 the American Birding Association's Roger Tory Peterson Award. Donations can be made to the Roger Tory Peterson Institute, 311 Curtis St., Jamestown, New York 14701. 1/3

MEARA--Anne. Anne, along with her husband Jerry Stiller, was a wonderful friend for 61 years. First we were actors together, then we bonded at the Russian Tea Room and our children, my Ellen and her Ben and Amy, grew up together. Anne and Jerry were great supporters in times of need and in times of celebration. Her talent for friendship, her wit, generosity and candor made her a unique person, and she will be so much missed by all who loved her. Faith Stewart-Gordon 1/3

SHORETZ--Rochelle Lee. The Board of Directors and staff of Sharsheret are saddened by the passing of Rochelle Lee Shoretz, known to many as Rochie. Rochelle, 42, passed away on Sunday, May 31st, of complications from breast cancer. In 2001, following her own breast cancer diagnosis at age 28, Rochelle founded and served as the Executive Director of Sharsheret, (Hebrew for "chain"), a national not-for-profit organization supporting young Jewish women and families facing breast cancer and ovarian cancer. A graduate of Barnard College (1995) and Columbia Law School (1996), she served as a law clerk to United States Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg (1998-1999), a law clerk to Judge Amalya L. Kearse, Second Circuit (1996-1997), and an attorney at Debevoise and Plimpton in Manhattan. A major force in the world of breast cancer and the Jewish community, Rochelle was appointed to the Federal Advisory Committee on Breast Cancer in Young Women, and gave back to other groups such as First Descents, Joshua Venture Group, the Berrie Fellows Leadership Program of the UJA Federation of Northern New Jersey and the American Association of Cancer Research Scientist-Survivor Program. We at Sharsheret have lost our founder, our leader, our mentor. The Jewish world and the cancer world have lost a true champion of women and their families. Rochelle's legacy is her children and an incredible organization that only she could have built. Her passion and drive will forever remain the foundation of Sharsheret. Our condolences go out to her sons, Shlomo and Dovid Mirsky, her parents, and siblings. Contributions in memory of Rochelle can be sent to Sharsheret, 1086 Teaneck Road, Suite 2G, Teaneck, NJ, 07666 or online at www.sharsheret.org. Dana Norris, President, Board of Directors Elana Silber, Director of Operations 1/3
EHRSAM--Marcia (Spector) Posner. December 1, 1921 - May 28, 2015. Dear mother, grandmother, and great- grandmother. Our world will not be the same without you. 1/3

Loving father of Patti Askwith Kenner, Dennis Askwith, and Kathy Franklin. Cherished patriarch of a large, extended family, including Madeline Dreifus and family, the Udows, and the Bowmans. Proud grandfather of Julie, Jeff, Ivan, Max and Lisa and great-grandfather of Canaan, Wyatt, Sebastian, Annabelle and Emily. Founder, and President of Campus Coach Lines for 85 years. Bert was a loyal and generous supporter of his beloved alma mater, the University of Michigan, and his parents' alma mater, Harvard University, as well as United Way of Westchester, the Food Allergy Research and Education (FARE), the Museum of Jewish Heritage, the Educational Alliance, and many more. He will be fondly remembered for his wise counsel, his sense of humor, and his love for life. Services Thursday, June 4 at Riverside Memorial Chapel. 1/3

CASTEL--Nico, had a huge impact on generations of singers at The Juilliard School and beyond, both through his performing and his teaching. His ready wit, keen intelligence, and warm heart will be sorely missed. He has left a lasting legacy both through his teaching and his remarkable collection of opera translations and diction guides. Polisi, President Ara Guzelimian, Provost and Dean Brian Zeger, Artistic Director, Marcus Institute for Vocal Arts 1/3

CROWELL--Joan Lewisohn. poet author composer and activist died on Saturday, April 18 at her home in Quogue, New York, surrounded by her children. She was 93. She was the wife of David G Crowell who pre-deceased her six years ago, and the former wife of Sidney Simon the artist who co-founded the Skowhegan School of Painting and Sculpture while they were married. Joan Lewisohn was born in New York the daughter of Sam A Lewisohn and Margaret Seligman Lewisohn. Her parents marriage joined two members of New Yorks great Jewish families a photo of Mrs. Crowell and her sisters is on the cover of Stephen Birminghams Our Crowd. In the 1960s Mrs. Crowell writing as Joan Simon published two books One was a novel: Portrait of a Father (Athenaeum, 1960) The other Fort Dix Stockade was a nonfiction accounting of the mistreatment of Vietnam War activists She also wrote an English language libretto for Glucks Orpheus and numerous poems published in various journals Several decades later she wrote both the music and librettos of operas including The Bell Witch of Tennessee and The Heights which were performed in concert format She wrote a variety of other music some of which was recorded Her recent poems were published in Poems of Possibilities (Sheep Meadow Press 2008) and Recent Poems (Lulu Press 2012). Joan Lewisohn was a young woman of amusing contradictions Though she told her parents she didn't want to go to college she got her BA from Bennington, where she studied with Francis Fergusson and earned a master's degree in English from NYU where she also taught in the 1940s Having gone to New York's progressive Lincoln School where children had a say in what they studied Mrs. Crowell claimed to have gone no farther in math than fractions Despite that she was the Business Manager of the Partisan Review in the 1940s and the treasurer of the authors union PEN in the 1970s In later years she did all her composing on computers to the astonishment of her children. Those ironies continued throughout her life despite often claiming that she was a loner Joan Crowell had five children 16 grandchildren and step grandchildren and five great-grandchildren who all adored her and on whom she doted. Her family mourns her passing architect son Mark Simon and his wife Penny Bellamy in Branford CT artist daughter Teru in Bennington VT designer manufacturer daughter Rachel Simon and her husband Philippe Labeau in Red Hook NY, artist daughter Nora Simon in Boston MA, and nonprofit executive daughter Juno Duenas and her husband Robert in San Francisco CA along with their numerous progeny. A memorial gathering is being planned for family and friends in New York City in September The family asks that memorial gifts be given to Support for Families (http://www.supportforfamilies.org/) or East End Hospice (www.eeh.org/) 1/3

TIERNEY--Patricia E.,passed away on Saturday, May 30, 2015 at the Mary Manning Walsh Home. Miss Tierney was the daughter of the late William E. Tierney and Evelyn MacDonald Tierney. She was born in Albany, NY on May 8, 1926. She was a descendant of Stephen Van Rensselaer, Hudson Valley patroon, Lt. Governor of the state of New York, member of the House of Representatives, and founder of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. She graduated from Brown University and worked as a copywriter in the advertising profession. Prior to retirement, she was a copywriter at Avon Products. Miss Tierney wrote several books including "Ladies of the Avenue" about women in the advertising field. She enjoyed the theatre and travelling. She will be remembered by her friends for her ready wit and sense of humor. Friends may call at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 9:00am. Mass of Christian Burial at St. John the Evangelist Church at 10:45am. Burial will follow at the Holy Sepulcher Cemetery in New Rochelle, NY. 1/3

HUGHES--Thomas James, 29, died on May 28, in New York. Tom attended Hackley School and the Taft School. He graduated from the Canterbury School, in New Milford, Connecticut, and from Northwestern University in Evanston, Illinois, with a bachelor's degree in economics. After college, Thomas worked as an investment banker at Duff & Phelps, UBS, Citibank, and, most recently, Moelis & Co. Thomas was popular and outgoing, and had a great sense of humor. He enjoyed frequent vacations, played golf and squash, and was an expert skier. He lived each day of his short life to its fullest potential. Thomas is survived by his grandmothers, his parents, and his two brothers. A memorial will be held at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club, on June 3. Friends are encouraged to arrive by 8pm. 1/3

AUERBACH--Robert, died peacefully at home on May 31st at the age of 81 following a long battle with complications from multiple strokes and diabetes. Cherished husband of Joyce, beloved father of Kendra Auerbach Mednick (Josh), dear brother of Larry, and loving brother-in-law of Thomas Kouba (Kiyomi). He was also a kind and caring uncle, cousin and friend. Bob was a self-made man with style and good taste, who always enjoyed a good time. He was charismatic, unforgettable and devoted to family and friends. A philanthropic man, he was involved in multiple charitable organizations, most notably serving as Chairman of the Board of JDRF. His memory is everlasting and he will live in our hearts forever. Funeral services at Riverside Memorial 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Wednesday, June 3rd at 10:00am. 1/3

AUERBACH--Robert. We note with sorrow the passing of our longtime member, Robert Auerbach, and extend sincerest condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Angela W. Buchdahl, President Abigail Pogrebin, Central Synagogue of New York City 1/3

SRYBNIK--Louis D.,passed away at Mount Sinai-Roosevelt hospital in New York City on May 30th, 2015, at 91 years of age. Louis was survived by three generations of his loving family. Beloved husband of Caroline, devoted brother of Simon and adored brother-in-law of Judith and her brother Josh, dear stepfather of Philippe, Charlotte, Arnaud, Olivier and Helene, cherished step-grandfather of Lucas, Manon, Martin and Kajsa; loving uncle of Leslie, Jed, Ronni, Edward, Frank, James, Arthur, Lawrence, Steven, Elaine, Phyllis, Linda and Mel, their wives, husbands and children. Louis was predeceased by his revered mother Libby and honored father Alter, his dearest brothers Jay and Aaron and treasured sisters Betty, Sylvia, Florence and Freddy, his sister-in-law Evelyn, nephew John and brothers-in-law Herbert, Jerry and Harry. Louis was a co-owner and President of numerous companies in the Aerospace, Machinery, Scientific Research, Medical, Film Studios, and various other industries during his 70-plus years in business with his brothers. He also contributed enormous time and resources to many philanthropic religious and charitable organizations, including the Sutton Place Synagogue, and was a longterm member of the N.Y.A.C. A world traveler, scholar, mentor, friend to mankind and prince among men, Louis brought love, elevation and good will to all he encountered. He is an indestructible spirit and will be forever enshrined in the hearts of his family, friends, co-workers, loved ones and all who knew him. Services will be held on June 3rd at the Sutton Place Synagogue for family and close friends. Contributions in Louis' memory may be made to the Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 East 51st Street, NYC, NY 10022. 1/3

CASTEL--Nico. Vocal artist and scholar, died May 31, 2015. He was on staff as artist and coach of the Metropolitan Opera Company for forty years and on the faculty of Juilliard. He was the Internationally acclaimed expert on language and diction for singers. Mr. Castel authored 20 volumes of Opera Libretti translations. ORTIZ--Wanda, passed away June 1st, 2015 at the age of 56, after battling Stage IV Lung Cancer. A life long New Yorker, she was born October 18, 1958 to Alexandra Murray and Leonard Ortiz. Wanda earned her Bachelors of Science in Nursing at Pace University and started her career as a pediatric oncology nurse for five years at Mt Sinai Hospital. Wanda later became an operating room nurse at NYU Medical Center for the last 27 years of her life. Wanda is remembered for her beautiful smile, generous spirit, and compassion towards all. She is survived by devoted husband Richard, beloved daughter Jessica, loving mother Alexandra, sister Enid and brother Leonard. Visitation will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel on 1076 Madison Ave, this Thursday from 2-5 and 7-10pm. A Funeral mass will be held at 9am Friday morning at St Ignatius Loyola Church at 980 Park Ave. 1/3

MARCUS--Jane Connor. The City College of New York mourns the passing of Jane Connor Marcus, Distinguished Professor of English, the Graduate Center, CUNY, and at City College. Dr. Marcus joined the CCNY faculty in 1986 and was appointed a Distinguished Professor in 1990. She was an authority on women writers, women's studies, and other forms of literature. Her publications included books on Virginia Woolf. She will be fondly remembered at City College as an outstanding teacher, mentor and writer. On behalf of our students, faculty and staff, we extend sincerest condolences to the Marcus family. Lisa S. Coico, President 1/3

ASKWITH--Bertram James, died peacefully on June 1 at 104 years old at home in New York City. Devoted son of the late Margaret Long and Herbert Askwith. Adoring husband for 59 years of the late Mimi Teidor Askwith. Loving father of Patti Askwith Kenner, Dennis Askwith, and Kathy Franklin. Cherished patriarch of a large, extended family, including Madeline Dreifus and family, the Udows, and the Bowmans. Proud grandfather of Julie, Jeff, Ivan, Max and Lisa and great-grandfather of Canaan, Wyatt, Sebastian, Annabelle and Emily. Founder, and President of Campus Coach Lines for 85 years. Bert was a loyal and generous supporter of his beloved alma mater, the University of Michigan, and his parents' alma mater, Harvard University, as well as United Way of Westchester, the Food Allergy Research and Education (FARE), the Museum of Jewish Heritage, the Educational Alliance, and many more. He will be fondly remembered for his wise counsel, his sense of humor, and his love for life. Services Thursday June 4 at Riverside Memorial Chapel at 11am. 1/3

An alumna of the College of New Rochelle, she served in its administration for over 35 years, retiring as Vice President for College Advancement in 1990. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 5 to 9pm, Thursday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Friday, June 5 at 10:45am. MacAVOY--Thomas C. Thomas C. MacAvoy, of Charlottesville, VA died Thursday, May 28th at Westminster-Canterbury of the Blue Ridge. He was born April 24th, 1928, in New York City. Tom was the beloved husband for 62 years of Peggy MacAvoy and father to Moira MacAvoy (husband Michael Lesniak), Ellen MacAvoy, Christopher MacAvoy (wife Lane), and Neil MacAvoy (wife Alisa). Tom also leaves behind two sisters: Sheila Block and Geraldine McCarthy. He had ten loving grandchildren: George, Mavia, Melissa, Meg, Ross, Kit, Deirdre, Connor, Marissa, Clara, and one great- granddaughter, Keeva. Tom's education included a B.S. from Queens College, an M.S. from St. John's University, and a Ph.D. from the University of Cincinnati. He served in the U.S. Navy at the end of World War II and was later a 1st Lieut. in the U.S. Air Force. An active Boy Scout, Tom was a Distinguished Eagle Scout, recipient of the Silver Beaver Award and national president of the Boy Scouts of America for three years. His longest working career was with Corning, Inc. He started as a scientist in 1957 and served in a variety of positions, rising to become president of the company in 1971. Upon retirement from Corning in 1988, Tom and Peggy moved to Charlottesville where he was a professor for ten years at the Darden Business School of the University of Virginia. Tom was also a member of a number of corporate boards. He was active as a board member and president of the Charlottesville Symphony at the University of Virginia. Tom was a long-time trustee of the Corning Museum of Glass and taught "The History of Glass" course for the Osher Lifelong Learning Institute. A funeral Mass will be held at St. Thomas Aquinas Church in Charlottesville on Friday, June 5th at 11:00am. Reception will follow in the church hall. Contributions in Tom's memory may be made to: St. Thomas Aquinas Church, 401 Alderman Rd., Charlottesville, VA 22903; Westminster- Canterbury of the Blue Ridge, 250 Pantops Mountain Rd., Charlottesville, VA 22911; Charlottesville Symphony at the University of Virginia, PO Box 4206, Charlottesville, VA 22905. Condolences may be sent to the family at www.hillandwood.com 1/3

KALLAS--Charles Kyrie, 97, of Brooklyn, NY, passed away May 31, 2015, with his wife of 64 years, Virginia ("Ginny") by his side. He was born in Piraeus, Greece in 1918 to Kyriakos Yulyeroglou and Aphrodite Andronoglou Danielides. He immigrated through Ellis Island in 1921. He graduated from Brooklyn Technical High School '37 and received a BBA '54 and MBA '56 from Baruch College. He volunteered for the US Army Aviation Cadet Program and began navigator training at Selman Field, AL in 1942, receiving his wings in 1943. He was based in Barksdon Heath, UK in 1944, and dropped paratroopers from C-47s in multiple battles in Europe. After the war, he served as a navigator on ships in the Merchant Marine. He was recalled for duty in the Strategic Air Command for the Korean Conflict in 1950, and served as a reservist in the Military Airlift Command, flying worldwide missions, including many to Vietnam, until his retirement as a lieutenant colonel in 1971. He left the Air Force as a Master Navigator with a total of 12,000 flying hours, which included 550 combat hours. After WWII, he operated as a successful independent businessman in retail wine and spirits, then dry cleaning, and entered the real estate market in 1960, when he began investing in commercial properties in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn. He also pursued a full-time teaching career in Mechanical Drawing (drafting) at his alma mater, Brooklyn Tech, and Manhattan Community College, from 1971 to 1983. A dedicated member of the Greek Orthodox community, he was twice President of the Board of Trustees of Three Hierarchs Church (Brooklyn), and a generous benefactor of both St Nicholas Church (Brooklyn) and St John the Baptist Church (Manhattan), as well as New York Presbyterian Hospital. He volunteered as a Greek translator for the NYC courts, and was committed to fundraising for the Wounded Warrior Project. His autobiography, "On the Wings of the Wind: The Story of the Last Navigator" was published on Amazon in 2013. He was a fiercely patriotic American and a staunch Brooklynite. In addition to his wife, he is survived by four children: Anthony Homer Kallas of Arlington, MA; Ianthe Kallas-Bortz of Brooklyn; Nicholas Orion Kallas of Lynbrook, NY; and Thalia Loffredo of New York, NY. He is also survived by six grandchildren: Dominic Hement Kallas, Raquel Forsythia Kallas, Zoe Sarah Bortz, Cena Ari Loffredo, Kira Elysia Kallas and Theodore Ellis Bortz. Visitation will be Wednesday, June 3 from 2-5 and 7-10 at the Cusimano & Russo Funeral Home, 2005 West 6 Street, Brooklyn, NY 11223. Funeral Liturgy will be on Thursday, June 4 at 11:00am at the St. John the Baptist Greek Orthodox Church, 143 East 17 St., NY, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Wounded Warriors Project. www.cusimanoandrusso funeralhome.com 1/3

BARRY--Edward. We are saddened to report that Ed Barry, who was the President of Oxford University Press, USA, from 1982 to 2000, has passed away after a short illness. Before joining OUP, Ed spent twenty years at Macmillan Publishing Company, achieving the post of President of The Free Press, and subsequently President to the Professional Books Division, which included The Free Press, Macmillan Library Reference, Schirmer Books, and Macmillan Scientific, Technical, Medical, and Professional. In the nearly two decades that Ed oversaw our US operations, the Press made significant strides in most every realm of its publishing. Oxford's reference publishing, an area in which Ed had particular expertise dating back to his Macmillan years, expanded dramatically. Our trade and college textbook publishing flourished, and academic publishing expanded from its beginnings as a small list in philosophy to a program that encompassed works in most humanities, social science, and science disciplines. And the overall profile of the Press changed significantly, with the US's role shifting from primarily that of distributor of UK-generated books to one with a distinct and influential publishing identity of its own. Ed also oversaw the relocation of both the warehouse facility from Fair Lawn, NJ to Cary, NC, and the New York offices from a relatively modest space at 200 Madison (in what was then, to Ed's discomfort, known as "the Putnam Berkeley building") to the current location, in each instance a challenging and complicated advancement for the Press. Ed was known as a strong advocate for his people, an ambitious publisher, and a "numbers man": someone who could tame the unwieldy beast of a publishing P&L. He combined business expertise and love of publishing in a way that set him, and Oxford USA, apart. To opt for an obvious metaphor, Ed Barry left his imprint on OUP. 1/3

FIORENZA--Vincent, on May 31, 2015. Former Vice President of Moore McCormack Lines, President of The Association of Water Transportation Accounting Offices and Assistant Director, U.S. Dept. of Commerce Seagoing Transportation. ASKWITH--Bertram The New York City board of directors, volunteers and staff of the American Heart Association mourn the loss of Mr. Bertram Askwith. Mr. Askwith and his family have enhanced the fight against heart disease and stroke through their longtime generosity. We extend our deepest sympathies to his daughter, Patti Kenner, and to the rest of the Askwith family. David Lefkowitz, Chairman Larry Chinitz, MD, President Helaine Baruch, AHA Michael Weamer, AHA Heather Kinder, AHA 1

CARTER--John, an actor whose diversity in his profession was filled with numerous roles on stage and screen passed away from pneumonia on May 23 at the young age of 87. John was born in Center Ridge, Arkansas. He and his family moved to Missouri where he grew up and attended college. After graduation he moved to New York to pursue his dream of becoming an actor and married Barbara Williams, an actor as well. John started out as a chorus boy and moved quickly up to appearing in "No Strings, "110 in the Shade" Take Me Along" and many other roles. John had a beautiful voice and brought to each character a defined presence. After divorcing Barara he moved to Los Angeles and became very busy in the world of television and film. He became a member of Theater West where he would meet his future wife Kendall Fewel a match made in heaven. While at Theater West he appeared in "The Price" and began directing. He directed Betty Garrett in her one woman show which was a jewel of a show. His roles in television at this time were "Winds of War" "Roots" and "Dallas" to name a few. Some of his films included the "Hoax", "Badlands" and "Joe Kidd". After marrying Kendall they moved to New York where John continued and thrived in the theater. He appeared in three Edward Albee plays Off Broadway and Edward Albee's On Broadway revival of "A Delicate Balance" featuring Rosemary Harris, George Grizzard and Elaine Stritch which won a Tony. Other Broadway roles were in "A Streetcar Named Desire" and "Festin". John was unique and touched the lives of all those who knew him. Handsome, talented, giving, honest in ever sense and such a gentle man. John is predeceased by his brother Rogers and his son Dan. He is survived by his brother Conlan, half brother, Jeff, three beautiful godchildren Kevin, Emily and Michael and his beloved Kendall. "This world was never meant for one as beautiful as you". 1/3

PEARCE--David. A man of parts, a fine doctor, a good friend whose intellectual curiosity was wide-ranging. He was as familiar with rare books as with college sports. His thoughtfulness to his friends knew no bounds. Our whole family mourns his death. Daniel and Joanna Rose 1/3

COHEN--Lynn Dell, the Countess of Glamour passed away Tuesday, June 2nd in Manhattan. Lynn was the fashion icon and owner of Off Broadway Boutique, a hallmark of the Upper West Side for fifty years. Lynn's fashion sense lead her to her own television show "Positively Lynn", a featured role in the book and documentary Advanced Style as well as many appearances on Huffington Post Live and the Today Show. Her passion for travel took her around the world in search of new and unusual designs for her store. Lynn is survived by her loving husband of 64 years, Sanford, sons Bradley (wife Yael) and Keith (wife Cheri) and grandchildren Boaz and Olivia. Services will be at Riverside Memorial, 76th and Amsterdam, Friday, June 5 at 10am. 1/3

CHAIT--Allan Stephen, son of the late Ralph M. and Libby E. Chait, passed away on June 3, 2015 at the age of 85 years. Beloved husband of Jocelyn (nee Feingold) for 58 years; cherished father of Andrew (Hedy), Madeleine (Steven), and Steven (Lisa). Adored grandfather of Matthew and Stephanie Brand, Hannah, Joshua, and Eliana Chait, and Jeremy Hartman- Chait. Predeceased by his loving sister Marion Chait Howe. President of the Ralph M. Chait Galleries founded by his father in 1910, a devoted family business world-renowned specialists in antique Chinese porcelains, works of art, and export silver - continued now by his sons Andrew and Steven - third generation. Allan was a highly respected authority in his field, a connoisseur and advisor to museums and private collectors the world-over. He was a former President of the National Antiques and Art Dealers Association of America, founding Chairman of the Winter Antiques Show Dealers Committee, and former member of the United States Cultural Property Advisory Committee appointed by President George H.W. Bush. Allan served as a Sergeant in the United States Marine Corps during the Korean War from 1951-53. Allan was a man of great kindness and integrity- devoted to his family and family business. A noble and loving man, compassionate, generous, and considerate. Service Friday, June 5th, 1pm at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Temple Emanu- El Philanthropic Fund, the Anti-Defamation League (ADL), or the Jewish National Fund (JNF). May his memory and good deeds be for a blessing. 1/3

PEARCE--David M.D.,died at home in Manhattan on June 1st. He was the son of the late Henry and Sally Pearce and is survived by his sister Linda Rosensweig and brother-in-law Dr. Norton Rosensweig, nephew J.P. Rosensweig, and nieces Julie Schwartz and Laurie Blank. Totally dedicated to his patients, he practiced ophthalmology in Manhattan for over 40 years. He was a true renaissance man; devoted to the arts, music, literature, sailing and lacrosse. Funeral services are private. 1/3
AUERBACH--Robert, a man of great spirit and courage. Our hearts go out to Joyce, Kendra and the entire family. May he rest in peace. Seymour Zises and Family 1/3

LEONARD--Sarah Adelaide Niles, wife of the late GustavePierre Leonard, died peacefully in Bronxville, NY on June 1, at 85, after a long illness. Born in Brooklyn, NY to the late Edward and Dorothy Niles, "Sally" lived almost all of her life in Bronxville and wintered for years in Atlantis, FL. Since 1936, she was a member of the Monmouth Beach Bath and Tennis Club, Monmouth Beach, NJ. An alumna of the College of New Rochelle, she served in its administration for over 35 years, retiring as Vice President for College Advancement in 1990. She is survived by her sisters Mary Kathryn (John W. Cooper), Dorothy Ann (Bernard A. Coyne) and Patricia Edmee (Robert C. Dohrenwend), nine nieces and nephews and 11 grand nieces and nephews. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 5 to 9pm, Thursday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Friday, June 5 at 10:45am. Memorial Gifts may be made to the College of New Rochelle, NY and the Jansen Hospice and Palliative Care, jansenhospice.org 1/3
KLEIN--Nancy. Dearest Nancy, forever in my thoughts and heart-- With love, Harold 1/3

SPITZER--Jeanne, age 95, of NYC, died peacefully at home on May 30, 2015. She was predeceased by her beloved husband, Henry Spitzer and her sister, Dorothy Becker. She is survived by her daughter, Helene Spitzer of NYC; her son and daughter-in-law, Stephen and Eila Spitzer, of Edison, NJ; and her grandson and his wife, Robert and Julie Spitzer of Hoboken, NJ. Private services were held June 3, 2015. Charitable donations in memory of Jeanne Spitzer may be made to: Congregation Beth Mordecai, 224 High St., Perth Amboy, NJ 08861 or at www.bethmordecai.org. 1/3

CHAIT--Allan S. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our devoted member, Allan Chait. We share the loss and sorrow with his family and hope that beautiful memories will linger as a legacy to his life. Allan will be deeply missed. 1/3

SCHNEIDER-SIEMSSEN-- Gunther. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Gunther Schneider-Siemssen, the visionary scenic designer whose work for the Met included acclaimed productions of nine Wagner operas, including two complete Ring cycles (beginning in 1967 and 1986); the company premiere of Rusalka; and stagings of Arabella, Les Contes d'Hoffmann, Die Fledermaus, and Jenufa. We offer our sincerest condolences to his family and friends. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director 1/3

GOLDHAIR -- Elayne. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Elayne Goldhair, who leaves behind a loving family that carries on a tradition of exceptional Jewish philanthropy. We extend condolences to Elayne's beloved children, Judith and Burton Resnick and Richard and Deborah Goldhair; her grandchildren; her great-grand children; and entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3

FIORENZA--Vincent, on May 31, 2015. Former Vice President of Moore McCormack Lines, President of The Association of Water Transportation Accounting Offices and Assistant Director, U.S. Dept. of Commerce Seagoing Transportation. Devoted husband of the late Mary. Dear brother of the late Vito. Loving father of James and David. Cherished grandfather of Lisa, Breanna and Steven. Dearest friend of John. Visiting Thursday, 7-9pm and Friday 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Colonial Funeral Home, Staten Island, NY. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday, 9:45am at The Shrine Church of St. Bernadette, Brooklyn, NY. Interment to follow at Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. 1/3

CHAIT--Allan S. The Women's Auxiliary of Congregation Emanu-El mourns the passing of Allan, the beloved husband of Jocelyn, our dear past and honorary president. His memory is a blessing to all who knew and loved him. 1/3

ASKWITH--Bert. The University of Michigan offers its condolences to the family of our alumnus and dear friend Bert Askwith (AB '31). His deep devotion to and support of his alma mater have had a significant impact on the lives of students throughout the University. His legacy at Michigan is powerful - from journalism, to libraries, to the arts, to public health, to the U-M Health System. We will miss his indomitable spirit. 1/3

GRUGETT--Sylvia Freeman died May 31, 2015, at the age of 96 in Valhalla, NY. She was predeceased by her beloved husband Eldridge and her sister Doris. Sylvia is survived by her cherished children: son Evan, his wife Carol, and daughter Lucy and her spouse Sally. She is also survived by her adored granddaughters Eva, Jaclyn, and Stephanie and five great-grandchildren. Born in the Bronx, NY, to Samuel and Yetta Freeman, Sylvia graduated from Walton High School and Hunter College. A proud New York liberal, her long professional life reflected her commitment to progressive causes, especially the labor movement. We raise a glass to toast her life, lived with spirit, intelligence, and love. 1/3

GERONEMUS--Alfred, on June 3, 2015. Born on March 1, 1925 in Brooklyn, NY, son of the late Helen and Alexander Geronemus and the brother of the late Clement and Saul Geronemus. A graduate of the NYU School of Dentistry, he made his home initially in Hollywood, Florida and later in Boca Raton, Florida with his wife Terry of 67 years. He practiced Dentistry for close to 50 years in Hollywood. He was a Captain in US Army, serving as a dentist to the first family in the Eisenhower administration. He is survived by his beloved wife Terry (Rosenbluth), his children Lynn (Geronemus) Bigelman, Roy and Gail (Urken) Geronemus and his grandchildren Jeffrey Bigelman, Jill (Bigelman) and Ramin Javahery, Joey and Sharone (Senk) Bigelman, Jessica (Bigelman) and Scott Shwedel, Evan and Ashley (Cornforth) Geronemus, and Greg and Katherine (Pier) Geronemus. He had eight great- grandchildren; Jonah, Ethan and Jacob Javahery, Noah, Ari, and Amelia Bigelman, Leah Shwedel and Jackson Geronemus. He was adored by his family, patients and friends, all of whom will miss him dearly. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the New York Stem Cell Foundation at 1995 Broadway, Suite 600 New York, NY 10023. 1/3

DeSCHERER--Mildred, passed away peacefully at home in Woodcliff Lake, NJ on June 3, 2015 at the age of 94. She was predeceased by her husband Bernard and her sister Phyllis Cobin. She is survived by her daughter Cathie and her sons Robert (Nilufer) and Richard (Jennie); her grandchildren David, Michael, Christopher and Kate and five great-grandchildren. Mildred was a graduate of Douglas College (now Rutgers University) and received her Masters Degree in Early Childhood Education from NYU. Mildred lived a long and fruitful life and will be remembered for her extraordinary devotion to her family and a successful career as a Nursery School Teacher. Funeral will be private. Donations in her honor may be made to Lupus Research Institute, 330 7th Ave., suite 1701, NYC, NY 10001 or The Greater Newark Conservancy, 32 Prince St., Newark, NJ 07163 or The Bergen County Players, 288 Kinderkamach Rd., Oradell, NJ 07649. 1/3
