DeLUCA--Jane Wellemeyer, M.D.,89, with more than 40 years in pediatric practice in New York City prior to retiring, died in Acton, MA June 7, 2015. Wife of the late Frank Ross DeLuca, M.D. Mother of Alexander DeLuca and wife Brooke Hersey of NYC, and Edward DeLuca and wife Alice of Stow, MA. Sister of the late Ruth Burke. Also survived by three grandchildren, a niece and two nephews. Memorial service on Saturday, June 13th at 2pm at the Acton Funeral Home, 470 Massachusetts Ave., Acton, MA. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to the American Academy of Pediatrics - The Friends of the Children Fund for Immunization, Attn. Dev. Dept., 141 Northwest Point Blvd, Elk Grove Village, IL 60007. 1/3

WARD--Arthur C. 1921-2015 Hilton Head, SC formerly of Franklin Lakes, NJ. On June 5th, Arthur Charles Ward passed away peacefully after a brief illness, just short of his 94th birthday. Truly a Renaissance man, he was an artist, a wordsmith and an entrepreneur but mostly he was a good, kind and generous man, above all he was Daddy, Poppop and Arfie. Born in New York City he grew up in Rutherford, NJ where he graduated from high school in 1939. He attended Hamilton College, graduating in February of 1943 and immediately entered the Army in the 293rd Combat Engineers. His unit was posted to Patten's Third Army and served from Normandy through Germany until the end of the war. Returning home with both his parents deceased, he started work at P.E. Guerin with his aunt, Marguerite Guerin. The firm had been closed during the war but was starting up again with little money, a skeleton work force but an established reputation as the finest source for decorative hardware and bathroom fittings. The clientele was the top architects and interior designers. He became the owner through the years and his artistry and design still graces well known public buildings, museums, park and historic residences, both in New York and throughout the country. He met Nancy (Ann) Davies on a blind date and they were married on May 16th , 1953. They had 62 wonderful years together and were truly soulmates. He is survived by his wife Nancy; daughter Kathryn and her husband Dr. Thaddeus Grabowy, Rumson, NJ, son Andrew and his wife, Mary, Franklin Lakes, NJ. Grandchildren: T.J., Allie, Katie, Christina and Thomas Grabowy, Tara, Ryan, Christopher and Cameron Ward. Niece Susie (Ken) Barkauskas, Allendale, NJ and nephew Doug (Ginger) Ward, AZ. Rest in peace Arthur Ward, you will be sorely missed. Funeral Mass will be celebrated Saturday, June 20, 2015, 10:30am in the Church of the Precious Blood, 72 Riverdale Avenue, Monmouth Beach, NJ 07750. Interment will be private. Friends may remember him with a gift to: Deep Well, P.O. Box 5543, Hilton Head, SC, 29938 or Hospice of the Low Country, P.O. Box 3827, Bluffton, SC 29910. The Island Funeral Home and Crematory. Theislandfuneralhome.com. 1/3

MODELL--Paula, Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, Paula Modell. To her family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn her passing. 1/3

VAGENAS--Nicholas. Surrounded by his family, Nick died at home at the age of 85 on May 31, 2015. Born in Manchester, NH, he considered Manhattan his home for more than sixty years. He attended Pratt Institute but left because he did not feel its direction was compatible with his own vision. Eventually he graduated from NYU. Devoted to his artwork he chronicled the landscape of the city, its people and fellow employees of the Typographical Union in paintings, watercolors, washes and etchings. His prints are represented by The Old Print Shop. With a wide range of interests and capabilities, he was especially proud of the home he built in Connecticut. He was a real trooper through many challenges. His love of the Maine coast, where many happy summers were spent, is where he will be laid to rest. But his twinkly blue eyes and winsome smile will be forever missed by those who knew him. 1/3

MAYER--Mary J. Selfhelp Community Services deeply mourns the passing of our long-time Board member and dear friend, Mary Mayer. For twenty years, Mary helped guide Selfhelp's home care and community-based services for New York City's senior residents, with vision and extensive knowledge developed through her high-level work with the New York City Department for the Aging, and her deep involvement with the International Federation on Aging at the United Nations. She was a steadfast advocate for the elderly and will be greatly missed. Our condolences to her entire family. Raymond V.J. Schrag, President Stuart C. Kaplan, CEO 1/3

ROTHENBERG--Bernard A.,86, passed away on June 7 in Boynton Beach, FL. Beloved husband of the late Bernice, devoted father of Les, Howard (Meg), Stuart (Margie). Loving and proud grandfather of seven. 1/3

WELLER--Captain George H. George Herbert Weller, retired US Coast Guard officer, attorney, and beloved family man, passed away on May 25th, Memorial Day, at age 94 at St. Paul's Towers retirement community in Oakland, California. Raised in Los Angeles, George attended Manual Arts High School and graduated from the US Coast Guard Academy in 1944. Shortly after graduation, he married the love of his life, Alice Carey, whom he had met at Connecticut College. George served at sea for many years, transporting GI's to Europe and returning with German POW's in the last year of WWII. After the war he captained an all-Filipino crew on a mission to relight Philippine lighthouses. With George as deck officer, the icebreaker CGC Eastwind pushed the farthest north of any ship under its own power up to that time (1948), and on its return home became the first ship to transit Fury and Hecla Strait. George spent several additional tours of duty on weather patrol in both the North Atlantic and the Pacific. Sent by the Coast Guard to George Washington University Law School, he received his J.D. in 1957 and subsequently served as USCG legal officer in California, Virginia, and New York. He coached a high school debate team and was frequently enlisted by colleagues and family members for his canny critiques. Committed to racial justice, he volunteered in the summers of 1964 and 1965 as a civil rights attorney for the Lawyers' Constitutional Defense Committed in Jacksonville, Florida and Shreveport, Louisiana. George later served as Assistant US Attorney, Eastern District of New York, 1971-1976, then as Assistant Attorney General for the State of Michigan, 1976-2002. In the latter post he defended statutes raising the drinking age to 21 and regulating lobbyists as well as arguing successfully before the US Supreme Court in Will v. Michigan State Police (1989). He retired at age 81 to California with his cherished wife Alice. George was a man of integrity, humility, humor, and courage. He was a lifelong active Catholic and liberal Democrat. Deeply loved by a wide circle of family and friends, George and Alice lent helping hands to countless people and causes over the years. In addition to his wife, George is survived by his son, Stephen Weller, daughter Karen Weller, daughter Valerie Weller and son-in-law Carl Guarneri, son-in-law Kevin McCoy and daughter-in-law Mary Geddes. His daughter Suzanne Weller passed away in 2000. He is also survived by more than a dozen beloved grandchildren and great- grandchildren. A celebration of his life will be held in Oakland, California, in August. Donations in his memory may be made to the Southern Poverty Law Center. 1/3

RUDORFER--Anita (nee Kutno), on June 9, 2015 at home after a long and good life devoted to her family. Predeceased by her husband Seymour after 46 years of marriage. Beloved mother to Linda, Janet (Sam) and Henry (Dara). Cherished grandmother to Adam, Deena, Max, Ian, Samantha and Joey. She will be missed by her family and friends. Services will be held at Riverside Nassau North Chapels of Great Neck on Thursday, June 11, 2015 at 12 noon. 1/3

BLAIR--Sue C.,age 84, died on June 6, after complications from ovarian cancer. Beloved mother of Robert, Laura and the late Bruce. Born in Kansas City, Missouri, she married Times foreign correspondent William G. Blair and lived abroad where she became the "muse" and top model in Paris for designer Francois Crahay at Lanvin in the 50's and 60's. She had an interest and appetite for life and culture: art, food, wine and travel. She was a consummate hostess and great friend who will be missed across the world by all. A memorial will be held at 4pm, Sunday, June 14 at 63 Marlorville Road, Wappingers Falls, NY. 1/3

DONOHOE--Virginia and Richard. Virginia Reynolds Donohoe (7/21/1917 - 2/19/2012) Richard Jenkins Donohoe (6/9/1917 - 4/16/2005) You filled our lives with love and laughter and happy ever afters. Forever in our hearts and always in our thoughts. The Donohoe and Reynolds Families 1/3
GILBERT--Ronnie. Ronnie lived a big, passionate life for 88 years which came to a peaceful end on June 6, 2015. She will be loved and missed always by Lisa Weg, Zoe Weg, and Donna Korones. 1/3

LERNER--M. Michael, died at home in New York on June 6, 2015. He was the beloved husband of the late Marie Louise (Power) Lerner and the proud father of Michael Aloysius (Susie Walter) and John Charles Lerner (Karen Russo), and grandson Augustus, all of New York. He is also survived by his sister, Ann Egan of Huntington Beach, CA and many nieces and nephews. He will be missed by his family and many, many friends. A Funeral Mass will be held at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola (Park Avenue at 84th Street) on Wednesday, June 10, 2015 at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in his name to Bard High School Early College - Manhattan, 525 East Houston Street, New York, NY 10002. www.bard.eduarlycollege 1/3

MODELL--Paula Deane. Daughter of the late Jules and Etta Gurstel of Minneapolis, MN passed away from cancer on June 9, 2105, at her home in Watermill, NY at the age of 71 years. Married for 42 years to her loving husband Gerald, she leaves her cherished sister, Rhea Isaacs and brother Norman Gurstel (Jane) both of Minneapolis. Dedicated mother to son Eric (Natalie) and step sons Gregg and Steven. Adored grandmother to Eden, Hudson and Rebecca. After coming to NYC in the late 1960's, Paula worked in the fashion industry for the family dress manufacturing business (Paula Deane Originals). In the mid-1970s she co-founded a diet and behavioral modification company called Thin Forever. After a successful business career, she devoted her full time to her family. Upon son Eric's graduation from the University of Virginia McIntire School of Commerce, Paula and Gerald established the Modell Family Scholarship for Entrepreneurial studies. Paula is also a member of the lawn society at UVa. Both Paula and Gerald have had an active involvement at Columbia Medical Center and the New York Presbyterian Hospital. She is a member of the Executive Circle of the James Lennox Society. Paula's outgoing friendly personality has befriended many with her kindness and generosity. Her charitable and loving spirit has helped many continue as an ongoing legacy. Services on Friday, June 12, at 10am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and 65th St. Contributions may be made in her memory to the James Lennox Society Executive Circle, New York Presbyterian Hospital, 654 West 170th St, NY, NY 10032, Attn: Tamiko Collier. The family will sit shiva at The Caryle Hotel on Friday from 4-7pm and Sunday from 3-9pm. 1/3

KAPPEL--Joseph W.,of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of NYC. Beloved husband of Barbara (nee Wetchler) and dear father of Maxine and James Portnof and Dr. Bruce and Elyse Kappel; loving brother of Louis and cherished grandfather of Rachel and Harry Portnof and Joshua and Brandon Kappel. Funeral Services will be held privately at the convenience of the family. 1/3

GOLD--Sylvia. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Sylvia Gold, beloved mother of Avis Richards, mother-in-law of Bruce Richards, and grandmother of Chloe and Dylan. Sylvia leaves behind a loving family that will carry on a tradition of exceptional Jewish philanthropy. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Sylvia's entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3

EISENBERG--Irene. The Yeshiva University family is grieved by the passing of an esteemed member of the Jewish community, Irene Eisenberg, a Yeshiva University Guardian, who endowed a scholarship fund to assist deserving students preparing to serve in the Jewish community. A refined and elegant lady in all her ways, she will be missed by all who knew her. Heartfelt condolences to her children and grandchildren. May they find comfort among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus 1/3

HEROLD--Tressa. On June 9th passed away peacefully after a full life. Beloved wife for 52 years to the late Bernie Herold, mother of Larry and Paula, mother in law of Michelle and grandmother of her pride and joy Spencer. Her wit and wisdom will be sorely missed. 1/3

HOPKINS--Martin Edward, one of the original inventors of the first RISC (Reduced Instruction Set Computer), died of complications of Parkinson's Disease on June 3rd at his home in Bronxville, New York. He was 81 years old. He served as corporal in the US Army during the Korean War and graduated cum laude from Amherst College with a degree in Philosophy. An IBM Fellow, Hopkins first learned about programming computers when they filled an entire room. He is survived by his wife of 59 years, Camille Hopkins (nee Rizzo); his children Ellen Hopkins, Andrew Hopkins, Katherine Hopkins and Sarah Hopkins; his sons-in law Tom Phillips and Anirudh Bansal; his brother John Hopkins and sister-in-law Linda Hopkins; his brothers-in-law Francis Rizzo and Gene Rizzo; and grandchildren Luke Phillips, Amelia Phillips, Nicola Phillips, Nolan Bansal, Jonah Bansal, Ryder Delgado, Max Bansal and Elsa Hopkins. He is pre-deceased by his grandson William Hopkins. Calling Hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, on Thursday, June 11th, from 5 to 8pm. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to the Jansen Hospice, jansenhospice.org. or Parkinson's Disease Foundation, www.pdf.org. 1/3
STOGNIEW--Alfred P. Dearest Daddy. Happy 100th Birthday. All our love, Janice, Christina, Kathleen, Alicia, Laurie. 1/3

ROSENTHAL--Donna M. (Kolar). Passed away quietly in Brooklyn on June 8. She was predeceased by her beloved husband of 30 years Thomas Kolar. A woman of valor who was recognized for her kind heart and dedication in giving generously of her time, and expertise to help others. Born in Rochester, NY to the Hon. Harry and Leila (Eber) Rosenthal, Donna lived in Brooklyn for 36 years. She was a world traveler, philanthropist and passionate lover of the arts, especially music, with her perfect pitch. Donna's life centered on building communities and aiding others. She initiated the legal services program for the New York State Office for the Aging, was the Assistant Director of the United Neighborhood Houses of New York, the first Executive Director of the National Down Syndrome Society, and the Executive Vice Chairman of CLAL-The National Jewish Center for Learning and Leadership. Volunteer service was of foremost importance to her. She was President of Congregation Beth Elohim, the Executive Women in Human Services, the Alumni Association of Columbia's School of Social Work and Chair of its Dean's Advisory Council. Columbia awarded her the Nicholas Butler Alumni Medal. She is survived by her devoted sister Barbara S. Rosenthal, mother-in-law Aurelia Kolar, six nieces and godson Jonathan Hessney. Service Thursday, June 11, 10am at Congregation Beth Elohim, 271 Garfield Place, Brooklyn. Contributions may be made to Columbia University School of Social Work or Congregation Beth Elohim. 1/3

SCHER--Marlene Diana, age 80, died peacefully free from pain, on June 9, 2015 with daughter Lisa Gottlieb at her side. She is also survived by her daughter Pamela Ahrens, son Dr. David Scher and wife Ronni, sister Marcia Bernstein, brother Gerald Scher, grandchildren Justin, Brett, Jamie, Evan, Matthew, Jonathan, Carly, great-grandson Carter, and loving members of her extended family and friends. Marlene attended Lafayette High School, Skidmore and Brooklyn Colleges. Her life included being a translator at the 1964 World's Fair, a singles' events planner, and founder of the first video dating company in NYC. She obtained licenses in real estate, securities, and insurance. Proud of her professional accomplishments but not personally fulfilled, she turned to her love of acting. An accomplished actor, she was a member of SAG-AFTRA and a voting member of AMPAS. Services will be at Riverside Memorial Chapel 180 West 76th Street on Thursday June 11 at 9:45am. 1/3

PATTERSON--David L.,age 85, on May 20, 2015. Survived by brother, George Patterson of Santa Maria, CA, George's wife Marion, children Bart and Tracy Patterson; nephew and niece Audrey and Graham Hollett of Cary, N.C.; and two grand-nephews. His was a blending of serenity, curiosity, simplicity and good cheer. He was cremated on May 21, 2015 in keeping with his desire. Joel Kirman 1/3

SCANLAN--Suzanne O'N.,94, died peacefully at home on Saturday June 6, 2015. She was predeceased by her husband Daniel F. Scanlan and her elder son, Marc T. Scanlan. Suzanne is survived by her son John E. Scanlan of New York City, her sister Mrs. Robert F. Brown of Scranton, PA, and many beloved nieces and nephews and their families. She was the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edmund F. O'Neill of Brooklyn, where she was born on August 6, 1920. Mrs. Scanlan had a long legal career, spending the last 37 years of her working life with the firm of Cullen & Dykman. Graduating from St. John's University School of Law in 1942, she began her career when many firms did not hire women associates, practicing until her son Marc was born in 1954. She and her husband, also a lawyer, lived in Riverdale for over 20 years, where they raised their sons. She returned to practicing law in 1975, and ran for the New York State Assembly in the 73rd District in 1986. A wake is being held at the Frank E. Campbell Madison Ave and 81st Street on Thursday and Friday 2-5pm and 7-9pm. A Funeral Mass is being celebrated at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church on Saturday June 13th at 10:00am. Contributions in her memory can be made to the St. John's University Law School. 1/3

EGENER--Stanley. March 31, 1934 - May 30, 2015. "Stan the Man" as he was commonly referred to, was truly beloved by family, friends and business associates. He is survived by his brother George, his two sons Mark and Todd, his wife Jennifer, his five grandchildren Daniel, Matthew, Sarah, Caroline and Elizabeth and his companion of many years, Aline Delbray. Stanley Egener was in the first class of men to graduate from Hunter College in New York. He served as an aviator in the U.S. Navy where he was stationed on the USS Intrepid, now a museum docked in New York. He was an exceptional athlete who played semi-pro football, golf and tennis. He was also an accomplished downhill skier. Stan began his career in finance in 1960 with Dreyfus Corporation and later worked with Oppenheimer. & Co. In 1972 Stan and two colleagues, Arthur Scherl and Richard Bassuk formed "Scherl, Egener & Bassuk" where they created a revolutionary new type of mutual fund called the "Side Fund". The Side Fund was eventually acquired by Neuberger Berman and later renamed the "Partners Fund". Stan joined Neuberger Berman and was instrumental in building their mutual fund business. In 1982, he was elected President of Neuberger Berman Management, Inc. and ultimately became a Partner in Neuberger Berman, LLC. Stan served for many years on the board of the Investment Company Institute and was President of the No-Load Mutual Fund Association. Considered a maverick both professionally and personally, Stanley's genius was his creativity and focus. He will be sorely missed and his life accomplishments will be an inspiration for all of the generations of family that will succeed him. Contributions in his memory to the Taub Alzheimer's Disease Research Institute 630 W. 168th St., PH 19, New York, NY 10032 would be greatly appreciated. 1/3

FIALKOFF--Frank, of Alpine, NJ and Crested Butte, CO, died peacefully Monday, June 8th after a brave battle with cancer at the age of 70. Known for his big personality and mischievous smile, he lived a full life that made an impact on so many. An adored husband of 50 years to wife Linda, father to Brett and Gabrielle, father-in-law to Heather, grandfather to Andie, Hannah, Jack and Thea and friend and mentor to countless individuals. He was the Chief Executive Officer of Haskell Jewels, LLC, the leading fashion jewelry company in the U.S. Fialkoff was raised in the Bronx and began his storied career in the accessories industry at the age of sixteen. He purchased his first company, jewelry manufacturer Albert Weiss, in 1970. Fialkoff joined Swank in 1975 as President where he founded the women's division. He joined Victoria Creations in 1980 as President, and later, CEO. In 1990, Fialkoff, together with wife, Linda, founded Haskell Jewels. Fialkoff was known throughout his career for his charm and tenacity. His charismatic leadership guided the fashion jewelry industry for decades. Fialkoff received the Fashion Accessories Benefit Ball (FABB) Achievement Award in 2009 and, in 2011, was honored with the Business Visionary Award by the Accessories Council. He was deeply involved with the Adaptive Sports Center (ASC) of Crested Butte, Colorado. He was an avid mountain biker, hiker and skier but what he enjoyed most was spending time with his family. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, June 16th, 2:00pm at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions may be made in his name to the Adaptive Sports Center of Crested Butte, CO. 1/3

Until his final days he made new friends and lived life to the fullest. Shiva Thursday 6-9pm at the home of James Kainen. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Contact jlkainen@gmail.com for details. Contributions in his memory can be made to Gould Farm. www.gouldfarm.org. 1/3

SCHER--Marlene Diana, age 80, died peacefully free from pain, on June 9, 2015 with daughter Lisa Gottlieb at her side. She is also survived by her daughter Pamela Ahrens, son Dr. David Scher and wife Ronni, sister Marcia Bernstein, brother Gerald Scher, grandchildren Justin, Brett, Jamie, Evan, Matthew, Jonathan, Carly, great-grandson Carter, and loving members of her extended family and friends. Marlene attended Lafayette High School, Skidmore and Brooklyn Colleges. Her life included being a translator at the 1964 World's Fair, a singles' events planner, and founder of the first video dating company in NYC. She obtained licenses in real estate, securities, and insurance. Proud of her professional accomplishments but not personally fulfilled, she turned to her love of acting. An accomplished actor, she was a member of SAG-AFTRA and a voting member of AMPAS. Services will be at Riverside Memorial Chapel 180 West 76th Street on Thursday June 11 at 9:45am. 1/3

ROSENTHAL--Donna. The Columbia School of Social Work community is deeply saddened by the death of Donna M. Rosenthal, a 1967 MS graduate. Donna was a dedicated social worker, committed to the ideals of her profession and to the success of the organizations she led. A devoted alumna, Donna was instrumental in the building of the School of Social Work's current home on Amsterdam Avenue. Her volunteer service to Columbia was extraordinary. Donna served as president of the School of Social Work's Alumni Association, chair of the Dean's Advisory Board, and co-chair of the School's Centennial Planning Committee. She represented the School at the University level as a founding board member of the Columbia Alumni Association and served as Vice President of the Columbia University Club of New York. For her many contributions to the Columbia community, Donna was awarded the University's Nicholas Murray Butler Medal and the Columbia University Alumni Medal. A mentor to alumni and students, Donna was someone the School of Social Work is very proud to have called an alumna, and she will be missed by all who knew her. Our sincerest condolences are extended to Donna's family, friends, and colleagues. Jeanette C. Takamura Dean 1/3

SHACK--Barbara. The boards and staff of NARAL Pro- Choice New York and the National Institute for Reproductive Health deeply mourn the loss of Barbara Shack, a driving force behind decades of progress in New York. As former chair of NARAL Pro- Choice New York, Barbara grew the organization strategically and expanded its influence with elected officials. A steadfast champion of women's full reproductive rights, persistent in even the toughest battles for equality, she was a mentor, a friend, and an inspiration. Our condolences to her loving husband Donald and her family. 1/3

DILLON--Monika. Monika Pyka Dillon died peacefully with her family by her side. In her final weeks, after her struggle with cancer, she said with conviction how thankful she was to be at peace with everyone and ready to move on. Monika was born in Warsaw on July 20, 1939, two months before the German invasion of Poland. Her father was a cavalry officer and a medical doctor in the Polish Army, captured and held prisoner by the Germans. He escaped and with his wife and young Monika travelled through Europe where they boarded a boat and made their way to New York City where they settled in 1941. Monika grew up in New York and graduated from the Convent ofthe Sacred Heart and Manhattanville College 1961. She married J. Brian Dillon in 1963. He retired as a creative director at Young and Rubicam and continues in creative writing. Monika retired as Director of Development at the Museum of Modem Art in 2007. She also worked at Paine Webber, Marine Midland, and the Museum of the City of New York. Monika served as President of CEC ArtsLink, and was a member of the Cosmopolitan Club. Monika was an optimist who saw the best in everyone and everything. She overcame polio in her youth, and later, stage 4 cancer four times. She was a tremendous catalyst for bringing people together for thoughtful discussions of the arts, literature and life. Monika is survived by her husband Brian, her two sons Peter and Gregory, their wives Diane Dillon and Samantha Skey, 5 grandchildren, her sister Yola Carlough and brother Marek Pyka and his wife Debby Gale and their son Matthew, her uncle Stas Pyka and her father's companion Wanda Wolinska. She was predeceased by her father William Pyka, her mother Aida Pyka, and her niece Amanda Gale-Pyka. A celebration of her life will be held at St. Ignatius Loyola on Thursday, June 11, at 10am. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to CEC ArtsLink: "Engaging communities through international arts partnerships." 1/3
MODELL--Paula. We are so sad to loose such a wonderful friend. Our condolences to our dear Jerry, Eric, Natalie and the entire family. Love, Mona & Dan Morello 1/3

ROSENTHAL--Donna M. (Kolar). Passed away quietly in Brooklyn on June 8. She was predeceased by her beloved husband of 30 years Thomas Kolar. A woman of valor who was recognized for her kind heart and dedication in giving generously of her time, and expertise to help others. Born in Rochester, NY to the Hon. Harry and Leila (Eber) Rosenthal, Donna lived in Brooklyn for 36 years. She was a world traveler, philanthropist and passionate lover of the arts, especially music, with her perfect pitch. Donna's life centered on building communities and aiding others. She initiated the legal services program for the New York State Office for the Aging, was the Assistant Director of the United Neighborhood Houses of New York, the first Executive Director of the National Down Syndrome Society, and the Executive Vice Chairman of CLAL-The National Jewish Center for Learning and Leadership. Volunteer service was of foremost importance to her. She was President of Congregation Beth Elohim, the Executive Women in Human Services, the Alumni Association of Columbia's School of Social Work and Chair of its Dean's Advisory Council. Columbia awarded her the Nicholas Butler Alumni Medal. She is survived by her devoted sister Barbara S. Rosenthal, mother-in-law Aurelia Kolar, six nieces and godson Jonathan Hessney. Service Thursday, June 11, 10am at Congregation Beth Elohim, 271 Garfield Place, Brooklyn. Contributions may be made to Columbia University School of Social Work or Congregation Beth Elohim. 1/3

We will love you always. 1/3

MODELL--Paula. NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital mourns the loss of a dear friend and passionate supporter, Paula Modell. For more than 30 years, Ms. Modell generously gave her time and energy to improving and expanding patient care efforts at our institution. Of particular note, she helped establish the Executive Circle of the James Lenox Society, a group that provides crucial funds and guidance to advance healthcare at the Hospital. Her extensive efforts on behalf of our patients embodied her compassionate and empathetic nature. We owe a debt of gratitude to her and her loving husband of 42 years, Gerald-- their beautiful and unique relationship touched the lives of thousands of New Yorkers and is an inspiration to us all. We offer our heartfelt condolences to him, her son Eric, her stepsons Gregg and Steven, and all of her family and loved ones. Steven J. Corwin, MD, CEO Herbert Pardes, MD, Executive Vice Chair NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital 1/3
MODELL--Paula. A Beautiful Elegant Lady, A Loyal Friend. We will always remember the joyous memories that we are privileged to have in knowing Paula. Nurit, Vivian, and Jody 1/3

CROWELL--Nanette Noffsinger, age 56, of Nolensville, TN passed away at her home Burke Hollow on June 8, 2015. Nanette was born in Nashville to Gerald and Helen Noffsinger on July 10, 1958. Throughout her early years, she lived in many different Middle Tennessee cities. Nanette was a graduate of Goodlettsville High School and Middle Tennessee State University with a degree in Communications and studied at New York University. Nanette began her professional career with HCA in Nashville and not long after decided to move to New York City to pursue a career in broadcasting. She worked for NBC News and The Today Show during the seventeen years she lived in New York, and continued to freelance for the network when she moved back to Tennessee. In 2002, Nanette started her own successful public relations firm, Burke Hollow Media. Nanette is preceded in death by her mother, Helen. Survived by her husband, Brooks Crowell, his son Eric; father, Gerald Noffsinger of Murfreesboro; brother Noland (Jeanette) Noffsinger of Murfreesboro; sister Natalie (Chris) Beckman of Murfreesboro; sister-in-law Melissa (Walter) Law of Knoxville and brother-in-law Chris (Amanda) Crowell of Lebanon, TN. She was a beloved aunt to her nieces and nephews Mackenzie, Kaitlyn and Garrett Noffsinger; Spencer and Madison Beckman; Rachel and Martha Law; Maggie and Ethan Crowell. Nanette was a member of Trinity United Methodist Church where she enjoyed singing in the choir, teaching Sunday school and participating in all aspects of the church's life. She had an adventurous spirit and loved to travel for work and pleasure. She built a home she loved and opened its doors to all the world. Nanette was known for a smile that would light up a room and a personality that always made you feel welcomed and loved. She was surrounded throughout her life with dear friends that brought much joy and laughter. Memorial Monday, June 15 at Trinity United Methodist Church, 2084 Wilson Pike, Franklin, TN. Memorials may be made to the Trinity United Methodist Church memorial fund. Services by Jennings and Ayers Funeral Home, 820 South Church St., Murfreesboro, TN. 615-893-2422. Please leave online condolences at www.jenningsandayers.com. 1/3

LISNOW--Harriet Sager, age 94, of Manhattan , formerly of Manhasset, NY passed away peacefully on June 9, 2015 with her family at her side. Beloved wife of Theodore (Ted) for more than 68 years. Funeral service private. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Gladney Center, 6300 John Ryan Drive, Fort Worth, Texas 76132-4122. 1/3

Stevenson moved quickly, whether it was on the road to far-flung destinations, or his impressive ability to integrate industry jargon, pop culture and well-constructed nicknames into rapid-fire conversation. The relationships he forged with investors and within the organization were unmatched. We will miss his selflessness and vigor dearly. 1/3

Bernstein, Samuel C. Bernstein, and great-granddaughters Aria and Keira. Her loving and gentle soul is missed. 1/3

MODELL--Paula. Our darling friend Paula has left this world but such a beautiful and strong spirit lives on eternally. We loved her dearly and will always remember the many joyous times together. MODELL--Paula. The Modell family is heartbroken over the untimely loss of their precious cousin. Paula was a woman of all seasons. Her humility, sincerity, grace and compassion were an inspiration to all who knew and loved her. May God grant Jerry and the family the strength to endure their enormous loss. Rest in Peace, Paula. We will love you always. 1/3

CHASIN--Helen S.,was born in New York on July 23, 1938, and attended Midwood High School in Brooklyn and Radcliffe College. Her first book of poetry won the Yale Younger Poets prize in 1968. Ms. Chasin was an inspiring and impassioned teacher of writing, co-founding The Writers Community in Manhattan in 1976. In her later years, she split her time between Rockport, Massachusetts and New York City. Chasin loved food, art and literature, travel, gardening, and her friends--and she loved to hate Nixon and the subway system. She died in her Manhattan home in early June, and is survived by Dana James Chasin and Alexandra Chasin. Please contact them for information about a private memorial gathering. 1/3

SHACK--Barbara. Died peacefully at her home on June 9, 2015, at the age of 83. Born and raised in Brooklyn, Barbara's professional life was one of passionate activism, devoted to defending and protecting the rights of New Yorkers. From 1971-84 she was associate director and legislative director of the New York Civil Liberties Union. She was co-founder of New Yorkers Against the Death Penalty and the New York State Task Force on Life and the Law, on which she served for thirty years. For a decade Barbara served as chairperson of NARAL Pro-Choice New York. She was appointed to several judicial screening committees, including the New York State Judicial Nominations Commission for the Court of Appeals, the New York State Committee on Open Government, the Disciplinary Committee of the Appellate Division First Judicial Department, and the New York State Commission on the Status of Women. Additionally, she represented the Women's Bar Association of the State of New York as its legislative counsel and chaired the Task Force on Bio-Ethics of the American Jewish Congress. But Barbara was most passionate when it came to relations with her family. She is survived by her devoted husband of 61 years, Donald. She was also a beloved mother to David and Laura, much loved grandmother to Nicole, Joseph, and Francesca, and great-grandmother to Emma and Olivia. Barbara was unrelenting in aiding their ambitions and applauding their victories; she was their foremost cheerleader. Contributions may be made in her memory to NYCLU or NARAL Pro-Choice New York. A memorial service will be held at 3pm Sunday, June 14 at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue. The family will be at home at 7 West 81st Street on Sunday and Monday after 6pm. 1/3

ROSE--Jules, 79, of Longboat Key, Florida passed away on June 10th, 2015. Jules was born in New York City and is a graduate of Dartmouth college. He was a successful business executive and champion of the arts. He is preceded in death by his first wife Marilyn Sloan Rose. He is survived by his wife Sheila and his children Patti and Mark, Mitchell and Marci, Randi and Todd, his nine grandchildren and Shelia's children Ricky, Leigh Ann, James, Julie and Marcus. Funeral will be held at 1:00 on June 14th at Riverside Nassau North in Great Neck. 1/3

MODELL--Paula. Paula Modell passed away from cancer on June 9, 2015 and was my dear friend just short of 40 years. When we met we were both so young, starting our lives, shaping our families and became friends instantly. Living far away from each other at times never diminished our friendship. She was compassionate, engaging and magical! Everyone who met her was enthralled with her kindness and beauty. Even though her loss has left a hole in my heart, a million memories of celebrations and life changes all flood my mind constantly and these memories will keep her with me forever. With love, Podi Constantiner 1/3
BRONSTEIN--Murray. On the 10th year after your death, forever in my heart, always in my thoughts. Love, Anne 1/3

MODELL--Paula. A Beautiful Elegant Lady, A Loyal Friend. We will always remember the joyous memories that we are privileged to have in knowing Paula. Nurit, Vivian, and Jody 1/3

MODELL--Paula. A courageous and beautiful woman whom we loved and who will live in our hearts forever. Our heartfelt condolences to Gerry and the entire family. Elinor Wohl and Martin Greitzer Jane and Richard Brickell Norman Brickell 1/3

STEINBERG--Eugene, age 88, died peacefully from a long battle with cancer, on June 11, 2015. He is survived by his devoted wife of 63 years Estelle, his children Sandy and Martin Pollock, Arthur and Ninette Steinberg, Norman Steinberg and Amy Davidson, his grandchildren Erica and Mike Distenfeld and great granddaughter Lucy, Brad and Shana Pollock, Jaclyn and Dave Cooper, Lauren, Alyx, Jason Steinberg and his fiance Alanna, Brian and Jonathan Steinberg. His father came to the United States from Pinsk Belarus and then brought over his mother, two brothers and two sisters. He grew up in Brownsville Brooklyn and went to Tilden High School. From those humble beginnings, Eugene founded two successful businesses, Largene Press and Bell Vending. He was an active synagogue member in Mill Basin, Brooklyn, Long Beach Island New Jersey, Del Ray Florida, and Monroe New Jersey. A devoted uncle and cousin, an active supporter of Israel and Jewish causes, Eugene understood people and was a generous soul with a loving heart. A true "mensch." He will always be with us. 1/3

EGENER--Stanley. March 31, 1934 - May 30, 2015. "Stan the Man" as he was commonly referred to, was truly beloved by family, friends and business associates. He is survived by his brother George, his two sons Mark and Todd, his wife Jennifer, his five grandchildren Daniel, Matthew, Sarah, Caroline and Elizabeth and his companion of many years, Aline Delbray. Stanley Egener was in the first class of men to graduate from Hunter College in New York. He served as an aviator in the U.S. Navy where he was stationed on the USS Intrepid, now a museum docked in New York. He was an exceptional athlete who played semi-pro football, golf and tennis. He was also an accomplished downhill skier. Stan began his career in finance in 1960 with Dreyfus Corporation and later worked with Oppenheimer. & Co. In 1972 Stan and two colleagues, Arthur Scherl and Richard Bassuk formed "Scherl, Egener & Bassuk" where they created a revolutionary new type of mutual fund called the "Side Fund". The Side Fund was eventually acquired by Neuberger Berman and later renamed the "Partners Fund". Stan joined Neuberger Berman and was instrumental in building their mutual fund business. In 1982, he was elected President of Neuberger Berman Management, Inc. and ultimately became a Partner in Neuberger Berman, LLC. Stan served for many years on the board of the Investment Company Institute and was President of the No-Load Mutual Fund Association. Considered a maverick both professionally and personally, Stanley's genius was his creativity and focus. He will be sorely missed and his life accomplishments will be an inspiration for all of the generations of family that will succeed him. Contributions in his memory to the Taub Alzheimer's Disease Research Institute 630 W. 168th St., PH 19, New York, NY 10032 would be greatly appreciated. 1/3

HECHT--Rita Ellen, born August 8, 1941, resident of the Vaux, died peacefully in her home, surrounded by loving family on June 7, 2015. Rita is preceded in death by parents Max and Sylvia Hecht. She is survived by her beloved husband, William P. Gellermann, PHD., sister-in-law Dianne Samuelson, nephew and niece Eric and Sally Samuelson, cousins Sheldon Turtletaub, Renee Turtletaub, Fanny Putter and son Lawrence Putter. Rita graduated from Hunter College High School. She received her B.A. from Brooklyn College, her Master's degree from CUNY and was a psychologist at Elmhurst Hospital for 30 years. She was loved and respected by patients and colleagues. A memorial gathering was held at the Vaux community center on June 9. Rita was a loyal friend to many, and she loved life, and the New York Times. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center gynecological cancer research. 1/3
FIALKOFF--Frank. Dearest nephew. You and yours are forever in our hearts. Aunt Roberta, Uncle Edgar and family 1/3

MODELL--Paula D. Dear Mom, All my life you worked hard to guide me to be a son you could be proud of. You taught me the importance and value of family and friends, to always continue to expand my mind and broaden my horizons, and to be adventurous, charitable and humble. As a father now, I hope to instill those same values in your grandchildren just as you did in me. You have been taken from us too soon, but your memory is alive in our hearts and minds. SHACK--Barbara. A bright star went out the morning of June 9th when we lost our dear and precious friend, Barbara Shack. Barbara was a most unusual woman. She was our hero. A fighter for civil rights, women's rights, gays, people of color, immigrants and children. Where there was darkness, she was a glowing star. Barbara valued the Constitution, she loved our country and tried to make it better for everyone. She was a true Citizen and a great New Yorker. To say we will miss this incredible loving woman is an understatement. Our condolences to Donald, her children, grandchildren and great- grandchildren. So long Barbara, we'll miss you always. Marsha, Nora, Roger & Seymour. 1/3

PRESSLER--David A. On June 11, 2015, A longtime resident of Englewood, N.J. and recently of Sparta, N.J. He was born September 27, 1930 in West Orange, N.J. and was raised in his youth in Newark, N.J. as the only child of Sol P. Pressler and Jessie Kurtz Pressler. He was a proud graduate of the Weequahic high school following a demanding tutelage in the then exemplary Newark public schools. Thereafter he matriculated at Rutgers in New Brunswick, N.J. graduating with the esteemed Class of 1952. There he had become a champion debater and eventually head of the Freshman Debate team and among others, President of the independent students (The Scarlet Barbarians) a larger group of students adverse to the xenophobic and racial and religious economic prodivities of the Greek letter societies (also called Fraternities) which were then prominent in college social life. Following Rutgers he enrolled at the estimable Harvard law school and graduated honorably in the Class of 1955. Before that he worked as a waiter in the summers at the Hollywood Hotel in West End Long branch in its great days and in the exalted summer of 1953 he met Sylvia Brodsky. They married August 22, 1954 and moved as a married pair to Cambridge, Ma. to live in an apartment (converted cellar). After graduation in May/ June 1955 they moved to Newark. Sylvia enrolled at Rutgers law school and eventually graduated with the best record in 16 years (as usual for her, first in class 1960). David A. Pressler completed mandatory clerkship, passed the exam and was sworn in as an Attorney at Law 1956. Immediately afterward he was drafted into the U.S. Army and served for two years in Colorado and Germany. After returning to the U.S.A. he practiced law (general practice) primarily in New Jersey for 55 years. At one time he was President of the Bergen County Bar association and at the time of his death he was President of the Alumni Class of Rutgers 1952 and was a diligent supporter of Rutgers throughout his life. He was pre-deceased by his wife Sylvia and his son Noah and is survived by his daughter Jessica, grandchildren Rachael, Brandon, Isabella and step grandchild Sofia and another son David. He had a strong life until the deaths of his loved ones overwhelmed him. Services will be held at Gutterman and Musicant Jewish Funeral Directors 402 Park St. Hackensack, N.J. 07601 on Sunday June 14, 2015 at 9:30am. Shiva will be Sunday after the burial and Monday and Tuesday 7-10pm at 161 Brayton St., Englewood, N.J. Contributions in his memory may be made to Visiting Nurses Assoc., 15 Engle Street Englewood, N.J. 07631 or The Rutgers college Class of 1952 Scholarship fund. 1/3

MULHOLLAND--James S.,II. James S. Mulholland, II, age 91, a pioneer in Computer Magazine Publishing and a Co- founder of Hayden Publishing Company, died peacefully at his home in Vero Beach, Florida. He is survived by his loving wife Clariel (Claire) of sixty years, his son James III of Vero Beach, FL, daughter Marie of Evergreen, CO, sister Ethel Barth of Scotch Plains, NJ, and nine Grandchildren. In addition to living in Florida, Jim spent more than fifty years as a summer resident of Southampton, New York. He was born and raised in Brooklyn, NY where he graduated as the class valedictorian from P.S. 201 and the St. Francis Preparatory School. Jim then went on to M.I.T. After his sophomore year, World War II erupted and he was drafted into the Navy. He served as a Lieutenant Junior Grade and Navigation Officer aboard the USS Columbus for three years. After the war he returned to M.I.T., completed his education and graduated with a degree in General Engineering. His first job was with Reinhold Publishing as an advertising salesman for the American Chemical Society magazine and he attended the N.Y.U. Graduate School of Business at night. The electronics market was burgeoning and it was in 1952 that he co-founded Hayden Publishing Company. Electronic Design magazine was the first publication from Hayden with Microwaves+RF, Computer Decisions, Personal Computing, Systems+Software, and the Gold Book, A Master Directory for the Electronics Industry, eventually joining the stable of magazines. In 1961, Hayden acquired the John F. Rider Book Company, along with Ahrens Publishing. The company in the early 1970's acquired the exclusive world-wide marketing and distribution rights to the books published by Spartan Books. Hayden Book Company published over six-hundred books under the Hayden, Rider and Ahrens imprints. Popular titles ranged from Basic Electricity (Volumes 1 through 5), Electronics One- Seven, Basic: Basic: An Introduction to Computer Programming, to Introduction to the Novel, Writing to be Read, Introduction to the Short Story, The Bakers' Manual for Quantity Baking and Pastry Making and Modern Hotel/Motel Management Methods. As an early proponent of personal computers, Jim founded the Hayden Software Company in 1978. The company specialized in personal computing software programs for the first generation of personal computers, including the Radio Shack, Atari, IBM and Apple computers. Programs such as Sargon III, and Pie Writer were some of the more successful Hayden programs during the early days of personal computers. As a prominent magazine publisher, Jim was a board member of the American Business Press, a trade group, and represented the association in negotiations with the Postal Rate Commission to grant equal postal rates and delivery times to the trade magazines which were already enjoyed by the commercial press. During the climax of the Cold War Years, Jim contacted Judge James L. Buckley, then President of Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty, to provide religious programming that would be broadcast to the Eastern European countries influenced and controlled by Soviet Communism. After selling Hayden Publishing, Hayden Book Company, and Hayden Software Company in 1986, Jim organized a World Day of Prayer on the Fortieth Anniversary of the ratification of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights by the United Nations. Jim in the 1990's continued with his love of technology with early stage investments in several Internet related businesses. Jim was an avid skier and tennis player, was an early proponent of Platform Tennis(Paddle Tennis), and loved the water as a life-long swimmer, and sailor. Jim was a member of the Young Presidents Organization, the World Business Organization and the Chief Executives Organization. Together with his wife, he enjoyed their world-wide travels with these organizations. Jim loved his Catholic Faith and created a Catholic Information Center on the Internet. He was a Knight Commander of St. Gregory, the highest honor granted to a layman by the Vatican, was a Knight of the Equestrian Order of the Holy Sepulchre of Jerusalem, as well as a Knight of the Sovereign Order of Malta. Jim was a past Director of the American Business, Press, The New York Athletic Club, The Portsmouth Abbey School Board of Consultants, The Research Center for Religious & Human Rights in Closed Societies, CREED (The Christian Rescue Effort for the Emancipation of Dissidents), The Temple of Understanding, the Religious News Service, and along with Cardinal Martino, the Papal Nuncio to the United Nations from the Holy See, the Path to Peace Foundation. Jim was a member of the New York Athletic Club, The John's Island Club, The Meadow Club of Southampton, and the Bathing Corporation of Southampton. In addition he was a patron of the National Symphony Orchestra, and a Patron of the Vatican Museum. He will be remembered for his business acumen, his fairness and his wonderful sense of humor. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to the Southampton Fresh Air Home, 36 Barkers Island Road Southampton, NY 11968. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated 10:00 a.m., Monday, June 15, 2015 at Holy Cross Catholic Church, Vero Beach, FL. Interment will follow in Crestlawn Cemetery, Vero Beach, FL. 1/3

MULHOLLAND--James S.,II. The Officers and The Board of Directors of the Southampton Fresh Air Home mourn the loss of a dear friend and passionate supporter, James Mulholland. A devoted husband, father, grandfather and great grandfather, Jim was a generous man who alongside his beloved wife Claire helped to transform the Fresh Air Home into a modern facility serving physically challenged children. Through his beneficence, he helped to better the lives of countless, less fortunate children. His legacy will live on at the Home for many years to come. We extend our deepest sympathy to Claire and the entire Mulholland Family. The Officers and Directors of the Southampton Fresh Air Home 1/3

FIALKOFF--Frank. On behalf of the Schwalbe family, we would like to offer our sincere condolences to all the members of the Fialkoff family. Not only was Frank a friend, he was a great tenant as well. We will sorely miss his decency, honesty and great sense of humor. Hilson Management Corp. & The Schwalbe Family 1/3

SHACK--Barbara. Died peacefully at her home on June 9, 2015, at the age of 83. Born and raised in Brooklyn, Barbara's professional life was one of passionate activism, devoted to defending and protecting the rights of New Yorkers. From 1971-84 she was associate director and legislative director of the New York Civil Liberties Union. She was co-founder of New Yorkers Against the Death Penalty and the New York State Task Force on Life and the Law, on which she served for thirty years. For a decade Barbara served as chairperson of NARAL Pro-Choice New York. She was appointed to several judicial screening committees, including the New York State Judicial Nominations Commission for the Court of Appeals, the New York State Committee on Open Government, the Disciplinary Committee of the Appellate Division First Judicial Department, and the New York State Commission on the Status of Women. Additionally, she represented the Women's Bar Association of the State of New York as its legislative counsel and chaired the Task Force on Bio-Ethics of the American Jewish Congress. But Barbara was most passionate when it came to relations with her family. She is survived by her devoted husband of 61 years, Donald. She was also a beloved mother to David and Laura, much loved grandmother to Nicole, Joseph, and Francesca, and great-grandmother to Emma and Olivia. Barbara was unrelenting in aiding their ambitions and applauding their victories; she was their foremost cheerleader. Contributions may be made in her memory to NYCLU or NARAL Pro-Choice New York. A memorial service will be held at 3pm Sunday, June 14 at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue. The family will be at home at 7 West 81st Street on Sunday and Monday after 6pm. 1/3

BRENNER--Miriam, nee Spierer. Born March 9th 1925; died June 11th 2015. Beloved mother, sister, grandmother, aunt, and mother-in-law. You were blessed with a wonderful marriage, loving family and many friends who will miss your laughter and zest for life. Services to be held at "The Riverside," on 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, on Sunday, June 14, 2015 at 12pm. 1/3

MOORE--George Bermejillo of New Canaan, CT and Sugar Hill, NH died peacefully at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital in New York on June 5, 2015, at the age of 75 after a four-year battle with myelodysplastic syndrome and acute myeloid leukemia. Born in New York City on October 10, 1939, Mr. Moore was the only child of George Stevens Moore, the former President and Chairman of the First National City Bank (predecessor to Citigroup), and Beatriz Bermejillo y Braniff, the Marquesa de Mohernando of Spain. Mr. Moore attended the St. Bernards School in New York and graduated from The Brooks School in 1957. He received a BA in History from Yale University in 1961. At Yale he was a member of The Fence Club, a member of the Berzelius society, and assistant editor of the Yale Daily News. In 1964, Mr. Moore received his MBA from Stanford Business School and joined the corporate finance department of White Weld & Co. in New York. He served in the U.S. Army Reserve as a Private stationed at Fort Dix. White Weld was acquired by Merrill Lynch in 1978, and Mr. Moore remained with Merrill Lynch as a private wealth investment manager in the New Canaan office until his retirement in the spring of this year. He was honored for 50 years of service in 2014. Mr. Moore was actively involved in numerous charitable activities and served as Trustee, Chairman and Chairman Emeritus of The Hispanic Society of America Museum in New York, on the Board of Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital in New York, as President of the New Canaan Chapter of the American Red Cross, on the Board of the New Canaan Country School, on the Board of the New Canaan Waveny Care Center, President of the Lockwood-Mathews Mansion Museum in Norwalk, CT and President of the New Canaan Community Foundation. Mr. Moore was a President and member of the New Canaan Country Club, a member of The Links, The Racquet & Tennis Club, The River Club and The Union Club in New York, Bohemian Club in San Francisco, Cypress Point Club in Pebble Beach, CA, Everglades Club and Bath & Tennis Club in Palm Beach, FL. Mr. Moore was a devoted husband, loving father and grandfather, and a loyal friend. He had an infectious laugh and a great sense of humor. He always had a positive outlook on life and was generous in spirit. He was a compassionate, kind and honorable man. Mr. Moore was fortunate to meet his wife, Kathie, while he was at Yale, and they were married in 1966. They enjoyed 49 happy and fun-filled years together in New York and New Canaan. He was a voracious reader and enjoyed playing the piano despite picking the instrument up late in life. He was also an avid golfer, tennis and squash player, and was a multi-sport club champion in both golf and squash. Mr. Moore is survived by his beloved wife, Katharine Lipson Moore; son George Braniff Moore, New York; daughter, Tanya Moore Jessop, New Canaan; five grandchildren, Carter, George and Schuyler Moore, and Katharine and Cooper Jessop; daughter-in-law, Calvert Saunders Moore; son-in-law, John C. Jessop; sisters-in-law, Sandra C. Ryon and Eleanor B. Naess, and brother-in-law, Peter S. Lipson; and two half- siblings, many nieces, nephews and cousins. A memorial service celebrating the life of George B. Moore will be held at St Aloysius Church, 21 Cherry St, New Canaan, CT at 11am on Friday, June 19, 2015. In lieu of flowers, friends may make donations to the George B. Moore Memorial Fund at The Hispanic Society of America (613 West 155th St, NY, NY 10032). www.hispanicsociety.org 1/3

CHARTOFF--Robert. I mourn the passing of my friend Bob. He will live on in our memories and his accomplishments and philanthropies will endure. His films have already become classics. My heart goes out to his family especially to his loving wife Jenny whose courage during his last illness matched his own. We became friends and fraternity brothers at Union College in 1951. Our friendship grew and became closer with age. I will miss him. Mort Silver 1/3

LeFRAK--Steven, MD, age 71 1/2 of Lincroft, NJ passed away at his home on Tuesday, June 9th. Dr. Lefrak was a graduate of The Bronx High School of Science in 1960. He went on to graduate in 1964 from Temple University, where he was the Class President, a member of Sword Honor Society, a member of Phi Lambda Kappa Medical Fraternity, and in the J. Marion Sims Society. In 1968, he graduated from Jefferson Medical College. Dr. Lefrak did his pediatric residency at Monmouth Medical Center from 1968-1971 and served as Chief Pediatric Resident. He was awarded the Martin Quirk Award for outstanding pediatric resident in 1971 at Monmouth Medical Center. From 1971-1974, he served in the US Army and was Chief of Pediatrics at Patterson Army Hospital, Fort Monmouth, NJ. After his honorable discharge, he joined Monmouth Pediatric Group, where he practiced until 2004. From 1971 to the present, Dr. Lefrak was a Clinical Instructor at the former Hahnemann Medical College (now Drexel College of Medicine). He was promoted to Assistant Professor of Pediatrics at this prestigious institution. From 1971 to the present time, Dr. Lefrak was on the staff at Riverview Hospital, where he was the recipient of the Physician's Recognition Award in 2012. He was an attending pediatrician, Department of Pediatrics at Monmouth Medical Center from 1973 to the present time. Dr. Lefrak also taught at Jefferson Medical College (now Sidney Kimmel College of Medicine) from 2005-2014. He established Pedihouse Calls in 2004 and was still actively practicing medicine. Dr. Lefrak volunteered at the Parker Family Health Center from 2003 to the present time. From 2008-2013, he served on their Board of Directors. Dr. Lefrak served as Pediatric Consultant for the United Cerebral Palsy of Monmouth & Ocean Counties, was on the Medical Board of the National Foundation of the Monmouth County Chapter of the March of Dimes, and served on the New Jersey State Crippled Children's Panel. He was the recipient of the Brigadier General A.J. Myer Military Service Award. Dr. Lefrak is survived by his wife of 48 years, Phyllis; his daughters, Joanne Lefrak of Santa Fe, NM, Karen Jill Lefrak, M.D. and her husband Jonathan Salvin, MD of Kennett Square, PA and their daughter Laurel Elisabeth Salvin. He is also survived by his sister Bonnie Ghiosay of Edison, NJ. Dr. Lefrak enjoyed traveling extensively with family and friends. He was an avid gardener, who also enjoyed photography and spending time at the beach. There will be a Memorial Gathering in celebration of his life on Saturday, June 13th, 1:00-4:00pm at the Thompson Memorial Home, 310 Broad St., Red Bank, NJ 07701. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations in his memory to: Steven Lefrak, MD Award for Excellence in Pediatrics at Monmouth Medical Center, Atten: Meg Fisher, MD, 300 Second Ave., Long Branch, NJ 07740 (Please make checks payable to The Steven Lefrak Fund). 1/3

DEUTSCH--David. It's been two years since we lost our beloved David, but his one-of-a-kind heart and soul lives on with us. Devoted husband to his cherished Francine for almost 60 years, doting father to Amy and Donny, proud grandpa (aka "Papa") to Dylan, Jillian, Chelsey, London and Daisy and loving uncle to Michael. There isn't a day that goes by that we don't cherish the fact that this kind, strong, compassionate, selfless man helped shape our lives. In addition to being the patriarch of his loving family, David had two phenomenally successful careers. First as the founder of a thriving advertising agency where today young people still stand on his creative shoulders, and as a fine artist whose work graced numerous art galleries and museums. A finer man has never walked this planet. We miss, cherish and celebrate you every day David. We love you forever. 1/3

OPPENHEIM--Steph, died peacefully on June 10, 2015. Affiliated with Citibank for over 20 years. Beloved husband of Wendy Weiner, cherished brother of Jeffrey, dear nephew of Henry and Mary Lou Bloch. He will also be missed by a myriad of friends. Service Monday, June 15, 11:15am, at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Lustgarten Foundation or www.pancan.org 1/3

KENNEDY--Ray (58), renowned jazz pianist passed away May 28. He is survived by his family: Eve Langner, daughters Lauren & Brielle, brother Tom Kennedy, and sister Wanda Kuntz. Service is June 14, 5pm, 4th Universalist Society (160 CPW). Eve Langner 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Arthur (Abe), passed away June 10th, 2015 in Pembroke Pines, FL at the age of 99. Beloved husband of Etta. Dear father of Eugene (Karin) and Donna Lee Goldin (Philip). Adoring grandfather of Gabrielle, Bret (Kim), Douglas, Jason and Nicole. Proud great-grand-father of Sadie, Lucy, and Mia. After a life of hard work for his family in the garment industry, he spent the last 35 years happily retired in Florida with his loving wife. Arthur and Etta recently celebrated their 75th wedding anniversary. Service Sunday, 11am, at "The Riverside", 76th Street. and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

LeFRAK--Steven, MD. The Cutler Family, The Mulheren Family and Visiting Nurse Association of Central Jersey deeply mourn the passing of Dr. Steve Lefrak. His passion and commitment to the health of children in our community was unsurpassed. 1/3

Antoine Vermette broke a 1-1 tie two minutes into the third period, and Chicago edged host Tampa Bay to move a victory away from winning the Stanley Cup.
Remember the days of basic, good-looking watches with nylon straps? Those days are now.

BEUSMAN--Curtis. Curtis Beusman, 84, of Mount Kisco, NY, died on May 19th. Curt was born in Chicago, IL, May 10, 1931. Curt is survived by sons Robert and Richard, daughter-in-law Margaret, four loving grandchildren and four rambunctious great- grandchildren. A Memorial Celebration of Curt's life will be held at the Saw Mill Club on Sunday, July 12, 3pm, which he founded with beloved wife, Jane, at 77 Kensico Dr., Mt Kisco, NY. All are welcome. RSVP to darena @sawmillclub.com. Services are being handled by Clark Associates Funeral Home. 1/3

DEUTSCH--David. It's been two years since we lost our beloved David, but his one-of-a-kind heart and soul lives on with us. Devoted husband to his cherished Francine for almost 60 years, doting father to Amy and Donny, proud grandpa (aka "Papa") to Dylan, Jillian, Chelsey, London and Daisy and loving uncle to Michael. There isn't a day that goes by that we don't cherish the fact that this kind, strong, compassionate, selfless man helped shape our lives. In addition to being the patriarch of his loving family, David had two phenomenally successful careers. First as the founder of a thriving advertising agency where today young people still stand on his creative shoulders, and as a fine artist whose work graced numerous art galleries and museums. A finer man has never walked this planet. We miss, cherish and celebrate you every day David. We love you forever. 1/3
BILLER--Abraham. We are so sad to loose such a wonderful and loyal friend. We will miss you always. Zipi, Dan, Gil Koppel 1/3

MOORE--George Bermejillo of New Canaan, CT and Sugar Hill, NH died peacefully at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital in New York on June 5, 2015, at the age of 75 after a four-year battle with myelodysplastic syndrome and acute myeloid leukemia. Born in New York City on October 10, 1939, Mr. Moore was the only child of George Stevens Moore, the former President and Chairman of the First National City Bank (predecessor to Citigroup), and Beatriz Bermejillo y Braniff, the Marquesa de Mohernando of Spain. Mr. Moore attended the St. Bernards School in New York and graduated from The Brooks School in 1957. He received a BA in History from Yale University in 1961. At Yale he was a member of The Fence Club, a member of the Berzelius society, and assistant editor of the Yale Daily News. In 1964, Mr. Moore received his MBA from Stanford Business School and joined the corporate finance department of White Weld & Co. in New York. He served in the U.S. Army Reserve as a Private stationed at Fort Dix. White Weld was acquired by Merrill Lynch in 1978, and Mr. Moore remained with Merrill Lynch as a private wealth investment manager in the New Canaan office until his retirement in the spring of this year. He was honored for 50 years of service in 2014. Mr. Moore was actively involved in numerous charitable activities and served as Trustee, Chairman and Chairman Emeritus of The Hispanic Society of America Museum in New York, on the Board of Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital in New York, as President of the New Canaan Chapter of the American Red Cross, on the Board of the New Canaan Country School, on the Board of the New Canaan Waveny Care Center, President of the Lockwood-Mathews Mansion Museum in Norwalk, CT and President of the New Canaan Community Foundation. Mr. Moore was a President and member of the New Canaan Country Club, a member of The Links, The Racquet & Tennis Club, The River Club and The Union Club in New York, Bohemian Club in San Francisco, Cypress Point Club in Pebble Beach, CA, Everglades Club and Bath & Tennis Club in Palm Beach, FL. Mr. Moore was a devoted husband, loving father and grandfather, and a loyal friend. He had an infectious laugh and a great sense of humor. He always had a positive outlook on life and was generous in spirit. He was a compassionate, kind and honorable man. Mr. Moore was fortunate to meet his wife, Kathie, while he was at Yale, and they were married in 1966. They enjoyed 49 happy and fun-filled years together in New York and New Canaan. He was a voracious reader and enjoyed playing the piano despite picking the instrument up late in life. He was also an avid golfer, tennis and squash player, and was a multi-sport club champion in both golf and squash. Mr. Moore is survived by his beloved wife, Katharine Lipson Moore; son George Braniff Moore, New York; daughter, Tanya Moore Jessop, New Canaan; five grandchildren, Carter, George and Schuyler Moore, and Katharine and Cooper Jessop; daughter-in-law, Calvert Saunders Moore; son-in-law, John C. Jessop; sisters-in-law, Sandra C. Ryon and Eleanor B. Naess, and brother-in-law, Peter S. Lipson; and two half- siblings, many nieces, nephews and cousins. A memorial service celebrating the life of George B. Moore will be held at St Aloysius Church, 21 Cherry St, New Canaan, CT at 11am on Friday, June 19, 2015. In lieu of flowers, friends may make donations to the George B. Moore Memorial Fund at The Hispanic Society of America (613 West 155th St, NY, NY 10032). www.hispanicsociety.org 1/3

ALBERT--Harold "Hal" Godfrey, Jr.,58, of Clinton, NY and New York City, died on May 27. He was preceded in death by parents Harold G. and Mary S. Albert and is survived by wife Cheryl A. Morgan and daughter Eleanor M. Albert; three sisters Mary Agnes Jopson, Katherine A. Albert, and E. Jane Albert Hubbard, and their families. Born on February 19, 1957 in Brooklyn, NY, Hal studied at the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor and earned a B. Mus. at Berklee College of Music in Boston, MA. In 1982, he married Cheryl in Harwich, MA. After teaching at Choate Rosemary Hall, Hal began a long career in information technology and financial data analytics at Morgan Stanley, Merrill Lynch, and Bank of America Merrill Lynch. Most recently he had joined friends at Quantbot Technologies, a quantitative investment adviser, to manage essential data and systems infrastructure. Hal loved playing guitar professionally, family trips, good wine and food, and walks with his dog. Memorial service at the First Church in Harwich, MA, August 15, 11am and gathering at the Playwright Tavern, 202 W. 42nd St., in New York, June 17, 6-8pm. Gifts in Hal's memory may be made to the Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. Please specify "brain tumor research": https://giving.mskcc.org/ 1/3

MULHOLLAND--James S.,II. James S. Mulholland, II, age 91, a pioneer in Computer Magazine Publishing and a Co- founder of Hayden Publishing Company, died peacefully at his home in Vero Beach, Florida. He is survived by his loving wife Clariel (Claire) of sixty years, his son James III of Vero Beach, FL, daughter Marie of Evergreen, CO, sister Ethel Barth of Scotch Plains, NJ, and nine Grandchildren. In addition to living in Florida, Jim spent more than fifty years as a summer resident of Southampton, New York. He was born and raised in Brooklyn, NY where he graduated as the class valedictorian from P.S. 201 and the St. Francis Preparatory School. Jim then went on to M.I.T. After his sophomore year, World War II erupted and he was drafted into the Navy. He served as a Lieutenant Junior Grade and Navigation Officer aboard the USS Columbus for three years. After the war he returned to M.I.T., completed his education and graduated with a degree in General Engineering. His first job was with Reinhold Publishing as an advertising salesman for the American Chemical Society magazine and he attended the N.Y.U. Graduate School of Business at night. The electronics market was burgeoning and it was in 1952 that he co-founded Hayden Publishing Company. Electronic Design magazine was the first publication from Hayden with Microwaves+RF, Computer Decisions, Personal Computing, Systems+Software, and the Gold Book, A Master Directory for the Electronics Industry, eventually joining the stable of magazines. In 1961, Hayden acquired the John F. Rider Book Company, along with Ahrens Publishing. The company in the early 1970's acquired the exclusive world-wide marketing and distribution rights to the books published by Spartan Books. Hayden Book Company published over six-hundred books under the Hayden, Rider and Ahrens imprints. Popular titles ranged from Basic Electricity (Volumes 1 through 5), Electronics One- Seven, Basic: Basic: An Introduction to Computer Programming, to Introduction to the Novel, Writing to be Read, Introduction to the Short Story, The Bakers' Manual for Quantity Baking and Pastry Making and Modern Hotel/Motel Management Methods. As an early proponent of personal computers, Jim founded the Hayden Software Company in 1978. The company specialized in personal computing software programs for the first generation of personal computers, including the Radio Shack, Atari, IBM and Apple computers. Programs such as Sargon III, and Pie Writer were some of the more successful Hayden programs during the early days of personal computers. As a prominent magazine publisher, Jim was a board member of the American Business Press, a trade group, and represented the association in negotiations with the Postal Rate Commission to grant equal postal rates and delivery times to the trade magazines which were already enjoyed by the commercial press. During the climax of the Cold War Years, Jim contacted Judge James L. Buckley, then President of Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty, to provide religious programming that would be broadcast to the Eastern European countries influenced and controlled by Soviet Communism. After selling Hayden Publishing, Hayden Book Company, and Hayden Software Company in 1986, Jim organized a World Day of Prayer on the Fortieth Anniversary of the ratification of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights by the United Nations. Jim in the 1990's continued with his love of technology with early stage investments in several Internet related businesses. Jim was an avid skier and tennis player, was an early proponent of Platform Tennis(Paddle Tennis), and loved the water as a life-long swimmer, and sailor. Jim was a member of the Young Presidents Organization, the World Business Organization and the Chief Executives Organization. Together with his wife, he enjoyed their world-wide travels with these organizations. Jim loved his Catholic Faith and created a Catholic Information Center on the Internet. He was a Knight Commander of St. Gregory, the highest honor granted to a layman by the Vatican, was a Knight of the Equestrian Order of the Holy Sepulchre of Jerusalem, as well as a Knight of the Sovereign Order of Malta. Jim was a past Director of the American Business, Press, The New York Athletic Club, The Portsmouth Abbey School Board of Consultants, The Research Center for Religious & Human Rights in Closed Societies, CREED (The Christian Rescue Effort for the Emancipation of Dissidents), The Temple of Understanding, the Religious News Service, and along with Cardinal Martino, the Papal Nuncio to the United Nations from the Holy See, the Path to Peace Foundation. Jim was a member of the New York Athletic Club, The John's Island Club, The Meadow Club of Southampton, and the Bathing Corporation of Southampton. In addition he was a patron of the National Symphony Orchestra, and a Patron of the Vatican Museum. He will be remembered for his business acumen, his fairness and his wonderful sense of humor. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to the Southampton Fresh Air Home, 36 Barkers Island Road Southampton, NY 11968. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated 10:00 a.m., Monday, June 15, 2015 at Holy Cross Catholic Church, Vero Beach, FL. Interment will follow in Crestlawn Cemetery, Vero Beach, FL. 1/3
